                               The Frontier Star

                           February 28, 2015 Saturday

USAID opens 2015 Pakistan agriculture conference

SECTION: Vol. 20 No. 58

LENGTH: 315  words


Director for US Agency for International Development (USAID) Pakistan Gregory
Gottlieb served as the keynote speaker to open the Pakistan Agriculture
Conference and Exposition 2015 in Islamabad.

The twoday exposition will showcase the latest technological advances in the
agriculture industry and provide government agencies and the private sector a
forum to discuss agriculture engagement strategies. The United States
contributed a five stall pavilion to exhibit the agriculture development efforts
supported by USAID in Pakistan.

Gottlieb said, "This is yet another example of how support for Pakistan's
agriculture development is a priority of the United States. We believe our
agriculture projects will continue to contribute to the growth of Pakistan's
economy. Working together with a strong cadre of local farmers, agribusinesses
and policymakers, the United States and Pakistan's joint efforts in agriculture
development will contribute to a stronger, brighter future for all Pakistan."

Agriculture employs 44 percent of the national labor force and provides 21
percent of Pakistan's Gross Domestic Product. Speakers from the Ministry of
National Food Security and Research, as well as representatives from the
Pakistan Agricultural Research Council engaged audiences on wide range of topics
and spoke strategies to improve resources and development in the agriculture
industry.

During the past five years, United States agriculture assistance has helped
nearly one million farmers increase productivity and income. This assistance
helped Pakistan directly generate over $45 million in domestic sales and $28
million in export sales.

Helping Pakistani farmers improve the quality of agricultural products while
increasing productivity is a critical priority for the United States and
approximately 800,000 farmer families have increased their incomes through the
U.S.Pakistani cooperation.

                                US Official News

                            September 9, 2016 Friday

California: Seven NASDA Leaders to Attend USDA's Women in Agriculture Trade
Mission

LENGTH: 482  words

DATELINE: New York



 Sacramento: State Departments of Agriculture, The State of California has
issued the following news release:



   Leaders from seven state departments of agriculture and 23 U.S.
agribusinesses and organizations will accompany Deputy Under Secretary for Farm
and Foreign Agriculture Services Alexis Taylor on a trade mission to Hong Kong
and Shanghai Sept. 7 to Sept. 15 to extend USDA's Women in Agriculture
initiative abroad and expand export opportunities for U.S. food and agricultural
products.





 "USDA is committed to building opportunities for women to grow, learn from one
another and lead within their industries," said Taylor. "Women in agriculture
have a powerful story to tell - one of leadership, stewardship and resilience -
from the combine, to the classroom, to the boardroom. This trade mission
provides us an opportunity to discuss the impacts women in the United States and
China are having on agriculture and to share our visions for the next
generation. In addition, I look forward to joining U.S. agricultural leaders as
we seek to enhance our trading opportunities in this region."



 The United States has strong trading relations with both China and Hong Kong.
Last year, China was the second-largest market for U.S. agricultural exports
reaching $23.5 billion. Sustained high demand for bulk commodities such as
soybeans and cotton continues, and demand for high-value food, meat and alcohol
products is surging. Next year, China is projected to return as the United
States' top export market.



 In contrast to China, where more than 70 percent of U.S. exports are bulk
commodities, more than 90 percent of U.S. exports to Hong Kong are high-value,
consumer-oriented products. With a population of more than 7.2 million people
packed into 426 square miles, Hong Kong relies on imports for more than 95
percent of its food supply. It is the United States' seventh-largest market,
with top U.S. exports including tree nuts, beef, poultry and fresh fruit.



 Mission participants come from across the United States and represent a range
of agricultural products and commodities. They will meet with potential
customers and host government representatives, forging relationships and
learning about the market conditions and business environment.



 Participating U.S. Organizations and Companies:



     Michigan Department of Agriculture and Rural Development, Lansing, Mich.

     Mississippi Department of Agriculture and Commerce, Jackson, Miss.

     Oklahoma Department of Agriculture Food and Forestry, Oklahoma City, Okla.

     Oregon Department of Agriculture, Salem, Ore.

     Tennessee Department of Agriculture, Nashville, Tenn.

     Virginia Department of Agriculture and Consumer Services, Richmond, Va.

     Washington State Department of Agriculture, Olympia, Wash.

editorial@plusmediasolutions.com

                              Daily Deal/The Deal

                              May 13, 2011 Friday

Consolidation threatens food safety, warn farmers, activists

LENGTH: 270 words


Independent farmers and environmental activist groups are asking antitrust
regulators to examine agriculture consolidation as a driver of food-borne
illnesses and other health risks allegedly fueled by practices of ag
conglomerates.Farm and environmental groups sent a joint letter to Secretary of
Agriculture Tom Vilsack and Attorney General Eric Holder asking the Department
of Agriculture and the Justice Department to update the industry on what was
found in a series of field hearings the agencies conducted on agriculture
competition. The hearings began in March 2010. "The American public now awaits
the next steps the departments will take to address excessive corporate
concentration in the U.S. food and agriculture sectors and its devastating
impacts on American lives and livelihoods," the groups wrote.

They said a final report on the hearings "should include an analysis of the
scope, causes and nature of the problems and identify changes necessary to begin
to address current trends in agricultural consolidation, and develop appropriate
antitrust approaches to curtail monopoly or monopoly power of the seed, beef,
hog, poultry and dairy industries and end the harmful impacts of unrestrained
corporate power on U.S. food and farming," their letter said. "Our rural
communities, our food supply and the fate of a major portion of the American
economy depend on us fixing this problem." Groups signing the letter included:
Alliance for a Sustainable Future, American Corn Growers Association, R-CALF
United Stockgrowers of America and American Raw Milk Producers Pricing
Association.  - Bill McConnell

DOCUMENT-TYPE: Article

                               The New York Times

              October 19, 1983, Wednesday, Late City Final Edition

E.E.C. Farm Policy Issue

BYLINE: Reuters

SECTION: Section D; Page 21, Column 2; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 122 words

DATELINE: ROME, Oct. 18


The United States is mounting a major diplomatic offensive against European
Common Market farm policy changes that could lead to a new trade war, United
States and other officials said today.

United States Agriculture Department officials in the 10 European Economic
Community capitals are intensively lobbying against what they regard as
disguised import levies that would affect farm trade worth $5 billion a year.
Washington's anger is shared by developing countries in Asia, Latin America and
Africa.

Officials at the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization's headquarters
here say the issue will be raised next month when farm ministers of the 152
member states meet for the body's top-level governing conference.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                   Copyright 1983 The New York Times Company


                              17 of 998 DOCUMENTS

                       St. Louis Post-Dispatch (Missouri)

                March 24, 2001, Saturday, FIVE STAR LIFT EDITION

U.S. CONFISCATES SECOND FLOCK OF SHEEP OVER MAD COW FEARS

BYLINE: From News Services

SECTION: NEWS, Pg. 5

LENGTH: 537 words

DATELINE: EAST WARREN, VT.EAST WARREN, VERMONT; MAD COW DISEASE; CONFISCATE;
SHEEP FLOCK; U.S.; DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE; U.S.; MARSHALS SERVICE



* Officials plan to destroy the animals after they are tested.

U.S. officials on Friday seized the second of two flocks of dairy sheep
suspected of carrying an ailment related to mad cow disease.

The government had been fighting in the courts for nine months to seize and
destroy the animals, saying they pose a threat to the U.S. food supply. The
action began in July, when several tested positive for transmissible spongiform
encephalopathy, a class of degenerative neurological disorders that includes
scrapie and mad cow disease.

The sheep's owners charge that the U.S. Department of Agriculture's tests were
flawed, but the courts have consistently sided with the government.

Earlier in the week, the government seized another flock of sheep in Greensboro,
Vt. The action highlighted the Agriculture Department's d etermination to act
decisively to head off any risk that mad cow disease, or bovine spongiform
encephalopathy, could be introduced into the United States.

About 25 federal agents from the Agriculture Department and the U.S. Marshals
Service arrived at the farm of Larry and Linda Faillace shortly after 6 a.m.

As federal agents seized the sheep, protesters mockingly gave the Nazi salute.

"They were stolen from our farm today," owner Larry Faillace said.

The 126 sheep were loaded into a truck bound for Iowa, where they will be
destroyed and their brains tested for mad cow disease.

The truck was briefly blocked by protesters before it left.

"This is a government agency completely out of control. We have no check on this
agency," protester John Barkhausen said. "It doesn't follow its own rules or
regulations."

Three Faillace children - Jackie, Francis and Heather - each held young lambs
marked with red dye.

"This is not justice," said Francis Faillace. "Where are our rights?"

The farm couple had fought to keep their flock, urging officials to first
complete tests on 234 sheep confiscated Wednesday from the farm in Greensboro,
40 miles away. The request was denied.

"This is very difficult for them," U.S. Department of Agriculture spokes man Ed
Curlett said. "This is very difficult for us as well. However, it is our duty,
it is our mission to protect American agriculture."

The sheep will be tested for one of a family of neurological diseases that
include mad cow disease. The farmers will be paid fair market value for the
sheep, U.S. officials said.

The government said some of the sheep at the two Vermont farms may have been
exposed to mad cow disease through contaminated feed before they were imported
from Europe in 1996. They have been quarantined since 1998.

The seizure of the flock earlier this week marked the first time the U.S.
government has confiscated livestock and marked it for destruction because of
mad cow fears.

Nearly 100 people in Europe have died of the human form of mad cow disease since
1995, but no cases have been confirmed in the United States.

The seizures come against a background of growing concern about food safety in
Europe and the United States. Europe is battling an outbreak of foot-and-mouth
disease, which has led governments to destroy tens of thousands of cows, sheep
and pigs.

LOAD-DATE: March 24, 2001

LANGUAGE: English

NOTES: TOP OF THE NEWS

GRAPHIC: PHOTO Photo by the ASSOCIATED PRESS - Mary Jo Cahilly-Bretzin, 8,
carries out the last lamb to a waiting federal stock truck at the Faillace farm
in East Warren, Vt., on Friday. Federal agents seized a second flock of sheep
suspected of having been exposed to a form of mad cow disease.

                               The New York Times

                October 1, 1998, Thursday, Late Edition - Final

Farm Prices Fell in September, U.S. Says

BYLINE: Reuters

SECTION: Section C; Page 22; Column 5; Business/Financial Desk

LENGTH: 204 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30


Prices received by United States farmers for their crops and livestock were down
8.4 percent in September compared with the month last year, according to the
Agriculture Department.

The All Farm Products Index, which reflects prices for a mix of commodities, had
a September reading of 98, compared with 101 in August and 107 in September
1997, the department said in its monthly agricultural prices report.

The news will not come as a surprise to United States farmers, who have seen
prices drop this year as huge worldwide crops and meat production and the
decline of export demand from Asia, the top foreign market for United States
farm products, weigh heavily on income.

Congress is currently working on a package to help United States farmers during
the price crisis.

Wheat prices slid to their lowest level since August 1987, the department said.
Wheat prices during September reached an average $2.37 a bushel, down 2 cents
from the previous month and $1.29 lower than the same month last year.

The average corn price at $1.76 a bushel was the lowest since December 1987. The
September corn price was down 14 cents from August and 76 cents from September
1997, the Agriculture Department said.

LOAD-DATE: October 1, 1998

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                   Copyright 1998 The New York Times Company


                              19 of 998 DOCUMENTS

                               The New York Times

                November 10, 1992, Tuesday, Late Edition - Final

SCIENCE WATCH;
U.S. and Russia to Swap Fungi

BYLINE: By MARY RAFFALLI

SECTION: Section C; Page 8; Column 1; Science Desk

LENGTH: 310 words


The United States Department of Agriculture announced that for the first time
its researchers are preparing a collaboration with Russian scientists to
exchange and study samples of fungi, insects and parasites.

Dr. Amy Rossman, who studies fungi and was one of the three scientists who spent
a week in Russia working out the research exchange, said this kind of scientific
trade is an important corollary of free-trade agreements.

For example, she said, if timber from Siberia is brought into the United States,
it may be infested with fungi and other plant parasites indigenous to the
region, so it is important for scientists to be aware of and understand those
organisms.

Fungi, simple plant forms that include mushrooms, molds and yeast, often cause
diseases in animals and other plants. According to the agriculture department,
fungi cause over $3.5 billion in yearly crop damage in the United States.

But some of these organisms can be beneficial. One United States entomologist,
Dr. Douglass Miller of the U.S.D.A., said he plans to work on insect-control
programs with a Russian scientist who is an international authority on flies
that eat wheat aphids, which do more than $50 million in damage to the United
States wheat crop each year.

The 200-year-old Russian insect collection is twice the age of the American
collection and has 35 million specimens, 5 million more than the United States
collection. The United States fungus collection, however, with a million
samples, is five times the size of the Russian collection.

Dr. Rossman said it was not the relative sizes but the diversity of the
collections that had prompted the United States team to study Russian fungi
specimens. Initially, she plans to study a Russian fungus that causes a disease
called brown-spot in soy beans and other legumes imported to the United States.

LOAD-DATE: November 10, 1992

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                   Copyright 1992 The New York Times Company


                              20 of 998 DOCUMENTS


                           Daily Balochistan Express

                           February 28, 2015 Saturday

One million farmers increase productivity with US agri assistance

LENGTH: 310  words


Nearly one million Pakistani farmers have increased their agricultural
productivity and income with the assistance of the United States during the last
five years, Director for United States Agency for International Development
(USAID) Pakistan Gregory Gottlieb said on Friday.

Speaking as keynote speaker to open Pakistan Agriculture Conference and
Exposition 2015 here, he said that this assistance helped Pakistan directly
generate over $45 million in domestic sales and $28 million in export sales.

Helping Pakistani farmers improve the quality of agricultural products while
increasing productivity is a critical priority for the United States and
approximately 800,000 farmer families have increased their incomes through the
USPakistani cooperation, he added.

The twoday exposition will showcase the latest technological advances in the
agriculture industry and provide government agencies and the private sector a
forum to discuss agriculture engagement strategies.

The United States contributed a five stall pavilion to exhibit the agriculture
development efforts supported by USAID in Pakistan. Gregory Gottlieb said that
this is yet another example of how support for Pakistan's agriculture
development is a priority of the United States.

"We believe our agriculture projects will continue to contribute to the growth
of Pakistan's economy," he added.

Working together with a strong cadre of local farmers, agribusinesses and policy
makers, the United States and Pakistan's joint efforts in agriculture
development will contribute to a stronger, brighter future for all Pakistan, he
added.

Speakers from the Ministry of National Food Security and Research, as well as
representatives from the Pakistan Agricultural Research Council engaged
audiences on wide range of topics and spoke strategies to improve resources and
development in the agriculture industry.

LOAD-DATE: March 2, 2015

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

Pakistan: One million farmers increase productivity with US agri assistance

LENGTH: 347  words

DATELINE: ISLAMABAD


ISLAMABAD, Feb. 28 -- Nearly one million Pakistani farmers have

increased their agricultural productivity and income with the assistance of the
United States during the last five years, Director for United States Agency for
International Development (USAID) Pakistan Gregory Gottlieb said on Friday.

Speaking as keynote speaker to open Pakistan Agriculture Conference and
Exposition 2015 here, he said that this assistance helped Pakistan directly
generate over $45 million in domestic sales and $28 million in export sales.

Helping Pakistani farmers improve the quality of agricultural products while
increasing productivity is a critical priority for the United States and
approximately 800,000 farmer families have increased their incomes through the
US-Pakistani cooperation, he added.

The two-day exposition will showcase the latest technological advances

in the agriculture industry and provide government agencies and the private

sector a forum to discuss agriculture engagement strategies.

The United States contributed a five stall pavilion to exhibit the

agriculture development efforts supported by USAID in Pakistan.

Gregory Gottlieb said that this is yet another example of how support for
Pakistan's agriculture development is a priority of the United States.

"We believe our agriculture projects will continue to contribute to the growth
of Pakistan's economy," he added.

Working together with a strong cadre of local farmers, agribusinesses and policy
makers, the United States and Pakistan's joint efforts in agriculture
development will contribute to a stronger, brighter future for all Pakistan, he
added.

Speakers from the Ministry of National Food Security and Research, as well as
representatives from the Pakistan Agricultural Research Council engaged
audiences on wide range of topics and spoke strategies to improve resources and
development in the agriculture industry

                               The New York Times

             December 14, 1988, Wednesday, Late City Final Edition

Bush Makes Agriculture Post Choice

BYLINE: By GERALD M. BOYD, Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section B; Page 12, Column 3; National Desk

LENGTH: 605 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13


President-elect Bush has decided to offer the position of Secretary of
Agriculture to Clayton K. Yeutter, now the United States Trade Representative,
Bush transition officials said today.

In addition, another Cabinet position, that of Transportion Secretary, is
virtually certain to go to Samuel K. Skinner, the chairman of the Northern
Illinois Regional Transportation Authority, the officials said. Mr. Skinner has
been among the leading contenders for the job for several days, and no strong
rival has emerged.

Both announcements could come this week.

Mr. Bush met late today with Mr. Yeutter, who associates said had not decided
whether he would take the Agriculture Department post. For weeks he has told
friends that he wants to return to the private sector after three and a half
grueling years as Trade Representative.

Help in Trade Talks

One transition official said Mr. Bush was prepared to agree that Mr. Yeutter
could serve for less than four years if that was necessary to win him over.

Mr. Yeutter is an experienced Washington hand, having worked in three
administrations in both trade and agriculture areas. He would be expected to
bring continuity in the agriculture trade negotiations between the United States
and the European Community. He has also worked closely with James A. Baker 3d,
Mr. Bush's designee for Secretary of State, and Nicholas F. Brady, Mr. Bush's
choice for Treasury Secretary.

Mr. Yeutter, who turned 58 last Saturday, received a law degree and a Ph.D. in
agricultural economics from the University of Nebraska. He has been a farmer and
a president of the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. He joined the Reagan
Administration in July 1985, when his predecessor as Trade Representative,
William E. Brock, became Secretary of Labor.

He was Assistant Secretary of Agriculture under President Nixon and the Deputy
Trade Representative under President Ford.

As President Reagan's Trade Representative, he promoted an aggressive posture to
force some trading partners to open their markets further to American goods. In
his tenure, the United States also completed a free-trade agreement with Canada.

Another leading candidate for the top Agriculture post had been Representative
E. Thomas Coleman, Republican of Missouri. But Mr. Bush indicated on Monday that
he would not name any Republicans in Congress to his Cabinet so as not to
deplete their numbers.

That decision removed several other legislators from consideration for Cabinet
positions, including Representatives Lynn Martin of Illinois, Guy V. Molinari of
New York, Tom Ridge of Pennsylvania and John Paul Hammerschmidt of Arkansas.

Defense Choice Near

Mr. Bush is close to making his choice for Secretary of Defense, transition
officials also said. Mr. Bush's legal advisers are expected to meet Wednesday
with former Senator John G. Tower of Texas to review an investigation of his
background by the Federal Bureau of Investigation. Aides said the meeting could
be the final step before a formal announcement.

Besides considering personnel matters, Mr. Bush met for about 20 minutes today
with Coretta Scott King, the widow of The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. It was
one in a series of meetings that Mr. Bush has held with civil rights leaders
since the election.

Mrs. King, describing the sesssion with Mr. Bush as ''very warm and cordial,''
said they discussed the elimination of what she called the ''triple evils:''
war, racism and poverty.

''We don't disagree on goals,'' she said. ''The goals that he seems to want for
his administration are very similar to the goals that I would like to see.''

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

(NYT/Paul Hosefros)

               October 1, 1981, Thursday, Late City Final Edition

U.S.-Soviet Grain Talks

BYLINE: Reuters

SECTION: Section D; Page 7, Column 6; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 194 words

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Sept. 30


A United States Government delegation began talks in Moscow today on the sale of
millions of tons of grain to the Soviet Union, now facing its third poor harvest
in a row.

The seven-man team, headed by Agriculture Department Under Secretary Seeley
Lodwick, met Soviet negotiators at the Foreign Trade Ministry for what are
expected to be two days of hard bargaining.

The United States has said it is ready to offer Moscow at least 10 million tons
of wheat and corn and as much as 18 million tons. This would be in addition to a
maximum of eight million tons allowed under a current United States-Soviet sales
agreement.

United States farmers have had record grain harvests this year while the Soviet
crop, hit by drought in some areas and floods in others, is expected by
Agriculture Department experts to be the worst since the disastrous year of
1975.

But United States officials say Moscow is likely to give a cool reception to the
offer of millions of tons of additional American supplies, and to try to cover
its needs from non-United States sources.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                   Copyright 1981 The New York Times Company

                      The Financial Post (Toronto, Canada)

                      April 7, 1989, Friday, DAILY EDITION

U.S. land grab

SECTION: SECTION 1, NEWS; Pg. 6, U.S. BUSINESS BRIEFS

LENGTH: 92 words


  Foreign ownership of agricultural land in the U.S. rose to 12.5 million acres
at the end of last year, an increase of 99,100 acres from the previous year, the
U.S. Agriculture Department said yesterday. Despite the rise, foreign ownership
remained at slightly less than 1% of the total privately owned agricultural land
in the U.S. Citizens or corporations from Britain, Canada, France, West Germany,
the Netherlands Antilles, the Netherlands and Switzerland own 74% of the
foreign-held acreage. Japanese citizens own 2% of the total.

                              26 of 998 DOCUMENTS

                               The Financial Post

                   January 14, 1998 Wednesday DAILY EDITIONS

Washington gears up for wheat battle

BYLINE: Peter Morton, Washington Bureau Chief

SECTION: SECTION 1, NEWS; Pg. 3

LENGTH: 479 words

DATELINE: Washington, DC


Washington has launched two new probes into Canada's rising wheat exports to the
U.S.

One is being done by the U.S. Government Accounting Office, which looks into
claims of government fraud. Since late 1997 it has been looking into U.S.
imports of Canadian wheat and the role of the Canadian Wheat Board.

The GAO audit is parallel to one announced yesterday by U.S. Agriculture
Secretary Dan Glickman, after a meeting with Canadian Agriculture Minister Lyle
Vanclief.

The unusual GAO audit may be used by U.S. negotiators to demand the dismantling
of state-run sales and marketing operations, such as the CWB, when global farm
trade talks start in 1999, a senior GAO official said.

'This has implications far beyond just the wheat board,' said GAO assistant
director Phil Thomas.

Canada and the U.S. have been at odds over the high level of Canadian wheat
exports to the U.S., partly because U.S. wheat and grain has been unable to
enter Canada.

In a bid to ease tensions, Vanclief said a pilot project is being set up to
allow U.S. grain to be easily shipped to Canada.

'It would help to quell the feeling that perhaps we are in an unfair trading
scenario,' Glickman said.

But the U.S. is still convinced the CWB unfairly subsidizes Canadian farmers
because it refuses to make public the prices it gets on global wheat sales.

The GAO began the audit late last year at the request of Senator Byron Dorgan, a
long-time critic of the CWB. His spokesman said: 'The senator believes Canada is
engaging in unfair trade practices and has violated handshake agreements to
limit exports.'

So far, GAO investigators have talked to Canadian officials in Ottawa and at CWB
headquarters in Winnipeg. The probe is not expected to wrap up until mid-year.

U.S. officials say Canadian wheat shipments to the U.S. were expected to reach a
record 1.6 million tonnes last year. Canadian officials refused to reveal an
exact figure.

Dorgan has claimed Canadian officials told him and the U.S. administration that
Ottawa would voluntarily cap exports as it did in 1994. Ottawa denies making any
pledges.

Vanclief said Canada has no intention of limiting grain exports to the U.S. this
year. He said Ottawa is not worried about the audit ordered by Glickman. 'This
is not the first time that an audit has taken place. The actions of the wheat
board show that it is trading fairly.'

U.S. Trade Representative Charlene Barshefsky tried to pressure Ottawa into
making concessions on wheat late last year when President Bill Clinton was
trying, unsuccessfully, to get Congress to give him fast-track trade negotiating
authority.

Clinton needs the unique power to continue to expand the North American Free
Trade Agreement to Chile and beyond. Congress refused, and is unlikely to vote
approval this year because of U.S. mid-term elections and the unpopularity of
free trade.

LOAD-DATE: January 14, 1998

                               The New York Times

               June 19, 1985, Wednesday, Late City Final Edition

U.S.-SOVIET ACCORD ON FARMS SIGNED

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS, Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section A; Page 8, Column 4; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 357 words

DATELINE: MOSCOW, June 18


The Under Secretary of Agriculture, Daniel Amstutz, said here today that the
Soviet Union and the United States had agreed to resume agricultural cooperation
broken off after Soviet forces swept into Afghanistan in late 1979.

He said at a news conference that an accord signed after two days of talks
provided for exchanges of information, research and application of technology in
a number of agricultural areas. The two countries already have an agreement
regarding grain sales.

The new accord provides for exchanges of scientists and crop information,
although, Mr. Anstutz said, ''not be as much as we would like.''

Since 1980, the Soviet Union has imposed total secrecy on the size of its grain
harvest and on grain yields per acre, both on a national basis and for
individual regions. It still reports the size of other major crops such as sugar
beets, cotton, sunflower seeds and flax.

Mr. Amstutz said the current agreement, which resumes agricultural contacts
first started in 1973, took six months to negotiate. It follows a statement by
President Reagan last year that he wanted closer links in a number of areas,
including agriculture.

The Soviet Agriculture Minister, Valentin K. Mesyats, was in the United States
late last year and invited Secretary of Agriculture John R. Block to return the
visit.

The accord today provides for an exchange of 15 Soviet and 15 American young
farmers who will exchange places to learn about farming methods.

He said Soviet officials sounded optimistic about this year's grain crop and
expected it to exceed last year's, though no figures were offered.

The United States Department of Agriculture makes its own estimates of the
Soviet grain crop in the absence of Soviet official information, and expects the
grain crop this year to be 195 million metric tons compared with an estimate of
175 million for the 1984 harvest.

Agriculture has been a perennial trouble area in the Soviet economy, with a
series of poor harvests in the early 1980's. The average grain crop in the
five-year period 1976-80, before a statistical blackout was imposed in 1981, was
205 million metric tons.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                   Copyright 1985 The New York Times Company


                              28 of 998 DOCUMENTS

                      The Financial Post (Toronto, Canada)

                    January 30, 1990, Tuesday, DAILY EDITION

U.S. move to hike export subsidies could hurt Canada

BYLINE: Johanna Powell

SECTION: SECTION 1, NEWS; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 368 words

DATELINE: Edmonton,Alta.


  Despite assurances to the contrary, the Bush administration has proposed a 60%
increase in export subsidies in its trade war with Europe - meaning Canadian
farmers may be the victims.

The increase to US$900 million ($1.06 trillion) from US$566 million in the Bush
administration's request for the Export Enhancement Program is ''very bad news,
especially for Prairie farmers,'' Don Knoerr, president of the Canadian
Federation of Agriculture, said yesterday.

The administration's fiscal 1991 budget for the Agriculture Department - part of
Bush's overall US$1.23 trillion spending blueprint - said US$900 million would
be spent on subsidizing agricultural exports, a US$334-million increase from the
limit imposed this year. Export subsidies have been a major U.S. tool in
combating the policies of competitors.

The subsidies are applied mainly to wheat and, to a lesser extent, eggs and
vegetable oil.

Knoerr said the U.S. is clearly raising the ante in its trade war with the
European Community, and the Canadian treasury does not have the resources to
compete.

Canada's ability to play is limited and ''our farmers are the losers,'' Knoerr
said.

Only last month, Agriculture Minister Don Mazankowski was assured by U.S.
Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter that the EEP would be reduced in the 1991
fiscal budget.

A spokesman for Mazankowski yesterday said there would be no comment from the
department until the official figures have been studied.

A spokesperson for the U.S. Department of Agriculture confirmed the main reason
behind boosting the request for the EEP by $334 million from this year's
allocated $566 million is to pressure the EC into talking about subsidies during
the current round of GATT negotiations, due to end in December.

The spokesperson said the department has a new policy of looking carefully at
the impact of the EEP on non-subsidizing nations such as Canada and Australia,
and is trying to ensure that their market share is maintained.

Secretary of Agriculture Clayton Yeutter said that the EEP provided leverage for
bargaining with the EC ''to neutralize the export subsidies of other countries
if and when necessary.''

TYPE: NEWS

                              29 of 998 DOCUMENTS

                               The New York Times

                June 20, 1981, Saturday, Late City Final Edition

U.S. SHARPLY INCREASES FARM EXPORTS TO CHINA

BYLINE: By JAMES P. STERBA, Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section 2; Page 38, Column 5; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 325 words

DATELINE: PEKING, June 19


China has quietly become the United States' fourth-largest customer of food and
other agricultural commodities, with an estimated 12 million acres of American
farmland now planted annually to grow crops bound for China, according to
American agriculture officials.

American exports of food grains and fiber to China rose to more than $2 billion
last year from $64 million in 1977. Sales this year are expected to exceed $2.5
billion. Wheat accounted for roughly half the total last year.

Under an agreement signed last October, the Chinese have agreed to buy a minimum
of six million tons of wheat annually through 1984.

Drought in North China

For the wheat-buying year, ending June 30, China has so far purchased more than
8.5 million tons from the United States. The wheat has helped to make up for
domestic production shortfalls, the result primarily of drought in the North
China plain.

China buys all of its American grain on the open market without Washington's
participation, an American agricultural official at the embassy here said. But
under the October grain agreement, Peking has promised to consult with the
United States Department of Agriculture if its grain buying exceeds nine million
tons annually.

American agricultural exports to China will amount to 55 to 61 percent of all
American exports to that country this year. China's total imports from the
United States may top $4.5 billion this year, representing about 20 percent of
China's imports.

United States cotton shipments to China reached nearly $700 million last year,
or roughly one-fourth of America's total cotton exports.  China uses the cotton
to produce textiles and clothing, which now accounts for about half of its
exports to the United States.

Corn and soybean oil are other major American food exports to China - each
amounting to nearly $200 million last year.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                   Copyright 1981 The New York Times Company


                              30 of 998 DOCUMENTS



                                US Official News

                           September 26, 2014 Friday

Washington: Secretary Kerry, Secretary Vilsack Launch Global Alliance for
Climate-Smart Agriculture

LENGTH: 708  words

DATELINE: Washington


US Department of Agriculture, The Government of USA has issued the following
news release:

The United States is a founding member of the Global Alliance for Climate-Smart
Agriculture. As part of its commitment to promoting climate smart agriculture
around the world, the U.S. government supports the following initiatives:

In the United States, the Department of Agriculture (USDA) manages seven
"Climate Hubs" around the country to deliver information to farmers, ranchers
and forest landowners to help them adapt to climate change and weather
variability.
 The Global Research Alliance on Agricultural Greenhouse Gases, to which the
United States contributes, aims to deepen and broaden mitigation research
through collaboration and data sharing.
 Feed the Future, the U.S. government's global hunger and food security
initiative, focuses on agriculture-led development to spur broad-based economic
growth that can reduce hunger, poverty, and under nutrition. It is helping
mitigate risks of climate change by supporting smallholder farmers in producing
more and better quality foods, improving access to new tools and technologies,
and building resilience while using land, energy, water and other inputs more
efficiently.
 Feed the Future is pairing American ingenuity and expertise with some of the
best and brightest minds across the globe through its 24 Feed the Future
Innovation Labs, a unique network supported by more than 60 top U.S. colleges
and universities along with many partner country research and educational
institutions.
 The United States helped create the Climate and Clean Air Coalition on
Short-Lived Pollutants, housed at the UN Environment Program, which includes an
action-oriented Agriculture Initiative to address methane and black carbon
emissions associated with open agricultural burning, paddy rice production, and
livestock management.
 The U.S. Global Climate Change Initiative provides climate-related assistance
to more than 50 developing countries. Programs, like the SERVIR climate data
hubs, help developing countries build the critical capacities they need to
increase resilience to changes in climate, to protect lives and livelihoods, and
to promote low-carbon growth and development.

The United States also supports multilateral funds and organizations that
provide dedicated financing to agricultural development in developing countries.

The United States is the largest donor to the Global Agriculture and Food
Security Program, which has provided $912 million in grant financing to support
agricultural development in the world's poorest countries. About one-third of
the current portfolio, or roughly $300 million, focuses on climate adaptation
and mitigation activities.
 The United States is also the largest contributor to the International Fund for
Agricultural Development, which finances climate smart agriculture in the
poorest and most vulnerable agricultural communities.
 U.S. support to the international Climate Investment Funds (CIF), including the
Pilot Program on Climate Resilience (PPCR), helps the most vulnerable countries
protect their economies and citizens from the negative effects of climate
change. Agriculture and land management are one of the key sectors supported by
the PPCR. The Forest Investment Program (FIP) is providing more than $600
million for activities to address reducing emissions from deforestation and
degradation - often with significant agriculture components - in Brazil, Burkina
Faso, Democratic Republic of Congo, Ghana, Indonesia, Laos, Mexico, and Peru.
 In partnership with the Environmental Protection Agency and a range of private
and non-profit partners, USDA has created a new Food Waste Challenge to
encourage people to find new ways to reduce food loss and waste, to recover
unneeded, wholesome food that can help feed those in need, and to recycle wasted
food as much as possible. Food is the single largest component of municipal
solid waste going to landfills - and those landfills are the third largest
source of methane. By reducing the amount of food we toss into the trash, we can
help reduce these potent greenhouse gas emissions.

In case of any query regarding this article or other content needs please
contact: editorial@plusmediasolutions.com

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newswire

                              31 of 998 DOCUMENTS

                      The Financial Post (Toronto, Canada)

                     June 24, 1993, Thursday, DAILY EDITION

U.S. plans subsidy on wheat sales to Mexico

BYLINE: Associated Press

SECTION: SECTION 1, NEWS; Pg. 3

LENGTH: 198 words

DATELINE: Washington, DC


The U.S. will subsidize its wheat exports to Mexico to counter growing Canadian
sales, congressmen said yesterday.

Senator Byron Dorgan said the White House told him yesterday that the
administration will define Canada as a ''subsidizer,'' a move that will enable
the U.S. Department of Agriculture to use its export enhancement program to
subsidize wheat sales to Mexico.

Representative Tim Johnson also said he was notified by the White House of the
decision. He is chairman of the House of Representatives' agriculture
subcommittee on general farm commodities.

Neither White House press secretary Dee Dee Myers, nor Agriculture Department
spokesman Tom Amontree, was aware of the decision.

Dorgan said the administration plans to increase all wheat sales under the
program by 10%, in part to allow for sales to Mexico. He did not know how much
would be set aside for Mexico.

Other congressional sources said the amount would include one million tonnes of
wheat for Mexico.

U.S. wheat-growers face price declines. On some markets, per bushel prices have
dropped below US$3 because of the largest expected harvest since 1984 and a
declining export market.

                              32 of 998 DOCUMENTS

                           The Daily Yomiuri (Tokyo)

                           January 22, 2004 Thursday

Whose beef is the safest?;
BSE debate highlights Japan-U.S. split on meat inspection

BYLINE: Toshiaki SuzukiC Shigehisa Hanamura and Kyoichi Sasazawa / Yomiuri
Shimbun Staff Writers

SOURCE: Yomiuri

SECTION: Pg. 3

LENGTH: 756 words


The diagnosis of the first case of mad cow disease in the United States and the
resultant ban on U.S. beef imports in Japan clearly shows the different
approaches to food safety in Japan and the United States.

The two countries are expected to hold heated discussions on the issue as the
United States insists that U.S. beef is safe while Japan wants to ensure
consumers peace of mind.

During a visit by a government fact-finding mission earlier this month, U.S.
Agriculture Department officials emphasized that U.S. inspections for bovine
spongiform encephalopathy were being carried out for the purpose of
surveillance, not food safety.

Hirofumi Kugita, who was one of the members of the team and is director of the
International Animal Health Affairs Office of the Agriculture, Forestry and
Fisheries Ministry said: "For them, a scientific safety measure is to remove any
sections of cattle carcasses that are likely to contain BSE, or specified risk
material. They believe getting rid of these parts makes the meat safe."

The U.S. government announced Jan. 12 that all specified risk material would be
separated from all cattle 30 months or older when they are processed by a
slaughterhouse and banned the distribution of meat from cattle that were unable
to walk.

In a New York Times article last month, Ron DeHaven, the chief veterinarian at
the U.S. Agriculture Department, said Japan had overreacted and was "like a
doctor testing every patient who comes through the door for prostate cancer."

However, even opinions in the United States are divided, as some have criticized
U.S. measures.

Former Vermont Gov. Howard Dean, who is a candidate hoping to win the Democratic
presidential nomination, said that it cost only "three cents per pound" (453
grams) of beef to inspect all of the cattle.

However, the U.S. Agriculture Department maintains its stance that current
measures are sufficient.

The United States is proud of being the first country to introduce BSE
countermeasures.

BSE surveillance began in 1990 in the United States, six years before Japan. The
country also banned the use of meat-and-bone meal as cattle feed in August 1997,
four years before Japan. Meat-and-bone meal is one of the suspected sources of
BSE infection.

However, Japan imposed the most rigorous BSE measures in the world.

"Japan takes scientific safety measures. But more than that, we carry out
measures to ensure peace of mind (for consumers)," an Agriculture, Forestry and
Fisheries Ministry official said. "That's a big difference from the United
States," the official added.

Japan introduced inspection of all cows after the first BSE case was confirmed
in September 2001. This measure was seen as a way to reassure consumers of the
safety of food products.

An executive of a Tokyo nongovernmental organization on food safety also
highlighted the differences between the ways Japan and the United States view
food safety.

"For many Americans, food safety means methods that prevent obesity. Their
concerns are surprisingly different (to Japanese consumers)," Junichi Kowaka,
secretary general of the Japan Offspring Fund, said.

The different scale of livestock industries' business in each country is another
factor that demonstrates the differing views on food safety.

About 1.14 million cows are processed for meat annually in Japan, compared to 35
million cows per year in the United States.

Some observers have said the reluctance demonstrated by the United States to
introduce inspection of all cows reflects the opinions of the U.S. agriculture
industry, which is hesitant to implement checks on such a large number of cows.

Seoul also took the news of the first U.S. BSE case seriously as about 40
percent of the beef sold in South Korea comes from the United States.

However, only a few stories concerning the issue of inspections in the United
States were published in the South Korean media. BSE stories reported in the
country mainly dealt with the disease's impacts on the distribution industry.

The issue of inspecting all U.S. cattle is expected to remain the main topic of
negotiations between Japan and the United States.

"If we lift the ban on U.S. beef now and another BSE case is discovered,
Japanese consumers will never buy U.S. beef again," a senior Agriculture,
Forestry and Fisheries Ministry said.

"It will benefit the United States if it introduces high level measures now,"
the senior official added, expressing hopes for a compromise from the United
States.

LOAD-DATE: January 21, 2004

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                       Copyright 2004 The Yomiuri Shimbun


                              33 of 998 DOCUMENTS



                                US Official News

                             January 2, 2015 Friday

NFU President Brings Expertise in Agriculture, NFU Cooperative Model to Ghana;
Meets with the President, Minister of Food and Agriculture

LENGTH: 374  words

DATELINE: Washington


National Farmers Union has issued the following press release:

National Farmers Union (NFU) President Roger Johnson arrived in the Republic of
Ghana today to discuss the history of NFU and the development of cooperatives in
the United States at the National Food and Agric Show (FAGRO). Johnson will also
meet with President John Dramani Mahama, Minister for Food and Agriculture Fifi
Kwetey and Minister for Fisheries and Aquaculture Sherry Ayitey to discuss how
cooperatives can promote sustainable agriculture in Ghana.

"I am excited to be able to discuss and promote cooperatives as a means for
agricultural sustainability in Ghana," said Johnson. "Cooperatives provide
education and training for members, managers and employees, who can then utilize
that knowledge to effectively develop not only their cooperatives, but also
their communities."

Johnson noted that Farmers Union has a rich history of supporting and developing
cooperatives, and with that comes the ability to speak to the successes of
cooperatives in agriculture. Through the technical assistance and funding
provided by Farmers Union, cooperatives throughout the United States have been
able to benefit their local communities.

"Ghanaian officials have reached out to NFU in the past to explore the
cooperative model in the United States," said Johnson. "I believe that the
successes of the Farmers Union push for cooperatives in the United States can be
modeled in Ghana for the betterment of their agriculture industry."

Johnson will also be the guest speaker at the opening ceremony of FAGRO 2014,
where he will speak on the topics of sustainable agricultural growth and
development, and treating agriculture as a business.  He noted that Ghana's
economy relies heavily upon its agriculture sector, as it represents 21 percent
of the nation's GDP and 52 percent of the labor force.

"The health and vibrancy of Ghana's agriculture sector, just as it is in the
United States, is incredibly important to the health and vibrancy of the entire
nation," said Johnson. "I am happy to be able to help in the development of a
sustainable model for agriculture in Ghana."

                              34 of 998 DOCUMENTS

                               The New York Times

               March 10, 1988, Thursday, Late City Final Edition

Sugar Import Plan Blocked

BYLINE: Reuters

SECTION: Section D; Page 20, Column 5; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 236 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 9


The Agriculture Department announced this week that it lacks the legal authority
to carry out a program passed by Congress in December that would subsidize the
re-export of foreign-produced sugar.

The one-year program was intended to compensate developing nations for sharp
cuts in the United States sugar-import quota, now at 750,000 tons a year, which
keeps American prices above world rates. Government-owned commodities would
subsidize the re-export of refined sugar that was first imported in its raw form
at higher United States prices.

Under the plan, Caribbean nations could sell the United States 290,000 tons of
sugar and the Philippines 110,000 tons above prescribed quotas at the United
States price of 18 cents a pound. The world price is slightly more than 8 cents.

The controversial quotas prop up United States prices to protect a few thousand
American sugar growers.

Congress failed to give the Agriculture Department the authority it needed to
subsidize the re-export of foreign agricultural products, said John Nuttal, head
of the department's sugar group, in announcing the decision, which was reached
Tuesday.

The Reagan Administration is divided on how to respond to the department's
decision, according to one official. Representatives of affected countries said
failure to carry out the program would cost them about $97 million in lost sugar
sales at the higher United States price.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                   Copyright 1988 The New York Times Company


                              35 of 998 DOCUMENTS


                          The Globe and Mail (Canada)

                            February 25, 1991 Monday

PEI farmers fear   U.S. potato ban   Growers seek compensation after   seed
spuds found to have a virus

BYLINE: DEBORAH JONES; SPCL

LENGTH: 579 words

DATELINE: Halifax NS


BY DEBORAH JONES
Special to The Globe and Mail
  HALIFAX
 Potato farmers on Prince Edward Island will meet federal officials in PEI
this week to discuss compensation for tens of millions of dollars in
losses caused by a U.S. ban on seed potato imports.

"It's the gravest issue that has ever hit the PEI potato industry,"
said Robert Heaney, a farmer in Kensington.

Tom Van Dusen, spokesman for federal Agriculture Minister Donald
Mazankowski, said it will be at least two weeks before a decision is made
on compensation.

Scientists have identified the PVY-N virus, known as the necrotic
strain of potato virus Y, on between 1 and 2 per cent of potatoes on 14
PEI farms.

Last week, the U.S. Department of Agriculture told Agriculture Canada
that imports of seed potatoes from all but a small part of PEI are
prohibited.

Severe restrictions placed early this month on all potato imports from
PEI and New Brunswick were relaxed by the United States last week, leaving
most PEI farmers scrambling to find markets for their seed potatoes.

Table potatoes can be imported into the United States if treated with a
chemical to inhibit growth of sprouts or if used in processing.

Canada exports about 120,000 tonnes of seed potatoes, worth about $40-
million, annually throughout the world. About 90 per cent of the potatoes
come from PEI and New Brunswick and the biggest export market is the
United States.

The restrictions were imposed early this month after a January
conference of a U.S. potato association. A Canadian scientist presented
research on a 1989 PVY-N virus infection of an Ontario tobacco crop, which
was traced to PEI seed potatoes, which were previously considered clear of
the virus.

The virus does not affect humans or even the potatoes that carry it,
but can devastate tobacco crops and possibly harm tomato and pepper plants
when transmitted by insects. The strain of the virus is common throughout
the world, but North America has been considered largely clear of it. No
one knows how PEI potatoes became infected.

Scientists had known of the PEI problem for many months and were
dealing with it - Agriculture Canada quarantined several PEI farms in
December - when, without warning, the United States slapped restrictions
on Canadian potatoes.

Ben Borrel, chief of technical services for Agriculture Canada, said
Canada informed the United States of the problem at a Sept. 28 meeting in
Washington.

But Stephen Poe, a plant pathologist with the USDA, said the United
States was not formally notified. "Either they didn't tell us real good,
or we didn't pick up on it real good . . . no serious attention was paid
until January. Potatoes were routinely coming in. Somehow, someone looked
at this and said, 'Whoa, this is a problem.' "
   Canadian industry and government officials charge the sudden U.S.
embargo is prompted by trade protectionism more than plant protection.

PEI Agriculture Minister Keith Milligan suggested the United States
could be the source of the infection and asked Ottawa to inspect seed
tubers entering Canada. "Our eradication efforts cannot be jeopardized by
the risk of infection from the U.S."

PEI farmers are seeking federal compensation of up to $200,000 each
because this summer's crop cannot be sold to important U.S. markets, and
because of expected long-term damage to markets and to PEI's reputation
for growing healthy seed potatoes.

"The only way for this portion of our industry to recover is through
massive compensation," said George Webster, chairman of the PEI potato
board.

LOAD-DATE: January 9, 2007

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                              All Rights Reserved


                              36 of 998 DOCUMENTS

                              Journal of Commerce

                           April 21, 1999, Wednesday

US agriculture secretary mending fences in Canada

BYLINE: BY COURTNEY TOWER

SECTION: WORLD TRADE; Pg. 11A

LENGTH: 614 words

DATELINE: OTTAWA


U.S. Secretary of Agriculture Dan Glickman is reaching out to Canadian
agriculture industry leaders this week to form a U.S.-Canada consensus on global
farm trade issues.

But Mr. Glickman has also criticized Canada's agricultural support mechanisms -
and some Canadians have returned the criticism by noting examples of U.S. farm
subsidies.

In talks to bring agriculture within Word Trade Organization rules reducing
tariffs, quotas and other trade-distorting protections, the United States will
draw a special bead on ""state trading agencies,'' and in particular the
Canadian Wheat Board, Mr. Glickman said in a speech to Canadian farm and agri-
food business representatives.

AUDIENCE APPLAUDS GLICKMAN

The audience did applaud Mr. Glickman's statements declaring that the United
States would offer tough leadership on export subsidy issues and other barriers
to free-market trade.

But questioners who said the United States would do well first to reduce its own
subsidy supports to farmers also were applauded.

The new round of negotiations, to bring agriculture and financial services under
World Trade Organization auspices, begins Nov. 30 in Seattle.

Mr. Glickman said the United States would propose the elimination of export
subsidies, particularly those doled out by the European Union, and to ""rein in
the trade-distorting practices of what we perceive to be state trading
enterprises.''

""I recognize that this is a serious bone of contention between our two
countries, particularly with respect to the Canadian Wheat Board,'' he said. But
the world had to look at everything that distorts markets, he noted.

The Canadian Wheat Board markets all Western Canada's export wheat and barley,
about a fifth of world wheat exports.

U.S. agriculture representatives and politicians say that it effectively
subsidizes wheat exports and sells at less than market rates in order to grab
market share.

Canada says the CWB is paid for collectively by farmers, receives no government
financial aid, and because of its size and 70 years of expertise is adept at
marketing grain for the best prices.

PERENNIAL TRADE ISSUE

The CWB has been a perennial agricultural trade issue between the United States
and Canada.

One U.S. agricultural trade objective in the coming world negotiations includes
reducing tariffs, officials have said, adding the United States has the lowest
agricultural tariffs in the world.

A second U.S. goal would be to ""discipline'' so-called tariff-rate quotas
(TRQs). These are prohibitive tariffs many countries place on imports of foods,
especially sensitive to their own agriculture industries. Tariffs can run as
high as 300 percent. The high tariffs replace former prohibitive import quotas
and bans on such goods, but do the same job.

US HAS ITS TRQS

The United States has its own TRQs on peanuts, sugar and cotton. Canada applies
TRQs to dairy products, eggs and poultry.

Mr. Glickman said a third U.S. objective would be for countries to discipline
domestic subsidies to agriculture as well.

The United States has many agriculture support programs, and last year passed
legislation providing more than $6 billion in emergency support for farmers, he
said. But none of these distorted trade and were ""well within'' WTO limits, Mr.
Glickman said.

Mr. Glickman, addressing reporters after the speech, said the Canadian Wheat
Board lacked transparency on its trades, prices and volumes, while, generally
speaking, private U.S. grain companies were more transparent.

He refused to say whether the U.S. would be appeased if the Canadian Wheat Board
became equally transparent with U.S. grain trading companies.

LOAD-DATE: April 21, 1999

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                    Copyright 1999 Journal of Commerce, Inc.


                              37 of 998 DOCUMENTS


                            The New York Times Blogs
                                  (Sinosphere)

                            January 8, 2015 Thursday

U.S. Charter Airline Cited for Neglecting Cargo of Macaques From China

BYLINE: SHAOJIE HUANG

SECTION: WORLD; asia

LENGTH: 541 words



HIGHLIGHT: The U.S. Department of Agriculture said Air Transport International
failed to provide food and water for more than 24 hours to the crab-eating
macaques it flew to Houston from Guangzhou on Dec. 7.


An American charter airline has been accused by the United States Department of
Agriculture of violating an animal protection law while shipping monkeys to
laboratories in the United States from China.

In its inspection report, the Agriculture Department said that Air Transport
International shipped 1,148 crab-eating macaques to Houston from the southern
Chinese city of Guangzhou on Dec. 7 and failed to provide the animals with food
and water for more than 24 hours, in violation of the Animal Welfare Act. The
report also cited insecure crates that it said put the animals in danger.

The case reflects recent shifts in the international trade in animals for
experiments, as more commercial airlines have halted such shipments under
pressure from animal welfare advocates, and as research facilities and
pharmaceutical companies have increasingly had to rely on charter flights - a
more expensive alternative.

China is the leading supplier of primates to the United States, exporting more
than 10,000 monkeys in 2013, or 56 percent of the total, according to the
International Primate Protection League, an advocacy group. Crab-eating
macaques, which are widely used in biomedical experiments, are not native to
China but are bred there commercially for export. The cost of raising a monkey
in China is about half that of the United States.

It is the second time Air Transport International has run afoul of the law while
transporting monkeys from China for laboratory research. In July, it was accused
of neglecting to feed more than 1,700 macaques for more than 32 hours.

Air Transport International and Air Transport Services Group, its parent
company, did not respond to requests, via telephone and email, for comment. The
Agriculture Department has not opened an investigation on either citation of
noncompliance yet, said a department public affairs specialist, Tanya Espinosa,
adding that the report was posted on the department's database on Jan. 2.

If an investigation confirms the inspector's report, the Agriculture Department
may impose a fine. Last year, China Southern Airlines, a state-owned carrier,
settled an animal welfare violation charge with the Agriculture Department and
paid a fine of $11,600. It later announced that it would no longer transport
monkeys to the United States.

China Southern's decision to end such transports was hailed by the People for
the Ethical Treatment of Animals and other animal welfare advocates who have
campaigned for years to cut off the supply of monkeys for laboratory
experiments. But defenders of such experiments argue that primates, and other
species, cannot be completely replaced, and that the greater reliance on charter
airlines only increases the cost of important research.

"The shipments they are doing are quite large, as you can see in these reports,"
Justin Goodman, PETA's director of laboratory investigations, said of the
charter flights. "Unfortunately they are picking up the slack of many Chinese
companies that now refuse to take part in this bloody industry, and they are
capitalizing on that."

Another challenge is that charter airlines "are not as accountable to the public
as the passenger airlines," Mr. Goodman said. "They are able to fly under the
radar a little more."

LOAD-DATE: January 8, 2015

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

DOCUMENT-TYPE: News

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Web Blog


                   Copyright 2015 The News York Times Company
                              All Rights Reserved


                              38 of 998 DOCUMENTS


                            The New York Times Blogs
                                  (Sinosphere)

                            January 8, 2015 Thursday

U.S. Charter Airline Cited for Neglecting Cargo of Macaques From China

BYLINE: SHAOJIE HUANG

SECTION: WORLD; asia

LENGTH: 541 words



HIGHLIGHT: The U.S. Department of Agriculture said Air Transport International

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Web Blog


                   Copyright 2015 The News York Times Company
                              All Rights Reserved


                              39 of 998 DOCUMENTS

                               The New York Times

                June 11, 1981, Thursday, Late City Final Edition

U.S. SEEKS PLAN TO AVOID SALES OF BUTTER TO SOVIET

BYLINE: Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section D; Page 16, Column 5; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 575 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 10


At the request of Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr., President Reagan has
rejected an Agriculture Department recommendation that the United States dispose
of its surplus butter in the open market, where it might be purchased by the
Soviet Union.

White House officials said today that, instead, Mr. Reagan has directed
Agriculture Secretary John R. Block to devise ways of selling the butter while
making sure that it does not end up in Russian hands.

Mr. Haig had argued against an unrestricted sale on the ground that it would
send the ''wrong signal'' to the Russians at a time of rising American concern
about Soviet behavior around the world, the official said.

Mr. Reagan's preliminary decision on butter sales, made at a Cabinet meeting
last week, was seen by White House officials as a victory for Mr. Haig, who had
earlier argued without success against lifting the curbs on grain sales to the
Russians.

The Secretary of State had warned that lifting the grain sale curbs would also
be a ''wrong signal.'' In that case, however, he was overruled because Mr.
Reagan had promised to lift the curbs during the Presidential campaign. White
House officials also maintained that the grain sale curbs had not been effective
in their originally stated purpose of punishing the Russians for their 1979
military intervention in Afghanistan.

Surplus of 400 Million Pounds

The United States has accumulated a surplus of more than 400 million pounds of
butter, which it buys from American farmers at prices below the American market
price and then freezes and stores.  World butter prices are now below the
American market price. If the Russians had bought the butter at world prices,
the United States might have been seen as subsidizing the Russians' ability to
get a cut-rate deal on the butter.

The United States purchased the butter at roughly $1.50 a pound, a price set by
Federal legislation, according to the Agriculture Department. The world price
for butter is $1 a pound.

An aide to Mr. Reagan said today that the President had been persuaded by the
argument that it would look bad for the United States to be seen subsidizing
Russian butter purchases.

American consumers purchase butter for about $2 a pound, so that the United
States would also be selling the butter overseas a prices better than those
available to Americans. This aspect also contributed to Mr. Reagan's reluctance
to sell the butter to the Russians, White House officials said.

''The matter is still under consideration,'' the aide said.  ''There's a series
of other options the Agriculture Secretary is looking at, so that we can sell
the butter at the world price without it going to the Soviets. We have all this
butter sitting here, purchased by the Government, and it would be nice to do
something to recoup the money that's been spent.''

Agriculture officials have said that the Soviet Union is the one nation that
seems to be most in need of butter at the present time, and they doubted whether
there would be a market for the purchases if the Russians were ruled out.

A White House official said the new options being put together by Mr. Block
would likely be discussed next week at another Cabinet meeting.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                   Copyright 1981 The New York Times Company


                              40 of 998 DOCUMENTS


                          The Globe and Mail (Canada)

                             April 24, 2001 Tuesday

Agriculture Minister ridiculed in House

BYLINE: DANIEL LEBLANC

SECTION: NATIONAL NEWS; Pg. A9

LENGTH: 293 words

DATELINE: OTTAWA


Agriculture Minister Lyle Vanclief painted himself as a security threat
yesterday, saying he was not allowed into the Summit of the Americas to discuss
the PEI potato ban with his American counterpart.

"Arrangements could not be made for security reasons for me to get into the
summit," he said in the Commons. Opposition MPs ridiculed Mr. Vanclief's excuse
for not attending the summit.

"Why could the Prime Minister not get the Minister of Agriculture in? The
secretary of state from the United States got in. Why could the Minister of
Agriculture not get into the talks?" Conservative MP Rick Borotsik asked.

Mr. Vanclief has been embarrassed on a number of occasions during the potato
dispute with the United States.

Last October, the United States banned all imports of Prince Edward Island
potatoes after a wart fungus was discovered in one field.

Recently, Mr. Vanclief was criticized by PEI politicians and farmers for saying
that the United States was unlikely to back away from the ban and that farmers
should consider growing something else or developing other markets.

Then he announced that the United States had agreed to lift the import ban if
certain conditions were met. He was later forced to backtrack, after the
Americans insisted that their position had not changed.

Mr. Vanclief insisted yesterday that negotiations are moving along positively,
in part thanks to a telephone conversation with U.S. Agriculture Secretary Ann
Veneman.

"I did not have to spend thousands of taxpayer dollars to be there for a
meeting, and our officials are in Washington this afternoon to continue those
discussions," he said.

Mr. Vanclief also pointed out that Prime Minister Jean Chrétien had raised the
issue with U.S. President George W. Bush.

LOAD-DATE: September 21, 2006

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                              41 of 998 DOCUMENTS



                                US Official News

                            August 14, 2014 Thursday

Washington: United States and Five African Countries Announce Intention To Join
Global Alliance for Climate-Smart Agriculture

LENGTH: 586  words

DATELINE: Washington


Office of the Secretary of State has issued the following news release:

Liberia, Malawi, Niger, Nigeria, Tanzania and the United States confirmed last
week their intention to join the Global Alliance for Climate Smart Agriculture
(GACSA). At the August 4 U.S.-Africa Leaders Summit event entitled "Resilience
and Food Security in a Changing Climate," Secretary of State John Kerry
announced the United States' intention to join GACSA and encouraged African
countries to participate. The event highlighted the nexus of food security,
climate change, and resilience - issues that are of particular concern among
African nations, where much of the population, relying on rain-fed agriculture,
is especially vulnerable to the impacts of climate change on rainfall patterns
and seasonal temperatures.

Slated for launch at the UN Secretary General's Climate Summit on September 23,
GACSA is expected to engage a range of government, multinational organizations,
private sector, farmers and civil society stakeholders to achieve sustainable
increases in agricultural productivity, greater resilience and a reduction of
agriculture-related greenhouse gas emissions.

The United States supports climate-smart agriculture globally through its Feed
the Future and Global Climate Change initiatives. This year, USAID initiated ten
new Feed the Future Innovation Laboratories to increase global food security and
help smallholder farmers boost incomes and improve nutrition. These laboratories
draw the expertise of top U.S. universities and developing country research
institutions, and will tackle some of the world's most challenging agricultural
research problems with the premise of introducing safe, environmentally
sustainable proven and appropriate technologies to the world's most vulnerable
people.

Earlier this year, the U.S. Department of Agriculture announced the
establishment of seven regional climate hubs to deliver information to farmers,
ranchers and forest landowners in the United States to help them adapt to
climate change and weather variability.

The U.S. State Department also supports targeted programs that advance climate
resilience and food security throughout the world including through
contributions to the multilateral Least Developed Countries Fund and Special
Climate Change Fund and through support for the Climate and Clean Air
Coalition's new Agriculture Initiative.

Full text of the joint announcement:

Statement of Endorsement for a Global Alliance for Climate-Smart Agriculture

The Malabo Declaration on Accelerated Agricultural Growth and Transformation for
Shared Prosperity includes, in Section VI, a Commitment to Enhancing Resilience
of Livelihoods and Production Systems to Climate Variability and other related
risks. This commitment is consistent with the aspirations of those supporting
the founding, later this year, of the Global Alliance for Climate-Smart
Agriculture (GACSA).

Liberia, Malawi, Niger, Nigeria, Tanzania, and the United States announce our
intention to:

Join and support the Global Alliance for Climate Smart Agriculture expected to
be launched in September of this year at the UN Secretary General's Climate
Summit.
 Urge other countries, along with civil society organizations, private sector
representatives, farmer organizations, and other enterprises to join the Global
Alliance for Climate-Smart Agriculture to help fulfill our shared aspirations
for strengthened global food and nutrition security and resilience.

For more information please visit: http://www.state.gov

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newswire

                              42 of 998 DOCUMENTS

                               The New York Times

              September 26, 1988, Monday, Late City Final Edition

A Low for Crop Acreage

BYLINE: Reuters

SECTION: Section D; Page 4, Column 6; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 84 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25


American farmers this year are likely to harvest the lowest number of acres in
this century, the United States Agriculture Department said Friday. In a monthly
report, the department said that record acreage left unplanted under Government
programs and high crop failure this year because of the summer drought resulted
in the record low acreage. Harvested cropland in the United States was estimated
at about 284 million acres, down 9 million from last year and 67 million acres
below the 1981 peak.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                   Copyright 1988 The New York Times Company


                              43 of 998 DOCUMENTS

                       St. Louis Post-Dispatch (Missouri)

                 July 31, 2000, Monday, FIVE STAR LIFT EDITION

ALTON AREA BRIEFS

SECTION: ALTON AREA POST, Pg. 1

LENGTH: 602 words



GODFREY

Missionary Oblates, land trust reach agreement

The Great Rivers Land Trust has signed a contract with the Missionary Oblates of
Mary Immaculates to protect the area from future development.

The Missionary Oblates donated the development rights for a mile-long stretch of
bluff that overlooks the Mississippi River. That donation was used to match a
grant from the Illinois Department of Natural Resources, which was used in turn
to match a grant from the U.S. Department of Agriculture.

The land trust then used the grant money - more than $ 500,000 - to buy other
conservation easements on the Missionary Oblates' property.

Although the Missionary Oblates still have title to the property, they must
participate in a management plan to preserve the land. The agreement will stand
even if the property is sold, said Annie Hoagland, vice president of the land
trust.

"They are able to continue what they have been doing." Hoagland said. "But we've
managed to provide them with an income so they don't get in a crunch and have to
sell off pieces of (their land).

"They give posterity a great gift."

GODFREY

Lewis and Clark College will host tennis tourney

Lewis and Clark Community College will host the U.S. Tennis Association Men's
Futures Tournament next week.

Lewis and Clark could become the tournament's permanent home, said Jeff Allsman,
the college's sports information director. This is the college's third year to
host the tournament.

The event begins on Friday with qualifying rounds. The main-draw tournament runs
Aug. 8-13. All matches will be played at the Andy Simpson Tennis Complex on the
college's campus, 5800 Godfrey Road.

The event is a satellite tournament of the 2000 Men's USTA Prudential Services
Circuit, an introductory stage for professional tennis competition.

The matches are free and open to the public. Play starts at 10 a.m. each day and
runs into the early evening. For details, call Allsman at 468-3220.

ALTON

Gospel group will perform at Hayner Main Library

Wilma and the Messengers, a St. Louis gospel group, will perform at 6:30 p.m.
Aug. 8 at the Hayner Main Library, 401 State Street.

The musicians use drums, keyboards and guitars to accompany their performances
of contemporary and traditional gospel music. The group started more than 20
years ago, when most of its members were still in elementary or high school.

The group performs worldwide, with concerts planned for parts of Africa,
Barbados and Haiti.

The event is free, but registration is required. For information or
registration, call 462-0677.

GODFREY

Parks department will offer youth soccer leagues

The Godfrey Parks and Recreation Department will offer soccer leagues this fall
for children ages 3-7.

The Start Smart Soccer program is open to children ages 3-5 whose parents or
other adults can accompany them to six one-hour sessions.

The program teaches soccer skills and techniques in a fun environment. Sessions
will be held from 6 to 7 p.m. on Tuesdays and Thursdays from Sept. 5 to 21. The
cost is $ 12 for Godfrey residents and $ 15 for non-residents.

The youth soccer league, for ages 6 to 7, will play 10 games. Games will be held
on Tuesdays and Thursdays, Sept. 5 to 21, and on Saturdays from Sept. 23 to Oct.
14. The cost is $ 15 for Godfrey residents and $ 20 for nonresidents.

Both programs will be held at Glazebrook Park.

The advance registration deadline is Friday. Late registrants will be charged a
$ 5 fee. For more information, call Godfrey Parks and Recreation at 466-1483.
