                   The Star Phoenix (Saskatoon, Saskatchewan)

                            August 9, 2006 Wednesday
                                 Final Edition

Fair trade tops agenda for Wartman

BYLINE: Saskatchewan News Network; Regina Leader-Post

SECTION: BUSINESS; Pg. C6

LENGTH: 317 words

DATELINE: REGINA


REGINA -- Saskatchewan Agriculture Minister Mark Wartman says fair trade with
the U.S. will be among the issues he will raise at this week's 16th annual
Tri-National Agricultural Accord meetings in Alberta.

Wartman leaves today for the meetings, which will be attended by Canadian
agriculture ministers, U.S. commissioners and secretaries of agriculture and
Mexican secretaries of agriculture.

A number of agriculture- and traderelated issues are on the agenda for the four
days of meetings in Banff, including trade-distorting subsidies, anti-dumping
and countervail measures, and plant pesticide and veterinary drug harmonization.

"I will work to ensure that solutions to these concerns are developed and will
continue to emphasize our government's position that trade between our
countries, particularly the United States, must be fair.

Saskatchewan farmers must be able to get a fair return for what they produce."
Wartman referred to previous trade disputes, such as U.S. challenges over how
the Canadian Wheat Board operates, as trade harassment, and wants to ensure
trade rules are applied fairly by the United States.

Another important issue for Saskatchewan is harmonization of standards in Canada
and United States in the development of pesticides and veterinary drugs.

At present, it can take up to three years longer to get approval in Canada,
giving U.S. companies a considerable advantage, Wartman said.

Offi cials will be discussing issues that affect billions of dollars in
agriculture and agri-food sales between the three countries. Saskatchewan
agriculturalrelated exports to the U.S. exceeded $850 million in 2005, while
sales to Mexico totalled more than $263 million.

A year ago, when accord participants met in California, Wartman's goal was to
lessen barriers to the fl ow of cattle into the United States. He said those
meetings proved benefi cial in easing border restrictions on cattle.

                              Journal of Commerce

                          September 7, 1989, Thursday

US MEAT EXPORTERS EYE PACIFIC RIM

BYLINE: PAULA L. GREEN; Journal of Commerce Staff

SECTION: EXPORTS, Pg. 4A

LENGTH: 298 words


U.S. exporters of red meat are targeting markets throughout the Pacific Rim with
the help of a $ 9 million grant from the U.S. Department of Agriculture.

The U.S. Meat Export Federation program is using almost 40 percent of the funds
to try to expand the Japanese market for beef, pork and lamb products and about
25 percent to target markets in the China-Pacific region, from South Korea to
Singapore, said Philip Seng, the federation's senior vice president of
nternational programs.

The federation is one of about 50 associations that will receive funds through
the Targeted Export Assistance program, which is run by the department's foreign
agriculture service.

The $ 200 million appropriation for the 1990 fiscal year is the last in the
five-year program, which was authorized under the 1985 Farm Bill. The program
was designed to help commodity producers that were facing unfair trade practices
in foreign countries, a department official said.

This year, for example, the American Soybean Association will receive $ 11.5
million and the California Walnut Commission $ 8 million.

Mr. Seng said U.S. meat exporters want to be ready when Japan's meat market
opens up in 1991. "Right now the market is very controlled," he said. ''As
quotas are lifted and the distribution system is simplified, we want to expand."

U.S. red-meat producers ship about $ 1 billion worth of their output, or 70
percent of their exports, to Japan each year, he said. Before the European
Community banned imports of meats treated with hormones, the 12 EC nations
imported about $ 250 million worth of beef, pork and lamb products, he said.

The Denver-based federation represents a broad range of players in the meat
industry, from cattle feeders to members of the packing industry.

                          The Globe and Mail (Canada)

                          December 20, 1989 Wednesday

Canada defends marketing boards

BYLINE: JENNIFER LEWINGTON; GAM

LENGTH: 596 words

DATELINE: Washington DC


BY  JENNIFER LEWINGTON
 The Globe and Mail
  WASHINGTON
   Canada aims to strengthen protection for its system of marketing boards
in the current global trade talks, Agriculture Minister Donald Mazankowski
has vowed, defending Canadian agricultural practices that the Bush
administration hopes to eliminate.
   'Marketing boards are not trade-distorting. They don't contribute to a
world surplus in agriculture,' he told reporters yesterday after meeting
U.S. Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter on the Uruguay Round of trade
negotiations and a menu of bilateral food irritants.

While the United States wants a global agreement to get rid of all
agricultural subsidies, marketing boards and other forms of domestic
protection, Mr. Mazankowski said Canada wants to 'clarify and
strengthen' the wording of current rules that permit some supply-
management practices.

'We've made it very clear that the supply-managed system is a very  important
component of our agricultural industry,' he said, adding that  new rules could
give 'a better understanding of what is appropriate.'     One U.S. trade
official said Canada 'is the only one arguing for more  protective rules for
agriculture.' He reiterated the ambitious U.S.  agenda to eliminate, or at worst
reduce, the import barriers imposed by  the United States, the European
Community and other agricultural  exporters, including Canada.

Mr. Mazankowski said Canada is not prepared to cut a bilateral deal
with the United States over ice cream and yogurt, one of several bilateral
trade complaints, before settling the agriculture issue more broadly at
the Uruguay Round.

Those negotiations, conducted under the auspices of the General
Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, are intended, among other things, to
reduce barriers to agricultural trade.

Canada and the United States impose stiff restrictions against each
other on dairy products, although they use different mechanisms to achieve
the same end.

Recently, GATT ruled against Canada's import restrictions on the dairy
products and the United States has been pushing for a settlement.

Mr. Mazankowski said Canada is 'not prepared to negotiate' on the
basis of the U.S. proposal because 'the access they are asking for is too
much in our view.' U.S. officials, unhappy about Canadian import
restrictions that effectively limit U.S. exporters to 0.13 per cent of the
ice cream market, want full access.

While defending Canada's use of marketing boards, Mr. Mazankowski
criticized U.S. export subsidy programs, especially for grain, that
effectively depress the world market price. He said that 'Canada is
caught in the cross-fire' in an agricultural trade war between the United
States and the European Community in third markets, making it difficult
for Canada to compete.

He said Mr. Yeutter indicated the United States may ease off on its use
of grain export subsidies for budgetary reasons.

Mr. Mazankowski said he is 'encouraged' by signals from the EC that
they may cut back on their export subsidies as well, which could raise
world producer prices a little.

On bilateral trade frictions, many of which involve food products at
the border, the minister said: 'I'm satisified on agricultural issues
that we're going to be able to resolve these issues.' For the moment,
however, the new mechanisms in the bilateral free-trade agreement have
failed to end several longstanding disputes, including Canadian
restrictions on salmon and herring, labelling requirements for imports of
fruit and vegetables, as well as U.S. import curbs on pork and restrictive
rules on meat inspection and products that contain sugar.

                      The Financial Post (Toronto, Canada)

                   November 10, 1988, Thursday, DAILY EDITION

Farm-policy challenge will come in budget cuts

BYLINE: Reuters

SECTION: SECTION 1, NEWS; Pg. 9

LENGTH: 236 words

DATELINE: Washington,D.C.


  President-elect George Bush will probably continue the aim of President Ronald
Reagan to reduce federal involvement in agriculture, farm policy experts say.

But he also is likely to put his own stamp on the U.S. Department of
Agriculture, and a stronger Democratic Congress is expected to force compromises
that could increase the government's role in supporting farm prices.

''I think the Bush administration will not be inclined to take a hard look at
recent agriculture policy decisions because they were made by friendly hands,''
said agriculture consultant John Schnittker, a former Democratic official of the
USDA.

Under Reagan, the government reduced price supports to make farm exports more
competitive but retained income assistance for farmers through costly direct
payments.

Bush has endorsed Reagan administration goals at the General Agreement on
Tariffs & Trade to phase out agricultural subsidies worldwide.

Bush's first major domestic challenge in agriculture is likely to come next
spring, when Congress and the White House begin debating ways to make US$30
billion in budget cuts needed to reach deficit-reduction targets. U.S. farm
programs have cost about US$60 billion over the past three years and will be
likely targets in any budget-reduction efforts.

U.S. Agriculture Secretary Richard Lyng has long said he will step down at the
end of Reagan's term.

                              89 of 998 DOCUMENTS

                               The New York Times

              September 20, 1983, Tuesday, Late City Final Edition

SCIENCE WATCH;
Farming by the Slice

SECTION: Section C; Page 6, Column 4; Science Desk

LENGTH: 262 words


A new method of planting crops is being tested by the United States Department
of Agriculture in the hope of helping protect the nation's farmlands against
erosion, a problem considered to be the most serious currently facing American
agriculture. Recent studies indicate that wind and rain annually strip four to
eight tons of topsoil per acre from the country's croplands.

The procedure, performed by a newly-developed implement called a slit planter,
is being tried out in fields near Auburn, Ala., by the Federal agency's
Agriculture Research Services. It uses a knifelike blade to slice the ground
into slit trenches 15 inches deep, but only one-sixteenth of an inch wide at the
bottom. The planter spreads a layer of topsoil over the top of the trench and
the seeds are then planted in the topsoil. The resulting field looks like a
sliced cake, with all slices parallel.

Charles B. Elkins, an Agriculture Department soil scientist who is leader of the
test project, has found that the slicing technique, called slit planting, works
best in hardpan soils. There it lets the roots of such crops as soybeans,
sunflowers, okra and peanuts penetrate the firmly packed soil to find nutrients
and water in the subsoil. At the same time, the slicing leaves the topsoil and
its crop residues in place to act as anchors against the ravages of wind and
rain.  Dr. Elkins is now working with the research agency's agricultural
engineers to develop the slit-planting farm implement so it can be mass-
produced for use in areas where it would prove to be most advantageous.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                   Copyright 1983 The New York Times Company


                              90 of 998 DOCUMENTS


                          International New York Times

                             June 21, 2014 Saturday

Farming rebounds after drought;
Off The Charts

BYLINE: BY FLOYD NORRIS

SECTION: FINANCE; Pg. 16

LENGTH: 492 words


Agriculture is a small part of the United States economy, but last year it was
the best part.

The output of the agriculture sector grew 16.4 percent after inflation last
year, the fastest rise for the sector since at least 1998 and far faster than
any other part of the economy. The United States gross domestic product grew
just 1.8 percent, while the second-fastest-growing sector, the information
industry, rose 3.2 percent.

On June 11, the government released its estimates of state economic growth in
2013. North Dakota led the pack with a growth rate of 9.7 percent. Alaska was
the only state whose economy declined, shrinking by 2.1 percent, largely because
of falling oil production.

The economy of the District of Columbia also declined, but that was because of
cuts in government spending.

North Dakota benefited from its rising production of shale oil, but it was also
helped by the fact that its agriculture sector amounts to 12.9 percent of the
state's economy, more than that of any other state except South Dakota.

By contrast, agriculture accounted for just 1.6 percent of United States overall
output in 2013. But that was the largest share in recent years, up from a recent
low of 0.9 percent in 2006. The agriculture sector includes forestry, fishing
and hunting as well as farming, but farming is much larger than the other
categories.

Last year, the government changed the way it calculated G.D.P. figures,
including counting research and development spending as investments rather than
as consumption. It revised historic figures only back to 1997, so earlier years'
output and growth figures for agriculture are not comparable.

Mitch Morehart,  an economist with the Agriculture Department, said the strong
growth in agriculture reflected a recovery in production for some crops after a
drought in 2012, as well as strong production and rising prices for livestock.

This year, he said, it appeared that agriculture was not doing nearly as well.

Over all, the economies of the 10 states that are most dependent on agriculture
grew at an average annual rate of 3.4 percent in 2013, while the 10 states that
are least dependent on the farm economy grew at an average rate of 1.3 percent.

California is by far the largest agricultural producer, accounting for $46.7
billion, or 17 percent of the total national agricultural output of $269.1
billion. But the state is so large that agriculture makes up only 2.1 percent of
its output, less than 16 other states. Iowa, which ranks second in dollar value,
at $16.1 billion, depends on agriculture for almost 10 percent of its total
economic output.

The 2013 surge in agriculture ended a string of three years in which that sector
did not do as well as the overall United States economy. But since 1998,
agriculture outperformed the rest of the economy in nine of the 15 years.

During that stretch, agriculture grew at an annual rate of 4 percent, double the
2 percent average for the national economy.

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                              91 of 998 DOCUMENTS

                                The Toronto Star

              January 27, 1996, Saturday, SATURDAY SECOND EDITION

Canada, U.S. almost eye-to-eye on spuds Dispute has roots in potato crop failure
in Maine

BYLINE: CP

SECTION: BUSINESS; Pg. E8

LENGTH: 342 words

DATELINE: OTTAWA


   OTTAWA (CP) - Canadian agriculture officials are claiming some progress after
day-long meetings with their American counterparts at a potato summit here
yesterday.

While border checks will continue on Canadian spuds entering the United States,
there are signs the protectionist measures may soon be dropped, said a senior
trade official with the agriculture department.

"All we can report is that we have a much better idea of where both countries
stand," said Mike Gifford, the department's acting assistant deputy minister for
marketing.

"We've sorted out - cleared the air - on a number of issues."

The dispute has its roots in last year's potato crop failure in Maine. U.S.
producers were upset when potato growers in New Brunswick and Prince Edward
Island moved to take advantage of the market shortage.

The U.S. Department of Agriculture responded by stepping up inspection of
Canadian potatoes and rejecting truckloads of Canadian spuds.

Two weeks ago, Agriculture Minister Ralph Goodale countered with a strategy of
his own. He added more Canadian inspectors of U.S. spuds to ensure the Americans
were being fair in their treatment of Canadian exports.

"We have every confidence in the quality of Canadian potatoes," Goodale said at
the time.

The minister said he's encouraged because the number of border crossings with
checks has dropped to just one - between Woodstock, N.B. and Houlton, Me. - from
four or five.

"We don't know if they'll continue now. If they terminate their guys, we'll
terminate ours."

An aide said Goodale had no comment on yesterday's talks.

The United States exports more potatoes and horticultural products to Canada
than it imports. In 1994, Canada shipped 179,000 tonnes of table potatoes to the
United States while importing 253,000 tonnes of U.S. spuds.

Gifford said talks between the two countries will likely continue next week by
telephone.

He said a number of other topics, including trade in sugar, grain and a new U.S.
farm bill, will also continue to be discussed.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                  Copyright 1996 Toronto Star Newspapers, Ltd.


                              92 of 998 DOCUMENTS

                      The Financial Post (Toronto, Canada)

                   May 21, 1993, Friday, DAILY: WEST EDITION

Canada said to be cheating

BYLINE: Kelly McParland

SECTION: SECTION 1, NEWS; Pg. 6

LENGTH: 302 words

DATELINE: Washington, DC


A group of 25 congressmen has accused Canada of cheating on wheat exports and
urged the Department of Agriculture to retaliate.

In a toughly worded letter to Secretary of Agriculture Mike Espey, the group
urged subsidies be used to help U.S. grain exports compete.

It attacked the Canadian Wheat Board and accused Canada of ''hypocritically''
masquerading as a free trader.

The letter comes at a time when the administration is under pressure to widen
use of the Export Enhancement Program, which allows use of subsidies to help
U.S. grain compete in export markets.

The group is led by Tim Johnson, Democrat of South Dakota, who is chairman of
the House subcommittee of general farm commodities. It includes 14 Democrats and
11 Republicans. They are upset at Canadian inroads into foreign markets,
particularly Mexico. Canada's share of Mexico's wheat market has grown to 66%,
the letter says, while the U.S. share has fallen to 14% from 75%.

''Over the last seven years, as the Department of Agriculture has used
(subsidies) against the European Community to counter its unfair trading
policies, similarly damaging policies emanating from Canada went unchecked,'' it
says. ''As a result, U.S. wheat producers lost significant export market share
to Canada.''

The Canadian Wheat Board, it says, ''routinely . . . undercuts U.S. and world
wheat prices to make inroads into traditional U.S. markets.''

A Canadian Embassy official rejected the charges and said it's not Canada that
is responsible for forcing down wheat prices around the world, but the European
Community and the U.S. ''We are often caught in the middle of these things.''

He said use of subsidies against Canadian wheat ''would be in direct violation
of their obligations under the free trade agreement.''

                             January 9, 2017 Monday

Commend Mississippi Commissioner of Agriculture and Commerce for appointment to
President's Agriculture Advisory Committee.

LENGTH: 782  words

DATELINE: New York



 Jackson: Mississippi Legislature has issued the following Status of House Bill:




   MISSISSIPPI LEGISLATURE



 2017 Regular Session



 To: Rules



 By: Senator(s) Burton

 Senate Concurrent Resolution 502

 (As Adopted by Senate)



 A CONCURRENT RESOLUTION COMMENDING AND CONGRATULATING MISSISSIPPI'S
COMMISSIONER OF AGRICULTURE AND COMMERCE CINDY HYDE-SMITH UPON HER APPOINTMENT
AS CO-CHAIRMAN OF THE AGRICULTURE ADVISORY COMMITTEE TO PRESIDENT-ELECT DONALD
TRUMP AND HER SELECTION BY GOVERNING MAGAZINE AS A NATIONAL TOP 25 FEMALE
LEADER.





      WHEREAS, Mississippi Commissioner of Agriculture and Commerce Cindy
Hyde-Smith of Brookhaven, Mississippi, has been named as Co-Chairman of the
Agriculture Advisory Committee for the Donald Trump Presidential Campaign; and



      WHEREAS, President-elect Donald Trump unveiled a list of Agricultural
Advisers on November 14, 2016, with strong ties to the agriculture industry.
The committee is charged with advising the President-elect on issues important
to the American farmer, agribusinesses and rural America.  The 64-person
committee includes the Chairmen of both the United States Senate and House
Agriculture Committees, former United States Secretaries of Agriculture, current
and former governors, including former Texas Governor Rick Perry, as well as
business executives including Forrest Lucas, CEO of Lucas Oil; and



      WHEREAS, "The members of my Agricultural Advisory Committee represent the
best that America can offer to help serve agricultural communities," President
Trump said; and



      WHEREAS, on November 16, 2016, Mississippi Agriculture Commissioner Cindy
Hyde-Smith was selected a "Top 25 Female Leaders" by Governing Magazine.  She
attended a national awards event with other Top Female Leaders from other
states, bringing extensive recognition to our state; and



      WHEREAS, Commissioner Hyde-Smith, who raises beef cattle, was elected to
the Mississippi State Senate in 1999, where she served three terms.  During her
tenure as Senator, she served as Chairman of the Agriculture Committee for two
of those terms.  In 2011, she made history by becoming the first woman ever
elected as Mississippi's Commissioner of Agriculture and Commerce and was
re-elected for a second term in 2015; and



      WHEREAS, known as a passionate advocate for agriculture, Hyde-Smith has
been recognized by the Mississippi Farm Bureau Federation and numerous other
organizations for her outstanding leadership in agriculture, especially for her
efforts to protect property rights of private landowners.  She was recently
selected to lead the Southern United States Trade Association as its upcoming
President beginning in 2017.  In August 2016, she received the distinguished
honor of being named to The Governing Institute's Women in Leadership Class as
one of the nation's top 25 women in politics.  At the invitation of the United
States Department of Agriculture, Hyde-Smith participated in a Trade Mission to
China in September 2016, where she met with foreign agriculture dignitaries and
agribusinesses in efforts to increase agricultural trade opportunities; and



      WHEREAS, "I am so honored to have been chosen to serve in this capacity,"
Hyde-Smith said.  "This provides a great opportunity for Mississippi's
agriculture industry, our state's largest industry, to have a voice on issues
that impact our farmers, ranchers and agribusinesses daily, but even more
importantly, playing a role in shaping agricultural policy at the national level
gives me confidence that the voice of the American farmer is heard; and



      WHEREAS, it is with great pride that we recognize a Mississippi citizen
and former State Senator who has become a powerful role model for young women
and girls who admire her integrity, her tenacity and for whom she blazed a trail
as the first female Commissioner of Agriculture in Mississippi:



      NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT RESOLVED BY THE SENATE OF THE STATE OF MISSISSIPPI,
THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES CONCURRING THEREIN, That we do hereby commend and
congratulate Mississippi's Commissioner of Agriculture and Commerce Cindy
Hyde-Smith upon her appointment as Co-Chairman of the Agriculture Advisory
Committee to President-elect Donald Trump and her selection by Governing
Magazine as a national "Top 25 Female Leader," and extend to Commissioner Cindy
Hyde-Smith our best wishes as she represents Mississippi in this important
capacity.



      BE IT FURTHER RESOLVED, That this resolution be presented to Commissioner
Hyde-Smith and made available to the Capitol Press Corps

                          The Globe and Mail (Canada)

                             March 24, 1987 Tuesday

Farm subsidies   in Japan found   world's highest

BYLINE: REUT

LENGTH: 349 words

DATELINE: Washington DC


Reuter WASHINGTON
  Japan has the highest agriculture subsidies in the world and dairy
farmers benefit more than any other commodity producers, a controversial
study of farm subsidies shows.

The study was carried out by the Paris-based Organization for Economic
Co-operation and Development . It has not been released by the OECD
because of objections from some countries, but results were provided to
Reuter by officials of several countries on condition they not be
identified.

In the study, the OECD calculates the level of farm subsidies for the
years 1979-81, using a new measure called the producer subsidy equivalent,
or the amount of aid to farmers expressed as a percentage of the value of
their products.

The study has generated controversy because some countries with high
subsidy levels prefer not to highlight that fact, officials familiar with
the study said. Domestic farm support programs are seen by many analysts
as a major cause of the current problems in world agriculture.

For dairy products, the PSE for Japan was 83.3 per cent, the European
Community 68.8 per cent and the United States 48.2 per cent.

For wheat, Japan averaged 95.8 per cent, the EC 28.1 per cent and the
United States 17.2 per cent. Japan's rice PSE was 68.8 per cent, compared
with 13.6 per cent for the EC and 5.4 per cent for the United States.

The OECD calculated farm subsidies for other industrial countries, such
as Canada, Australia and New Zealand, but in most cases the results were
much lower than for the United States, the EC and Japan, the sources said.

The U.S. Agriculture Department's Economic Research Service recently
published a study of farm subsidies in an attempt to verify the OECD
results and update them to 1982-84.

In some cases, the results were substantially different from the
OECD's, in part because farm policies had changed markedly by 1982-84 from
the OECD base period of 1979-81, U.S. officials said.

Officials of several countries have been asked to contribute data to
the OECD so that the study can be updated to 1985 subsidy levels, a much
more relevant measure of the current world farm situation.

                               The New York Times

              December 17, 1981, Thursday, Late City Final Edition

E.E.C. Farm Policy Faulted;
E.E.C. Farm Policy Faulted

BYLINE: AP

SECTION: Section D; Page 16, Column 2; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 244 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16


Agriculture Secretary John R. Block said today that it was as a result of the
European Economic Community's farm-subsidy policy that the United States
government will have to make payments of $400 million to wheat farmers this
year.

Mr. Block also assured the Foreign Agriculture Policy Subcommittee of the
Senate's Agriculture, Nutrition and Forestry Committee that the situation in
Poland would not result in a trade embargo involving only United States
agricultural products.

''The agriculture community can rest easily, to the extent that we are not going
to be the sacrifical lamb; we're not going to be singled out,'' he said.

In reporting to the subcommittee on his recent trade talks with European
leaders, Mr. Block said the high subsidies provided farmers in European nations
had led to a doubling of European grain for export.

He said 7 million metric tons of extra wheat put on the global market had sent
the world price down by 50 cents a bushel, forcing it below the level that
requires Federal income-protection payments to American farmers.

''Although we'd asked them to do something,'' Mr. Block told the subcommittee,
''almost nothing has been done. There's been no progress.''

In fact, Mr. Block said, the trade talks last weekend left him with the
impression that the Common Market's attitude on subsidization of exports is one
of continuing the subsidies.

                                US Official News

                            January 30, 2017 Monday

Errol Woman Convicted Of Making False Statements To The U.S. Department Of
Agriculture

LENGTH: 327  words

DATELINE: New York



 Washington: Office for the United States Attorneys, District of New Hampshire
has issued the following news release:



   United States Attorney Emily Gray Rice announced that on January 26, 2017, a
jury found Suzanne Brown, age 51, of Errol, New Hampshire, guilty of twelve
counts of making a material false statement to a federal agency in violation of
Title 18, United States Code, Section 1001(a)(2), after a five-day trial in the
United States District Court for the District of New Hampshire.









             The trial began on Wednesday, January 18, 2017 and ended with the
jury's verdict on January 26, 2017. The guilty verdict means that the jury found
that on twelve occasions Brown made false statements and representations in
documents submitted to the United States Department of Agriculture ("USDA").
Brown, acting as Executive Director of the New Hampshire Institute of
Agriculture and Forestry ("NHIAF"), submitted documents certifying that NHIAF
had paid thousands of dollars to employees for services rendered. These
statements were made in order to draw down funds from a USDA Rural Business
Enterprise Grant. The statements were false because NHIAF had not paid the
employees for their services. In nine of the twelve submissions to the USDA,
Brown created fraudulent invoices purportedly prepared by one or more employees
outlining the services they performed and money they were owed.







             Brown's sentencing before United States District Court Chief Judge
Joseph N. LaPlante is scheduled for May 11, 2017.







             The case was investigated by the United States Department of
Agriculture Office of Inspector General and was prosecuted by Assistant United
States Attorneys Seth Aframe and Georgiana Konesky. Former Assistant United
States Attorney Nick Abramson previously was involved in the matter.

                      Chico Enterprise-Record (California)

                             August 11, 2013 Sunday

Farm Briefs for Aug. 11

BYLINE: Chico Enterprise-Record

SECTION: LOCAL

LENGTH: 406 words


United States reclaims No. 1 spot as biggest ag exporter in world

BUFFALO, N.Y.   U.S. agricultural exports will hit an all-time record of $139.5
billion in fiscal year 2013, making the United States the No. 1 agricultural
exporter in the world.

An economist at the United States Department of Agriculture's Foreign
Agricultural Service presented this as well as other assessments of global
agriculture at the 15th annual Agriculture Media Summit Newsmaker Session held
August 3-7. The United States was the top agricultural exporter in 2011 but
slipped to second in 2012, behind Brazil, due to the drought last year, which
affected many crops.

Rice Leadership Development Program accepting applications

STUTTGART, Ark.   The Rice Foundation is accepting applications for the 2014
Rice Leadership Development Program. Rice producers or industry-related
professionals between the ages of 25 and 45 are eligible to apply for the
program by Oct. 5.

The Rice Leadership Development Program provides an understanding of the rice
industry, with an emphasis on personal development and communication skills.
During a two-year period, class members attend four one-week sessions designed
to strengthen leadership skills through studies of all aspects of the rice
industry.

The class of seven is chosen by a committee of agribusiness leaders.

For additional information:http://www.usarice.com and click on the 2014 Rice
Leadership icon in the lower right of the page.

U-pick 'em in Tehama County; variety of produce is available

Growers in Tehama County have created a directory of places where consumers can
pick their own produce.

Eight growers are taking part, and the list is available at Wolf, Sale and
Haynes orchards, or by calling 524-2223 or email:info@tehamatogether.org .

The directory lists produce by season and provides directions and contact
information for each farm. Call ahead to check on availability, price and hours.
A Spanish version of the listing is also available.

Mushroom production rises in California, spurring U.S. to record

California farmers have been increasing their mushroom production. In addition
to familiar button mushrooms, more exotic species are also being raised on the
state's farms. Mushroom sales in the U.S. reached a record of more than $1
billion last year. California ranks as the second-largest producer of mushrooms,
growing about 20 percent of the nation's crop, the California Farm Bureau
Federation reported.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


            Copyright 2013 MediaNews Group, Inc. and ANG Newspapers
                              All Rights Reserved


                              100 of 998 DOCUMENTS

                               The New York Times

                August 12, 1988, Friday, Late City Final Edition

Drought Cutting U.S. Grain Crop 31% This Year

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER, Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section A; Page 1, Column 5; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1106 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 11


In the gloomiest assessment yet of damage wrought by the drought, the
Agriculture Department said today that the United States grain harvest this year
would be 31 percent lower than last year. The harvest, estimated at 192 million
metric tons, would be the smallest since 1970.

Hours before the estimate was issued, President Reagan signed legislation to
provide billions of dollars to farmers and agricultural businesses in nearly
2,200 counties that have lost crops and income because of the drought.

Both developments underscore that the 1988 drought is becoming the costliest in
American history. The drought is also having important political implications in
the United States and in Europe, where efforts to change expensive farm policies
have lost steam.

Corn and Soybean Figures

The Agriculture Department estimated that this nation's corn harvest might total
no more than 4.47 billion bushels, down 2.6 billion bushels from last year. The
soybean harvest is not expected to exceed 1.47 billion bushels, down 430
million. The estimates reflect field conditions of Aug. 1 and are sharply lower
than those made on July 1.

In today's commodity trading, before the report was released, grain and soybean
prices fell. Analysts predicted that prices of corn and soybeans would rise
sharply Friday. ''The drought has caused a disastrous reduction in crops,'' said
Ewen M. Wilson, Assistant Secretary of Agriculture for Economics. ''Across the
northern Great Plains the crop has failed. On a national basis, it's a massive
reduction.''

The loss in corn, at current prices, amounts to nearly $7.4 billion. The loss in
soybeans totals $3.7 billion. Billions of dollars have also been lost in spring
wheat, vegetables, fruits, hay, livestock and other farm products, the
Agriculture Department and private economists have estimated.

Mr. Wilson said the latest estimates could significantly raise the cost of the
legislation that became law today. The Agriculture Department estimated last
week that the package, which will pay farmers up to $100,000 for crop losses
caused by the drought, would cost $3.9 billion. The Congressional Budget Office
estimated today that it would be closer to $5.1 billion.

The legislation is to be paid for with funds that have been saved in the
Government's farm income support programs. Higher commodity prices have reduced
payments. The savings, according to the latest Agriculture Department estimate,
could total $6 billion next year.

Political Impact Abroad

But in cutting surpluses, raising commodity prices and reducing the budget for
income support programs, the drought is having political effects. The United
States and the European Community have been meeting for months in Geneva to
develop a program to alter policies of subsidizing crop exports and farm
incomes. President Reagan has often spoken forcefully about his desire for a
worldwide end to farm subsidies.

The budget for farm programs soared to $26 billion in 1986, and similar costs
have been borne by European nations as well. Mr. Wilson said today, though, that
the drought was dissipating pressure in the United States and in Europe to
change farm policies.

Daniel G. Amstutz, chief farm negotiator for the United States trade
representative, said, ''The drought has taken away the short-term incentives to
negotiate seriously.''

The severity of the drought is also complicating efforts by the Agriculture
Department and the Congressional Budget Office to develop accurate estimates of
the cost of the relief legislation signed today. At a ceremony in the Rose
Garden at the White House, President Reagan called the legislation ''the largest
disaster relief measure in history.''

Legislation Cost Unclear

How much the Government will spend on the legislation - which will pay any
farmer who suffers crop losses of at least 35 percent, up to $100,000 - remains
a mystery, with estimates seeming to change weekly.

''In all,'' Mr. Reagan said, ''hundreds of thousands of farmers and ranchers
will benefit. The bill expresses a distinctly American tradition, that of
lending a helping hand when misfortune strikes.''

The Agriculture Department's crop report is the clearest sign yet that the cost
of the relief legislation and the amount of losses will be enormous.

Oat production this year is expected to total 206 million bushels, 45 percent
less than in 1987. Barley production is down 45 percent. Spring wheat, which
last year amounted to 542.3 million bushels, has been cut in half. According to
a recent analysis by North Dakota State University, the drought will reduce that
state's economic activity by more than $3 billion in the next year.

Meteorologists Pessimistic

Agriculture Department officials said today that the losses could increase
significantly if the drought continues to be severe, and meteorologists said
there was every indication that hot, dry weather in the northern Great Plains,
the West and the Midwest would persist until the end of August.

The rains that moistened soil in the Midwest and the Great Plains two weeks ago
have all but disappeared, and more than 40 percent of the United States is
considered in severe or extreme drought, according to a report issued yesterday
by the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration. The Agriculture
Department said the drought had damaged crops in 43 states. It has also taken a
steep toll in Canada.

The increasing losses caused the Agriculture Department to raise its 1989
estimate of food price inflation. Economists said rising commodity prices would
increase consumer food prices by 3 to 5 percent next year.

Tight Grain Stocks Ahead

Other analysts predicted that food price inflation could be even higher. The
reason, they said, is that world stocks of grain next year are going to be the
tightest since the mid-1970's, contributing to further escalation in the prices
of wheat, corn, rice, oats, barley and other crops. The Agriculture Department
said grain stocks in storage next year would total 288 million metric tons, a
63-day supply.

The estimates of sharply tighter grain supplies reflect damage not only in the
United States but also in Canada, China, Argentina and several other countries.
The estimates of world grain stocks essentially confirm those made by private
analysts last week and are worrisome to Agriculture Department officials.

Mr. Wilson said that although stocks are adequate to supply all of the needs in
the United States and around the world, a second year of drought would be
catastrophic.

The Agriculture Department will issue its next crop estimate Sept. 12.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: Graph showing the U.S. corn production from '60-'88 (source:
Agriculture Dept.) (NYT); photo of Sen. Patrick J. Leahy taking a picture of
Pres. Reagan (pg. D5) (NYT/Jose R. Lopez)

                   Copyright 1988 The New York Times Company


                              101 of 998 DOCUMENTS

                      The Financial Post (Toronto, Canada)

                     August 12, 1988, Friday, DAILY EDITION

U.S. report predicts drought will slash grain harvests

BYLINE: By Frances Phillips and Reuters

SECTION: SECTION 1, NEWS; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 694 words

DATELINE: Washington,DC


  The U.S. Agriculture Department predicted yesterday that the drought,
considered the worst in more than half a century, would lead to dramatic
declines in this year's harvests of corn, soybeans and wheat.

The department's monthly crop report estimated U.S. farmers would produce 4.48
billion bushels of corn this year, 37% less than last year.

The soybean crop was forecast at 1.47 billion bushels, 23% smaller than the 1987
harvest and projected to be the lowest since 1976.

The survey estimated that a smaller spring wheat crop would result in total U.S.
wheat production of 1.82 billion bushels this year, a 13% decline from last
year.

However, poor U.S. harvests will not increase exports for the Canadian Wheat
Board. Prairie farm crops have also been decimated by drought.

''Our (marketing) experience will be totally dominated by our available
supplies,'' John Morriss, CWB information director, said in a telephone
interview yesterday.

''There is no question of us filling in because we don't have the product
either.''

In the 1986-87 crop year the U.S. and Canada accounted for 33% and 24%
respectively of world wheat and flour exports.''

EARLY ESTIMATES

The dramatic decline in U.S. grains production is unlikely to push commodity
prices much beyond current levels. ''Those numbers are already factored into the
market,'' Morriss said.

The extent of drought damage in Canada will become clearer when the United Grain
Growers farmers' co-operative issues its Prairie crop report later this month.

Economists are also anxiously awaiting Statistics Canada's crop report due Sept.
2.

Early estimates suggest Prairie wheat farmers will harvest 36% less wheat than
projected and Ontario farms will harvest 22% to 40% less.

Ontario corn producers are looking at yields 30% below expectations.

Meanwhile, the Rome-based United Nations Food & Agriculture Organization said
yesterday in its August outlook the drought will cause world cereal production
to fall for the second consecutive year and cut global stocks to the bare
minimum.

BILL SIGNED

World cereal production is forecast to fall to 1.77 billion metric tons this
year, 13 million below last month's forecast and 24 million below last year's
output.

Earlier yesterday, U.S. President Ronald Reagan signed into law a
multi-billion-dollar bill to reduce losses suffered by drought-stricken farmers
and ranchers.

The USDA crop report, based on conditions as of Aug. 1, was the first
comprehensive field survey of the season and the most accurate assessment to
date of the drought.

It confirmed the conviction shared by most analysts that since July, widespread
hot, dry weather has continued to take its toll on major U.S. crops and cut into
projected world grain and soybean stocks.

The prospect of small grain and soybean harvests has important implications for
inflation and trade flows.

Rising grain and soybean prices have pushed up U.S. food prices and contributed
to a modest acceleration in overall inflation.

In a survey released earlier this week by the widely watched Blue Chip Economic
Indicators of Sedona, Ariz., 58 economists mentioned higher U.S. food prices as
the most important factor that could cause inflation to flare up next year.

In the latest report, based on a survey of more than 60,000 farms, the USDA
trimmed its July estimates of corn, soybeans and spring wheat production.

The department estimated the 1988 corn crop would drop to 4.48 billion bushels
from 7.06 billion bushels last year. The July report pegged the 1988 corn crop
at 5.20 billion bushels.

U.S. corn stocks at Aug. 30, 1989, were projected to be 1.58 billion bushels,
down from 4.35 billion bushels estimated to be stockpiled at the end of this
month.

The 1988 soybean crop was estimated at 1.47 billion bushels, compared with 1.90
billion bushels in 1987. Last month 1988 soybean production was forecast at 1.65
billion bushels.

Total U.S. wheat production was forecast at 1.82 billion bushels, 284 million
bushels below 1987. In July, the USDA estimated 1988 all-wheat production at 1.8
billion bushels.




LOAD-DATE: December 9, 1997

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC:  Photo: U.S. farms have been hard-hit by worst dry spell in 50 years

TYPE: NEWS

                       Copyright 1988 Financial Post Ltd.


                              102 of 998 DOCUMENTS

                      The Financial Post (Toronto, Canada)

                      May 31, 1991, Friday, DAILY EDITION

HEAVY RAINFALL STYMIES U.S. FARMERS: Wet, wet, wet' in Mississippi

BYLINE: Bob Burgdorfer Reuter

SECTION: SECTION 2, INVESTMENT AND FINANCE; Pg. 17

LENGTH: 618 words

DATELINE: Chicago, IL


Spring planting has been a long, arduous process in the U.S. this year as heavy
rain has kept farmers out of fields from Louisana to Minnesota, but analysts say
it is unlikely to send food and textile prices higher.

''We are wet, wet, wet,'' says Kenneth Hood of Gunnison, Miss., who has 2,000
acres of cotton left to plant. Normally, planting of his 6,500 acres would be
done by now. ''Our soils are so wet we can't get into the fields,'' he says.

The villain is a high-pressure system over the eastern seaboard, which has
forced warm air from the Gulf of Mexico to move north along the Mississippi
River, spawning a parade of thunderstorms, says Peter Leavitt of Weather
Services Corp. in Bedford, Mass.

The late planting shortens the crop's growing season and will hurt production.
Normally, Hood's cotton averages 750 pounds to 800 pounds of cotton an acre.
This year, he will be lucky to get 700 pounds.

Surveys by the U.S. Agriculture Department surveys show 40% of Mississippi
cotton was planted as of Sunday, against 95% by this time last year and a
five-year average of 92%.

''For the most part we are three weeks behind on cotton planting, and about a
month late on rice,'' says Joe Love, the county agriculture extension agent for
Bolivar County, Miss. ''Planting this late means we need a warm October to allow
the (cotton) crop to mature.''

Love says history shows there is a ''seven-in-10 chance'' for a warm October.

The moisture has damaged the soft red winter wheat crops in the South and
southern Midwest. Low yields have been reported in Louisiana and disease is
evident in southern Illinois, crop experts say.

In Iowa, the leading corn-producing state, 70% of the corn has been planted.
That's behind last year's 87% pace and the average of 95%.

Corn and soybean prices have not risen in reaction to the delayed planting, but
cotton prices have shot higher in recent months.

Unless crop losses are severe, consumers are unlikely to be pinched by higher
food and textile prices.

Steve Freed, analyst with Dean Witter Reynolds, says prices paid to farmers
account for less than 5% of retail food prices, with the bulk of food costs
linked to labor and transportation.

''It should not have a price impact at all,'' Freed says. He notes that
bountiful crops in the last few years resulted in lower prices paid to the
farmers, but consumer prices went higher.

Clear skies early this week allowed Bob Sienknecht of Dunkerton, Iowa to plant
corn, but more rain late Wednesday forced him to stop.

''I have never planted this late,'' he says of his corn. ''I don't have any
soybeans planted and I'm usually done by now.''

Sienknecht says his farm in east central Iowa has received seven inches of rain
in past two weeks, and some neighbors have reported 10 inches in that time.

Because soils are wet, crops will establish shallow roots. Sienknecht says that
can be a problem if the summer is dry, because the crops will be unable to use
moisture deep in the soil.


Weather Services Corp.'s Leavitt says that may be a real concern this year. The
high-pressure ridge on the east coast has the potential of bringing long periods
of hot, dry weather to the Midwest.

''We feel that the developing ridge will be a persistent feature,'' he says.
''As it grows and moves westward it should bring warm temperatures to the
Midwest and drier weather.''

He estimated a 50-50 chance that the system could produce crop-threatening hot,
dry weather in the Midwest.

''It very well could be severe to crops,'' Leavitt says. He says if his
forecasts are accurate, then hot, dry weather might occur soon and last four to
six weeks.




LOAD-DATE: November 6, 1997

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: NEWS

                       Copyright 1991 Financial Post Ltd.


                              103 of 998 DOCUMENTS


                          The Globe and Mail (Canada)

                           December 21, 2000 Thursday

Canada considering spud war with U.S.

BYLINE: HEATHER SCOFFIELD AND KEVIN COX, With a report from Canadian Press

SECTION: NATIONAL NEWS; Pg. A4

LENGTH: 314 words

DATELINE: OTTAWA and HALIFAX


Canada is preparing to retaliate against the United States, government officials
said yesterday after the U.S. administration said it will continue its ban on
PEI potatoes even though they acknowledge that they have no scientific basis for
doing so.

Scientists from both countries have spent the past couple of days sharing data
and samples of potatoes from Prince Edward Island. And both sides agree that
there is no basis on which to continue the two-month-long ban on the province's
main export for fear of spreading the potato wart disease, Agriculture Canada
officials said yesterday.

But the United States has not opened up its border and U.S. Agriculture
Secretary Dan Glickman has told Agriculture Minister Lyle Vanclief that it will
not even consider doing so until tomorrow.

"It's very evident that this is politically driven. This is totally unacceptable
to us," said Sylvie Millette-Leduc, spokeswoman for Mr. Vanclief.

She said the Canadian government is consulting with the PEI potato industry to
see how it feels about Canada blocking potato imports from the United States, in
retaliation for the American ban.

PEI Agriculture Minister Mitch Murphy is urging the federal government to use
the same kind of sanctions against United States potatoes that have been imposed
on PEI shippers. He said in an interview this week that shipments of potatoes
from areas of the United States where diseases such as golden nematode are
present should not be allowed into Canada if PEI spuds can't be shipped south
due to the potato wart.

Mr. Murphy said that more than 10,000 soil tests have been done that show the
potato wart fungus has been limited to a 0.4 hectare plot of land.

" . . . Now we've asked the federal government to put similar restrictions on
the U.S.," he said.

However, federal government insiders fear that a retaliation could spark a
broader trade war.

LOAD-DATE: September 20, 2006

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


 Copyright 2000 The Globe and Mail, a division of CTVglobemedia Publishing Inc.
                              All Rights Reserved


                              104 of 998 DOCUMENTS

                      The Financial Post (Toronto, Canada)

                    February 8, 1991, Friday, DAILY EDITION

U.S. BANS P.E.I.'S SPUDS, PROVINCE SET TO FIGHT BACK: Sudden move endangers most
of the island's business

BYLINE: Barbara MacAndrew with files from Jill Vardy

SECTION: SECTION 1, NEWS; Pg. 3

LENGTH: 445 words

DATELINE: Charlottetown, P.E.I.


A ban on P.E.I. potatoes entering the U.S. could jeopardize up to 70% of the
province's $100-million industry, Agriculture Minister Keith Milligan said
yesterday.

The U.S. Department of Agriculture placed the ban on potato imports because of a
virus affecting some P.E.I. seed potatoes.

As of Wednesday, seed potatoes from P.E.I. and New Brunswick were not being
allowed into the U.S.

Milligan said the provincial government will mount a strong campaign to get the
U.S. ban dropped.

Kevin McKenna, of McKenna Brothers, a potato producer from Cardigan, P.E.I, said
the U.S. ruling was ''straight harrassment.''

He said the decision, which could cost his company several million dollars in
lost sales, was a move by the state of Maine to limit the number of Canadian
potatoes entering the U.S.

McKenna estimates that 50%-70% of the island's potato crop goes to the U.S. each
year.

McKenna said several of his company's trucks are heading back to Cardigan, in
the eastern section of the province, after being turned away at the border.

In Ottawa, Diane Milne, director of plant protection with Agriculture Canada,
said the ban was imposed without any consultation with the Canadian government.

Milne said U.S. officials have agreed to meet their Canadian counterparts next
week to work on a plan to get the border reopened for the potatoes. ''We are
hoping this issue can be resolved quickly,'' she said.

The ban also covers table stock from the Maritimes, Ontario and Quebec.

Paul Farrell, Agriculture Canada's regional director of inspection and plant
health, said some seed potatoes from other parts of Canada are also affected.

Those potatoes are only being allowed into the U.S. if they are accompanied by
certificates stating they are not the progeny of recent P.E.I. stock.

Maine halted all imports of P.E.I. seed potatoes last month because the virus
can damage tobacco crops.

The wider ban comes at a time when potato producers in the two provinces are
putting together seed orders. Farrell said the ban effectively kills those
orders.

He said precautions are also being taken in Canada, but the actions are not as
severe. Seed potatoes are being tested, and only ones that show no sign of the
virus will be planted.

The virus has affected 17 farms since it was discovered on the island about a
month ago.

When Maine announced its ban, the head of the P.E.I. Potato Board accused the
Americans of employing the virus as an excuse to block Canadian imports.

''We're a competitor with Maine and I don't think they really want us to be
selling to U.S. producers,'' George Webster said then.

TYPE: NEWS

                        The Camp Verde Journal (Arizona)

  This content, including derivations, may not be stored or distributed in any
  manner, disseminated, published, broadcast, rewritten or reproduced without
                      express, written consent from STPNS

                                August 12, 2015

Agricultural-related jobs on the rise

BYLINE: The Camp Verde Journal staff

LENGTH: 497  words


U.S. Department of Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack recently announced a new
report showing tremendous demand for recent college graduates with a degree in
agricultural programs with an estimated 57,900 high-skilled job openings
annually in the food, agriculture, renewable natural resources and environment
fields in the United States.

According to an employment outlook report released by USDA's National Institute
of Food and Agriculture and Purdue University, there is an average of 35,400 new
U.S. graduates with a bachelor's degree or higher in agriculture related fields
-- 22,500 short of the jobs available annually.

"There is incredible opportunity for highly-skilled jobs in agriculture,"
Vilsack said. "Those receiving degrees in agricultural fields can expect to have
ample career opportunities. Not only will those who study agriculture be likely
to get well-paying jobs upon graduation, they will also have the satisfaction of
working in a field that addresses some of the world's most pressing challenges.
These jobs will only become more important as we continue to develop solutions
to feed more than 9 billion people by 2050."

The report projects almost half of the job opportunities will be in management
and business. Another 27 percent will be in science, technology, engineering and
mathematics areas. Jobs in food and biomaterials production will make up 15
percent, and 12 percent of the openings will be in education, communication, and
governmental services.

The report also shows that women make up more than half of the food, agriculture
, renewable natural resources and environment higher education graduates in the
United States.

Other highlights of the report include:

While most employers prefer to hire graduates of food, agriculture, renewable
natural resources and environment programs, graduates from these programs only
fill about 60 percent of the expected annual openings. Even as enrollments in
these programs increase and the job market becomes somewhat more competitive,
good employment opportunities for the next five years are expected.

Growth in job opportunities will be uneven. Employers in some areas will
struggle to find enough graduates to fill jobs. In a few areas, employers will
find an oversupply of job seekers.

Expect to see a strong employment market for e-commerce managers and marketing
agents, ecosystem managers, agricultural science and business educators, crop
advisors and pest control specialists.

Job opportunities in STEM areas are expected to grow. Expect the strongest job
market for plant scientists, food scientists, sustainable biomaterials
specialists, water resources scientists and engineers, precision agriculture
specialists and veterinarians.

The report, Employment Opportunities for College Graduates in Food, Agriculture,
Renewable Natural Resources, and the Environment, United States, 2015-2020, is
available on the purdue.edu website. The report was produced by Purdue
University with grant support from NIFA.

LOAD-DATE: June 23, 2016

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

DOCUMENT-TYPE: Agriculture

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

JOURNAL-CODE: CPV

                                August 12, 2015

Agricultural-related jobs on rise

BYLINE: Cottonwood Journal Extra staff

LENGTH: 497  words


U.S. Department of Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack recently announced a new
report showing tremendous demand for recent college graduates with a degree in
agricultural programs with an estimated 57,900 high-skilled job openings
annually in the food, agriculture, renewable natural resources and environment

According to an employment outlook report released by USDA's National Institute
of Food and Agriculture and Purdue University, there is an average of 35,400 new
U.S. graduates with a bachelor's degree or higher in agriculture related fields
-- 22,500 short of the jobs available annually.

"There is incredible opportunity for highly-skilled jobs in agriculture,"
Vilsack said. "Those receiving degrees in agricultural fields can expect to have
ample career opportunities. Not only will those who study agriculture be likely
to get well-paying jobs upon graduation, they will also have the satisfaction of
working in a field that addresses some of the world's most pressing challenges.
These jobs will only become more important as we continue to develop solutions
to feed more than 9 billion people by 2050."

The report projects almost half of the job opportunities will be in management
and business.

Another 27 percent will be in science, technology, engineering and mathematics
areas. Jobs in food and biomaterials production will make up 15 percent, and 12
percent of the openings will be in education, communication, and governmental
services.

The report also shows that women make up more than half of the food, agriculture
, renewable natural resources and environment higher education graduates in the
United States.

Other highlights of the report include:

While most employers prefer to hire graduates of food, agriculture, renewable
natural resources and environment programs, graduates from these programs only
fill about 60 percent of the expected annual openings. Even as enrollments in
these programs increase and the job market becomes somewhat more competitive,

Expect to see a strong employment market for e-commerce managers and marketing

market for plant scientists, food scientists, sustainable biomaterials
specialists, water resources scientists and engineers, precision agriculture
specialists and veterinarians.

The report, Employment Opportunities for College Graduates in Food, Agriculture,
Renewable Natural Resources, and the Environment, United States, 2015-2020, is
available on the purdue.edu website.

The report was produced by Purdue University with grant support from NIFA.

                      The Financial Post (Toronto, Canada)

                      May 30, 1989, Tuesday, DAILY EDITION

U.S. likely to raise wheat planting limit

BYLINE: Reuters

SECTION: SECTION 3, THE MARKETS; Pg. 20

LENGTH: 211 words

DATELINE: Washington,DC


  Worried by dwindling supplies, the U.S. government is widely expected to let
farmers plant more wheat for harvest next year to top up reserves and fend off a
food price surge.

The decision would reassure foreign countries like the Soviet Union, China and
Egypt who rely on U.S. wheat to help feed their people and pay lower prices when
wheat bins are brimming.

But wheat trade competitors say the U.S. would be unfairly boosting exports and
throwing a wrench into world trade talks.

American wheat farmers who benefit from federal price supports and income
subsidies must keep idle a certain share of their land as part of a national
effort to keep the country from ending up with too much or little wheat.

The Agriculture Department must announce by June 1 how much land farmers will
have to set aside for the 1990 wheat crop. For the current crop, farmers had to
keep idle one out of every 10 acres.

''Farmers will probably be allowed to plant more acres this year,'' agriculture
consultant Randy Russell said.

While drought has eased its grip on much of the farm belt, it has persisted in
the heart of winter wheat country, severely damaging production prospects and
driving up wheat prices to their highest levels in years.




LOAD-DATE: December 9, 1997

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: NEWS

                              108 of 998 DOCUMENTS

                       St. Louis Post-Dispatch (Missouri)

                 May 10, 2001, Thursday, FIVE STAR LIFT EDITION

LAW & ORDER

SECTION: METRO, Pg. C2

LENGTH: 538 words



ST. LOUIS

Check of welfare rolls nets 99 fugitive arrests

By cross-checking welfare rolls and active felony arrest warrants filed with St.
Louis area police departments, officers have been able to arrest 99 fugitive
felons, the U.S. Department of Agriculture Office of Inspector General announced
recently.

The nationwide crackdown, known as "Operation Talon," has netted nearly 7,500
arrests. Investigators were able to identify 600 food stamp recipients who were
also fugitive felons. Arrest teams made up of local police officers, deputies,
and federal agents searched St. Louis area streets for them. Among those who
made it to the list were some wanted for homicide, kidnapping and
counterfeiting.

The sweep was made possible by the Welfare Reform Act of 1996. Officers
participating locally included those from the St. Louis Metropolitan Police
Department Fugitive Apprehension Strike Team, St. Louis County police, U.S.
Marshals Service, and sheriff's deputies from St. Charles and Jefferson
Counties. The Missouri Department of Social Services provided the information.

Fire heavily damages two houses

Four people, including two children, escaped injury Wednesday night when a fire
damaged their home in the 4400 block of Penrose Street, near North Newstead
Avenue.

Witnesses said a resident of the neighborhood saw smoke coming from the rear of
a vacant two-story house at 4412 Penrose and alerted the owner of the house next
door, Charles Hennings, who was at a nearby store.

Hennings rushed home and alerted his family, including two grandchildren. They
escaped without injury, fire officials said.

Firefighters said the fire started about 8:40 p.m. in the abandoned house and
quickly spread to the house owned by Hennings.

Firefighters arrived about five minutes later and got the fire under control but
not before both structures were heavily damaged.

Fire Capt. Robert Hennicke said the cause of the fire was under investigation.

CENTREVILLE

Charge is filed in beating

Terry Devin Brooks, 28, of Centreville, was charged Wednesday with aggravated
battery in the beating last week of an autistic man who was left with two broken
legs, a broken arm and head injuries.

The victim, Reginald Brooks, was beaten with an iron pipe near the intersection
of Bond Avenue and 42nd Street. His mother said her son had made some friendly
remarks to a woman who took offense.

BETHALTO

3 are suspected of sexual assault

A 13-year-old girl from Bethalto was sexually assaulted by two men and a
juvenile male last week, Bethalto Police Chief William Hays said Wednesday.

Police presented their case against the three suspects to prosecutors on
Tuesday, Hays said. No charges have been filed. Prosecutors plan to take the
case to a grand jury, possibly as soon as next week.

Hays said officers were called to the scene about 9 p.m. May 1. But he would not
disclose further information. "I won't take a chance about jeopardizing this
case. I won't do that, for the sake of the little girl alone."

Hays said the case was the first sexual assault reported in Bethalto this year.
Madison County State's Attorney William R. Haine declined to comment.

LANGUAGE: English

TYPE: Law & Order Column

                               The New York Times

                  July 14, 1992, Tuesday, Late Edition - Final

COMPANY NEWS;
U.S. PROPOSES DEREGULATING CALGENE'S BIOTECH TOMATO

SECTION: Section D; Page 4; Column 1; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 119 words


Calgene Inc.'s genetically engineered tomato, the Flavr Savr, may soon be free
of restrictions as a result of the United States Department of Agriculture's
proposal yesterday to deregulate the product. The tomato, which is designed to
have an extended shelf life of two to three weeks, has been under Agriculture
Department regulation for the last three years.

Calgene, a biotechnology company focused on producing genetically engineered
agricultural products, is the first company to petition the Government to grow
gene-altered plants commercially without Agriculture Department permits. The
company, based in Davis, Calif., plans to begin marketing the Flavr Savr tomato
to consumers next year.

                               The New York Times

              February 19, 1985, Tuesday, Late City Final Edition

Trade Talks Seen Likely

BYLINE: Reuters

SECTION: Section D; Page 2, Column 5; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 146 words

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, Feb. 18


Increasing United States calls for reduction of European trade barriers, mainly
in agriculture, will likely lead to discussion of the issue by leaders of major
industrial nations at the Bonn economic summit conference in May, Daniel
Amstutz, United States Under Secretary of Agriculture, said today.

He told journalists that United States sentiment for a new round of multilateral
trade negotiations is growing.

If Europeans show no willingness to dismantle barriers by the summer, political
pressure could become difficult to resist, he said, even though the Reagan
Administration is against protectionist measures,

Mr. Amstutz said, ''One of the alternatives that could come from lack of
movement ahead on trade negotiations is that unhappiness in our country is at
such a high level that Congress is very likely to pass legislation of a
protectionist nature.''

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                   Copyright 1985 The New York Times Company


                              111 of 998 DOCUMENTS


                                 Ontario Farmer

                              June 7, 2016 Tuesday
                                 Final Edition

Off to a difficult start; Getting into agriculture can be challenging,
especially for young and new farmers who increasingly face barriers

BYLINE: Steph Smith, Ontario Farmer

SECTION: SUCCESSION; Pg. A20

LENGTH: 731  words


In Canada and the United States "renewal in agriculture" is becoming a growing
concern.

While the population is aging, so are farming communities. According to
FarmStart, an Ontario-based initiative, there are several factors preventing new
and young farmers from getting into the agricultural sector, such as structural,
economic and practical challenges.

In Canada alone, 50 per cent of farm assets will be transferred within the next
10 years as the population continues to age, with 85 per cent of retiring
farmers not ot having a successor to take over r where they left off.

"We need a federal-provincial farm renewal and new farmer initiative that will
provide funding for programs and services that support a new generation of
farmers and successful farm succession," said Christie Young, executive director
of FarmStart. "New entrant farmers include second career farmers, both young and
old, new Canadians, and young people from farms and non-farm backgrounds."

Young said the initiative she would like to see would be similar to the United
States Department of Agriculture's (USDA) Beginning Farmer and Rancher
Development Program.

According to the USDA, its program began with the 2008 Food, Conservation and
Energy Act appropriating "$75 million to

develop and offer education, training, outreach and mentoring programs to
enhance the sustainability of the next generation of farmers." In addition, the
2014 Agriculture Act "provided an additional $20 million per year for 2014
through 2018 " to create further enhancement in the form of grants to academic
institutions, producer groups and community organizations, that provide programs
for new farmers.

Agriculture is on a decline in Canada and the US, with less than 30,000 young
farmers in Canada, and a projected eight per cent decrease in the number of
farmers and ranchers in the US between 2008 and 2018. This means fewer and fewer
farmers will be producing food in the future.

A survey conducted by the National Farmers Union in 2015 concluded the
challenges new and young farmers most commonly face, in addition to access to
educational and informational resources, includes access to land and equipment.

According to a farm report released in 2014 by Remax, farmland in parts of
Canada had either held steady or increased rapidly.

For example, in British Columbia's

Fraser Valley, highs of $63,000 per acre were seen, while in Saskatchewan and
Manitoba prices were seen as low as $950 per acre.

In Ontario, land prices were leveling off, but north of the Greater Toronto
Area, prices hovered around $54,000 per acre for developers looking to purchase
farmland, more than double what farmers were normally paying in other parts of
the province.

Though each area of land provides its own set of advantages and disadvantages,
these inflated land prices are part of what makes purchasing land and farms
difficult for new farmers, especially where a large down payment is required.

"We need to encourage and support [the] new generation of farmers ... and we
need to intervene to support what could be a transformative and dynamic
generational transition," says the FarmStart website. "New farmers bring skills,
connections and passion that can lead to innovation and renewal for our food
economies, agricultural landscape and rural communities."

Some suggestions FarmStart has made regarding support include:

Creating farm policies that support smaller farms: many new/young farmers start
out on small farms.

Creatingaretirement plan for retiring farmers: this would make room for new
farmers by implementing a retirement plan that enables existing farmers to leave
and pass on the farm.

Long-term land tenure and stewardship: investments need to be made over the
long-term in order to care for the land, soil and ecosystems. Local communities
require secure land tenure for those who grow food, and access on affordable
terms for those who want to begin.

"Farm renewal must become a priority if we hope to have vibrant local food
economies, healthy, locally produced food and the long-term stewardship of our
productive soils and valuable ecosystems," says the FarmStart website. "These
will be impossible without a diversifying and growing number of local, viable
and resilient farmers."

For more information, visit www.farmstart.ca.To see the full Remax 2014 Farm
Report, visit download.remax.ca/PR/Farm Report/Final Report. pdf#20389715

LOAD-DATE: July 9, 2016

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

with less than 30,000 young farmers in Canada, and a projected eight per cent
decrease in the number of farmers and ranchers in the US between 2008 and 2018.
This means fewer and fewer farmers will be producing food in the future.;

                                US Official News

                           November 21, 2015 Saturday

Washington: CBP Agriculture Specialists Discover Prohibited Meat Concealed in
Baby Formula Containers at Vancouver Preclearance

LENGTH: 360 words

DATELINE: Lahore



 Washington: U.S. Customs and Border Protection has issued the following news
release:



 U.S. Customs and Border Protection agriculture specialists seized prohibited
meat products concealed inside baby formula and milk powder containers at the
Vancouver Preclearance Facility on Nov. 13.





 CBP agriculture specialists discovered pork belly meat and pork sausages in
baby formula and milk powder containers.The traveler was referred for an
agriculture inspection and provided a negative verbal declaration when asked if
they had any agriculture products in their luggage. Upon inspection, CBP
agriculture specialists discovered 4.4 pounds of pork belly meat and pork
sausages inside baby formula and milk powder containers.



 &ldquo;This interception demonstrates the benefits of Preclearance locations
where CBP can stop threats or prohibited items prior to reaching the United
States,&rdquo; said Kurry Pastilong, assistant director, Office of Field
Operations, Preclearance. &ldquo;The fact that these items were found even
though they were concealed in an unusual product speaks to the level of detail
and vigilance CBP agriculture specialists display on a daily basis to accomplish
the CBP mission.&rdquo;



 CBP agriculture specialists discovered pork belly meat and pork sausages in
baby formula and milk powder containers.The traveler, who was originating from
China with a final destination of San Francisco, was assessed a penalty and the
prohibited meat was seized and destroyed under CBP supervision.



 CBP Preclearance operations allow for advance inspection of passengers and
special coordination with law enforcement upon arrival in the United States.
Through preclearance, the same immigration, customs, and agriculture inspections
of international air passengers performed on arrival in the United States are
instead completed before departure at foreign airports.  Currently, preclearance
operations exist at 15 foreign airports in six different countries, benefitting
air passengers, airports, and air carriers, in the United States and abroad.

                              113 of 998 DOCUMENTS


                                 Ontario Farmer

                            January 17, 2017 Tuesday
                                 Final Edition

MacAulay pitches importance of Canada-U.S. ag trade; $50 billion a year crosses
the border in a relative balance and should be protected

BYLINE: Alex Binkley, Ontario Farmer

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. A12

LENGTH: 593  words


A mid rumblings of U.S. action against Canadian agrifood imports, Agriculture
Minister Lawrence MacAulay recently spelled out the importance of cross border
trade to American agriculture leaders.

In a speech in Baton Rouge, Louisiana to the annual meeting of the State
Agriculture Leaders and the Legislative Agriculture Chairs Summit, MacAulay said
in 2016, "$50 billion in agriculture and food products crossed our borders. We
are each other's largest trading partner in agriculture and food. Our
agricultural trade is balanced, meaning we export just about as much as we
import."

Nine million American jobs "depend on trade and investment with Canada," he
pointed out. "North America is a marketplace of close to half a billion
consumers for our home-grown North American farm and food products.

The Canada-United States trading partnership has been great for our economies.
And it continues to be.

"We have no closer friend, partner, and ally than the United States," MacAulay
stated.

The integration of the North American agrifood systems "makes us more
competitive here in North America and around the world," he added. "And it gives
our consumers access to great food products 365 days a year.

"The fact is, Canada and the United States make great food together. Whether
it's beer or burgers or bacon, chances are you'll find a little bit of Canada
and the United States in every bite."

The minister also reminded the audience that "the United States exports more
agricultural products to Canada than it exports to China. Over half of the
states in the Union count Canada as their No. 1 agricultural export market. The
bottom line is this: if we grow our trade, we grow our economies -together. The
sector creates jobs and we put more money in the pockets of farmers."

MacAulay noted that adding Mexico to the equation made North America even more
important to the global economy. "We export close to a quarter of a trillion
dollars in agri-food and seafood products to the world."

In addition to protests against supply managed products and a new challenge
under consideration over wheat, there is concern that the U.S. Country of Origin
Labelling for meat shipments could be revived even though the World Trade
Organization ruled it violated international trade laws.

MacAulay said a better course of action is continuing to work together to become
more competitive around the world. "That helps all of us. It helps our farmers,
and it helps our people and our economies.

"The long-standing partnership between the United States and Canada continues to
grow and we look forward to building on this partnership with the new
administration.

"Our two countries are also working hard to streamline trade in agriculture and
food through regulatory cooperation," he said. "Through such co-operation, we
can reduce red tape, streamline our regulations and cut costs.

"Our common goal is to keep our agriculture sectors strong and competitive," he
noted. "That's the best way to ensure farmers have a prosperous future. Today,
the need for collaboration is even more important given the growing competition
we face beyond our common shores."

At the same time, the two countries need to work to address their differences,
he said. "The world's demand for food is growing. There's no question that our
nations can respond to that demand, with our high-quality food and world-class
producers. I want our producers to have access to those markets.

"And we must continue to show the world the benefits that trade brings for job
creation and economic growth not only for agriculture,

LOAD-DATE: January 17, 2017
