                              167 of 998 DOCUMENTS

                              Journal of Commerce

                          February 24, 1988, Wednesday

EXPORT BRIEFS

BYLINE: Wire and Staff Reports

SECTION: EXPORTS, Pg. 5A

LENGTH: 153 words

DATELINE:  WASHINGTON


Chinese Buy Wheat

From US Exporters

Exporters have sold China an additional 405,000 metric tons of U.S. wheat at
subsidized prices for delivery in the 1987-88 marketing year, the Agriculture
Department reported.

William L. Davis, acting general sales manager for the department's Foreign
Agricultural Service, said the sales were part of an authorized 1.2 million
metric tons of wheat announced Feb. 5 under the Export Enhancement Program.

15 Projects to Receive

Export Assistance

WASHINGTON - The U.S. Department of Agriculture has announced that 15 projects,
including those sponsored by the American Soybean Association, the U.S. Feed
Grains Council and the U.S. Meat Export Federation, would receive the $ 30
million remaining in the targeted export assistance program for fiscal 1988.

The program is aimed at promoting U.S. farm products overseas to combat unfair
foreign trade practices.

                              168 of 998 DOCUMENTS

                              Journal of Commerce

                             May 11, 1999, Tuesday

Man sentenced in illegal fruit case

BYLINE: BY JACK LUCENTINI

SECTION: COMMODITIES/CHEMICALS/ENERGY; Pg. 11A

LENGTH: 369 words

DATELINE: NEW YORK


A man linked to a conspiracy to import and distribute a banned fruit in the
United States pleaded guilty and was sentenced to five months each in prison and
in home confinement, officials said.

Tu Chin Lin pleaded guilty in Federal Court in Manhattan Thursday to making a
false statement to a government agency, officials said.

The plea came after a nearly five-year federal investigation of imports of a
sweet, white fruit called longans, primarily grown in Asia.

The Agriculture Department's Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service
prohibits the fruit in the United States because it often carries harmful fruit
flies and other exotic pests. It also can carry plant diseases that are foreign
to the United States, agricultural officials said.

USDA officials launched the investigation in the summer of 1994 when its
investigative and enforcement services unit discovered the fruit being sold in
several stores in Manhattan's Chinatown, according to an agency statement.

The ensuing probe, officials said, extended from Florida to Canada. It revealed
that Mr. Lin was conspiring with others to buy the fruit in Canada, and smuggle
it into the United States by falsifying invoices and customs documents.

Mr. Lin, who could not be reached for comment, will serve five months in prison
and five months in home confinement, followed by two years of supervised
release, said U.S. Department of Agriculture officials.

Officials gave no further details as to the age, nationality or background of
the accused importer. They also did not specify whether the longans were being
sold in places other than Chinatown.

""Importing prohibited fruits into our country puts our billion-dollar citrus
industry at risk,'' said Michael V. Dunn, undersecretary for the Agriculture
Department's marketing and regulatory programs. ""Violators of our import
regulations will pay the price for doing so.''

The U.S. attorney in Manhattan indicted Mr. Lin in October, Agriculture
Department officials said.

No other indictments are expected, said Dawn Schu, an Agriculture Department
spokeswoman, but she added that authorities are investigating a few other people
in Canada in connection with the case.

LOAD-DATE: May 11, 1999

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                    Copyright 1999 Journal of Commerce, Inc.

                              May 9, 2013 Thursday

US reaffirms support to small farmers in Pakistan

LENGTH: 603 words

DATELINE: ISLAMABAD


ISLAMABAD, May 9 -- US Ambassador Richard Olson Wednesday reaffirmed the United
States government's long-term support to farming communities in Pakistan.

Since 1950s, the United States has been working to support agriculture in
Pakistan, introducing the kinnow orange and helping to double Pakistan's wheat
production. Today, we continue our support because improving crop yields,
protecting food sources from disease and boosting milk production will increase
farmers' incomes, improve nutrition, and ultimately strengthen Pakistan's
prosperity, he said.

During his visit to the National Agriculture Research Centre (NARC), which was
established with the help of the US government in the 1980s, Olson said, "United
States is committed to helping the small farmers of Pakistan through projects
that enhance agricultural productivity."

He lauded the progress made by the Wheat Productivity Enhancement Project
(WPEP), a United States Department of Agriculture (USDA) programme managed in
collaboration with national and provincial research partners that has
successfully introduced the UG 99-resistant wheat variety, 'NARC 2011'.

The introduction of this wheat variety helps protect Pakistan against UG 99, a
virulent wheat disease in the region that poses a threat to Pakistan's farming
community.

Wheat accounts for approximately 60 percent of the daily caloric intake of the
average Pakistani, so our joint efforts to combat this disease are critical,
said Olson.

The WPEP team and Pakistani scientists at national and provincial research
stations have made great progress in the fight against wheat rusts and I
encourage you to continue your work together, he maintained.

In addition to support for the WPEP, the United States has provided new
harvesting machines and funded improvements to research stations around Pakistan
to develop more disease-resistant wheat varieties. The United States also
provides specialised training opportunities to Pakistani wheat scientists.

The United States and Pakistan have similar agricultural systems and for that
reason we have been effective partners in agriculture for more than half a
century, working together to improve agricultural yields and to combat disease,
said Olson.

Since the 1950s US and Pakistani scientists have collaborated to increase wheat
production. At that time Dr Manzoor Bajwa and Dr Norman Borlaug worked together
to develop 'Mexi-Pak,' the wheat variety that started the Green Revolution in
Pakistan and helped to double Pakistan's wheat production between 1965 and 1970.

Today, our long-term commitment to Pakistan's agriculture sector is sustained
through projects that help fight animal and crop diseases, increase vegetable
and mango production, improve irrigation, increase dairy production and support
wheat research, he added.

Improvement Centre said without disease-resistant varieties of wheat, such as
the one being harvested at NARC, experts estimated Pakistan's annual wheat
harvest could be reduced by as much as 50 percent if and when UG 99 arrives.

Agriculture contributes 21 percent to the GDP of Pakistan and employs 45 percent
of the labor force, making it one of the most significant economic drivers of
Pakistan, Dr Imtiaz said.

Pakistani farmers grew about 24 million tonnes of wheat on eight million
hectares last year, accounting for about 2.4 percent of the GDP. Published by HT

                                The Toronto Star

                    April 6, 1988, Wednesday, FINAL EDITION

U.S. wheat sales to Soviets at peak

BYLINE: (CP)

SECTION: BUSINESS TODAY; Pg. H4

LENGTH: 279 words

DATELINE: WINNIPEG, Manitoba


   WINNIPEG (CP) - The United States is on its way to exporting record amounts
of wheat to the Soviet Union, Canada's largest grain customer, a Canadian Wheat
Board spokesman said yesterday.

Since April, 1987, the United States has sold the Soviets 11.8 million tonnes of
wheat at bargain basement prices blamed for keeping down the market value of
Canadian wheat.

"I think you could safely say it will be the largest," said John Morriss of the
wheat board.

"These are really heavy purchases. A lot of people don't realize how high it's
gone.

Since last spring the United States has wooed the Soviets with generous offers
under the Export Enhancement Program, a kind of deal-sweetening arrangement that
entices importers to buy American wheat.

The two countries grabbed headlines last May after the Soviet Union agreed to
buy 4 million tonnes of American wheat at $80 (U.S.) a tonne, a price about $40
below the world price. The U.S. treasury swallowed the difference.

Since then the Americans have been selling the Soviets a steady supply of cheap
wheat. The subsidy dropped to about $20 a tonne because crop troubles around the
globe have sent world prices inching up.

On Monday the United States Department of Agriculture made another million tonne
offer to the Russians at prices that weren't revealed.

In total that's already more than the 9.4 million tonnes of American wheat
shipped to the U.S.S.R. in the 1972-73 crop year.

That deal, where the Soviets secretly negotiated with a handful of American
grain companies, was dubbed the "Great Grain Robbery" because it sparked fears
of a grain shortage in the United States.

LOAD-DATE: May 13, 1999

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                              172 of 998 DOCUMENTS

                               The New York Times

                December 30, 1991, Monday, Late Edition - Final

U.S. Says Number of Farm Owners Is at Lowest Level in the Century

BYLINE: AP

SECTION: Section A; Page 12; Column 5; National Desk

LENGTH: 412 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 29


A Government study has found that the number of people who own farmland in this
country has dwindled to the lowest level in the century.

The report, by the United States Agriculture Department, said nearly half of all
American farmland is in the hands of 124,000 owners.

Most of the owners are individuals or couples who own the farms jointly, it
said; corporations hold about 15 percent of the land.

Farm Size Tripled

And while total farm acreage was slightly more than in 1900, the average farm
size has more than tripled, the study found.

The number of owners of farmland is of great interest to the Government because
as it drops, decisions about the use of land and about improvements,
conservation and other significant areas will be made by an increasingly smaller
proportion of the overall population, the report said.

The report, by the Agriculture Department's Economic Research Service, also
found that many current owners have little direct role in operating the nation's
2 million farms and ranches.

"That means that decisions concerning larger operations are being made by fewer
farmers and fewer, but proportionately more, non-farmer landowners," the report
said. "These changes in the structure of farmland ownership parallel the
enlargement of farm size, reduction in farm numbers and reduction in farm
employment."

The report said a 1989 survey of farm ownership estimated that by the end of
1988, 2.95 million people owned 833 million acres of private farmland.  But
roughly 124,000 owners held 47 percent of the land. And owners whose holdings
consisted of fewer than 50 acres accounted for 30 percent of the total but held
only 2 percent of the acreage.

Outlook for Some Trends

The report also said that of the total number of owners, 44 percent were
non-operators who held 41 percent of the land.

"The century began with more operators than owners, and is ending with
substantially more owners than operators," the study said. "Compared with owners
and operators, the amount of land in farms, which peaked in the 1950's, has
changed little."

The study said current trends should leave 1.7 million farms and 2.7 million
owners by the year 2000, as against 5.7 million farms and 4.9 million
agricultural landowners in 1900.

"The shrinking number of farms and landowners will contribute further to the
decline of rural communities and may affect markets for commodities and factors
of production," the report said.

LOAD-DATE: December 30, 1991

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                              173 of 998 DOCUMENTS

                         Telegraph Herald (Dubuque, IA)

                           November 23, 2004 Tuesday

Farmers on alert for soybean rust; Experts say growers should be prepared, but
not panicked, now that the fungus has come to the U.S.

BYLINE: JOHN EVERLY

SECTION: Tristate; Pg. a3

LENGTH: 406 words


A troublesome fungus that has threatened soybean crops around the world has
entered the United States.

The U.S. Department of Agriculture recently confirmed soybean rust in
Mississippi, Florida, Alabama and Georgia. The disease was first found in the
United States in two research plots near Baton Rouge, La.

Growers should be prepared, but not panicked, experts said.

Web Link

More information about soybean rust is available at www.soybeanrust.info.

Iowa Secretary of Agriculture Patty Judge said the Environmental Protection
Agency approved six fungicides on an emergency basis for combating Asian Soybean
Rust in Iowa for the 2005 growing season. The emergency designation includes
Wisconsin and Illinois.

"Even though Iowa does not have Asian Soybean Rust, we must be prepared and plan
to combat the disease before it makes its way across the United States," Judge
said.

The disease can cause extensive damage to plants and can travel quickly through
infected areas depending on environmental conditions. The disease poses no human
health risk, but can reduce soybean yield substantially, said Greg Tylka, Iowa
State plant pathologist.

"There's no guarantee it'll be here next year, or when it will arrive (in
Iowa)," Tylka said. "If it comes to Iowa late in the season, it might not be
worth treating."

The fungus probably will not overwinter in Iowa or other northern
soybean-growing areas, Tylka said. In order to infect Iowa fields, the spores
must be carried from the southern United States by winds every year.

"Soybean farmers in the United States will adjust and take the necessary steps
to manage the disease," said United Soybean Board Chairman Criss Davis, a
soybean farmer from Shullsburg, Wis.

The bottom line, Tylka said, is treatment will not be cheap, at $20 to $25 per
acre.

Faced with that expensive alternative, growers could opt to substitute corn or
another crop on their soybean acres next year, said University of Illinois
economist Darrel Good.

"It is difficult to anticipate the direction and magnitude of soybean acreage
change in 2005," he said. "Producers will have to carefully evaluate all of the
decision factors, including production costs and relative yields and prices of
alternative crops."

Meanwhile, lawmakers included $800,000 in a 2005 federal bill for soybean rust
research by Iowa State University and the Agriculture Research Service in
Beltsville, Md.

LOAD-DATE: November 23, 2004

                              174 of 998 DOCUMENTS

                      The Financial Post (Toronto, Canada)

                     October 6, 1989, Friday, DAILY EDITION

Positive outlook for harvest cuts soybean prices

BYLINE: Farm Market News

SECTION: SECTION 3, THE MARKETS; Pg. 20, FARM COMMODITIES

LENGTH: 352 words

DATELINE: Winnipeg,Man.


  Favorable harvest conditions continued to depress Chicago Board of Trade
soybean futures yesterday.

Speculation that soybean production will be higher than the markets had been
expecting also helped undermine values.

CBOT soybean prices settled US2 1/2 cents-to-US5 cents-a-bushel lower with the
January contract - the most active - closing at US$5.84 3/4, down US4 cents.

From the opening of the market, CBOT soybean prices were put on the defensive by
a production estimate by private crop forecaster Sparks Commodities. It now sees
soybean production in the U.S. coming in at 1.921 billion bushels. In September,
the U.S. Agriculture Department estimated the crop at 1.889 billion bushels.

Investors also speculate that soybean yields are coming in better than expected
in many areas, which in turn supported the contention that crop size could rise
considerably from the Agriculture Department's most recent estimate.

The U.S. National Weather Service in its latest forecast calls for clear
conditions over the next six to 10 days in the U.S. Midwest, which prompted
speculation that harvest progress would be good and depressed CBOT soybean
futures.

Corn futures at the CBOT closed unchanged to US4 1/4 cents higher. December was
the most actively traded contract, ending US4 1/4 cents-a-bushel higher at
US$2.43 1/4.

Corn values had been pressured early in the session yesterday by the ongoing
harvest. However, by midday, those prices turned higher, reflecting trade rumors
that the Soviet Union may have purchased up to seven million metric tons of U.S.
corn during the past few days. The U.S. Agriculture Department has confirmed a
total of 2.2 million metric tons of corn to the Soviet Union so far.

CBOT wheat futures ended US1 1/2 cents higher to US2 1/2 cents lower. The
December contract finished US1 1/2 cents higher at US$4.10 3/4.

Buying in the recent contracts yesterday reflected news that Egypt will bid for
more subsidized wheat soon. Country movement to the elevator system has also
been slow, which also lifted CBOT wheat values slightly.

                              175 of 998 DOCUMENTS

                      The Financial Post (Toronto, Canada)

                      May 18, 1990, Friday, DAILY EDITION

House scrap over farm subsidies

BYLINE: Reuters

SECTION: SECTION 1, NEWS; Pg. 9

LENGTH: 417 words

DATELINE: Washington,DC


  Farmers across the U.S. looking forward to continued government subsidies for
their crops have encountered opposition from city-bound congressmen.

The congressmen plan to fight passage of a new farm bill when it reaches the
floor of the House of Representatives this summer. The lawmakers accuse their
farm-district counterparts of writing programs that benefit their rural
constituents at the expense of the mass of U.S. consumers and taxpayers.

''In the past, the Agriculture Committee got up and then everyone voted for the
bill,'' said Rep. Barney Frank. (D-Mass.) ''Those days are over.''

Under the 1985 Farm Act, farmers receive ''deficiency payments,'' or subsidies,
on certain crops if they keep some acreage fallow to comply with conservation
plans or reduce output. The payments are made directly to farmers, supporting
prices by cutting supply.

The House Agriculture Committee's 1990 farm bill will establish U.S. agriculture
policy for the next five years. Members of both the House and Senate agriculture
committees, which are working on bill proposals, appear determined to support
farmers' incomes at current levels.

But the 20-strong coalition of opposing congressmen says farm programs cost too
much, damage the environment, impede international trade and only help big-scale
farmers - not the small family farms they are supposed to preserve.

Stephen Dewhurst, the Agriculture Department's budget officer, said that by
October almost US$80 billion will have been spent on the programs over the past
five years. If they continue at this year's pace, US$56 billion would be paid
out over the next five years.

The Bush administration, struggling with a budget deficit and teetering close to
new taxes, wants that cut to US$48 billion.

But the farmers have strong support.

House Agriculture Committee Chairman Kika de la Garza dismissed the coalition of
opposing congressmen as a bunch of city folk who do not understand agriculture
and do not appreciate the way past farm policies have produced a bounty of
low-cost food.

One proposal from the urban congressmen, which would have a far-reaching effect
on farm policy, is to set a US$100,000 annual-income ceiling, or means test, for
those qualifying for subsidies.

The urban group argues that farmers making more than most U.S. citizens should
not receive payments. By gearing payments to acreage and production, they say,
the government spends most of its money on bigger farms.




LOAD-DATE: November 6, 1997

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: NEWS

                       Copyright 1990 Financial Post Ltd.

                           Oakes Times (North Dakota)

  This content, including derivations, may not be stored or distributed in any
  manner, disseminated, published, broadcast, rewritten or reproduced without
                      express, written consent from STPNS

                                 March 26, 2015

Family Farms are the Focus of New Agriculture Census Data

BYLINE: The Oakes Times staff

LENGTH: 501  words


97 Percent of All U.S. Farms are Family-Owned, USDA Reports

WASHINGTON - The U.S. Department of Agriculture's National Agricultural
Statistics Service (NASS) reports that family-owned farms remain the backbone of
the agriculture industry. The latest data come from the Census of Agriculture
farm typology report and help shine light on the question, "What is a family
farm?"

"As we wrap up mining the 6 million data points from the latest Census of
Agriculture, we used typology to further explore the demographics of who is
farming and ranching today," said NASS Statistics Division Director Hubert
Hamer. "What we found is that family-owned businesses, while very diverse, are
at the core of the U.S. agriculture industry. In fact, 97 percent of all U.S.
farms are family-owned."

The 2012 Census of Agriculture Farm Typology report is a special data series
that primarily focuses on the "family farm." By definition, a family farm is any
farm where the majority of the business is owned by the operator and individuals
related to the operator, including through blood, marriage, or adoption. Key
highlights from the report include the following five facts about family farms
in the United States:

5 Facts to Know about Family Farms

1. Food equals family - 97 percent of the 2.1 million farms in the United States
are family-owned operations.

'2. Small business matters - 88% of all U.S. farms are small family farms.

3. Local connections come in small packages - 58 percent of all direct farm
sales to consumers come from small family farms.

4. Big business matters too - 64 percent of all vegetable sales and 66 percent
of all dairy sales come from the 3 percent of farms that are large or very large
family farms.

5. Farming provides new beginnings - 18 percent of principal operators on family
farms in the U.S. started within the last 10 years.

"Whether small or large - on the East Coast, West Coast, or the Midwest - family
farms produce food and fiber for people all across the U.S. and the world," said
Hamer. "It's due in part to information such as this from the Census of
Agriculture that we can help show the uniqueness and importance of U.S.
agriculture to rural communities, families, and the world."

The 2012 Census of Agriculture Farm Typology report classifies all farms into
unique categories based on three criteria: who owns the operation, whether
farming is the principal operator's primary occupation, and gross cash farm cash
income (GCFI). Small family farms have GCFI less than $350,000; midsize family
farms have GCFI from $350,000 to $999,999; and large family farms have GCFI of $
1 million or more. Small farms are further divided based on whether the
principal operator works primarily on or off the farm.

To access all the data products from the Census typology report, including
Highlights, infographics and maps, visit www.agcensus.usda.gov.

To learn more demographic data about women farmers, join a USDA Google+ Hangout
on March 18, 2015 at 2 PM Eastern by visiting www.usda.gov/live.

LOAD-DATE: April 21, 2016

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

DOCUMENT-TYPE: Agriculture

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

JOURNAL-CODE: OAK

                                  China Daily

                           January 28, 2015 Wednesday

US apples to tickle Chinese taste buds

BYLINE: MU CHEN

LENGTH: 476  words


China has agreed to import all varieties of apples from the United States, the
US Department of Agriculture said on Monday.

Ralph Hugus, owner of Hugus Fruit Farm, loads crates of apples onto a trailer in
Rushville, Ohio, the United States. China has agreed to import all varieties of
apples from the United States, the US Department of Agriculture said on Monday.
[Photo/Agencies]

China has agreed to import all varieties of apples from the United States, the
US Department of Agriculture said on Monday.

The green light for the shipments follows an agreement signed by the USDA and
China's General Administration of Quality Supervision, Inspection and Quarantine
in San Francisco, California over the weekend.

"The efforts will result in high quality, fresh US apple varieties being made
available to consumers in China and boost sales for American apple producers,"
said Tom Vilsack, the US secretary of agriculture, in a statement.

US fresh apple exports were valued at more than $1 billion in 2013. The USDA
estimates that the agreement can increase total apple exports by around 10
percent, with a target of shipping $100 million of apples to China every year in
two years.

Previously, China only allowed the Red Delicious and Golden Delicious varieties
to enter the country but suspended orders in August 2012 after repeated
detection of apple pests. The suspension was lifted in October, 2014.

Apple imports from the US surpassed 54,446 metric tons and were valued at $55
million during the 2010-11 marketing years.

The Washington Apple Commission, representing producers in Washington State that
account for 90 percent of all US apple exports, has been advocating for China to
open its doors to the many varieties of apples grown in the state since 1995.

A key reason is that the Red and Golden Delicious now account for less than 40
percent of Washington's overall production, meaning that over 60 percent of its
apple varieties have been barred from the Chinese market.

Wang Miao, marketing director of the commission in China, told China Daily that
a full access to the Chinese market is an important opportunity for Washington's
apple industry to expand exports.

"Although China is the largest global producer of apples, domestic varieties are
very limited with Fuji apples accounting for around 85 percent of all
production," he said. "We, on the other hand, have eight main varieties and more
than 10 'club' (newly cultivated and limited production) varieties ready to be
introduced to the Chinese market."

With quality and variety on offer, Wang said importers will be able to pick the
products that best suit the taste of their customers.

Jiang Wei, senior public relations manager at Wal-Mart China, said that the
retailer directly imports Red Delicious apples from the US and it has been
welcomed by customers for its high quality and competitive prices.

LOAD-DATE: January 28, 2015

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

JOURNAL-CODE: 1493


                    Copyright 2015 China Daily Information.
                Provided by Syndigate Media Inc.(Syndigate.info)
                              All Rights Reserved


                              178 of 998 DOCUMENTS



                          China Daily - Africa Weekly

                                January 28, 2015

US apples to tickle Chinese taste buds

BYLINE: MU CHEN

LENGTH: 476  words


China has agreed to import all varieties of apples from the United States, the
US Department of Agriculture said on Monday.

Ralph Hugus, owner of Hugus Fruit Farm, loads crates of apples onto a trailer in
Rushville, Ohio, the United States. China has agreed to import all varieties of
apples from the United States, the US Department of Agriculture said on Monday.
[Photo/Agencies]

China has agreed to import all varieties of apples from the United States, the
US Department of Agriculture said on Monday.

The green light for the shipments follows an agreement signed by the USDA and
China's General Administration of Quality Supervision, Inspection and Quarantine
in San Francisco, California over the weekend.

"The efforts will result in high quality, fresh US apple varieties being made
available to consumers in China and boost sales for American apple producers,"
said Tom Vilsack, the US secretary of agriculture, in a statement.

US fresh apple exports were valued at more than $1 billion in 2013. The USDA
estimates that the agreement can increase total apple exports by around 10
percent, with a target of shipping $100 million of apples to China every year in
two years.

Previously, China only allowed the Red Delicious and Golden Delicious varieties
to enter the country but suspended orders in August 2012 after repeated
detection of apple pests. The suspension was lifted in October, 2014.

Apple imports from the US surpassed 54,446 metric tons and were valued at $55
million during the 2010-11 marketing years.

The Washington Apple Commission, representing producers in Washington State that
account for 90 percent of all US apple exports, has been advocating for China to
open its doors to the many varieties of apples grown in the state since 1995.

A key reason is that the Red and Golden Delicious now account for less than 40
percent of Washington's overall production, meaning that over 60 percent of its
apple varieties have been barred from the Chinese market.

Wang Miao, marketing director of the commission in China, told China Daily that
a full access to the Chinese market is an important opportunity for Washington's
apple industry to expand exports.

"Although China is the largest global producer of apples, domestic varieties are
very limited with Fuji apples accounting for around 85 percent of all
production," he said. "We, on the other hand, have eight main varieties and more
than 10 'club' (newly cultivated and limited production) varieties ready to be
introduced to the Chinese market."

With quality and variety on offer, Wang said importers will be able to pick the
products that best suit the taste of their customers.

Jiang Wei, senior public relations manager at Wal-Mart China, said that the
retailer directly imports Red Delicious apples from the US and it has been
welcomed by customers for its high quality and competitive prices.

LOAD-DATE: January 28, 2015

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

JOURNAL-CODE: 1497


                    Copyright 2015 China Daily Information.
                Provided by Syndigate Media Inc.(Syndigate.info)
                              All Rights Reserved

                          China Daily - Africa Weekly

                                January 28, 2015

US apples to tickle Chinese taste buds

BYLINE: MU CHEN

LENGTH: 476  words


China has agreed to import all varieties of apples from the United States, the
US Department of Agriculture said on Monday.

Ralph Hugus, owner of Hugus Fruit Farm, loads crates of apples onto a trailer in
Rushville, Ohio, the United States. China has agreed to import all varieties of
apples from the United States, the US Department of Agriculture said on Monday.
[Photo/Agencies]

China has agreed to import all varieties of apples from the United States, the
US Department of Agriculture said on Monday.

The green light for the shipments follows an agreement signed by the USDA and
China's General Administration of Quality Supervision, Inspection and Quarantine
in San Francisco, California over the weekend.

"The efforts will result in high quality, fresh US apple varieties being made

                              180 of 998 DOCUMENTS

                      The Financial Post (Toronto, Canada)

                   November 25, 1991, Monday, WEEKLY EDITION

EC-U.S. crisis played down by GATT chief

BYLINE: William Dullforce Financial Times of London

SECTION: SECTION 1, NEWS; Pg. 6

LENGTH: 362 words

DATELINE: Geneva, Switzerland


Trade officials and negotiators Friday played down the crisis in the Uruguay
Round of trade talks resulting from the failure of the European Community and
the U.S. to resolve their differences about reductions in farm subsidies.

Arthur Dunkel, director general of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade,
did not consider the multilateral negotiating process to be blocked or in
danger, his spokesman said.

The EC and the U.S. were clearly prepared to continue seeking a consensus, the
spokesman added. It was true that negotiators were now faced with the toughest
issues of all, but the fact that EC and U.S. agricultural negotiators had
returned to their capitals reflected their need to seek new instructions to
continue negotiating.

A senior U.S. official said the round was ''still a viable process.'' There were
important stumbling blocks, particularly between the U.S. and the EC in
agriculture, but there were also lots elsewhere.

EC and U.S. officials had earlier acknowledged that Guy Legras, the EC director
general for agriculture, and Richard Crowder, U.S. agriculture undersecretary,
had made no progress in their one-day meeting in settling significant
outstanding differences between them over agriculture.

Tension over the farm issue within the EC camp was reflected Friday at a meeting
of trade policy directors from the 12 capitals, which had been switched from
Brussels to Geneva. The French and Irish insisted that the EC should make no
further concessions on agriculture, while the Germans, British and Dutch called
for the European Commission to be given the flexibility needed to seek
compromises.

The French were particularly critical of working papers on agriculture
circulated on Thursday by Dunkel.

In a broader context, Japan and Canada objected to the ''comprehensive
tarification'' - the conversion into customs duties and subsequent reduction of
all barriers to farm imports - which is a basic point in the Dunkel blueprint.
Japan does not want its ban on rice imports converted into a tariff. The
Canadians argue that their supply management programs would be unworkable
without import quotas.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: NEWS

                       Copyright 1991 Financial Post Ltd.

Donors want resources aligned to local agricultural priorities

BYLINE: MARTIN LUTHER OKETCH -1

LENGTH: 365  words


The United States government has been running a Shs402 billion financial support
programme since 2012

Kampala.
The United International Agency for International Development (Usaid) has said
all donor resources for agriculture projects should be well-aligned with
Uganda's national agricultural priorities as outlined in the Agricultural Sector
Development Strategy and Investment Plan.


In her closing remarks during the launch of the agriculture financial year book
2013/14 last week in Kampala, Ms Jo Lesser-Oltheten, the Office Director
Economic Growth Team Usaid/Uganda, echoed the United States government's
commitment to support initiatives that promote agriculture development in
Uganda.
"... The United States Government is earnestly working with the Ministry of
Agriculture to ensure that donor resources are well-aligned with Uganda's
national agricultural priorities as outlined in the Agricultural Sector
Development Strategy and Investment Plan," she said.
Usaid's contribution to broaden the financial sector includes loan guarantee
facilities with lenders; an agriculture equity fund with investor's Savings and
Credit Co-operatives with borrowers, and technology-based funds knowledge
transfer platforms with innovators.
Ms Oltheten said: "The US government continues to look for new ways to support
financial inclusion and eliminate frontiers for access to financial services."
She revealed to Daily Monitor in an interview that the United States government
through Usaid under 'Feed the Future' initiative is running a Shs402 billion
($150 million) financial support programme which started in 2012 and is ending
2017.

sector investment in three crops namely coffee, maize and beans.

Bucyanayandi, said there is need to increase financial resources by the
government into the sector using new innovative means such as mobile money
services.

                              182 of 998 DOCUMENTS

                      The Atlanta Journal and Constitution

                      July 21, 1995, Friday, ALL EDITIONS

Equestrian events' cancellation raises concerns for Olympics

BYLINE: Karen Rosen; STAFF WRITER

SECTION: SPORTS OLYMPICS, Pg. 2E

LENGTH: 566 words

DATELINE: Denver


The outbreak of an equine disease that caused the cancellation of the equestrian
events at the U.S. Olympic Festival has raised concerns about the 1996 Atlanta
Olympic Games if the disease is not contained.

There are 130 positive cases of vesicular stomatitis in the Southwest, mostly in
New Mexico. Festival officials feared horses that entered Colorado would not be
able to return home because of national and international regulations.

"I would think an outbreak such as this could pose grave threats to the
equestrian events in Atlanta," said Bill Barnes, a shipping agent in New Jersey
who transports horses internationally for the U.S. Equestrian Team. "For the
Games, we certainly don't want to invite horses from abroad and expose them to
various diseases they might not have in their countries."

Vesicular stomatitis is rarely fatal and can also occur in cattle, sheep, llamas
and even humans. It is usually spread through biting insects, but can also be
spread orally, such as when the same "lead" rope is used on different horses.

Barnes applauded the cancellation, saying, "Veterinary officials and other
management showed people their first concern has to be the safety of our
domestic horses."

Kate Jackson, ACOG's competition manager for equestrian events, has been in
contact with the U.S. Department of Agriculture, which is investigating the
disease.

"So far, I can't see it affecting us," said Jackson. "They're really hoping to
contain it."

Jackson said the disease is not a problem for the Atlanta Cup, next month's
event at the Georgia International Horse Park, because there are no horses
entered from the states with positive cases.

"Let's certainly hope this nasty thing doesn't spread over the country, or then
it could be a problem," said Jackson.

Several states, including New Jersey, where the U.S. Equestrian Team is based,
have banned the entry of horses from New Mexico, Arizona or Colorado, or horses
that have visited those states. Georgia was not on the most recent list. The
European Community has also banned horses that have been in any infected state.

The Festival field included one horse from Georgia, ridden by King Hackley of
Greenville.

Olympic competitors are currently training on horses they plan to ride in the
Olympics.

Modern pentathlon, which also includes riding, was not affected at the Festival
because horses in that sport are supplied locally.

TICKET WOES: A year before the Atlanta Olympics, hundreds of thousands of people
are keeping their fingers crossed that they'll get tickets. On the eve of the
Festival, officials are just as fervently wishing they'll sell tickets to the 36
sports in Denver, Colorado Springs and Boulder.

The Festival, which begins today, has sold more than $ 1.5 million worth of
tickets, or about 200,000 seats. The goal is $ 2.4 million. Encouragingly, the
once-sluggish sales have increased to between $ 20,000 and $ 30,000 a day.

The loss of the show jumping and dressage in equestrian was a blow to the
Festival because the sport ranked among the top eight in ticket sales.

CELEBRATION: Opening ceremonies tonight in Denver's Mile High Stadium will
include a salute to the 1996 Atlanta Olympics. Singer Kenny Loggins is the
headliner, and there will also be a fly-by by one or two United Airlines jets, a
speech by Miss America Heather Whitestone and a fireworks show.

LOAD-DATE: August 3, 1995

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: Photo: Ice dancer Shannon Simon adjusts her brother Jason's costume
during practice Thursday. / Associated Press
Chart: U.S. Olympic Festival
-What: A multisport event designed to give Olympic prospects a taste of
the Games on a smaller, U.S.-only scale.
-Where: Denver, Colorado Springs and Boulder.
-When: Today through July 30.
-Who: More than 3,000 athletes from around the U.S..
-Sports: 36 individual and team competitions, including some from the
Winter Olympics (figure skating, speedskating and ice hockey) and the Pan
American Games (bowling, racquetball, roller skating). The others:
archery, track and field, badminton, baseball, basketball, boxing,
canoe/kayak, cycling, disabled sports, diving, fencing, field hockey,
gymnastics, rhythmic gymnastics, judo, modern pentathlon, rowing,
shooting, soccer, softball, swimming, synchronized swimming, table
tennis, team handball, tae- kwondo, volleyball, weightlifting, water
polo, wrestling, sailing. -Qualifying: The athletes were selected through
tryouts and by officials from the governing body of each sport.
-Today's highlights: Opening ceremonies with Kenny Loggins, Miss America
Heather Whitestone and fireworks. Competition begins in rowing, team
handball, volleyball, diving and tennis.
-Television: Today: none. Saturday: CBS/Channel 46, 4-6 p.m. (boxing,
figure skating); SportsSouth 8-10 p.m. (opening ceremonies, women's 1-
meter diving, men's 3-meter diving, men's figure skating, swimming).

                              183 of 998 DOCUMENTS

                       St. Louis Post-Dispatch (Missouri)

                 July 23, 2000, Sunday, FIVE STAR LIFT EDITION

WORKING WITHOUT A NET

SECTION: EDITORIAL, Pg. B2

LENGTH: 571 words



HUNGER

GLOWING economic statistics may bode well for Wall Street and middle-class
America, but financial security remains a distant dream for the working poor. As
more welfare recipients and other low-skilled laborers migrate to minimum wage
jobs, food pantries have been besieged with requests for emergency assistance
from people who work but still cannot afford to feed their children.

Last year, the U.S. Conference of Mayors reported that requests for emergency
food assistance rose by an average of 18 percent. Two-thirds of adults who made
those requests were workers. And the U.S. Department of Agriculture estimates
that 31 million Americans -- one in 10 households -- live with uncertain or
limited access to food.

When working Americans cannot afford to feed themselves and their children, our
safety net clearly needs repair.

At the heart of that safety net is the federal food stamp program. Food stamp
eligibility rules exclude many working poor families. And families that qualify
often fail to receive them. Participation in the program nationally has dropped
by one-third since 1994.

In Missouri, a study by the Missouri Association for Social Welfare estimated
that only 57 percent of those who qualify are receiving food stamps. A strong
economy accounts for some of that decline. But persistent poverty rates -- plus
long lines at soup kitchens and food pantries nationwide -- suggest that many
Americans who need food stamps are not getting them.

Critics of the food stamp program in Missouri blame welfare reform and its
resulting confusion for leading some former welfare recipients -- and even some
of their caseworkers -- to believe they no longer qualify for food stamps. The
report also cites a relatively new system that requires the working poor and
others to reapply for food stamps more often and a lack of coordination between
the food pantries that serve the hungry and the Division of Family Services,
which administers food stamps.

Family Services Director Denise Cross said her agency now encourages its county
offices to coordinate with local charities to promote the program. That's a good
start. Ms. Cross should make that push statewide, and accompany it with longer
office hours to make caseworkers more accessible to working clients. Missouri
also must find ways to attract and keep more caseworkers, pay them decent wages
and avoid burying them under unreasonable caseloads.

On the federal level, food stamp eligibility rules must better support the
working poor. The Hunger Relief Act pending in Congress would expand eligibility
to low-income people who are now disqualified because of the value of their car
(which often ensures their continued access to employment). It would also
include legal immigrants -- many of whom work and pay taxes but were cut off
from food stamps in 1996 -- and families that spend more than half of their
income on housing. The cost: $ 2.5 billion over five years -- an investment that
would confirm America's commitment to encouraging work.

Missouri and Illinois lawmakers -- including 18 Missouri and Illinois House
members and Republican Sens. John Ashcroft and Christopher "Kit" Bond of
Missouri and Peter Fitzgerald of Illinois, who have not yet signed on -- should
support the bipartisan bill and prove that Americans still bel ieve in rewarding
work, feeding the hungry and sharing abundance in the land of plenty.

LOAD-DATE: July 23, 2000

LANGUAGE: English

                  Copyright 2000 St. Louis Post-Dispatch, Inc.


                              184 of 998 DOCUMENTS

                              Journal of Commerce

                            March 2, 1989, Thursday

GEOFFREY BROWN'S TRADETALK

BYLINE: Geoffrey Brown

SECTION: EXPORTS, Pg. 5A

LENGTH: 534 words


CUT-FLOWER IMPORTS may have U.S. producers in the pink.

In testimony before the International Trade Commission, John R. Block, president
of the National-American Wholesale Grocers' Association said that an increase in
imports of fresh-cut roses actually benefits the domestic flower ndustry.

"Because of the increasing availability of roses through imports, non-
traditional suppliers of flowers such as convenience stores have been able to
increase consumer appetites for a product they would not have otherwise
purchased," he said.

According to an October 1988 Penn State University study entitled "Flower
Marketing Information," 779 million roses were sold in the United States in 1987
compared with 592 million in 1984, an increase of more than 30 percent.

The domestic rose industry has shared in this growth.

An April 1988 U.S. Department of Agriculture report says the number of
commercial rose plants being cultivated in the United States rose to 19.5
million in 1987 from 16.4 million in 1984. Mr. Block was a secretary of
agriculture in the Reagan administration.

* * * * *

THE PORTUGUESE GOVERNMENT is reorganizing its trade offices around the world in
an effort to better attract foreign investment to Portugal.

At a luncheon in New York last month given by the Portugal-U.S. Chamber of
Commerce, Luis Fontoura, chairman of the Institute of Foreign Trade of Portugal,
said that since Jan. 1 it has been responsible for attracting investment to
Portugal as well as promoting Portuguese exports.

Speaking through a translator, Mr. Fontoura said the Foreign Investment
Institute, which used to be responsible for attracting foreign investment to
Portugal, is being phased out.

The Foreign Investment Institute was hampered because it lacked overseas
offices, said Paulo Almeida d'Eca, executive director of the Portugal-U.S.
Chamber of Commerce.

"Investment promotion should be enhanced by the fact that the Institute of
Foreign Trade has offices and extensive contacts in over 45 countries," Mr.
d'Eca said.

In line with these structural changes, Mr. Fontoura said, the directors of the
Institute of Foreign Trade had named Jose Vital Morgado the new U.S. trade
commissioner. Mr. Morgado formerly was the institute's director in Portugal.

* * * * *

FOREIGN INVESTORS should look at the opportunities to develop tourism in
northern Portugal, said an attorney at the luncheon.

Preconser Ltd., a Portuguese investment group, has assembled between 200 and 250
acres in one valley that it intends to transform into a Catskill, N.Y.-like
development near the town of Oliveira do-Hospital, the attorney said.

"The valley, which is north of the university town of Coimbra and near a main
road coming from Spain, is ideally suited to the development of smaller type
accommodations," the attorney said.

The attorney said the investment group had assembled about 40 percent of the $
20 million needed for the development project. The Portuguese government is
expected to be a significant contributor.

* * * * *

"1992 IS JUST A SOUND BITE," one luncheon attendee said. "European unification
will no doubt still be continuing in 2010.

LOAD-DATE: December 19, 1996

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

EDITOR-NOTE: GEOFFREY BROWN'S TRADETALK. Briefs

                  Copyright 1989 The Journal of Commerce, Inc.


                              185 of 998 DOCUMENTS


                               Business Recorder

                              May 9, 2013 Thursday

US to continue support to agriculture sector: Olson

SECTION: Vol. XLIX No. 128

LENGTH: 639  words


US Ambassador Richard Olson on Wednesday reaffirmed the United States
government's long-term support to farming communities in Pakistan. "Since the
1950s, the United States has been working to support agriculture in Pakistan,
introducing the Kinnow orange and helping to double Pakistan's wheat production.
Today, we continue our support because improving crop yields, protecting food
sources from disease, and boosting milk production will increase farmers'
incomes, improve nutrition, and ultimately strengthen Pakistan's prosperity."

Addressing a gathering of government officials, researchers, and farmers during
his visit to the National Agriculture Research Center (NARC), which was
established with the help of the US government in the 1980s, Ambassador Olson
said, "The United States is committed to helping the small farmers of Pakistan
through projects that enhance agricultural productivity." The Ambassador lauded
the progress made by the Wheat Productivity Enhancement Project (WPEP), a United
States Department of Agriculture (USDA) program managed in collaboration with
national and provincial research partners that has successfully introduced the
UG 99-resistant wheat variety, "NARC 2011."

The introduction of this wheat variety helps protect Pakistan against UG 99, a
virulent wheat disease in the region that poses a threat to Pakistan's farming
community. "Wheat accounts for approximately 60 percent of the daily caloric
intake of the average Pakistani, so our joint efforts to combat this disease are
critical," said Ambassador Olson.

"The Wheat Productivity Enhancement Project team and Pakistani scientists at
national and provincial research stations have made great progress in the fight
against wheat rusts, and I encourage you to continue your work together." In
addition to support for the Wheat Productivity Enhancement Project, the United
States has provided new harvesting machines and funded improvements to research
stations around Pakistan to develop more disease-resistant wheat varieties. The
United States also provides specialised training opportunities to Pakistani
wheat scientists.

Dr Muhammad Imtiaz, Country Liaison Officer for the International Maize and
Wheat Improvement Center, noted that without disease-resistant varieties of
wheat, such as the one being harvested at NARC, experts estimate that Pakistan's
annual wheat harvest could be reduced by as much as 50 percent if and when UG 99
arrives. "Agriculture contributes 21 percent to the GDP of Pakistan and employs
45 percent of the labour force, making it one of the most significant economic
drivers of Pakistan," Dr Imtiaz said. Pakistani farmers grew about 24 million
tons of wheat on eight million hectares last year, accounting for about 2.4
percent of the GDP.

"The United States and Pakistan have similar agricultural systems, and for that
reason we have been effective partners in agriculture for more than half a
century, working together to improve agricultural yields and to combat disease,"
said Ambassador Olson.

"Since the 1950s, US and Pakistani scientists have collaborated to increase
wheat production. At that time, Dr Manzoor Bajwa and Dr Norman Borlaug worked
together to develop 'Mexi-Pak,' the wheat variety that started the Green
Revolution in Pakistan and helped to double Pakistan's wheat production between
1965 and 1970."

"Today, our long-term commitment to Pakistan's agriculture sector is sustained
through projects that help fight animal and crop diseases, increase vegetable
and mango production, improve irrigation, increase dairy production, and support
wheat research, " Ambassador Olson concluded. Taimur Azmat Osman, Secretary,
Ministry of National Food Security and Research and Dr Iftikar Ahmed, Chairman,
Pakistan Agriculture Research Centre (PARC) were among others who were present
on the occasion.

LOAD-DATE: May 9, 2013

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


                        Copyright 2013 Business Recorder
                              All Rights Reserved

                               The New York Times

                 August 25, 1991, Sunday, Late Edition - Final

Miss O'Hanlon Weds Thomas Evanoff

SECTION: Section 1; Part 2; Page 57; Column 2; Society Desk

LENGTH: 170 words


Karin Ann O'Hanlon, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John R. O'Hanlon of Armonk, N.Y.,
was married there yesterday to Thomas Walter Evanoff, a son of Mr. and Mrs.
Walter M. Evanoff of Vienna, Va. Msgr. Walter Schroeder performed the ceremony
at St. Patrick Church.

The couple, both 25 years old, are graduates of the University of Delaware. Mrs.
Evanoff is a mortgage insurance specialist at the First Union Mortgage
Corporation in Raleigh, N.C. Her father is a vice president and deputy general
counsel of the New York Life Insurance Company. Her mother, Nancy O'Hanlon, is a
registered nurse.

The bridegroom is a security specialist with Northern Telecom Inc., a Canadian
telecommunications company, in Raleigh. His mother, Lyle Evanoff, who is
retired, was the first female police officer on the staff of the United States
Supreme Court. His father, who is retired, was a detective sergeant with the
Washington Police Department and was the chief of security for the United States
Department of Agriculture.

                              187 of 998 DOCUMENTS

                               The New York Times

              November 29, 1983, Tuesday, Late City Final Edition

Drop in Farm Workers Found in U.S. Survey

BYLINE: AP

SECTION: Section A; Page 17, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 170 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON , Nov. 28


An Agriculture Department survey of farm workers in the United States shows a 47
percent decline from 1979 to 1981 in the number of migrant laborers traveling to
harvest fruit, vegetables and other crops.

One reason for the sharp decline, to 115,000 in 1981, in a level that held
fairly steady in recent years, may be that illegal aliens have taken over many
of the jobs formerly held by American migrants, the report said.

But that is uncertain. Other possible explanations include radical changes in
crop production patterns and errors in the survey sample.

The report was by Susan Pollack and William R. Jackson Jr. of the agency's
Economic Research Service.

In 1979, a survey of migrant workers reported 217,000 rtraveling from area to
area. That figure was comparable to reports in other years going back to 1970
when 196,000 were reported.

''Another explanation for the decrease,'' the report said, ''may be that farm
operators are increasingly substituting illegal aliens for domestic farm
workers.''


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                   Copyright 1983 The New York Times Company


                              188 of 998 DOCUMENTS



                                US Official News

                           December 15, 2016 Thursday

Washington: USDA Expands Public-Private Partnerships to Create Economic
Opportunities through Regional Food Supply Chains

LENGTH: 594  words

DATELINE: New York



 Washington: United States Department of Agriculture has issued the following
news release:



 U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) Deputy Under Secretary for Rural
Development Lillian Salerno today announced three new public-private
partnerships that will create economic opportunities in Elgin, Texas; Fresno,
Calif.; and Chicago. The Food LINC partnerships will help community leaders and
private philanthropic partners develop regional food supply chains that drive
job growth and increase farm income while helping to meet consumer demand for
regionally produced food.





 "USDA investments in regional food have the biggest impact when coordination
between producers, processors, distributors and buyers is strong and locally
led," said Salerno. "We are excited to add three new locations to the nationwide
network of cities that are already leveraging government and private resources
to build robust regional food systems, for the benefit of consumers, producers,
and the economy."



 USDA Food LINC (Leveraging Investment for Network Coordination) partnerships
are already working in ten communities to better connect the urban demand for
local food and agricultural products with the supply from regional farmers,
ranchers and entrepreneurs. USDA's initial investment of $1 million provided the
seed capital to attract an additional $2.5 million from 18 philanthropic
organizations, plus more than $1.5 million from the Appalachian Regional
Commission and the Delta Regional Authority. This expansion establishes
partnerships in three new regions:



     The Texas Center for Local FoodThis is an external link or third-party site
outside of the United States Department of Agriculture (USDA) website. will help
farmers in the Elgin, Texas region receive more for their products, support good
jobs in rural communities and improve access to locally-produced food. A town of
8,000 people, Elgin is centrally located within a 200-mile radius of nearly 18
million Texans, making it an ideal production and transportation hub for the
region.

     Food Commons FresnoThis is an external link or third-party site outside of
the United States Department of Agriculture (USDA) website. will incubate a
community food hub and grocery store in South Fresno, a community education
space and a processing and distribution facility to develop markets for
agricultural producers in California's San Joaquin Valley.

     FamilyFarmedThis is an external link or third-party site outside of the
United States Department of Agriculture (USDA) website. will help producers from
the Midwest take advantage of Chicago's growing demand for regionally-sourced,
sustainably-grown specialty grains.



 USDA has partnered with The Wallace CenterThis is an external link or
third-party site outside of the United States Department of Agriculture (USDA)
website. to document work in each of the 13 Food LINC regions and share best
practices with other organizations that are working to grow similar
opportunities in their communities. Other Food LINC partnerships include the
Louisville Farm to Table Program in Kentucky; the Conservation Fund in North
Carolina; Common Market in Georgia; Rocky Mountain Farmers Union in Colorado; La
Montañita in New Mexico; Fair Food Philadelphia; Metro Washington Council of
Governments in Washington, D.C.; Appalachian Sustainable Development in
Virginia; Soul City Hospitality in Mississippi; and Communities Unlimited in
Tennessee.





 In case of any query regarding this article or other content needs please
contact:

 editorial@plusmediasolutions.com

LOAD-DATE: December 16, 2016

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newswire

                              189 of 998 DOCUMENTS



                                US Official News

                           December 15, 2016 Thursday

Washington: USDA Expands Public-Private Partnerships to Create Economic
Opportunities through Regional Food Supply Chains

LENGTH: 594  words

DATELINE: New York



 Washington: United States Department of Agriculture has issued the following
news release:



 U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) Deputy Under Secretary for Rural
Development Lillian Salerno today announced three new public-private
partnerships that will create economic opportunities in Elgin, Texas; Fresno,
Calif.; and Chicago. The Food LINC partnerships will help community leaders and
private philanthropic partners develop regional food supply chains that drive
job growth and increase farm income while helping to meet consumer demand for
regionally produced food.





 "USDA investments in regional food have the biggest impact when coordination
between producers, processors, distributors and buyers is strong and locally
led," said Salerno. "We are excited to add three new locations to the nationwide
network of cities that are already leveraging government and private resources
to build robust regional food systems, for the benefit of consumers, producers,
and the economy."



 USDA Food LINC (Leveraging Investment for Network Coordination) partnerships
are already working in ten communities to better connect the urban demand for
local food and agricultural products with the supply from regional farmers,
ranchers and entrepreneurs. USDA's initial investment of $1 million provided the
seed capital to attract an additional $2.5 million from 18 philanthropic
organizations, plus more than $1.5 million from the Appalachian Regional
Commission and the Delta Regional Authority. This expansion establishes
partnerships in three new regions:



     The Texas Center for Local FoodThis is an external link or third-party site
outside of the United States Department of Agriculture (USDA) website. will help
farmers in the Elgin, Texas region receive more for their products, support good
jobs in rural communities and improve access to locally-produced food. A town of
8,000 people, Elgin is centrally located within a 200-mile radius of nearly 18
million Texans, making it an ideal production and transportation hub for the
region.

     Food Commons FresnoThis is an external link or third-party site outside of
the United States Department of Agriculture (USDA) website. will incubate a
community food hub and grocery store in South Fresno, a community education
space and a processing and distribution facility to develop markets for
agricultural producers in California's San Joaquin Valley.

     FamilyFarmedThis is an external link or third-party site outside of the
United States Department of Agriculture (USDA) website. will help producers from
the Midwest take advantage of Chicago's growing demand for regionally-sourced,
sustainably-grown specialty grains.



 USDA has partnered with The Wallace CenterThis is an external link or
third-party site outside of the United States Department of Agriculture (USDA)
website. to document work in each of the 13 Food LINC regions and share best
practices with other organizations that are working to grow similar
opportunities in their communities. Other Food LINC partnerships include the
Louisville Farm to Table Program in Kentucky; the Conservation Fund in North
Carolina; Common Market in Georgia; Rocky Mountain Farmers Union in Colorado; La
Montañita in New Mexico; Fair Food Philadelphia; Metro Washington Council of
Governments in Washington, D.C.; Appalachian Sustainable Development in
Virginia; Soul City Hospitality in Mississippi; and Communities Unlimited in
Tennessee.

                           November 29, 2016 Tuesday

Washington: USDA Expands Public-Private Partnerships to Create Economic

network of cities that are already leveraging government and private resources

                              191 of 998 DOCUMENTS


                          The Globe and Mail (Canada)

                           September 25, 1981 Friday

U.S. may be heading for a trade war   with EEC over its agricultural policies

BYLINE: REUT

LENGTH: 318 words

DATELINE: Washington DC


WASHINGTON  (Reuter) - The United States and the European Economic
 Community may be headed for a major trade war over EEC agricultural
 policies.

U.S. officials see current and proposed EEC export policies as curbing
 the U.S. share of agricultural markets at a time when bumper crops are
 expected world-wide.

Facing one of the first real tests of the Reagan Administration's
 'tough talk' approach to protecting U.S. agricultural trade, U.S.
 officials have sworn to retaliate if EEC policies edge U.S. farm products
 out of vital markets.

Attacks by U.S. officials on EEC export policies have increased in
 recent weeks as the EEC Commission considers a proposal to tax vegetable
 oil imports at a time when U.S. farmers are preparing to harvest a near-
 record soybean crop.

Meanwhile, U.S. Agriculture Department analysts are preparing an
 internal paper that will outline possible retaliatory measures in response
 to a vegetable oil tax, including possible taxes on imports from the EEC
 such as wine, officials said.

In addition, legislation is pending in Congress to allow the United
 States to subsidize products that compete with exports subsidized by the
 EEC, such as wheat and wheat flour.
    'If they adversely affect our trade flow, we'll have to do the same to
 them,' Thomas Hammer, deputy undersecretary of agriculture for
 international affairs, said. He said that while the United States is
 prepared to 'be as tough as need be' if the oil tax is imposed, the
 Administration is working harder to avert it than it is on planning
 retaliation.

U.S. Agriculture Secretary John Block recently restated in a speech in
 New York the same message he took to Europe during a visit last May. EEC
 action to restrict imports of U.S. soybeans and soya products 'would lead
 to immediate counteraction.'
    EEC policies that do not allow the United States to compete on equal
 terms in other markets will not be tolerated, he said.

LOAD-DATE: January 12, 2007

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


 Copyright 1981 The Globe and Mail, a division of CTVglobemedia Publishing Inc.
                              All Rights Reserved


                              192 of 998 DOCUMENTS


                        The Balochistan Times (AsiaNet)

                            February 12, 2010 Friday

US to provide $100 million for agriculture development in Pakistan and
Afghanistan

SECTION: Vol. XXXIV No. 43

LENGTH: 769  words


A trilateral US-Pakistan-Afghanistan forum on agriculture has made a robust
start in its first meeting held in Qatar with United States making initial
commitment of $100 million as first tranche out of a hefty fund it promised to
bolster agriculture in Pakistan and Afghanistan.  "More money will flow as
concrete projects get underway," US deputy under secretary agriculture Burnham
Philbrook observed in the plenary session.  According to a message received here
Friday, the meeting was organized in Doha by the US Embassy in Pakistan for
security reason and to avoid visa and other complications envisaged in holding
it in the United States.  Pakistan delegation that comprised nearly two dozen
top agriculture experts and officials was led by the director general of the
trilateral secretariat, Mr. Zahoor Malik.

Working groups comprising experts from the three countries in their
deliberations focused on areas of food security, trade corridors and water
management. Malik announced that the next meeting of the forum will be held in
Pakistan in April.

Pakistan voiced its concerns on the dam being built on River Kabul with India's
assistance and suggested a profound engagement between Pakistan and Afghanistan
to address these concerns.

Philbrook said development of agriculture in both countries was part of the
strategy to boosting their economies, uplifting living standards of their people
and winning the hearts and minds of the rural populace.  "We believe that peace
depends on improving the lot of the people for which development of agriculture
is vital because more than eighty per cent population depends on it," Philbrook
remarked. He said the United States intends to vigorously pursue the goal of
agricultural growth adding that in case of Afghanistan it would also work as an
incentive to farmers to stop planting poppy.

"Agriculture is key to making peace sustainable" Philbrook said while pointing
out that drug trade is a major source of instability and funding for militancy
in Afghanistan.

Responding to points raised by Mr. Malik in his welcome speech regarding the
tardy approach adopted by the United States in the past in committing funds that
has hampered progress in formulating policies and designing projects, Philbrooke
assured that adequate and prompt funding would be provided to launch viable
programmes in agriculture. He said the US secretary agriculture during his
recent visit to the region felt more determined than ever to build international
awareness about the importance of Afghanistan's agricultural economy to its
long-term security and sustainability.

He referred to last year's trilateral summit in Washington attended by president
Barack Obama and his Afghan and Pakistani counterparts Hamid Karazi and Asif Ali
Zardari during which they agreed on a roadmap for the progress and prosperity of
people of this region.

"We, too, are here in the midst of a great challenge and understand that
generating sustained economic development in Pakistan and Afghanistan will not
be easy. But we will not be deterred."

Malik said the United States has been a generous donor to developing countries
in promoting their economies but its assistance has failed to produce desired
results.

"In this context we hear our American friends expressing frustration why people
hate America despite all the goodwill it has shown in helping the developing
countries," Malik said.

"One major reason for this state of affairs is that the US assistance has failed
to trickle down to real stake-holders- the under-privileged sections of society
who have become poorer over the period of time," he said.  "In order to move in
the right direction, we have to acknowledge our past mistakes and stop enriching
the rich and empowering the powerful, "Malik said adding:"People are skeptical
and there is also a trust deficit as people are not sure if the Americans would
again wash off their hands, as in the past, and leave everything high and dry."

Philbrook said the United States and its allies are determined this time not to
abandon the people of this region and would do everything to become their
partners in peace and prosperity.

Afghan deputy minister Saleem Kundozi said his government's agricultural
strategy has three pillars; to protect and restore the environment; to grow
agricultural production and productivity; and to foster agri-business to boost
exports and family income for creating new jobs on and off the farms. He
underpinned the importance of cooperation between Afghanistan and Pakistan and

said his country can learn from the broader experiences of Pakistan.

LOAD-DATE: November 16, 2011

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


                      Copyright 2010 The Balochistan Times
                              All Rights Reserved


                              193 of 998 DOCUMENTS


                        The Balochistan Times (AsiaNet)

                             August 23, 2009 Sunday

US, Pak, Afghanistan to form working groups in agricultural trade

LENGTH: 558  words


Dr. Zafar Altaf, Chairman, Pakistan Agricultural Research Council (PARC) Sunday
said that United States, Pakistan and Afghanistan's collaboration to monitor
wheat rust UG99 through trilateral pledge will help to ensure food security in
the region. This he stated while speaking a galaxy of scientists from Mexico,
USA, Syria, Iran, Afghanistan, Australia, Pakistan and across all provinces who
came to attend this two day symposium organized by PARC in collaboration with
United States Department of Agriculture (USDA) here at the National Agricultural
Research Centre (NARC) to make an action plan for combating UG99, a wheat stem
rust.

It is to be noted that the United States, Afghanistan and Pakistan plan to
increase cooperation on agricultural development and support research on food
production, agriculture-related issues/resources, and improvement of
agricultural trade and markets.

The countries have agreed to form working groups which were established in the
areas of Food Security, Agricultural Trade Corridors, Water Management and
Watershed Rehabilitation.

The food security working groups priority challenge area targeted stem rust UG99
race as a major hazard to wheat production, The United States plans to join
Afghanistan and Pakistan in accelerating a focused development effort that is
expected to improve trade, increase the productivity of agriculture, revitalize
local and regional agricultural markets improve food security, and transform the
agriculture sector. The United States is planning to spend $27.5 million under
the U.S. Department of Agriculture's Food for Progress Program for Pakistan and
Afghanistan to help improve the sustainable development of their agricultural
sectors, which will help provide the foundation on which the economies of the
two countries can prosper and thrive.

UG99 since its origin in Uganda in 1999 has migrated reached Iran and has become
a regional threat that now confronts wheat production and stability. It has
opened up doors for Pakistani researchers to take a closer look at the
constraint and make efforts to tackle the problem. Pakistan is well positioned
and has the capacity to handle this program and be the focal point. Through this
activity hub would be promoted the wheat crop yield security functions that will
simultaneously provide opportunities arid strategies complimenting the perceive
trilateral food security mandate.

Pakistan would take the lead role in producing and deploying unique resistant
wheat varieties within the region. At this occasion Secretary Ministry of Food
and Agriculture gave an over view of the symposium. The trilateral alliance
would in addition, allow research to be conducted on the local stem rust
virulence and enhance our capacities to avert the fungal threat, solidify
leadership within Pakistan, building up regional capacities for making global
impacts.  The galaxy of approximately 60 professionals represent
institutions/organizations from Mexico, USA, Syria, Iran, Afghanistan, Australia
and Pakistan across all provinces.

The participants of the symposium prepared recommendation on a diverse range of
aspects relating to the rust pathogens containment and target on capacity
building across multidisciplinary facets to ensure regional food security and
pave the way forward for other food commodities to be focused upon in the
future.

LOAD-DATE: November 23, 2011

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


                      Copyright 2009 The Balochistan Times
                              All Rights Reserved


                              194 of 998 DOCUMENTS


                               The Frontier Star

                            April 6, 2016 Wednesday

Expo held to modernize agriculture sector

SECTION: Vol. 21 No. 97

LENGTH: 241  words


- The United States showcased its longstanding support for Pakistan's
agriculture sector at the 5th Annual Dawn Food and Agri Expo in the city with a
pavilion featuring its ongoing initiatives.

The Expo highlighted efforts to modernize the agriculture sector, improve market
access, and increase crop yields, says a press release issued by USAID here on
Tuesday.

The Expo's U.S. pavilion featured agricultural assistance programs supported by
the U.S. Agency for International Development (USAID) and the U.S. Department of
Agriculture (USDA).

These programs promote advanced farming practices, enhance export capacity,
build irrigation infrastructure and introduce the latest in water management
practices.

The United States has maintained a longstanding partnership with Pakistan to
improve the livelihoods of farmers and increase access to nutritious food for
millions of Pakistanis.

Since 2009, the United States, in partnership with the government of Pakistan
and the private sector, has invested more than $550 million to fund projects
that support economic growth and agriculture.

Over the past five years, USAID projects have helped increase exports from
Pakistan by $59 million, increased sales by $153 million, and helped develop
over $16 million in new investments.

More than 910,000 farming households have increased their incomes since 2010
utilizing U.S.-funded programs, and 45,000 more have received training in
dairy-related operations.

LOAD-DATE: April 6, 2016

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


                        Copyright 2016 The Frontier Star
                              All Rights Reserved


                              195 of 998 DOCUMENTS

                      The Financial Post (Toronto, Canada)

                     January 5, 1990, Friday, DAILY EDITION

Japan, U.S. disagree on rice rule

BYLINE: Reuters

SECTION: SECTION 3, THE MARKETS; Pg. 20

LENGTH: 132 words

DATELINE: Orlando,FL


U.S. Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter said yesterday that Washington
opposes Japan's proposal that it be allowed to subsidize its rice farmers and
keep a ban on rice imports despite other countries' moves toward freer trade.

He said Japan's plan was at odds with U.S. efforts to cut agricultural trade
barriers and subsidies through negotiations under the General Agreement on
Tariffs & Trade.

''Japan's proposal certainly is by no means synonymous with our food position,''
Yeutter said during a break at an informal meeting of agriculture ministers
here.

Japanese Agriculture, Forestry & Fisheries Minister Michihiko Kano detailed
Tokyo's proposal at the meeting, with was attended by ministers from Canada, the
U.S., the European Community and Australia.




LOAD-DATE: November 6, 1997

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: NEWS

                       Copyright 1990 Financial Post Ltd.


                              196 of 998 DOCUMENTS

                               The New York Times

               February 10, 1986, Monday, Late City Final Edition

Advertising;
Rosenfeld Prepares Ads For Hunger Campaign

BYLINE: By Philip H. Dougherty

SECTION: Section D; Page 24, Column 4; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 130 words


Rosenfeld, Sirowitz & Humphrey, as a volunteer Advertising Council agency, has
prepared a multimedia advertising campaign to help the United States Department
of Agriculture in the fight against hunger in America.

The particular assignment is to familiarize those needy segments of the public
with the 800 phone number where they can receive information on their
eligibility for food stamps. A brochure is also available.

The theme of the campaign is ''Meal times don't have to be tough times.''

The 60-second TV commercial opens up on a waving field of grain, the traditional
sign of plenty. Through it wend the needy toward a table set for dinner while
the voice over says, ''America has made a place at our table of plenty for you.
We want to make sure you get there.''

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                   Copyright 1986 The New York Times Company
