                               The New York Times

                  May 28, 1996, Tuesday, Late Edition - Final

Deal Lets Infected Horses Enter Country for Olympics

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS

SECTION: Section A;  Page 12;  Column 5;  National Desk

LENGTH: 1076 words

DATELINE: ATLANTA, May 27


Yielding to international pressure, Georgia and Federal agriculture officials
have decided to permit some horses to compete in the Summer Olympics even though
they carry a tick-borne disease and would ordinarily be barred from the United
States. But other states' officials, horsemen and scientists are still debating
the risks to the American horse population.

The disease, piroplasmosis, is pervasive, but generally benign, in parts of
Europe and South America. Because it is extremely rare in the United States,
however, it is debilitating and potentially fatal to horses here, and the United
States Department of Agriculture bans the entry of horses that test positive for
it. Similarly, Georgia agriculture rules keep such horses out of the state.

But application of these rules this summer would have barred from the Games at
least 20 European champions and contenders for medals. And the animals had some
impressive lobbyists -- including the King of Spain, who owns a horse with
piroplasmosis -- who sought a waiver from the rules, arguing that a blanket ban
on the horses might violate free-trade agreements.

There has been no official ruling that a prohibition on the horses would violate
trade rules. And organizations like the American Horse Shows Association, the
American Horse Council and the Georgia Horse Council opposed waiving the rules.
Nonetheless, after months of negotiations, Georgia and Federal officials agreed
that if horses that tested positive would undergo a rigorous protocol intended
to minimize the risk of spreading the disease, they could enter the country and
compete in two of the three Olympic equestrian events.

Under the plan, these horses will be housed in an isolation barn and allowed to
compete only in show jumping and dressage, which will be held east of the city
at the Georgia International Horse Park, a confined, tick-free area. The horses
will get regular anti-tick sprayings and frequent testing.

Horses with piroplasmosis will not be permitted to compete in the three-day
combined training event, which puts horses over a course through the open
countryside of central Georgia. In July, experts say, that area is tick heaven.

"We heard from the world-trade community that a blanket ban by us might violate
the GATT and Nafta trade agreements because we would be throwing up an illegal
trade barrier without sufficient scientific information," said the Georgia
Agriculture Commissioner, Tommy Irvin, referring to the General Agreement on
Tariffs and Trade and the North American Free Trade Agreement. Mr. Irvin
described "the intensity of the pressure, with all of these international
figures saying, 'How can the Agriculture Commissioner of Georgia say we can't
come here when we go everywhere in the world without problems?' "

The rules have been waived before. For example, horses carrying the disease were
allowed to compete in the 1984 Games in Los Angeles because that area is dry and
inhospitable to ticks.

Some in the United States horse community support the final decision. John
Strassburger, editor of The Chronicle of the Horse magazine, called the
opposition to letting the horses compete a "tempest in a teapot" fueled by
irrational fears among horse owners in the United States. Robin Gifford,
executive director of the United States Dressage Federation, whose members will
be competing against European horses with piroplasmosis, said she was satisfied
with the Georgia plan.

But others are troubled by the decision and the international pressure. They
said they are only reluctantly going along with the plan. "We did our very best
to stop this from happening," said Eric Straus, director of the American Horse
Show Association, "but the decision has been made. We are going to have to live
with whatever happens because of this decision."

Amy Mann, director of health and regulatory affairs for the American Horse
Council, said, "Georgia has taken a tough stand, but it's not tough enough for
us."

Equine piroplasmosis, which poses no risks to humans, is transmitted from
infected horses by tropical horse ticks who take in their blood and then move
on, through hay, bedding or feed, to uninfected horses. Tropical horse ticks do
not attach themselves to animals other than horses and are found in tropical and
subtropical areas of the Caribbean and South America, as well as in temperate
zones of southern Europe.

In those areas, most horses with piroplasmosis show symptoms no more serious
than a cold. But where the disease is uncommon and there is little or no
resistance, infection can result in pneumonia, jaundice, infected lesions and
death.

Dr. Ralph Knowles, a field veterinarian in the Maryland Department of
Agriculture who has done research on the disease, said the tropical horse tick
existed in the extreme southern parts of the United States.

But, Dr. Knowles said, recent research shows that the more common dog tick and
winter tick may also carry piroplasmosis. These ticks, found in the northern
United States as well as the South, move easily among rodents, dogs and horses.

The plan requires that the disease-carrying horses be housed in a
vegetation-free, fenced and quarantined barn at the Horse Park. They will be
under 24-hour surveillance and checked for ticks every eight hours. Between now
and the end of the Games, the area will be sprayed with tick-killing chemicals
at least four times. All other animals will be kept out. Hay must come from
northern areas that are not infested with ticks, and bedding must repel ticks.

An uninfected "sentinel horse" will be tested regularly to see whether, despite
these efforts, the disease somehow has spread. Within seven days of competition,
the horses will have to leave the country.

Faced with Georgia's plan, states like Kentucky and New Jersey, which have
significant horse industries, are moving to insure that the disease cannot
spread there. Kentucky plans to test and quarantine all horses entering the
state from the Olympics. New Jersey plans to isolate all Olympic horses for 30
days of examinations and spraying.

"We are doing this more in response to industry concern," said Dr. Ernie Zirkle,
director of animal health for New Jersey, "than out of any great concern on our
part. We feel Georgia is doing the right thing, and with the safeguards they are
putting into place, I think it will be impossible for a horse to go there and
come back with the disease."

LOAD-DATE: May 28, 1996

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                   Copyright 1996 The New York Times Company


                              230 of 998 DOCUMENTS

                               The New York Times

                July 12, 1988, Tuesday, Late City Final Edition

Broad Support Seen for Drought Aid

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER, Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section A; Page 14, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 900 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 11


As showers that began Saturday continued to fall on parts of the parched Midwest
and South, the chairmen of the House and Senate Agriculture Committees told
President Reagan today that there was widespread support in both parties for
legislation that would provide billions of dollars in relief to farmers whose
crops have been damaged.

In a meeting at the White House, Senator Patrick J. Leahy, Democrat of Vermont,
chairman of the Senate Agriculture Committee, and Representative E. (Kika) de la
Garza, Democrat of Texas, chairman of the House Agriculture Committee, said the
President expressed support for the legislation and indicated concern about
drought damage.

Agriculture Secretary Richard E. Lyng, Representative Edward R. Madigan,
Republican of Illinois, and Senator Richard G. Lugar, Republican of Indiana,
also attended the meeting.

'Encouraged' by Response

Senator Leahy said it was his intention to hold hearings on Capitol Hill this
week in order to shape the legislation into a form that could be approved. ''I'm
very encouraged by the response of the President,'' Mr. Leahy said. ''The
President asked us to be mindful of the budget. We are mindful of it.''

Republican Congressional leaders said they would be active in shaping the
legislation. ''There are no areas of disagreement,'' Mr. Lugar said.

The 25-minute meeting came as the Agriculture Department was preparing to
release a special study of the drought's effect on crop production. The study is
due out Tuesday. Mr. Lyng said, ''Perhaps never before in the history of the
United States has there been a July 11 on which so much uncertainty remained as
to the true supply and demand situation for U.S. agricultural production.''

'Wild Card' in Election

The activity at the White House and on Capitol Hill reflects a growing awareness
by both parties of the political consequences if they are seen as failing to
react to the distress caused by the drought. Republican political experts have
called the drought a ''wild card'' in the 1988 Presidential campaign, believing
that it may cause some voters to switch.

Democrats, meanwhile, hope to pick up support in the drought regions of the
northern Great Plains, the Middle West and the South, areas that have supported
Republican candidates in recent national elections.

The House and Senate versions, which are nearly identical, and which would cost
between $5 billion and $6 billion, call for disaster payments to be made to any
farmers who have lost at least 65 percent of their crops to the drought. The
payments are to be directed to farmers who raise vegetables, fruits, soybeans
and grains. Farmers would be eligible to receive payments amounting to
two-thirds of the market value of vegetable and fruit crops, and two-thirds of
the Congressionally set prices for grain crops.

Effect on Support Payments

In addition, some farmers who received support payments in advance from the
Government for grain crops would not have to refund portions of the payments if
the drought caused extensive damage. The Congressional staff members said they
believed that no more than $1 billion was involved in this part of the
legislation.

At the White House the drought has become a principal focus of activities this
week. On Tuesday, the President will meet with Congressional leaders of both
parties. On Wednesday, Mr. Reagan is tentatively scheduled to meet with Dean
Kleckner, president of the American Farm Bureau Federation, and presidents of
state farm bureaus. Both meetings will take place at the White House, officials
said.

On Thursday, Mr. Reagan leaves Washington to travel to Iowa and to tour parched
areas near Marion, Ill. He is scheduled to visit the farm of Herman Krone, who
raises corn and soybeans near Du Quoin. The trip, Mr. Reagan's first to assess
damage from the drought, recalled similar journeys by President Franklin D.
Roosevelt, who toured the Middle West and northern Great Plains in 1934 and
1936.

Reagan Wants Cooperation

Mr. Reagan, who has taken an active interest in the drought, has made it clear
to Mr. Lyng that he wants the Administration and Congress to work together to
aid farmers.

Meanwhile, the stubborn high-pressure weather system that produced the hot, dry
conditions over the northern Great Plains and Middle West collapsed over the
weekend, the National Weather Service said.

The weather system has been replaced by another that is helping to bring showers
over the Ohio Valley, the Dakotas, Iowa and parts of the South, particularly in
Arkansas. The showers are expected to persist through Tuesday and possibly into
Wednesday, meteorologists said.

Hot Weather Could Be Back

But the long-range forecast by the National Weather Service calls for the
high-pressure system to return, perhaps by the end of the week.

''The rain over the weekend and what we may get early this week helps,'' said
Ernest Paroczay, a meteorologist at the National Meteorological Center in Camp
Springs, Md., near Washington. ''But it's not going to end the drought.''

Across the Middle West, there were more indications that the corn crop has
already suffered extensive damage. Scientists at Purdue University in Lafayette,
Ind., estimated today that 40 percent of the state's harvest had been destroyed.
At about 650 million bushels of corn annually, Indiana is the nation's
fourth-largest producer.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                   Copyright 1988 The New York Times Company


                              231 of 998 DOCUMENTS

                      The Financial Post (Toronto, Canada)

                    July 13, 1988, Wednesday, DAILY EDITION

U.S. grain crop to tumble 24%

BYLINE: Giles Gherson

SECTION: SECTION 1, NEWS; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 393 words

DATELINE: Washington,DC


  U.S. grain production will fall 24% this year to 212 million metric tons, one
of the worst annual declines on record, the U.S. Department of Agriculture
reported yesterday in its latest forecast of the damage wrought by this summer's
drought.

But Agriculture officials said stockpiles of most grains will remain ample
throughout the year, allowing the U.S. to meet domestic demand and foreign
sales.

According to an American official, the U.S. will call on Canadian farmers for
additional supplies of higher grade Durham wheat.

The department warned that U.S. food prices will climb between 3% and 5% this
year because of rising prices that reflect decreasing supplies of farm
commodities. The estimate is one percentage point higher than food inflation
forecasts released by the department last month.

The higher food inflation forecast comes despite anticipated lower prices for
livestock, as supply mounts in the face of much higher-than-normal herd
liquidations due to feed shortages. U.S. red meat and poultry production is
expected to climb 3% from 1987.


The gloomy farm outlook could get worse if below-average rain levels continue in
the U.S. farm belt during the remainder of the growing season. The U.S. Weather
Service releases its updated 60-day forecast today.

Washington's eagerly awaited July World Crop Outlook sharply revised U.S. crop
expectations that were made only a month ago. The latest outlook calls for a 50%
fall in U.S. spring wheat production this year, a 26% decline in the corn crop,
a 45% smaller barley harvest, and a 13% cut in soybean production.

The 50% drop in anticipated spring wheat production, which accounts for 20% of
total U.S. wheat output, is a record decline. The previous record was a 30%
decline in spring wheat in 1949.

Overall, the U.S. wheat crop is expected to reach 1.84 billion bushels, 13%
below last year's harvest. U.S. winter wheat largely escaped drought damage,
turning in the fourth-highest yield per acre on record.

Ewen Wilson, U.S. assistant agriculture secretary, said the Agriculture
Department believes Canada's spring wheat crop has on balance received more rain
than the U.S. wheatlands. He said the Canadian wheat crop is expected to be 21
million metric tons this year, compared with 25.5 million metric tons last year,
a 17% decline.




LOAD-DATE: December 9, 1997

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: NEWS

                       Copyright 1988 Financial Post Ltd.


                              232 of 998 DOCUMENTS

                         Telegraph Herald (Dubuque, IA)

                             March 13, 2005 Sunday

Battle over Canadian cattle could hit home; Farmers Union official beefs about
reopening the border

BYLINE: JOHN EVERLY

SECTION: Agriculture; Pg. b8

LENGTH: 843 words


To open or not to open the border to Canadian cattle.

That question has been tossed around quite a bit lately by tri-state area
producers and the organizations that represent them. Our area is a major cattle
growing region, and local farmers understand that decisions made in Washington
could affect them one way or another.

For now, Canadian cattle older than 30 months of age are banned from the United
States. That ban has been in place since the December 2003 discovery of a single
case of mad cow disease in the United States in a cow of Canadian origin.

The Iowa Cattlemen's Association Board of Directors says re-establishing beef
trade with Canada should be conditional. The association opposes any cattle more
than 30 months of age, or product from any cattle more than 30 months of age,
entering the United States at this time. The group also insists that trade be
re-established with Japan and South Korea, and expanded in Mexico, before trade
in live cattle from Canada is resumed. The United States should have "absolute
assurance that the Canadian beef industry (ruminant protein) feed ban is in
place and working," the Iowa Cattlemen's Association said.

"We are adamantly opposed to reopening this border," said Iowa Farmers Union
President Chris Petersen. Petersen echoed the position of the National Farmers
Union, which has questioned Canada's safeguards against mad cow disease.

The U.S. Department of Agriculture published a final rule late in 2004
establishing minimal-risk regions for mad cow disease, with Canada as one of
those regions. That rule would have allowed in Canadian cattle younger than 30
months to be shipped across the border.

The rule was to become effective last Monday, but on March 2, the U.S. District
Court in Montana issued a temporary injunction to block the rule until a lawsuit
challenging the rule can be heard in federal court.

The next day, a resolution to disapprove the rule passed the Senate.

Meanwhile, the ag department's rule received a warmer reception during a House
Agriculture Committee hearing March 1.

The star witness was Agriculture Secretary Mike Johanns, who reported on his
department's recent fact-finding mission to Canada.

"Based on a review of inspection records and on-site observations, the team
found that Canada has a robust inspection program, that overall compliance with
the feed ban is good and that the feed ban is reducing the risk of transmission
of (mad cow disease) in the Canadian cattle population. Where isolated issues
were found to exist, they were related mostly to areas of documentation and
record-keeping," Johanns told the committee.

Committee chairman Bob Goodlatte, R-Va., thought the department was on the right
track.

"The United States has an array of protective measures including the feed ban,
Specific Risk Material removal and a robust (mad cow disease) surveillance
system. These are designed to shield our herd and consumers from current risks
and prevent the amplification of the disease if it was ever introduced into our
herd," he said.

Although some folks on this side of the border said the disease was Canada's
problem, it nonetheless brought our beef export trade to an abrupt halt. The
United States lost an estimated $3.3 billion in sales, accounting for between 9
and 10 percent of American beef production.

That means something to the tri-state area. Grant County, with 163,000 animals,
is Wisconsin's top cattle county and 48th among counties in the United States.
Dubuque County's 103,000 cattle make it the second biggest in Iowa and is ranked
76th in the nation. Jo Daviess County is Illinois' top cattle county, with a
herd of around 57,000.

*

Canadian feeder pig imports also are a contentious issue.

Last week, the U.S. Department of Commerce reaffirmed its October 2004 decision
that Canadian producers are dumping live hogs in the United States.

The department said that provisional anti-dumping duties averaging about 11
percent will be placed on imports of live hogs from Canada. The ruling was
hailed by the National Pork Producers Council.

"Canadian hog producers unfairly benefit from huge subsidies that cause
overproduction in Canada and allow Canadian producers to sell their hogs in the
U.S. at artificially low prices," said council president Jon Caspers. "The flood
of low-priced hogs from Canada has pushed down U.S. hog prices and inflicted
severe financial harm on U.S. hog producers."

Not so, say the Canadians, because American and Canadian producers operate in
the same integrated North American market.

"Canadian swine producers are no more dumping than are U.S. hog producers," said
Clare Schlegel, president of the Canadian Pork Council. "Despite a trade law
written to find dumping in almost every case, Canadian pigs and hogs are not
injuring the U.S., but rather contribute to the very success of the North
American sector."

Everly, a Telegraph Herald reporter, was farm director of Dubuque radio station
KDTH for nearly 10 years. His e-mail address is jeverly@wcinet.com.

LOAD-DATE: March 13, 2005

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                  Copyright 2005 Woodward Communications, Inc.


                              233 of 998 DOCUMENTS

                               The New York Times

               December 11, 1988, Sunday, Late City Final Edition

THE WORLD;
The World Debates How to Trade a Food Supply in Jeopardy

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH

SECTION: Section 4; Page 3, Column 1; Week in Review Desk

LENGTH: 864 words

DATELINE: MONTREAL


IN the United States, grain stockpiles are down 135 million tons from their
record high in 1986, largely because of last summer's drought. In the rest of
the world, grain stocks have fallen an additional 50 million tons, creating what
some see as a precarious balance between the world's supply of food and the
demand for it.

Comparisons are being made to the food crisis year of 1973, and some are
invoking the name of Thomas Malthus, who warned 200 years ago that population
growth was destined to outpace the world's ability to feed itself.

Yet policy makers in the United States, Canada, Australia and other major
food-producing countries, particularly outside Europe, say a pessimistic view of
world food supplies is as unjustified today as it was in the days of Malthus.

They make these arguments:

* Farm productivity has been growing; in the United States it has risen 30
percent in the last decade.

* Future advances in technology offer the prospect of new plant varieties
resistant to insects, heat, drought, frost and disease.

* Wider use of technology now available could also increase food production.

Thus the experts, particularly in the United States, say the drought is masking
what they consider the main problem of the future for agricultural trade policy
- not a lack of food but an oversupply, stimulated by the $220 billion a year
that developed countries pay to subsidize farmers.

''In a world of subsidized agriculture, the long-term tendency to
over-production lurks only slightly below the surface,'' said Ewen M. Wilson,
the Agriculture Department's top economist.

Such views are sharply contested by other experts, who argue that changes may be
taking place in the world's environment that will make it more difficult for
underdeveloped countries to produce food or gain access to it at reasonable
prices.

Still, in global talks in Montreal last week, trade ministers from 96 countries
were arguing over American demands that the subsidies and other measures that
distort trade in agriculture be phased out early in the next century. The main
opposition came from the European Community, which rejects the notion that farm
protection should ever end.

When Europeans talk of farm subsidies, their arguments include the notion that
the world cannot be certain of an oversupply of food. They are also deeply
interested, for domestic political and social reasons, in preserving the
economic survival and way of life of their farmers.

In Montreal, the United States and the 12-nation European bloc were left in
deadlock. Trade ministers had some successes in other aspects of the
negotiations, whose aim was to advance a new round of trade liberalization
talks. But, in the end, the negotiators adopted a United States proposal to put
everything on hold for four months to give them a chance to break the farm
stalemate.

Washington is pressing Brussels on agriculture, American officials say, because
of ''near chaos'' in global agriculture - a condition they trace largely to
European policies. These policies, they say, stimulate overproduction, which in
turn results in the unloading of surpluses on the world. The Americans say this
undercuts the long-run ability of farmers in other countries to make a living.

Argentina and Uruguay export wheat and beef and are regarded as being among the
world's lowest-cost producers. Yet Barber B. Conable Jr., the World Bank
president, noted in Montreal that their share of the world market dropped from
11 percent to 3 percent over the last 15 years while the European Community
became one of the world's largest exporters. The United States also takes some
blame, for example, for tighter American import quotas that have cost Caribbean
islands $250 million in annual sugar exports.

But freer trade in agriculture has become such an important goal for the United
States that it has said it would drop its protection for sugar, dairy and other
American farmers if other countries cut supports as well.

On the other hand, the North American drought, by raising prices and thus
reducing the cost of export subsidies, has curbed some of the pressure on
Western Europe to restructure agriculture. Some experts argue that the effects
of the drought were made more severe by the so-called greenhouse effect,
described as a slow warming of the world that results particularly from the
burning of fossil fuels. In this view, the effort to get rid of subsidies is
misplaced because last summer's disaster will be repeated and the world needs to
protect agriculture in the interests of preserving food security.

''The talks in Montreal were focused on surpluses that may no longer exist, or
if they do exist are not real in the sense that they are being produced with the
unsustainable use of land and water,'' said Lester R. Brown, president of the
Worldwatch Institute.

Those who want farm trade policies restructured counter that the efficient
exporters who are best able to respond to shortages are the ones who could be
forced under by heavily subsidized competition. William M. Miner, a Canadian
agricultural expert, put the argument this way: ''Bad weather is not an excuse
for bad policies.''

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: Photo of Spanish farmer sowing seed (Black Star/Bob Krist); graph of
grain exports vs. imports, 1960-1988, by North America, Latin America, Western
Europe, Eastern Europe and U.S.S.R., Afria, Asia, Australia and New Zealand
(Source: Worldwatch Institute)

                              234 of 998 DOCUMENTS


                          The Globe and Mail (Canada)

                               May 9, 1988 Monday

REPORT ON THE NETHERLANDS   Agricultural trade rules prompt painful debate

BYLINE: DAVID CLIMENHAGA; GAM

LENGTH: 858 words

DATELINE: THE HAGUE, The Netherlands


By  DAVID CLIMENHAGA
 The Globe and Mail
  THE HAGUE, The Netherlands
  The vexing question of European agricultural policy is a painful one for
the Dutch, long renowned as energetic free traders.

The United States, demanding an end to all subsidies on agricultural
products by the year 2000, is pressing the European Community hard to come
up with an agricultural position sooon to put before the latest round of
the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.

Failure to reach agreement on agriculture, almost everyone agrees,
could destroy the GATT.

The EC, meanwhile, is hard pressed to reach agreement on agriculture
among its own members to put before the mid-term review of the so-called
GATT Uruguay round in Montreal in December.

For the Dutch - traditional free traders but loyal (and dependent)
members of the EC - the situation is distinctly uncomfortable. That the
Netherlands is the world's second-largest exporter of agricultural
products after the United States (and the world's largest in dairy and
poultry products), exporting more than 55 per cent of its total farm
output, compounds the discomfort.

More than 70 per cent of the country's agricultural exports go to the
EC, so bad news for the EC on agricultural policy is bad news for the
Netherlands. But the Dutch are still among the world's foremost traders,
so bad news for the GATT system is also bad news for the Netherlands.

"One should keep in mind that agriculture, for many reasons, is a bit
different from industrial sectors and services sectors," said Dutch
foreign trade minister Yvonne van Rooy. "It's not realistic to expect that
you can come to a new system where there's no protection, or no market
organization at all (for agriculture)."

"I believe that the Community is not able, in this year, to have
committed themselves completely to change their agriculture policy," said
Aart de Zeeuw, the Dutch Agriculture Ministry's director-general of
international affairs and chairman of the GATT agricultural negotiating
group. "That is impossible."

The U.S. position, Mrs. van Rooy argued, amounts to "get rid of all the
subsidies and trade barriers and then we will enter a sort of agricultural
paradise.

"Well, as you know, paradise does not exist on Earth, and not in
agriculture either. So I think the American position is not realistic."

In the months leading up to the mid-term talks in Montreal, Mrs. van
Rooy said, both the EC and the United States must be prepared to give a
little ground on the current positions.

"I think if we are prepared to discuss the long-term approach
(advocated by the United States) in the sense that we really have to
reduce our subsidies . . . the Americans and other trading partners, Japan
especially, should also be prepared to discuss the short-term approach."

Moreover, she said, "a country like Japan cannot say 'We are not a net
exporter, so it's none of our business.' They are a super net exporter in
industrial products, and therefore should allow in the field of
agriculture more imports into their country. They should not just sit
behind and leave the scene to Europe and the United States to do the
fighting."

The basis for a compromise, Mrs. van Rooy suggested, may be an approach
to subsidies developed by Mr. de Zeeuw under which the strong farm
subsidies in use today would be replaced by a system of fixed levies that
would still give farmers some protection from fluctuations in
international commodity prices.

Under his proposal, Mr. de Zeeuw said in an interview, agricultural
trading nations would agree to end practices such as direct payments to
farmers, variable levies on imports, quotas and export subsidies. They
would be replaced by import levies set at agreed-upon fixed levels.

The levies, which by agreement would not be subject to change, would
give farmers some protection from imports, but not nearly as much as in
the market-distorting norm today.

"What I say is you can have a different price on your own market than
on the international market and you can realize it by a fixed tariff . . .
so that your price is always 10 or 20 (European currency units) higher
than the international market . . . but it still goes up and down."

Despite the firm U.S. position and the danger to the GATT of no
compromise being found, Mr. de Zeeuw added, "I'm not too pessimistic about
the atmosphere between the United States and the Community.

"They know very well that they need to compromise at a certain moment.
I believe that within a few months they will try to be constructive. . . .

"The United States, in my view, is willing - if there is a commitment
that shows the direction (the EC will take) - to come to a compromise."

The political problem now facing the EC, Mr. de Zeeuw said, is to go at
least that far - to make a commitment by the end of the year on the
direction Western European agricultural policy will go.

The fundamental problem that confronts all parties to the world's
agricultural conundrum was summed up by Jan Bergman, director of the Dutch
Agriculture Ministry's economic affairs and market regulation departments:
"The Americans, the Canadians, the Europeans, they want free trade for
those products in which they have a good competitive position. Yes?"

                      The Financial Post (Toronto, Canada)

                    October 8, 1992, Thursday, DAILY EDITION

U.S. barley subsidy aims at EC

BYLINE: Associated Press

SECTION: SECTION 1, NEWS; Pg. 10

LENGTH: 137 words

DATELINE: Washington, DC


The U.S. Department of Agriculture yesterday announced a package of export
subsidies to help U.S. growers compete with the European Community for barley
malt sales in several overseas markets.

Ann Veneman, deputy secretary of agriculture, said the U.S. would subsidize
sales of up to 175,000 tonnes of U.S. barley malt through June 30, 1993.

The EC's barley malt subsidies, which total about two-thirds of the value of the
barley malt itself, ''hurt U.S. producers and cannot be left unchallenged,'' she
said.

''With today's announcement, we are continuing our efforts to pressure the EC to
reduce subsidies, curb expansion of its production of all commodities and make
meaningful policy reforms in the Uruguay Round of negotiations under the General
Agreement on Tariffs and Trade,'' Veneman said.

                                US Official News

                            April 13, 2016 Wednesday

National 4-H Conference Delegates Present to House Agriculture Committee

LENGTH: 409  words

DATELINE: Lahore



 Jackson: Growing Mississippi has issued the following news release:



  Yesterday, the House Agriculture Subcommittee on Biotechnology, Horticulture,
and Research gathered to hear a presentation by the National 4-H Conference
participants concerning the future of agriculture in the United States.





 The National 4-H Organization is the nation's largest youth development
organization that serves to help its six million student members better
understand the agriculture industry. Last year, members of the Agriculture
Committee heard from 17 distinguished 4-H delegates to the National 4-H
Conference whose presentation highlighted the importance of bridging the gap
between rural and urban areas. Today, that discussion continued with 16
delegates from this year's conference recognizing the challenges associated with
food and fiber production, how to enhance global food security, and how those
challenges affect the future of agriculture.



 "For the second year in a row, it has been a pleasure to hear from such
distinguished young leaders in the agriculture industry on what they believe to
be the biggest challenges and opportunities facing agriculture in the United
States. The National 4-H Organization is a great platform for young students of
both agriculture and non-agriculture related backgrounds to develop leadership
skills and learn about this great industry. As we work toward developing the
next farm bill, it is essential we hear from a wide variety of stakeholders on
where we can make meaningful improvements to agriculture policy. Today's
discussion provided a great opportunity to hear from some of these young
stakeholders on what they hope to see for the future of agriculture," said
Subcommittee Chairman Rodney Davis (R-IL).



 "It's great to see so many young people involved and committed to agriculture.
We're often reminded that the average age of a farmer is in the 50s, but we
don't always hear about the great number of youth involved. It's critical that
we continue to make transitioning a farm from one family member to another as
easy as possible, as well as support policies that help pave the way for the
next generation of farmers. Organizations like 4-H, which I participated in many
years ago, are an important part of achieving those goals," said Subcommittee
Ranking Member Suzan DelBene (D-WA).

                          The Globe and Mail (Canada)

                           September 6, 1983 Tuesday

U.S. ponders   more boards

BYLINE: GAM

LENGTH: 203 words


Critics of Canada's marketing boards often point to the United States to
 back up their claims. They attribute lower food prices there to the free
 enterprise structure of the U.S. food industry.

However, the United States has innumerable marketing boards of its own
 and is considering more, according to Dale May of the Agricultural
 Marketing Service of the U.S. Department of Agriculture.

Called marketing orders, the U.S. boards differ in several ways. But,
 as in Canada, some of them control prices and supplies, and others are
 involved in research, market promotion or quality control.

They are used by producers of milk, citrus fruits, potatoes, walnuts,
 hops, cotton and wool. Suppliers of eggs and flowers are considering new
 marketing boards for their products.

The milk boards are the most similar to their Canadian equivalent. A
 market administrator is appointed by the U.S. Secretary of Agriculture to
 oversee a region or a state. He sets the minimum farm gate price for milk
 and tries to even out production over the year.

In addition to the boards, U.S. food producers are also assisted by a
 range of federal subsidies which, according to some estimates, will cost
 the taxpayers up to $30-billion (U.S.) this year.

                              238 of 998 DOCUMENTS

                               The New York Times

              February 27, 1988, Saturday, Late City Final Edition

Farm Export Gains Seen

BYLINE: AP

SECTION: Section 1; Page 38, Column 4; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 164 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26


The Agriculture Department has predicted that the value of United States
agricultural exports will rise to a four-year high in the fiscal year 1988.

The new forecast, of $32.5 billion, is $500 million higher than the previous
estimate given Dec. 17. The increase stemmed from recent sales of grain to the
Soviet Union and China, partly under a special export subsidy program.

Steve MacDonald of the department's Economic Research Service said the Soviet
Union might account for $1.7 billion of the total exports in the fiscal year,
which began Oct. 1. That would be the most since 1985, when Moscow's purchases
totaled $2.5 billion. Soviet purchases last year were about $700 million.

China's purchases of American farm exports are expected to be about $500
million, more than double the $200 million of 1987, Mr. MacDonald said.

If the Agriculture Department projections are correct, the 1988 farm exports
will be the highest since 1984, when they were valued at $38 billion.

                              239 of 998 DOCUMENTS



                                US Official News

                           August 17, 2016 Wednesday

Washington: Brownsville Port of Entry CBP Agriculture Specialists Intercept
First in Port Pest in Corn

LENGTH: 299  words

DATELINE: New York



 Washington: U.S. Customs and Border Protection has issued the following news
release:



 Agriculture specialists with U.S. Customs and Border Protection, Office of
Field Operations (OFO) at the Veterans International Bridge import cargo lot
intercepted a "First in Port" pest in a shipment of fresh corn.





 "The interception of this miniscule, yet destructive pest, for the first time
at the Port of Brownsville, is an outstanding example of the diligence and
dedication of our CBP agriculture specialists in safeguarding the agriculture of
the United States," said Port Director Petra Horne, Brownsville Port of
Entry.The interception occurred on July 27, at the Veterans International Bridge
import lot when a shipment of fresh corn was referred to agriculture for
inspection.  Upon inspection of the corn, CBP agriculture specialists
intercepted a pest.  The pest was submitted for identification to a U.S.
Department of Agriculture (USDA) entomologist who identified it as Oncometopia
clarior (Walker) (Cicadellidae) an actionable pest. On July 28, 2016,
identifiers with U.S. Department of Agriculture Plant Inspection Station,
confirmed the interception of Oncometopia clarior (Walker) (Cicadellidae), as a
first time interception at the Port of Brownsville.



 Oncometopia clarior (Walker) is a pest not known to occur in the United States.
This insect belongs to the Cicadellidae family, commonly known as leafhoppers.
Many leafhoppers are serious pests of cultivated plants, and a few act as
vectors of plant diseases.



 Given the quarantine status of Oncometopia clarior (Walker), the shipment of
corn was re-exported to Mexico as a precautionary measure.

                                 EKantipur.com

                       July 17, 2015 Friday 2:08 PM  EST

US CUSTOMS AND BORDER PROTECTION AGRICULTURE SPECIALISTS IN FLORIDA INTERCEPT
FIRST-IN-PORT PEST AT PORT EVERGLADES

LENGTH: 327 words


FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., July 17 -- The U.S. Department of Homeland Security's
U.S. Customs and Border Protection issued the following press release:

U.S. Customs and Border Protection (CBP) Office of Field Operations (OFO)
agriculture specialists working at Port Everglades discovered a strange pest on
ginger arriving in a shipment from Lima, Peru on July 1.

Upon completing a visual and physical examination of the cargo, the container
was sealed pending quarantine action. Agriculture specialists submitted the pest
to the U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) Systematic Entomology Laboratory
and identified as Oliarus sp. (Cixiidae), an actionable pest confirmed to be a
"first-in-port" pest at Port Everglades.

Cixiid species are comparatively small and inconspicuous. Nymphs live
underground, feeding on roots. Adults feed on herbs, shrubs and/or trees. Some
are polyphagous, while others are specialized on their host plants (monophagous)
and feed on the juices of a variety of plants.

"Our CBP agriculture specialists are very skillful in identifying actionable
pests and determining all potential threats to agriculture in the United States
," said Port Everglades Port Director Jorge Roig. "We are proud of their hard
work every day on the job."

Each day, U.S. Customs and Border Protection (CBP) helps to prevent the
intentional and unintentional introduction of potentially harmful plant pests
and foreign animal diseases from entering the United States at more than 300
ports of entry.

Millions of pounds of fresh fruits, vegetables, cut flowers, herbs, and other
items enter the United States via commercial shipments from other countries
every year. In Fiscal Year 2014, there were 66,857 reportable pest
interceptions. View CBP's Agriculture Fact Sheet.

To see more CBP activity in Florida, visit @CBPFlorida on Twitter. For any query
with respect to this article or any other content requirement, please contact
Editor at htsyndication@hindustantimes.com

                              241 of 998 DOCUMENTS

                     Belfast News Letter (Northern Ireland)

                            April 17, 2004, Saturday

STATES IN CASH BOOST

SECTION: 1st Edition; NEWS; Pg. 11

LENGTH: 266 words


AGRICULTURE Secretary, Ann M Veneman, has announced that the United States
Department of Agriculture will contribute $ 8.8 million (pounds 4.9 million) to
two international research collaboratives seeking to control and eliminate
Johne's Disease in cattle, sheep and goats and porcine reproductive and
respiratory syndrome, or PRRS, in swine.

"These grants will support critical research, education and extension activities
to develop practical applications against these diseases," said Ms Veneman.

"We are pleased to partner with the University of Minnesota's College of
Veterinary Medicine on this project."

These diseases cause more than $ 800 million (pounds 446.5 million) a year in
losses to the industry and the consuming public.

"Project collaborators include more than 100 scientists and education experts
from two dozen institutions in 20 states as well as experts in Canada, Mexico,
Spain, Germany, the United Kingdom and Australia," said Joseph J Jen, USDA
undersecretary for Research, Education, and Economics.

PRRS first appeared in the United States in 1986 and is found worldwide and in
all major swine-producing areas of the United States. PRRS results in
reproductive failure in adult females and pneumonia in nursing pigs and can lead
to death. It spreads easily among herds.

Johne's Disease is a chronic, infectious, wasting disease of cattle. Symptoms
include chronic diarrhea and weight loss, decreased milk production, reduced
fertility, and eventually death.

An estimated 22 per cent of all US dairy herds are infected with Johne's
Disease.

PUB-TYPE: PAPER

                              242 of 998 DOCUMENTS

                               The New York Times

               November 13, 1981, Friday, Late City Final Edition

COMMODITIES;
Grains, Soybeans Rise On Foreign-Sale Rumor

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

SECTION: Section D; Page 12, Column 5; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 402 words


Grain and soybean futures prices rose a little yesterday amid rumors of foreign
demand, some of which were confirmed following the close.

During the session, there were numerous rumors that China and the Soviet Union
were in the market for sizable amounts of soybeans and that the Soviet Union,
China and India were buying wheat and corn.

After the close, the United States Agriculture Department said private exporters
reported the sale of 100,000 tons of wheat to unknown destinations and 400,000
tons of wheat and 325,000 tons of corn to the Soviet Union.

Analysts said European markets were active as the United States dollar declined
against foreign currencies, a development that improves the exchange rate and so
tends to encourage foreign buying.

Higher Bids Reported

Meanwhile, a major exporting concern reportedly increased its bids on soybeans
in the cash market at Gulf of Mexico export locations.

Some traders were reportedly evening up their contract positions ahead of the
Agriculture Department's crop production report released after the close.

It projected that the United States corn crop now being harvested would be a
record 8.1 billion bushels, up 22 percent from last year's crop and slightly
more than projected a month ago. Soybean production was put at 2.08 billion
bushels, up 16 percent from the 1980 harvest of 1.82 billion bushels and 1
percent lower than what was forecast a month ago. Analysts later said the
figures were on the low side of market expectations and could prompt a little
buying today.

On the Chicago Board of Trade, wheat settled yesterday as much as 5 1/4 cents
higher, with the contract for delivery in December at $4.35 3/4 a bushel, and
corn 3 cents higher, with December at $2.81 1/2 a bushel.

On the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange in New York, coffee prices rose sharply
as traders focused again on the possibility that supplies certified for delivery
against the futures contract will not be sufficient to cover outstanding
contracts. December-delivery coffee rose 4.41 cents, to 148.86 a pound.

Cattle prices were mostly higher and pork fell on the Chicago Mercantile
Exchange. Analysts cited weaker prices for hogs at livestock terminals in the
morning and expectations for weaker prices today.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                   Copyright 1981 The New York Times Company

                          The Globe and Mail (Canada)

                          November 24, 1999 Wednesday

Canada's agriculture trade rules criticized

BYLINE: HEATHER SCOFFIELD Parliamentary Bureau

SECTION: REPORT ON BUSINESS: CANADIAN; Pg. B8

LENGTH: 317 words

DATELINE: Ottawa


Criticism about the federal government's position on agriculture at the World
Trade Organization is growing, both within and outside of Canada.

New Zealand's special agricultural trade envoy and Saskatchewan's Agriculture
Minister yesterday accused Ottawa of being hypocritical, by promoting the end of
subsidies for grains but requesting protection for Canada's dairy and poultry
industries.

"Canada still wants to have special treatment in terms of supply management,"
complained New Zealand envoy Malcolm Bailey.

New Zealand is counting on Canada's support to fight massive grain subsidies
dished out by the European Union and the United States, he said. And since
Canadian grain farmers would benefit from such a reduction in subsidies, Canada
should also be prepared to give up some of its protectionist measures such as
supply management of dairy, poultry and eggs.

Federal Agriculture Minister Lyle Vanclief has said that Canada will fight hard
for the reduction of domestic and export subsidies for agriculture during the
round of multilateral trade talks due to be launched next week in Seattle.

Saskatchewan Agriculture Minister Dwain Lingenfelter said yesterday that Ottawa
was not taking a strong enough stand against the high grain subsidies paid by
the European Union and the United States. And while Ottawa has slashed its
subsidies to grain farmers in the West, it is actively campaigning to protect
dairy and poultry producers in Ontario and Quebec.

"They're not speaking up loudly enough against [European] subsidies, and at the
same time they've disqualified one part of Canada for subsidies," he said.

The Canadian Wheat Board pleaded with the federal government to increase aid to
Prairie farmers.

"Many Western Canadian farmers, despite being as or more efficient than their
U.S. and EU counterparts, are going broke," Greg Arason, chief executive officer
of the wheat board, said yesterday.

                                Vanguard (Lagos)

                             April 16, 2012 Monday

Agric to Become Mainstay of Local Economy - Adesina

LENGTH: 514 words

DATELINE: Abuja


MINISTER of Agriculture and Rural Development, Dr Akinwunmi Adesina, weekend,
said Nigeria was set to reclaim her pride of place in agriculture as the main
stay of the economy.

The minister made this statement at the just concluded agric business summit
organised by the Embassy of Nigeria and Corporate Council on Africa, CCA, with
support from the World Bank.

Dr. Adesina in his address, "articulated investment opportunities in Nigeria's
agricultural sector. He noted that agriculture accounts for 75% of the growth of
the non-oil sector of the Nigerian economy, and assured that the present
administration is "creating enabling environment, developing infrastructure,
safeguarding investments, reducing official bottlenecks and motivating local and
international investors."

The minister confidently proclaimed the feasibility of reclaiming the former
glory of Nigeria as a net exporter of food from its current net importer
position.

One of the panel discussion focused on the huge potential for tomato paste
processing and fresh produce grading and packaging export centres.

The Minister's presentation, which drew applause, triggered more than a dozen
prospective investors to meet with him after his presentation.

A former US Ambassador to Nigeria, Amb. Howard Jeter said "we are deeply
impressed with the calibre, knowlege and vision of the Minister of Agriculture
of Nigeria. This is Nigeria at its best".

If Nigeria keeps on this way it will become Africa's leader in agriculture". The
Vice President of the US-Exim Bank, Wanda Felton, praised the Nigerian Minister
of Agriculture for "smart leadership" in steering a revolution of agriculture as
a business, with several concrete results, in such a short time in office. "This
has a huge potential to transform Nigeria's economy and diversify it away from
oil and gas", she said.

Nigeria's Vice President, Namadi Sambo led the high-powered delegation, which
also included the governors of Rivers, Kaduna, Kwara, Nasarawa and Ekiti States.
The event witnessed a sell-out capacity of 600 registered attendees from across
the United States of America and Nigeria.

Among other high profile participants at the forum were Sanusi Lamido, Governor
of the Central Bank, Evelyn Oputu of the Bank of Industries, CEO of Union Bank,
Funke Osibodu, CEO of Nigerian Stock Exchange, Oscar Onyema, Former United
States Ambassador to Nigeria, Robin Sanders, Chairman, Nigerian Economic Summit
Group, Foluso Phillips, who moderated the panel discussion on Nigeria's
Agribusiness Investment Climate and Financing Framework.

Managing Director of Nigeria Export-Import Bank, Robert Orya, and his United
States counterpart, Rick Angiuoni, Regional Director of Export-Import Bank of
the United States, CEO of Dominion Farms Limited, Calvin Burgess, who recently
signed a $40 million investment partnership with Taraba state government in
collaboration with the Federal Ministry of Agriculture and Rural Development,
while Timothy Prewitt of USAID MARKETS highlighted on the role of market in
ensuring the success of the Agricultural Transformation Agenda.

United States of America, as represented by the Secretary of Agriculture, titled
as "Carbonated Estolides And Methods Of Making And Using The Same"  for the

                              246 of 998 DOCUMENTS

                               The New York Times

                 March 9, 1994, Wednesday, Late Edition - Final

FUTURES MARKETS;
Prospects of Weak Demand Push Corn to 4-Month Low

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

SECTION: Section D;  Page 16;  Column 1;  Financial Desk

LENGTH: 419 words


Corn futures prices dropped to a four-month low yesterday on the Chicago Board
of Trade amid prospects for a bigger South African crop and weaker demand for
United States corn.

Corn for March delivery fell 5 cents, to $2.7575 a bushel, the lowest settlement
for near-term deliveries since Nov. 11.

The March corn contract has lost 11.5 percent of its value since Jan. 13, when
it traded at a five-and-a-half- year high of $3.1175 a bushel. The market's
decline has been partly a result of slack demand for American corn.


South Africa

The prospects for weak demand weighed even more heavily on the market yesterday
after the attache in South Africa for the United States Agriculture Department
put that country's 1993-94 crop, which is nearly ready for harvest, at 14
million metric tons, 2 million more than the previous estimate.

The news means world demand for American corn could decline by up to 2 million
metric tons, or 78.8 million bushels, according to Gerald Zusel, a vice
president of E.D.& F. Man International Futures in Chicago.

"If South Africa has an additional two million tons, you could almost add that
back to the U.S. carry-out," he said. "That's going to reduce tightness in the
United States."

Last month, the Agriculture Department estimated the United States corn
carry-out, or ending stocks, at 777 million bushels on Aug. 31, the end of the
1993-94 marketing year.


Wheat Drops

Wheat futures sank as precipitation fell in the winter wheat fields of the
southern plains. A storm pounded south-central Kansas and the Texas and Oklahoma
panhandles with snow and thunderstorms.

March wheat fell 4.25 cents, to $3.38 a bushel, the lowest settlement since Nov.
9; March oats slipped 1 cent, to $1.2550 a bushel, and March soybeans fell 2.25
cents, to $6.6325 a bushel.

The Agriculture Department's rejection of an Egyptian bid for 200,000 metric
tons of United States wheat at subsidized prices also weighed on wheat futures,
analysts said.

Crude oil futures ended unchanged on the New York Mercantile Exchange, an
indication that traders continued to expect that the Organization of Petroleum
Exporting Countries would make no change in oil production at a March 25
meeting.

Light sweet crude for April delivery finished unchanged at $14.10 a barrel;
April heating oil slipped 0.02 cent, to 43.35 cents a gallon; April unleaded
gasoline rose 0.14 cent, to 43.89 cents a gallon, and April natural gas climbed
2.9 cents, to $2.196 for 1,000 cubic feet.

                              247 of 998 DOCUMENTS


                        The International Herald Tribune

                            January 24, 2006 Tuesday

Mandelson calls for farm tariff concession

BYLINE: Dan Bilefsky

SECTION: FINANCE; Pg. 12

LENGTH: 604 words

DATELINE: PARIS


Peter Mandelson, the European Union's chief trade negotiator, warned on Monday
that Europe's offer to cut its agriculture tariffs could evaporate if trading
partners like Brazil, India and the United States did not come forward with
further concessions.

''I cannot sell a deal in which Europe gives but gets nothing in return,''
Mandelson said in a speech in Berlin after meeting with Chancellor Angela Merkel
and Foreign Minister Frank-Walter Steinmeier. ''That is not a negotiation that
is a capitulation.''

Mandelson's defiant words came just two days before trade ministers are to meet
at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, in an effort to break a
deadlock in negotiations. At a meeting in Hong Kong last month, World Trade
Organization members gave themselves an April 30 deadline to hammer out a
compromise for opening trade in agriculture, services and industrial goods.

Trade analysts said Mandelson's hardening stance showed that little progress had
been made since Hong Kong and warned that a trade deal appeared increasingly
unlikely.

Richard Portes, director of the Center for Economic Policy Research in London,
said Merkel could potentially push a recalcitrant France to make more
concessions on agriculture reform, while acting as an interlocutor with the
United States. But he added that she had shown few signs so far of making trade
liberalization a priority.

''The only person who could make a difference is Merkel, who has unrivaled
popularity at home and is widely recognized as someone who is not caught up on
old arguments,'' he said. ''But she has a lot on her plate.''

People close to Mandelson said he and Merkel had agreed that progress depended
on developing countries like Brazil slashing industrial tariffs in key areas and
the United States easing demands for European cuts in agriculture.

''Merkel agreed that Mandelson was already at the outer limits of his
negotiation mandate and could not budge further,'' said a person present at the
talks who requested anonymity because of the sensitivity of the negotiations.

In his speech, Mandelson said Washington's excessive focus on agriculture was
threatening the talks. He said the United States, which will overhaul its own
farm programs next year, was using global trade negotiations for domestic ends.
And he warned that the EU would not accept ''post-dated checks'' written by
Washington, referring to a U.S. offer to cut subsidies on an unquantified basis
at some unspecified point in the future. ''The EU and the United States broadly
want the same things, but the different negotiating tactics are preventing us
from getting them,'' he said in an interview. ''Unless we close those
differences, we stand to lose what's on offer in agriculture.''

Christin Baker, spokeswoman for the U.S. trade representative, Robert Portman,
said congressional support for the United States' aggressive proposals to slash
subsidies and make deep tariff cuts depended on the EU providing greater market
access in agriculture.

''Agriculture remains the sticking point and everyone agrees that Europe hasn't
gone far enough,'' she said.

The EU has offered a 38 percent average cut in farm tariffs and an end to its
export subsidies by 2013. Washington argues this does not go far enough and has
proposed that wealthy nations cut their lowest tariffs by 55 percent and their
highest by 90 percent.

Mandelson said the EU's ability to cajole developing countries into opening
their markets for high-end exports from Europe was dependent on Europe dropping
''unreasonable'' import duties on inexpensive mass-produced goods from countries
like India and Brazil .

                          The Globe and Mail (Canada)

                             May 23, 1985 Thursday

U.S. grain plan   may hurt price

BYLINE: CP

LENGTH: 264 words

DATELINE: Ottawa ONT


Canadian Press
    OTTAWA  - Canada can depend on its good relations with the United
 States to help protect grain prices against the $2-million U.S. grain
 bonus plan announced last week, Agriculture Minister John Wise says.

"We can take some satisfaction in the fact that the U.S. Secretary of
Agriculture (John Block) indicated to me that he would do everything  possible
so that we would not get caught in the crossfire," he told the  House of
Commons.

Mr. Wise said he "expressed some concern" when Mr. Block informed him
 late last week of the program and the two plan further discussion "in the
 very near future regarding the issue, but I think we can take some
 satisfaction because of the improved relations between the two countries
 that has taken place and developed since Sept. 4."
    But Liberal agriculture critic Maurice Foster said the new program,
 which would make $2-million worth of grain available starting June 1 for
 bonuses to countries which purchase grain from the United States, "could
 have a very distorting and devastating impact on the price of grains in
 the world, perhaps even touching off a price war.
    "It sounds to me like the Minister was more of a pussycat than someone
 really defending the interests of agriculture in this country," Mr. Foster
 told Mr. Wise in the Commons.

A spokesman for the Department of Agriculture said the bonuses would
 effectively reduce the price of U.S. wheat and reduce world prices. Canada
 would likely have to lower its prices as well but full details of the
 program and its effects are not yet known, the spokesman said.

                               The New York Times

              December 29, 1981, Tuesday, Late City Final Edition

U.S. REPORTS A RISE IN FARMS

BYLINE: AP

SECTION: Section B; Page 12, Column 5; National Desk

LENGTH: 238 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 28


The number of farms in the United States increased this year for the first time
since the Depression, the Agriculture Department said today.

Some of the increase was attributed to higher agricultural produce prices. The
department defines a farm as a place that sells $1,000 of produce. Because of
price levels, some places that may have offered $800 in produce for sale, for
example, may get $1,000 for the same goods, and qualify as a farm.

But officials also said there is an increase in the number of small farmers,
particularly in the West.

8,000 Farms Added in a Year

It was estimated that there are 2,436,000 farms, or 8,000 more than in 1980, an
increase of three-tenths of 1 percent. The trend is expected to continue next
year, adding 1,000 farms to the total, the department said.

The increase is the first in 46 years. The Government reported an increase to
6,810,000 in 1935 from 6,780,000 farms in 1934. The decline has been steady
since.

There was a rise in farming this years in the West and, to a lesser degree, in
the East. The yearly decline in number of farms leveled off in the Middle West
and, in general, elsewhere.

Decline in Farms Has Slowed

While the decline in the number of farms in the Middle West has been steady,
that trend has been tapering off there and elsewhere.  Nationally, from 1975 to
1980, the numbers have been stable.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                                US Official News

                           September 23, 2016 Friday

Washington: Philadelphia CBP Intercepts a Nationâ[#x20ac][TM]s First

LENGTH: 391  words

DATELINE: New York



 Washington: U.S. Customs and Border Protection has issued the following news
release:



 The U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) recently confirmed the tiger moth
that U.S. Customs and Border Protection (CBP) agriculture specialists
intercepted in a shipment of Colombian apple bananas at the Philadelphia seaport
is the nation's first recorded find of this species.





 CBP agriculture specialists discovered the insect specimen on August 8 during a
routine produce container inspection and submitted the pest to the local USDA
entomologist for identification. The following day, the entomologist determined
the specimen to be Cosmosoma ruatana (Erebidae) with an additional comment that
this specimen is a new pest.  On September 9, the USDA national pest
identification database confirmed the specimen as the first reported discovery
of Cosmosoma ruatana (Erebidae) in the United States.Insects belonging to the
family Erebidae, or tiger moths, are considered polyphagous, which makes them
potential pests of concern to many different agriculture crops.



 "Intercepting destructive insect invaders at our nation's borders, before they
can threaten our agriculture industries, is of great importance to Customs and
Border Protection," said Margaret Braunstein, Acting CBP Area Port Director for
the Port of Philadelphia. "CBP agriculture specialists take their job very
seriously, and this 'First-in-Nation' insect interception is a significant
discovery."



 CBP agriculture specialists have extensive training and experience in the
biological sciences, risk analysis, and imported agriculture inspection
techniques.  CBP agriculture specialists are the first line of defense in the
protection of U.S. agriculture, forest, and livestock industries from exotic
destructive plant pests and animal diseases.



 On a typical day nationally, CBP agriculture specialists inspect over one
million people as well as cargo arriving by air and sea to the United States.
They also intercept approximately 4,548 prohibited meat, plant materials, or
animal products, and discover over 470 agriculture pests and diseases that could
have detrimental effects to our nation's agriculture resources, food production,
and animal and human health.

                               The New York Times

                June 4, 1983, Saturday, Late City Final Edition

Around the Nation;
Judge Bars Milk Support Paid by the Farmers

BYLINE: AP

SECTION: Section 1; Page 6, Column 6; National Desk

LENGTH: 159 words

DATELINE: COLUMBIA, S.C., June 3


A Federal district judge ordered the United States Department of Agriculture
today to stop making dairy farmers help finance milk price supports and to
return to them more than $21 million that had been collected.

The Agriculture Department last month began taking 50 cents for every 100 pounds
of milk sold by dairy farmers after the United States Court of Appeals for the
Fourth Circuit overturned a temporary restraining order against the assessments,
which was issued by District Judge Matthew Perry.

That order was handed down in April after the State of South Carolina and
several dairy farmer groups sued to halt the fees.  The appeals court dissolved
the order last month so that collection could begin while Judge Perry heard
arguments on the merits of the case. And today, after hearing those arguments,
Judge Perry issued his injuction blocking the collection of the funds.

                               The New York Times

                             June 28, 2014 Saturday
                              Late Edition - Final

U.S. Catfish Program Could Stymie Pacific Trade Pact, 10 Nations Say

BYLINE: By RON NIXON

SECTION: Section A; Column 0; National Desk; Pg. 15

LENGTH: 826 words


WASHINGTON -- Ten Asian and Pacific nations have told the Office of the United
States Trade Representative that the Agriculture Department's catfish inspection
program violates international law, and their objections could hamper Obama
administration efforts to reach a major Pacific trade agreement by the end of
next year.

They say that the inspection program is a trade barrier erected under the guise
of a food safety measure and that it violates the United States' obligations
under World Trade Organization agreements. Among the countries protesting are
Vietnam and Malaysia, which are taking part in talks for the trade agreement --
known as the Trans-Pacific Partnership -- and have the ability to derail or hold
up those negotiations.

The complaints are outlined in a May 28 letter signed by diplomats from the 10
countries. The letter does not threaten retaliation, but it emphasizes that the
American catfish program stood in the way of the trade talks.

Vietnam, a major catfish producer, has long complained about the program, but it
has never before won international support for its fight. Several of the
countries whose representatives signed the letter -- including the Philippines,
Myanmar, Thailand and Indonesia -- do not have catfish industries to protect and
are not involved in the trans-Pacific trade talks.

But the letter expresses the concern that the inspection program could lead the
Agriculture Department to expand its ability to regulate seafood exports to the
United States, catfish or not.

''Many of these countries are looking to see what happens to Vietnam on the
catfish issues, and what precedents it might set for other trade deals in the
region,'' said Jeffrey J. Schott, a senior fellow at the Peterson Institute for
International Economics in Washington and the co-author of a book on the
Trans-Pacific Partnership. The United States and 11 countries on both sides of
the Pacific -- as well as Australia, New Zealand and Brunei -- are still
negotiating the trade pact, which has been repeatedly delayed over various
disputes.

The Vietnam Association of Seafood Exporters and Producers recently hired James
Bacchus, a former chairman of the World Trade Organization's appeals panel, to
prepare a possible legal challenge to the catfish inspection program.

Mr. Bacchus said in an interview that only governments have standing to bring a
case before the trade organization, but that the export group was working
closely with Vietnamese officials to monitor the catfish inspection program.

''I'm confident that Vietnam would have a case before the W.T.O. if they decided
to bring one,'' said Mr. Bacchus, a former United States House member from
Florida who is now a lawyer with Greenberg Traurig in Washington.

The inspection program was inserted into the 2008 farm bill at the urging of
catfish farmers, who have been hurt by competition from both Vietnam and China
and by the rising cost of catfish feed. The domestic catfish industry has shrunk
by about 60 percent since its peak about a decade ago, and in the past few years
about 20 percent of American catfish farming operations have closed.

The catfish industry and lawmakers led by Senator Thad Cochran, Republican of
Mississippi, fought for the new office, saying it was needed to protect
Americans from eating fish raised in unsanitary conditions or contaminated with
drugs. The Food and Drug Administration has a similar program, but it inspects
less than 2 percent of food imports, and advocates of the Agriculture Department
program said that was not good enough.

The Agriculture Department has traditionally inspected meat and poultry, while
the F.D.A. has been responsible for all other foods, including seafood.

Agriculture Department inspections are more stringent than those conducted by
the F.D.A. The Agriculture Department also requires nations that export beef,
pork and poultry to the United States to set up inspections that are equivalent
to the agency's program -- an expensive and burdensome regulation that Vietnam
says is unnecessary for catfish. A Government Accountability Office report in
May 2012 called imported catfish a low-risk food and said an Agriculture
Department inspection program would ''not enhance the safety of catfish.''

The Agriculture Department said it had spent $20 million since 2009 to set up
its office, which has a staff of four, although it has yet to inspect a single
catfish. The department said it expected to spend about $14 million a year to
run the program; the F.D.A., by comparison, spends about $700,000 annually on
its existing seafood inspection office.

Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona, and other critics say the
Agriculture Department program is a waste of money, and Mr. McCain sponsored an
amendment in the latest farm bill that would have killed the program. But the
measure was never brought up for a vote. The Obama administration has also
called for eliminating the Agriculture Department program.

URL:
http://www.nytimes.com/2014/06/28/us/catfish-inspection-trans-pacific-partnershi
p.html

LOAD-DATE: June 28, 2014

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

program was called a trade barrier in a letter. (PHOTOGRAPH BY JUSTIN MOTT FOR
THE NEW YORK TIMES)

                      The Financial Post (Toronto, Canada)

                  December 26, 1992, Saturday, WEEKLY EDITION

Russia's unpaid debts mount up

BYLINE: Reuter

SECTION: SECTION 1, NEWS; Pg. 10

LENGTH: 219 words

DATELINE: Washington, DC


Russia's defaults on U.S. agricultural loans jumped Thursday to US$95.7 million
as banks filed 20 default notices totalling US$27.4 million, the U.S.
Agriculture Department said.

Russia has been suspended from the department's food credit program since late
November for failing to make scheduled payments on loans that enabled it to buy
millions of tons of U.S. grains and other food.

Russia still owes more than US$4 billion for the three-year loans it has
received since January 1991. The loans are offered by private banks, but backed
by the U.S. government.

So far no banks have filed claims for the government to reimburse them.

Banks filed the default notices before the holiday weekend and in some cases did
not wait the usual 10-day period to file claims after payments came due, an
Agriculture Department spokeswoman said. No more notices were expected before
Monday.

She said notices have been filed by six banks so far.

Banking sources say they doubt Russia will resume repaying the loans until it
settles on a debt-restructuring plan with its major creditor nations.

Meanwhile, Russia's suspension from the credit program has weighed on grain
prices as U.S. farmers have come to depend on the vast former Soviet Union
market to absorb much of their surplus production.
