                              254 of 998 DOCUMENTS


                               The New York Times

                              July 30, 2004 Friday
                              Late Edition - Final

Geneva Talks Move Toward Farm Pact

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH BECKER

SECTION: Section W; Column 3; Business/Financial Desk; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 1127 words

DATELINE: GENEVA, July 29


Working into the early hours of Thursday, five crucial players, including the
United States and the European Union, reached an informal agreement on
agriculture that has put global trade talks back on track, although behind
schedule.

Supachai Panitchpakdi, the director general of the World Trade Organization,
released a statement Thursday afternoon saying he welcomed the incipient
agreement on agriculture, which he said gives momentum to the talks.

With less than two days remaining, delegates and officials said that the United
States in particular had made significant compromises on Wednesday night,
inspiring optimism that the talks would lead to an agreement and advance the
Doha round of trade for the developing nations.

''I think it looks good,'' said Arancha Gonzalez, spokeswoman for Pascal Lamy,
the top trade official for the European Union.

While officials were reluctant to disclose specifics on the discussions or even
describe them as an agreement, they did say that the United States seemed
willing to put off some of its more contentious demands on agricultural
subsidies and, instead, offer to make cuts in other areas.

The United States had been the focus of attacks on Wednesday by some poor
countries for failing to make specific compromises in agriculture. Agriculture
has been so crucial to this round of talks that the World Bank has said that an
agreement could add $3 trillion in benefits to the global market place.

Attempts to reach an agreement last year in Cancun, Mexico, ended in failure.
Rich countries were accused of catering to their largest commercial farmers who
receive $300 billion in subsidies and supports every year to the detriment of
farmers in poor countries who cannot compete against the subsidized commodities.

However, in talks Wednesday through the early Thursday, the European Union's
offer of eliminating its export subsidies was matched by an American proposal
that was described as a cut in trade-distorting domestic subsidies in the first
year of a new trade accord, according to officials close to the discussions who
spoke on the condition of anonymity.

If that holds, the likelihood of an agreement improves, particularly because it
could satisfy the poor West African nations that have been demanding that the
United States end its cotton subsidy.

Richard Mills, the spokesman for Robert B. Zoellick, the United States trade
representative, refused to comment on details of the talks, but said they were
very useful.

''We're being realistic,'' he said after the talks that lasted until nearly 2
a.m. Thursday. ''We're not pessimistic, and we're not optimistic.''

Australia, Brazil and India were the other three countries meeting with the
United States and the European Union in a group known as the Five Interested
Parties. Together they are the crucial factions that must agree if the entire
147-member party is to reach an accord this week.

Now top officials at the World Trade Organization must assemble the compromises
suggested by this group, and a handful of other blocs representing the richest
and the poorest farmers of the world, and publish a text of an accord. Officials
were expecting that text by midnight on Thursday.

With an agreement on agriculture close, new questions were raised about efforts
to lower trade barriers to industrial goods, especially in the poorer,
developing countries. Wealthy countries argued that since they were overhauling
their agricultural programs, the developing world should further open their
markets to industrial goods.

But African delegates said that further negotiations were necessary to make this
an equal trade-off.

While most delegates met behind closed doors, several African officials held a
news briefing on Wednesday singling out the United States as a barrier to a
trade accord because of its cotton subsidies.

''Thousands and thousands of small farmers are being destroyed, their families
going hungry because of the unfair subsidies of American cotton,'' said Ousmane
Ngom, Senegal's minister of trade, who represents one of the four African
nations that have pressed for emergency relief from what they call unfair
trading practices on cotton.

For its part, the United States has offered some development assistance from its
existing aid programs. But it has been reluctant to single out cotton for deeper
subsidy cuts than other basic commodity programs, which include corn, wheat,
soybeans and rice, to avoid an unsettling precedent.

The African ministers agreed to put cotton back into overall agriculture talks,
but called the news conference to warn they had reached their bottom line and
were waiting for a response from Mr. Zoellick and the American delegation.

Then later Wednesday night, at least 27 countries registered their complaints
that the group negotiating behind closed doors was being accorded too great a
role in the talks. China, Malaysia, Chile and Japan were among the countries
voicing concerns.

China and Chile are powerful members of the Group of 20 developing nations that
was formed in Cancun last year to push the wealthy nations to cut their
agricultural supports.

Japan, which puts a 490 percent tariff on rice, is an outspoken member of the
Group of 10 wealthy countries that includes Norway and Switzerland. They have
joined with the European Union in asking for continued protections on what they
call sensitive products, a proposition that has been criticized by developing
nations.

Mr. Lamy was under pressure, as well, with European ministers gathering in
Geneva to meet and assess whatever new draft text is produced. Led by President
Jacques Chirac of France, several European countries including Hungary, Italy
and Poland -- allies of the United States in Iraq -- were concerned that Europe
had made greater concessions than the United States on agriculture and that
their farmers would suffer as a result.

But Mr. Zoellick has promised that the United States would be a leader in this
round of talks and has traveled around the world to wring out a compromise,
however vague, on agriculture.

''Although we won't unilaterally disarm,'' Mr. Mills, the American spokesman,
said, ''we are committed to global reform in the W.T.O. and the United States
has stated its willingness to cut subsidies and tariffs if others will.''

Phil Bloomer, the director of Oxfam International's Make Trade Fair Campaign
that has focused on European and American farm subsidies, said that the United
States had to make a serious concession immediately.

''The European Union has said it will eliminate export subsidies and give an end
date,'' Mr. Bloomer said. ''The West African nations made the concession of
putting cotton inside agricultural talks. Now its up to the United States to
make a similar concession.''



URL: http://www.nytimes.com

LOAD-DATE: July 30, 2004

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

United States to reduce its subsidies. (Photo by Alexandre Meneghini/Associated
Press)

                          The Globe and Mail (Canada)

                             August 29, 1986 Friday

Ottawa demands halt in U.S., EC trade war

BYLINE: OLIVER BERTIN; The Globe and Mail

SECTION: ROB; Pg. B5

LENGTH: 583 words


In a hard-hitting statement released in Cairns, Australia, federal
 Wheat Board Minister Charles Mayer warned the United States and the EC
 that their farm policies have severely distorted the world market in
 wheat, and that Canada is suffering.

He told them to "restrain both the production and the release of
 (wheat) to the world market." If they cannot figure out how, then Canada
 will tell them how at the next meeting of the International Wheat Council
 in Washington early next year.

The statement was supported by Australian Trade Minister John Dawkins
 and Lucio Reca, Agriculture Secretary of Argentina.

Australia, Argentina and Canada export wheat in competition with the
 United States and the EC.

Mr. Mayer was in Cairns for a meeting of 14 agricultural nations. The
 countries said they are the victims of a trade war between the United
 States and the EC that is costing them billions of dollars every year in
 lost sales and depressed prices.

They have formed an international trading alliance called Fair Traders
 in Agriculture to bring pressure on the United States and the EC to end
 their agricultural trade war. The members include: Canada, Australia, New
 Zealand, Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Fiji, Hungary, Indonesia,
 Malaysia, the Philippines, Thailand and Uruguay.

The EC is believed to spend about $100-billion (U.S.) annually on farm
 support programs and the United States about $35-billion. By comparison,
 Canada spends about $4.5-billion (Canadian) and Australia far less.

These large subsidies have severely distorted the world markets in
 grain, livestock and sugar, and caused global economic losses of $36-
 billion (U.S.) in 1980 dollars, according to a World Bank report released
 at the meeting.

Farmers in developing countries bear the brunt of the losses, about
 $28-billion a year, and this has intensified the rural poverty and human
 misery in the Third World, the bank said.

"But it has done more than this," Australian Prime Minister Robert
 Hawke said. "It has seriously undermined the capacity of these
 (developing) countries to service their external debt.

"As many as one in five western Canadian wheat farmers may be forced
 out of business and, in Australia's case, the (EC subsidy) policy has been
 costing about $1-billion (Australian) a year in recent years."

Mr. Mayer did not place a figure on Canada's losses, but the premiers
 of the three Prairie provinces have asked Ottawa for a $1-billion cash
 payment to compensate them for the effects of the trade war.

The United States will not volunteer to cut food production - despite
 Canada's threats - but it will try to scale down farm subsidies within two
 years, said Daniel Amstutz, U.S. undersecretary of agriculture.

He told reporters in Washington yesterday that he will try to speed up
 farm negotiations when the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade comes up
 for discussion in Uruguay next month.

"This fast track on agriculture is of fundamental importance to our
 position," he said. "We really want this agriculture thing put to bed in
 two years because (otherwise) the problems are enormous."

He said the United States was willing to compromise, but only if the EC
 and other exporters do so as well. "We have said time and time again that
 we're willing to put everything on the table and we think others should
 too."

However, he added that "I have no illusions about the difficulty" of
 the negotiations.

The EC, at the instigation of France, has so far refused to place
 agriculture on the agenda at the GATT talks.

LOAD-DATE: January 12, 2007

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


 Copyright 1986 The Globe and Mail, a division of CTVglobemedia Publishing Inc.

                                US Official News

                             March 13, 2015 Friday

MARYLAND:Maryland Celebrates National Agriculture Week; 10 Ways You Can Get
Involved With Maryland Agriculture

LENGTH: 412  words

DATELINE: Annapolis


Department of Agriculture, The state of Maryland has issued the following news
release:

Did you know that most of life's necessities - food, fiber, clothing and shelter
- start with agriculture? National Agriculture Week (March 15-21) recognizes and
celebrates the contributions of agriculture to American society. In recognition
of Maryland agriculture as one of the state's most important industries,
Governor Larry Hogan has declared "Maryland Agriculture Week," which coincides
with the national celebration. From the mountains of Western Maryland with its
dairy farms and hay to Central Maryland with its greenhouse and livestock
industries to the Eastern Shore's acres of corn and poultry - Maryland truly
grows something for everyone.

"Maryland's agriculture industry is vital to the long-term health of the state's
economy, environment and quality of life," said Governor Hogan. "Maryland
farmers are doing everything they can to balance protecting our Bay with
building strong, durable businesses. And we're going to do everything we can to
keep Maryland's agricultural industry strong, diverse and sustainable."

There are 2.1 million farms in the United States, a country with nearly 319
million people. Agriculture products remain the nations' top export. Each
American farmer today feeds more than 144 people - a dramatic increase from 25
people in the 1960s. American agriculture is doing more - and doing it better.
As the world population soars, there is an even greater demand for the food and
fiber produced in the United States.

"Agriculture Week is a great time to recognize the hard work of our farm
families and the important role they play in providing a safe and abundant food
supply and protecting the environment," said Agriculture Secretary Joe
Bartenfelder.

In Maryland, one-third of the land mass - over 2 million acres - is farmland. In
2013, the top commodity sectors were poultry (broilers), greenhouse and nursery,
corn, and dairy. In addition, Maryland farmers produced 33 million pounds of
apples, 673 million eggs, 3.9 million tons of peaches, and 68 million pounds of
watermelons just to name a few of the many products that are grown here. For
more interesting facts about Maryland agriculture, see the AgBrief.

The Maryland Department of Agriculture shares 10 suggestions to help citizens
recognize National and Maryland Agriculture Week:

                                US Official News

                            November 30, 2015 Monday

Washington: Baltimore CBP Intercepts First in Nation Destructive Beet Flea
Beetle in Shipment of Italian Ceramic Tiles

LENGTH: 322 words

DATELINE: Lahore



 Washington: U.S. Customs and Border Protection has issued the following news
release:



 A U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) entomologist confirmed Wednesday that
U.S. Customs and Border Protection (CBP) Office of Field Operations (OFO)
agriculture specialists at the Port of Baltimore made a first in nation pest
discovery when they intercepted a live insect known as Chaetocnema breviuscula
Felderman (Chrysomelidae), a beet flea beetle, while inspecting ceramic tile
from Italy.This jumping beetle chews little holes in the leaves of agriculture
crops.  Young plants suffer badly and normally die.





 &ldquo;Keeping this pest out of the nation saves the American agricultural
industry from the expense of eradication, and the hardship of finding their
crops damaged by a new danger,&rdquo; said Dianna Bowman CBP Area Port Director
for the Port of Baltimore.  &ldquo;By stopping destructive species at the
border, before they can enter the United States for the first time, CBP officers
and agriculture specialists protect this vital American industry.&rdquo;



 The beetle was discovered November 12 at the Baltimore Seaport in the interior
of a container containing ceramic tile from Italy.  The specimen was forwarded
to a USDA- Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS) - Plant Protection
Quarantine (PPQ) entomologist for identification.



 On November 25, USDA confirmed that this was the first identification of this
species in the United States.



 CBP Agriculture specialists have extensive training and experience in the
biological sciences and agriculture inspection. On a typical day nationally,
they inspect over 1 million people as well as air and sea cargo imported to the
United States and intercept 4,447 prohibited meat, plant materials or animal
products, including 425 agriculture pests and diseases.



 In case of any query regarding this article or other content needs please
contact:

 editorial@plusme.com

LOAD-DATE: November 30, 2015

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


              Copyright 2015 Plus Media Solutions Private Limited
                              All Rights Reserved

                               The Tuskegee News

  This content, including derivations, may not be stored or distributed in any
  manner, disseminated, published, broadcast, rewritten or reproduced without
                      express, written consent from STPNS

                                 August 6, 2009

TU awarded $145,119 in USDA grant funding

BYLINE: The Tuskegee News staff

LENGTH: 176  words


The United States Department of Agriculture announced last week it will
apporopriate more than $3.3 million in grants to 23 institutions in 19 states to
enhance their international research and teaching capabilities.

On that list is Tuskegee University, which USDA awarded $145,119.

USDA's Cooperative State Research, Education and Extension Service administers
the funds through the competitively awarded International Science and Education
Grants program.

The projects will enhance the international content of curricula, provide
faculty with the opportunity to work outside the United States to bring lessons
learned back to the classroom, promote international research partnerships,
enhance the use and application of foreign technologies in the United States and
strengthen the role that colleges and universities play in maintaining U.S.
competitiveness.

The goal of the grant program is to strengthen the global competitiveness of
students, faculty and staff in agriculture and related areas and enhance
business performance in international agriculture.

LOAD-DATE: November 15, 2009

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

DOCUMENT-TYPE: Accomplishment

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                               All Rights Reserved

                              260 of 998 DOCUMENTS


                             Arusha Times (Arusha)

                                 July 25, 2015

EA Whispers - The Region Can Now Truly Fight Food Poisoning [column]

BYLINE: Isaac Mwangi

LENGTH: 688 words


Kenya's recent decision to approve the use of Aflasafe - a product that combats
aflatoxin poisoning - by farmers is a major step with an impact that will be
felt in the agricultural, public health and trade sectors.

Aflatoxin contamination in food grain and feed in Kenya has become a major
concern. Aflatoxin causes liver cancer, suppresses immunity and stunts the
growth of children. Nearly 200 people, including school children, have died in
Kenya due to acute aflatoxin poisoning in the recent past.

The magnitude of the problem is easy to see. Whole swathes of the country and
the region are affected. The food chain is contaminated. Both human beings and
livestock suffer from the effects of aflatoxin poisoning. The effects on humans
are long-term and affect the development aspirations of communities, while the
effect on animals impacts negatively on trade in meat and livestock products.
Needless to say, trade in cereals and livestock feed is also affected by
aflatoxin contamination.

Yet, many poor rural households have really no option when it comes to dealing
with the problem. Sometimes, the choice is between eating contaminated food and
not eating at all. This, of course, also contributes to the ballooning health
bill that governments and communities have to meet.

Again, aflatoxin contamination may occur at various stages, either when the crop
is in the field or during post-harvest handling and storage. This makes it
imperative to obtain all-encompassing solutions that take care of every stage in
the handling of food.

This is why earlier in the year, the Ministry of Agriculture, Livestock and
Fisheries dedicated Ksh1.5 billion ($15 million) for aflatoxin mitigation in the
country.

This is what makes the decision by the Pest Control Products Board to register
Aflasafe so significant. AflasafeKe01 was developed by the Kenya Agricultural
and Livestock Research Organization. Other key participants in its development
have included the United States Agency for International Development,
USDA-Foreign Agriculture Service, the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation, the
African Agriculture Technology Foundation (AATF), and the CGIAR Research
Programme on Agriculture for Nutrition & Health.

This biological control principle, initially developed by the United States
Department of Agriculture - Agriculture Research Service (USDA-ARS) is widely
used in the United States. It was adapted by the International Institute of
Tropical Agriculture, in partnership with USDA-ARS and others, for use in
several African nations.

Nigeria is the only country in Africa with a manufacturing plant that produces
Aflasafe. Kenya began construction of its own plant to produce Aflasafe toward
the end of last year, ensuring that East Africa will soon be in a position to
effectively combat aflatoxin poisoning.

Aflasafe is said to be highly effective, with up to 98 per cent aflatoxin
reduction in farmers' fields. Moreover, it persists from one season to the next
and disperses beyond the fields that are treated. These characteristics allow
for area-wide approaches to aflatoxin management, with the potential for both
cumulative benefits that increase with each year and community-wide benefit
where entire areas can achieve relief.

It would be good to see similar approvals being granted by other national
authorities across the region. This will ensure that once the plant in Katumani,
Machakos, becomes operational, farmers across the region will easily access
Aflasafe without delay. It will be sad for any delays to be occasioned by
bureaucratic delays and approvals.

When all is said and done, no country can be truly independent without food
security. Aflatoxin poisoning is one of the major reasons for lack of food
security in tropical areas, including East Africa.

With all the other reasons for rising food insecurity being so difficult to
tackle and ranging from civil wars to corruption, sheer incompetence to economic
sabotage, and failed IMF prescriptions to poor agricultural practices, it is
welcome news that East Africa is well on the way to tackling one of the more
serious problems leading to food insecurity.

EANA

LOAD-DATE: July 30, 2015

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


                     Copyright 2015 AllAfrica Global Media.
                              All Rights Reserved


                              261 of 998 DOCUMENTS

                      The Financial Post (Toronto, Canada)

                    October 15, 1990, Monday, WEEKLY EDITION

Killing subsidies key to GATT agriculture deal

BYLINE: Jill Vardy

SECTION: SECTION 2, SPECIAL REPORT: WORLD TRADE; Pg. 19

LENGTH: 842 words

DATELINE: Ottawa,Ont.


  Nobody knows better than Deputy Prime Minister Don Mazankowski that without a
deal on agriculture, the Uruguay Round of world trade negotiations will be a
failure.

That's why Canada is calling for a substantial reduction in the level of
domestic farm subsidies and elimination of export subsidies by all nations
governed by the General Agreement on Tariffs & Trade (GATT).

Canada's position will be tabled by Monday. According to estimates, Canada
proposes a cut of 50% in domestic farm-subsidy programs and the scrapping of
export subsidies.

Mazankowski, who is also Canada's minister of Agriculture, hopes Canada's
position will be enough to save this round of trade talks.

''If there isn't a deal on agriculture, I'm fully convinced there's no deal on
the multilateral trade negotiations,'' Mazankowski says. But he added that the
political will of the major trading countries to make a deal on agriculture
seems to be intensifying.

The Uruguay Round is faced with resolving the contentious issues related to the
use of export subsidies (which distort competition in international trade),
quantitative restrictions (such as import quotas), and other nontariff barriers
(such as health and sanitary regulations) that restrict market access.

The Economic Council of Canada estimates that domestic farm-support programs
around the world now cost consumers and taxpayers about $290 billion a year. In
Canada, direct transfers to farmers amounted to about 40% of the value of
agricultural output in 1989, according to a recent GATT report.

The main stumbling block to an agreement on agriculture has been the high
political cost of eliminating farm-support programs, the council says. For
example, the European Community's Common Agricultural Policy is considered
sacrosanct by many European countries, and the EC has been the most unwilling of
all world trading partners to tamper with the formula.

How far the Europeans and the U.S. - the world's two biggest agricultural
exporters - will cut subsidies is the linchpin for the GATT negotiations. Some
analysts say cuts to internal farm support measures may be negotiated at around
50%, with a phase-out of export subsidies over a number of years.

Mazankowski says it must be the Europeans and the U.S. who go the furthest on
agricultural compromise.

''We've heard a lot of rhetoric both from the Americans and Europeans,'' he
says. ''They're the ones that have caused all the problems, so naturally, we
want to be very, very careful ensuring that they do their bit in a fairly
substantive way.

''A flat percentage )of cuts in subsidies( across the board will still create a
distortion. So there has to be a quantum adjustment so we can establish a fair
and equitable base.''

The EC has proposed a 30% cut in its farm support over 10 years (1986-96) and
has said it would negotiate cuts in its export subsidies, which totalled almost
$13 billion in 1989.

The U.S., meanwhile, is set to table a proposal that calls for a 90% cut in
export subsidies, a reduction of 75% in internal support measures and a 75% cut
in tariff barriers for all agricultural products.

One of the touchiest issues for Canada will be protecting its supply-management
system from being lumped in with international definitions of internal support
measures.

Supply management is used to match the production of agricultural products to
demand in the market. Imports are restricted to keep the balance intact.

Canada's GATT proposal would allow the country's supply-management system for
dairy products, poultry and eggs to continue, but import restrictions would be
relaxed and production rules enhanced.

Mazankowski added that the position Canada has carved out on supply management -
while not supported by most of its trading partners - has been endorsed by all
provinces and was protected by the Canada-U.S. Free Trade Agreement.

Getting a deal on export subsidies has become more of a priority for Canada
since the EC and the U.S. have beefed up their subsidization in recent months.
On grain exports, for example, the EC has tripled its subsidization in the past
year to almost $160 a metric ton, Mazankowski says. The U.S. export enhancement
has increased from US$20 a metric ton to US$60 a metric ton in the past three
months.

''I think what's happening is they're both flexing their muscles to demonstrate
that they really mean business, and that we better get on with some substantive
progress at the GATT negotiation,'' Mazankowski says. For Canada's grain
farmers, the need for progress increases with every hike in foreign subsidies.

International prices for grain are so low now that Canadian farmers are in
desperate need of government help to get them through the glut. Mazankowski is
designing a long-term safety-net program for Western farmers that would be
GATT-consistent, and not subject to trade dispute with other countries.


But it's a difficult process - especially while GATT rules about income support
remain unclear.




LOAD-DATE: November 6, 1997

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC:  Photo: Deputy PM Mazankowski: U.S., Europe must make the most out of
compromises

TYPE: NEWS

                       Copyright 1990 Financial Post Ltd.


                              262 of 998 DOCUMENTS

                               The New York Times

               February 7, 1982, Sunday, Late City Final Edition

The Young Farmers

SECTION: Section 6; Page 110, Column 5; Magazine Desk

LENGTH: 114 words


One might infer from reading David Kline's article ''The Embattled Independent
Farmer'' (Nov. 29) that young people are not going into farming. According to a
United States Department of Agriculture study made by Dr. Calvin Beale, there
were 401,000 farmers under the age of 35 in 1980. This may be compared with
265,000 under the age of 35 back in 1970. The group of younger farmers has
increased, whereas the total number of farmers has declined. Actually, the
median age of farmers has declined from a peak of 53.1 years in 1970, to 48.6
years, in 1980.
ROY M. KOTTMAN, Dean and Director, College of Agriculture and Home Economics,
The Ohio State University, Columbus, Ohio

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: letter

                   Copyright 1982 The New York Times Company


                              263 of 998 DOCUMENTS


                              The Nation (AsiaNet)

                              May 9, 2013 Thursday

Olson reaffirms US support to small farmers

SECTION: Vol. XXVII No. 72

LENGTH: 556  words


US Ambassador to Pakistan Richard Olson, while reaffirming the United States
government's long-term support to farming communities in Pakistan, on Wednesday
said that US is keen to promote agriculture in Pakistan.

He said this while addressing a gathering of government officials including
Taimur Azmat Osman, Secretary Ministry of National Food Security and Research,
Dr Iftikar Ahmed, Chairman Pakistan Agriculture Research Centre (PARC),
researchers, and farmers during his visit to the National Agriculture Research
Center (NARC), which was established with the help of the US government in the
1980s.

Ambassador Olson said, "The United States is committed to helping the small
farmers of Pakistan through projects that enhance agricultural productivity." He
also said that since the 1950s, the United States has been working to support
agriculture in Pakistan, introducing the Kinnow orange and helping to double
Pakistan's wheat production. Today, we continue our support because improving
crop yields, protecting food sources from disease, and boosting milk production
will increase farmers' incomes, improve nutrition, and ultimately strengthen
Pakistan's prosperity."

The Ambassador lauded the progress made by the Wheat Productivity Enhancement
Project (WPEP), a United States Department of Agriculture (USDA) program managed
in collaboration with national and provincial research partners that has
successfully introduced the UG 99-resistant wheat variety, "NARC 2011."

The introduction of this wheat variety helps protect Pakistan against UG 99, a
virulent wheat disease in the region that poses a threat to Pakistan's farming
community. "Wheat accounts for approximately 60 percent of the daily caloric
intake of the average Pakistani, so our joint efforts to combat this disease are
critical," said Ambassador Olson. "The Wheat Productivity Enhancement Project
team and Pakistani scientists at national and provincial research stations have
made great progress in the fight against wheat rusts, and I encourage you to
continue your work together."

In addition to support for the Wheat Productivity Enhancement Project, the
United States has provided new harvesting machines and funded improvements to
research stations around Pakistan to develop more disease-resistant wheat
varieties.  The United States also provides specialized training opportunities
to Pakistani wheat scientists.

Dr Muhammad Imtiaz, Country Liaison Officer for the International Maize and
Wheat Improvement Center, noted that without disease-resistant varieties of
wheat, such as the one being harvested at NARC, experts estimate that Pakistan's
annual wheat harvest could be reduced by as much as 50 percent if and when UG 99
arrives. "Agriculture contributes 21 percent to the GDP of Pakistan and employs
45 percent of the labor force, making it one of the most significant economic
drivers of Pakistan," Dr. Imtiaz said, adding, that Pakistani farmers grew about
24 million tons of wheat on eight million hectares last year, accounting for
about 2.4 percent of the GDP.

"Today, our long-term commitment to Pakistan's agriculture sector is sustained
through projects that help fight animal and crop diseases, increase vegetable
and mango production, improve irrigation, increase dairy production, and support
wheat research, " Ambassador Olson concluded.

LOAD-DATE: May 9, 2013

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                              All Rights Reserved


                              264 of 998 DOCUMENTS


                             The Gazette (Montreal)

                            November 19, 2004 Friday
                                 Final Edition

Possible discovery of mad cow disease in U.S.: Prime minister had hoped to press
Bush to reopen U.S. border to live Canadian cattle

BYLINE: JOE PARASKEVAS, CanWest News Service; CP contributed to this report

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. A16

LENGTH: 314  words

DATELINE: OTTAWA


The possible discovery of a new case of mad cow disease in the United States
shows the United States and Canada share a common - but minimal - problem with
the potentially fatal malady, beef industry and political representatives said
yesterday.

The U.S. Department of Agriculture announced it would run further tissue tests
on an animal that had raised the possibility of mad cow disease in preliminary
testing.

If the cow tests positive for BSE, the U.S. Agriculture Department will go
through a lengthy process of tracing the source of the disease, as it did when a
Canadian-born cow in Washington state tested positive last December.

Initial tests have been inconclusive, said U.S. officials, who cited privacy
concerns in refusing to reveal the location of the cow or where it was born.

Federal Agriculture Minister Andy Mitchell it would take up to a week for the
United States to have conclusive results.

The co-chair of the House of Commons agriculture committee said a positive test
result could actually prove to groups that have lobbied for the U.S. border to
remain shut to Canadian cattle that the two countries face the same challenge.

"The basic thing I'm hearing from home is that if it is positive it certainly
puts the States and us on a more level playing field when we talk about borders
opening and closing," said Saskatchewan Conservative MP Gerry Ritz.

"Now the States (would be) in the same boat we are."

Stan Eby, president of the Canadian Cattlemen's Association, said any new case
shouldn't derail negotiations on reopen the U.S. border to live Canadian cattle.

Prime Minister Paul Martin was planning to push U.S. President George W. Bush on
the issue during his visit to Ottawa on Nov. 30.

Mad cow disease attacks an animal's nervous system. People who eat food
contaminated with BSE can contract a rare illness that is nearly always fatal,
Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease.

LOAD-DATE: November 19, 2004

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                       St. Louis Post-Dispatch (Missouri)

             November 21, 1989, TUESDAY, ILLINOIS FIVE STAR Edition

VETERAN FARMER PICKED AS STATE AGRICULTURE HEAD

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 6A

LENGTH: 587 words


SPRINGFIELD, Ill. (AP) - John F. ''Jack'' Rundquist, a farmer for more than
40years who has studied farming systems as far away as Europe and China, was
appointed on Monday as director of the Illinois Department of Agriculture.
Rundquist's appointment to the $65,835-a-year post is subject to confirmation by
the Illinois Senate and is effective Dec. 1. He replaces Larry Werries, who
resigned Oct. 1 to become director of intergovernmental affairs at the U.S.
Department of Agriculture.  ''Jack has been a major influence in the
agricultural community over the years, including recent contributions as a board
member and chairman of the Illinois Farm Development Authority,'' Gov. James. R.
Thompson said in a statement announcing the appointment.  ''I am confident
Illinois farmers and agriculture, in general, will benefit greatly from both
Jack's knowledge of the needs of the farming community and his vast experience
in both domestic and international farm economies.'' Rundquist said one of his
first mo ves as director would be to travel the state to meet leaders of farm
organizations.  ''I think it's great to be in the governor's Cabinet, and I want
to do a real good job representing all the farmers and agribusinesses of
Illinois, '' he said.  Rundquist, 66, of Butler, recently retired as president
of Evergreen Farms Inc. and Illini Grain and Livestock Inc. He is still part
owner of the businesses, which are being run by his son, John.  Rep. Bruce
Richmond, D-Murphysboro, chairman of the Illinois House Agriculture Committee,
also had praise for Rundquist. ''He comes highly recommended, and I think he
will be a fine director,'' he said.  Rundquist said he had ''a real positive
feeling'' about the future of farming in the state.  ''There are a lot of
problems in Illinois agriculture, but we have a great state,'' he said. ''We
have a lot of resources. We've had an excellent crop yield in most parts of the
state this year. The farm economy is looking better.'' Rundquist has visited and
studied farming in Europe, China and Mexico.  During the past nine years, he
helped develop and start a project to import Chinese hogs for research at the
University of Illinois, Iowa State University and the U.S. Department of
Agriculture.  He received his bachelor's degree in agronomy from the University
of Illinois in 1946 and his master's degree in 1947.

LANGUAGE: English

chief...

                                 The Messenger

                            January 29, 2017 Sunday

US embassy leads trade delegation to promote innovation in agriculture

SECTION: Vol. 09 No. 29

LENGTH: 307  words


U.S. Embassy Economic Counselor Joel Robert Garverick will lead a delegation of
senior Pakistani government officials, businessmen, farmers and agriculture
experts to Atlanta,

Georgia, to promote US-Pakistan bilateral commercial ties and increase trade and
investment in agriculture.

According to a press release, the delegation will remain in US till February 4
and will attend the 2017 International Production and Processing Expo (IPPE),
the United States' largest annual trade show for the poultry, meat, and feed
industries, building on the theme, 'Innovation in agriculture.'

Following the expo, the group will meet with US agribusiness executives and
researchers, including experts at the Georgia Tech Agriculture Technology
Research Group and Innovation Lab, to explore innovations that could benefit
Pakistan, expand bilateral trade, and create investment opportunities for US
companies. The group will also visit a peach farm in Georgia, and conduct
meetings with Georgia' Farm Bureau, Cotton Commission, State Department of
Agriculture, and the US Department of Agriculture's Research Service.

Representatives from all four provinces of Pakistan will take part in the trade
mission, as well as officials from the Ministry of Food Security and Research,
the Pakistan Agriculture Research Council, and the Mohammad Nawaz Sharif
University of Agriculture Multan. Agriculture is Pakistan's leading industry,
accounting for more than twenty percent of GDP and two-fifths of employment.
Major products include cotton, wheat, rice, sugarcane, fruits, vegetables,
dairy, beef, mutton, poultry and eggs. The United States is Pakistan's largest
trading partner, exporting $447 million in agricultural goods to Pakistan in

2015. These imports help support Pakistani agricultural exports, which were $
3.7 billion in fiscal year 15/16 (July-June).

                              267 of 998 DOCUMENTS


                        The Atlanta Journal-Constitution

                    December 24, 2003 Wednesday Home Edition

'Mad cow' case found in U.S.;
Japan and South Korea halt imports; USDA assures beef on market is safe

BYLINE: JEFF NESMITH

SOURCE: Cox Washington Bureau

SECTION: News; Pg. 1A

LENGTH: 995 words


Washington --- The first known case of "mad cow disease" in the United States
has been identified in a paralyzed cow slaughtered at a Washington state packing
plant, Agriculture Secretary Ann Veneman said Tuesday.

Japan, the largest overseas market for U.S. beef, immediately banned imports
from the United States.

Exports totaled about $843 million in 2002, according to the U.S. Meat Export
Federation.

"Until its safety can be confirmed, we decided to ban U.S. beef imports for the
time being starting today," said Yasuo Fukuda, the Japanese government's top
spokesman. "We plan to recall meat products that might contain bits from cattle
brains and spinal cords."

In Seoul, South Korea, the government halted customs inspection of U.S. beef,
effectively preventing the meat from reaching market. South Korea's Agriculture
and Forestry Ministry said it also suspended sales of all U.S. beef already on
the market. Singapore and Malaysia followed suit and authorities in other Asian
nations were also deciding whether to invoke bans.

Veneman said the diseased animal, known as a "downer cow" because it could not
walk when brought to Vern's Moses Lake Meats slaughterhouse, was processed Dec.
9.

Parts of the cow that could be infected --- the brain, the spinal cord and the
lower part of the small intestine --- were removed before meat from the rest of
the cow was sent to a deboning plant called Midway Meats and then to two
processing facilities, Willamette and Interstate Meat, Agriculture Department
officials said.

A test first revealed the problem 12 days after slaughter.

But Veneman said Americans should not be concerned about the safety of beef. She
said she intended to serve beef for Christmas dinner.

Humans can contract a form of mad cow disease if they eat infected beef or nerve
tissue and possibly through blood transfusions. The human form of mad cow
disease, known as Cruetzfeldt-Jakob Disease, has killed 143 people in Britain
and 10 elsewhere. None have been in the United States. Blood donors possibly at
risk for the disease, which creates sponge-like holes in brain tissue, are
banned from giving.

Veneman said at a news conference that the Agriculture Department was working
with the Food and Drug Administration to trace and recall the meat.

She emphasized that there was no evidence of a terrorism link to the incident,
which came to light while the country is under a heightened "orange alert" for a
possible attack.

The announcement sent shock waves through the U.S. beef and meat industries,
which geared up immediately for an advertising and public relations campaign
aimed at assuring Americans that beef is safe to eat.

Agriculture Department meat inspectors took samples of brain and spinal cord
tissues for analysis after seeing the paralyzed cow --- a Holstein --- being
brought in for slaughter, Veneman said.

The tissues were tested and retested at a Agriculture Department laboratory in
Ames, Iowa, and found to be infected by bovine spongiform encephalopathy, the
scientific name for mad cow disease.

The farm near Yakima, Wash., from which the cow was sold has been quarantined,
Veneman said.

Veneman said scientists have yet to find a case of mad cow disease being
transmitted to humans from a cow's muscle tissues, which make up most of the
beef sold to consumers.

Veneman's press conference was held at about 5 p.m. EST, several hours after the
department had notified cattle and meat industry organizations.

Mad cow disease is one of a group of neurological disorders that have baffled
researchers for years.

Scientists say certain proteins, known as prions and found in brain tissue,
become damaged and cause tissue to develop sponge-like holes.

Diseased prions can cause other prions to become diseased, but scientists have
been unable to figure out how that happens.

However, the illness develops slowly, and symptoms may not appear until years
after a person is exposed to the infection.

The discovery of hundreds of diseased cows in England in 1986 led to the
decimation of the cattle industries there and in other European countries. The
Canadian beef industry is reeling from the discovery in May of an infected cow
in Alberta. Consumer groups have pressed the Agriculture Department and the FDA
for tighter restrictions and inspections.

After the European outbreaks, reforms were enacted in Europe and the United
States in the way cattle are fed and slaughtered. Specifically, cows cannot be
given feed that contains bone meal or other tissue rendered from other cows or
sheep.

However, manufacturers of cattle feed are allowed to put products of cooked-down
chicken and pig parts into cattle feed to enhance its protein content. Consumer
groups have lobbied for a ban on the use of any rendered meat in animal feed.

Veneman said all "downer cows" are tested for mad cow disease at
slaughterhouses. But a former Agriculture Department veterinarian, Lester
Friedlander of Wyalusing, Pa., said inspectors often ignore such animals because
of pressure from the government and meat processors.

In addition, he said in a telephone interview, industry pressure has caused the
department to relax inspections of ambulatory cattle for signs of neurological
disorders. Last week, a federal appeals court revived a lawsuit filed by the
animal rights group Farm Sanctuary that challenged the government's policy on
processing "downer" animals.

"We shouldn't be using downer cows in our food supply at all," said Karen Taylor
Mitchell of the advocacy group Safe Tables Our Priority. "There is a USDA
regulation about not using them for the school lunch program. Yet it is OK for
the same children who are protected at school to go home and be served sick
cows."

Veneman said consumers can get daily updates by reading the department's Web
site, http://www.usda.gov, or by calling 1-866-4USDACO.

--- Information from news services was used in this article.

LOAD-DATE: December 24, 2003

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: Photo: Midway Meats in Washington state is where a cow that tested
positive for mad cow disease was deboned, U.S. Department of Agriculture
officials announced Tuesday. / GARY J. CICHOWSKI / The Chronicle

                Copyright 2003 The Atlanta Journal-Constitution


                              268 of 998 DOCUMENTS


                               Right Vision News

                              May 10, 2013 Friday

Pakistan: Ambassador Olson highlights U.S. support to small farmers

LENGTH: 676 words

DATELINE: ISLAMABAD


ISLAMABAD, May 10 -- U.S. Ambassador Richard Olson today reaffirmed the United
States government's long-term support to farming communities in Pakistan. "Since
the 1950s, the United States has been working to support agriculture in
Pakistan, introducing the Kinnow orange and helping to double Pakistan's wheat
production.

Today, we continue our support because improving crop yields, protecting food
sources from disease, and boosting milk production will increase farmers'
incomes, improve nutrition, and ultimately strengthen Pakistan's prosperity."

Addressing a gathering of government officials, researchers, and farmers during
his visit to the National Agriculture Research Center (NARC), which was
established with the help of the U.S. government in the 1980s, Ambassador Olson
said, "The United States is committed to helping the small farmers of Pakistan
through projects that enhance agricultural productivity."

The Ambassador lauded the progress made by the Wheat Productivity Enhancement
Project (WPEP), a United States Department of Agriculture (USDA) program managed
in collaboration with national and provincial research partners that has
successfully introduced the UG 99-resistant wheat variety, "NARC 2011."

The introduction of this wheat variety helps protect Pakistan against UG 99, a
virulent wheat disease in the region that poses a threat to Pakistan's farming
community. "Wheat accounts for approximately 60 percent of the daily caloric
intake of the average Pakistani, so our joint efforts to combat this disease are
critical," said Ambassador Olson. "The Wheat Productivity Enhancement Project
team and Pakistani scientists at national and provincial research stations have
made great progress in the fight against wheat rusts, and I encourage you to
continue your work together."

In addition to support for the Wheat Productivity Enhancement Project, the
United States has provided new harvesting machines and funded improvements to
research stations around Pakistan to develop more disease-resistant wheat
varieties. The United States also provides specialized training opportunities to
Pakistani wheat scientists.

Dr. Muhammad Imtiaz, Country Liaison Officer for the International Maize and
Wheat Improvement Center, noted that without disease-resistant varieties of
wheat, such as the one being harvested at NARC, experts estimate that Pakistan's
annual wheat harvest could be reduced by as much as 50 percent if and when UG 99
arrives. "Agriculture contributes 21 percent to the GDP of Pakistan and employs
45 percent of the labor force, making it one of the most significant economic
drivers of Pakistan," Dr. Imtiaz said. Pakistani farmers grew about 24 million
tons of wheat on eight million hectares last year, accounting for about 2.4
percent of the GDP.

"The United States and Pakistan have similar agricultural systems, and for that
reason we have been effective partners in agriculture for more than half a
century, working together to improve agricultural yields and to combat disease,"
said Ambassador Olson. "Since the 1950s, U.S. and Pakistani scientists have
collaborated to increase wheat production.

At that time, Dr. Manzoor Bajwa and Dr. Norman Borlaug worked together to
develop 'Mexi-Pak,' the wheat variety that started the Green Revolution in
Pakistan and helped to double Pakistan's wheat production between 1965 and
1970."

"Today, our long-term commitment to Pakistan's agriculture sector is sustained
through projects that help fight animal and crop diseases, increase vegetable
and mango production, improve irrigation, increase dairy production, and support
wheat research, " Ambassador Olson concluded.

Taimur Azmat Osman, Secretary, Ministry of National Food Security and Research
and Dr. Iftikar Ahmed, Chairman, Pakistan Agriculture Research Centre (PARC)
were among others who were present on the occasion Published by HT Syndication
with permission from Right Vision News. For any query with respect to this
article or any other content requirement, please contact Editor at
htsyndication@hindustantimes.com

LOAD-DATE: May 10, 2013

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                              270 of 998 DOCUMENTS


                          The Globe and Mail (Canada)

                             July 15, 1995 Saturday

U.S. wheat growers back subsidies   Urge USDA to 'stay the course'

BYLINE: GAM

LENGTH: 312 words

DATELINE: Washington DC


Bloomberg Business News
  WASHINGTON
 U.S. wheat growers are urging Agriculture Secretary Dan Glickman to
continue wheat export subsidies, even as wheat supplies plunge in the
United States and around the world.

"Stronger prices do not mean the end of competition," said Ross Hansen,
president of the U.S. National Wheat Growers. Mr. Hansen added that the
U.S. Department of Agriculture must "stay the course" on its controversial
Export Enhancement Program.

Mr. Hansen met with Mr. Glickman Thursday, as Canadian Wheat Board
commissioner Richard Klassen issued a statement from Winnipeg, saying the
United States should end its use of the $800-million (U.S.) export subsidy
program.

"We are facing one of the tightest world wheat situations on record and
for the U.S. government to continue to use export subsidies - which are
difficult to justify even when supplies are abundant - simply defies
logic," Mr. Klassen said.

In a statement yesterday, Mr. Hansen dismissed Canada's arguments and
similar appeals by Australia. They are appeals by "state-run wheat
marketing monopolies" that also slash prices to compete in world markets,
he said.

The Export Enhancement Program pays exporters to offer a discount on
U.S. wheat. It's currently funded at $800-million but will tentatively
jump to about $959-million for fiscal 1996, which begins Oct. 1.

Wheat normally grabs about 80 per cent of all EEP subsidies. Even so,
the U.S. share of world wheat exports is 32 per cent, unchanged from five
years ago.
 Wheat futures in Chicago soared yesterday, as the European Union said it
will suspend its export subsidy program until September because of tight
stockpiles.

The USDA projected Wednesday that U.S. wheat supplies in storage by
May, 1996, will total 428 million bushels, the lowest level in 22 years.

World wheat stocks are projected to fall to 107 million tons, the
lowest in 20 years, the USDA said.

LOAD-DATE: January 10, 2007

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                              271 of 998 DOCUMENTS

                               The New York Times

             November 25, 1981, Wednesday, Late City Final Edition

Cotton Acres May Decline

BYLINE: By United Press International

SECTION: Section D; Page 17, Column 3; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 231 words


The Agriculture Department said yesterday that cotton acreage in the United
States for the 1982-83 season may fall slightly from this year's 14.3 million
acres.

In a cotton outlook and situation summary, the department said that its
projection of a downward trend in plantings was based on current and prospective
returns for cotton relative to sorghum and soybeans.

The largest declines in cotton acreage, the department said, would be in the
Southwest and the Mississippi Delta states.  In its latest supply-demand figures
for cotton, the Agriculture Department projected total stocks for the season to
end Aug. 1, 1982, at 5.4 million bales - about double the previous year's total.

The high yields, estimated at 543 pounds an acre compared with 404 pounds an
acre in 1980, combined with unusually low abandonment of land, result in a
1981-82 cotton production estimate of 15.6 million bales.

As a result, the department said that the United States may account for more
than 80 percent of the increase in estimated 1981-82 world cotton production,
now forecast at a record 70.9 million bales, 5.5 million above the previous
year.

Cotton prices continued in a downward trend during 1981, moving from an average
of 77 cents a pound in January to 64 cents in mid-October.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                   Copyright 1981 The New York Times Company


                              272 of 998 DOCUMENTS

                      The Financial Post (Toronto, Canada)

                     June 16, 1988, Thursday, DAILY EDITION

Grain futures surge, farmers' hopes fade

BYLINE: Deborah Hargreaves, Financial Times of London

SECTION: SECTION 1, NEWS; Pg. 8

LENGTH: 394 words

DATELINE: Chicago,IL.


  As temperatures soar in cloudless skies across the U.S. farm belt, farmers are
in fear for their crops amid a surge in farm commodity prices on Chicago's
futures exchanges.

The U.S. Department of Agriculture has declared a drought emergency in 18 states
as cattle pasture conditions have reached their poorest levels since the Dust
Bowl of 1934. In testimony before Congress on Tuesday, Richard Lyng, U.S.
secretary of agriculture, said major parts of the U.S. are nearing a crop
disaster caused by dry weather.

Livestock farmers have been worst-hit so far as the drought has dried up
pastures and forced some of them to send cattle to market earlier than usual
because of a lack of grazing.

In the corn belt, the next two weeks are crucial to the fate of corn and soybean
crops.

''In two more weeks, we will be getting past the time for planting more soybeans
and past the point of return for corn,'' said David Senter at the American
Agriculture Movement, a farm pressure group. Farmers in Illinois can usually
plant soybeans until the beginning of July to replace seeds that did not
germinate at the first planting.

Crop yields are already expected to be low this year because the drought has
occurred so soon after farmers in the Midwest completed their plantings,
depriving seeds of moisture for germination. In addition, farmers with
irrigation systems are being forced to use them two months earlier than usual,
which substantially pushes up their costs of production.

Commodity traders at the Chicago Board of Trade have seized on the drought to
extend the surge in grain prices, which were already soaring this year, as the
U.S. pulls itself out of its farm crisis. Trading in the exchange's grain
futures contracts has been frenzied as farmers have also rushed to hedge against
crop damage in a long drought.

But grain prices have staged wide swings in the past couple of days amid
uncertainty about the outlook for the weather.

Steve Freed, grains analyst at Dean Witter, said traders on the exchange floor
have become nervous this week about the soaring prices. ''A US$9 soybean price
(per bushel) is scary; it doesn't get there very often and it's a little too
early to be getting excited about a drought. Grain traders are looking for some
indication that the drought has really set in,'' Freed said.




LOAD-DATE: December 9, 1997

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: NEWS

                              273 of 998 DOCUMENTS

                               The New York Times

               February 13, 1992, Thursday, Late Edition - Final

India Plans Purchases Of Wheat

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE,  Special to The New York Times

SECTION: Section D; Page 22; Column 4; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 395 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12


For the first time since 1988, the Government of India will be buying wheat
abroad to bolster its stockpiles of food, Indian and American officials say.

The head of India's Food Deaprtment told the United States Agriculture
Department this week that New Delhi needs about one million tons of grain to
stabilize food prices, which have risen as a result of changes in economic
policies.

In looking for foreign wheat supplies, India is in competition with a number of
nations that were once part of the former Soviet Union. The United Nations Food
and Agriculture Organization in Rome said today that 12 former Soviet republics,
excluding the Baltic nations, might buy as much as 35 million tons of grain this
year, 11 million more than last year.

Worldwide, the food organization said, the demand for wheat alone would increase
12 million tons.

American officials say there is less fear in Washington that supplies will be
strained and more concern that subsidized European grain will siphon off buyers.
American wheat sells for about $180 a ton; wheat grown in Europe under heavy
European Community subsidies sells for $130 a ton.

India, which is self-sufficient in food production, bought two million tons of
American wheat in 1988 when food stockpiles were running low. The wheat was sold
under the 1985 Export Enhancement Program, which subsidizes sales of American
grain to make it more competitive with European grain.

New Delhi has asked the United States for price concessions again this year. In
the Agriculture Department, officials are inclined to support the Indian request
because India, with about 850 million people and a limited ability to expand
acreage, is seen as a long-term cash customer for American wheat.

Russia is seeking about 23 million tons on the world market this year, officials
say. But they believe that private ownership and improvements in Russian
agriculture will sooner or later make production more efficient.

The United States has made other poor South Asian nations, including Sri Lanka
and Bangladesh, eligible for the Export Enhancement Program subsidies on grain.
Asian nations with better economic performances and large trade imbalances with
the United States have been excluded. These include Japan, South Korea and
Taiwan, all of which continue to buy American wheat rather than cheaper European
grain.

LOAD-DATE: February 13, 1992

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                   Copyright 1992 The New York Times Company


                              274 of 998 DOCUMENTS

                               The New York Times

                 July 26, 1985, Friday, Late City Final Edition

'KILLER BEES' COLONY IS FOUND AND EXTERMINATED IN CALIFORNIA

BYLINE: By BAYARD WEBSTER

SECTION: Section A; Page 8, Column 5; National Desk

LENGTH: 403 words


A colony of about 50 aggressive Africanized honey bees has been found in an
oilfield near Lost Hills in Kern County in central California, the United States
Department of Agriculture reported yesterday. The bees were killed with an
aerosol insecticide.

Large colonies of Africanized bees, often called ''killer bees,'' are now native
to sections of South and Central America and have been expected to migrate
farther north to the lower United States within the next few years. Since the
bees have been found unable to survive in cooler climates, they are expected to
migrate no further north than the Southern tier of states.

The discovery of the bees in central California, about 30 miles northwest of
Bakersfield, is not believed to be evidence of the bee's northward migration. A
normal honey bee colony contains anywhere from 10,000 to 50,000 bees. Officials
found no evidence of a comb or a queen in the burrow and found no indications of
Africanized bees in any commercial bee hives in the area. Without a queen, the
bees will not reproduce.

In recent years there have been several cases of small groups of Africanized
bees having been found in the United States. These were usually on ships
carrying hollow pipes, machinery or empty containers from South American ports.

The Federal and state authorities now theorize that the bees found in the
California oil field were probably transported by ships carrying oil-drilling
pipes and other equipment from South America.

The Africanized strain, believed to have been hybridized somewhat by breeding
with the milder European honey bee in South America, sprang from a group of true
African bees that were transported to Brazil from Africa for a research project
in the 1950's. A number of swarms escaped from the laboratories and since then
have been slowly moving north and south.

The stings of the bees, which closely resemble the European honey bees that are
employed by American beekeepers for crop pollination and honey production in all
states, are no more venomous than those of the domestic bees. They are known,
however, for their tendency to become easily aroused and mass in great numbers
to attack humans or other intruders.

An oilfield worker found the bees and notified California agricultural experts,
who killed them with the insecticide and submitted them to the Sacramento office
of the Federal Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: photo of normal bee and killer bee (AP)

                   Copyright 1985 The New York Times Company


                              275 of 998 DOCUMENTS


                        The Balochistan Times (AsiaNet)

                            January 29, 2017 Sunday

US embassy leads trade delegation to promote innovation in agriculture

SECTION: Vol. 40 No. 29

LENGTH: 307  words


U.S. Embassy Economic Counselor Joel Robert Garverick will lead a delegation of
senior Pakistani government officials, businessmen, farmers and agriculture
experts to Atlanta, Georgia, to promote US-Pakistan bilateral commercial ties
and increase trade and investment in agriculture.

According to a press release, the delegation will remain in US till February 4
and will attend the 2017 International Production and Processing Expo (IPPE),
the United States' largest annual trade show for the poultry, meat, and feed
industries, building on the theme, 'Innovation in agriculture.'

Following the expo, the group will meet with US agribusiness executives and
researchers, including experts at the Georgia Tech Agriculture Technology
Research Group and Innovation Lab, to explore innovations that could benefit
Pakistan, expand bilateral trade, and create investment opportunities for US
companies.

The group will also visit a peach farm in Georgia, and conduct meetings with
Georgia' Farm Bureau, Cotton Commission, State Department of Agriculture, and
the US Department of Agriculture's Research Service.

Representatives from all four provinces of Pakistan will take part in the trade
mission, as well as officials from the Ministry of Food Security and Research,
the Pakistan Agriculture Research Council, and the Mohammad Nawaz Sharif
University of Agriculture Multan.

Agriculture is Pakistan's leading industry, accounting for more than twenty
percent of GDP and two-fifths of employment.  Major products include cotton,
wheat, rice, sugarcane, fruits, vegetables, dairy, beef, mutton, poultry and
eggs.

The United States is Pakistan's largest trading partner, exporting $447 million
in agricultural goods to Pakistan in 2015. These imports help support Pakistani
agricultural exports, which were $ 3.7 billion in fiscal year 15/16 (July-June).

                              277 of 998 DOCUMENTS


                          The Globe and Mail (Canada)

                              April 8, 1988 Friday

U.S. terms timid plan to trim farm subsidies

BYLINE: REUT

LENGTH: 458 words

DATELINE: Brussels BELGIUM


Reuter BRUSSELS
  The United States and the European Community have disagreed sharply at
the World Food Conference over the best way to reform agriculture and shed
costly subsidies.

Washington wants an end to all agricultural subsidies by the year 2000
and says the EC's new package of measures to curb output and spending is
timid.

But Frans Andriessen, EC Farm Commissioner, argued that for most
countries, completely dismantling all support for agriculture is neither
possible nor desirable, even in the long term.

The conference at the European Parliament in Brussels has been
organized to seek solutions to the global imbalance between huge food
surpluses in major industrial countries and chronic shortages in the Third
World.

Both the United States and the 12-nation EC subsidize their farmers
heavily, and some experts say both must stop spending so much money on
wasted food production.

Richard Lyng, U.S. Agriculture Secretary, told about 250 conference
delegates from over 60 countries that only a system devoid of subsidies
and protectionism could help developing countries and end trade friction.

'We must open markets, not restrict them. We must reject proposals  that lock in
markets and price stabilization schemes,' he said.

But the United States would continue aggressively supporting its
farmers if it did not get the results it wanted in multilateral
negotiations, he said.

Referring to the U.S. aim of abolishing subsidies, Mr. Andriessen said.
'It does not make sense to establish long-term goals while not being able
or willing to fill in intermediate steps.'
   If doing away with all subsidies was unrealistic, he told delegates,
major industrial countries could still go a long way 'toward reducing and
rebalancing agricultural support, and making it more selective.'
   The package of price cuts and other measures negotiated recently to
curb EC agricultural production was a pragmatic, immediate step in the
right direction, Mr. Andriessen added.

He also pointed out that abolishing subsidies would not magically help
Third World countries, because they would have to pay more for imports as
well as earning more for their xports.

Opening the two-day meeting, President Kenneth Kaunda of Zambia said
major industrial nations had to take the initiative to help feed the whole
world.

'The time has come for Europe and the rest of the developed world to  take a
lead in structural adjustment efforts,' he told the conference.  'We have not
begun to think together as internationalists.'     What less-developed countries
need is aid for the kind of technology  and training that can bring about
self-sufficiency, he said. 'The answer  does not lie in dumping surplus stocks
on us through food aid, no matter  how legitimate your intentions are.'

LOAD-DATE: January 10, 2007

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                              279 of 998 DOCUMENTS

                               The New York Times

              September 1, 1981, Tuesday, Late City Final Edition

PRICES PAID TO FARMER DOWN 2.1%

BYLINE: AP

SECTION: Section D; Page 20, Column 1; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 483 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31


Prices paid to farmers for raw products dropped 2.1 percent in August and, for
the first time in 14 months, averaged below the levels of a year earlier, the
Agriculture Department said today.

Nevertheless, the department's economists predict that retail food prices will
go up an average of 8.6 percent this year, matching last year's gain, which was
the smallest annual increase since 1977.

Scott Steele, a staff economist in the Agriculture Department, said this year's
prospects for big grain crops (including wheat, rice and corn) along with
sharply higher production of cotton and other commodities were the main reasons
for a price decline.

Moreover, he said, crop production in many other countries looks good this year.
That would mean stiffer competition for United States exports.

''It depends a lot on some of these foreign market purchases and how those come
about in the next several months,'' Mr. Steele said.  This nation's farm prices
in August averaged 138 percent of the 1977 base that is used for comparison,
against the July index of 141.

A Few Prices Higher

Lower prices for corn, cattle, soybeans, dry edible beans and cotton led the
August decline, the department's Crop Reporting Board said. But higher prices
for apples, oranges, lemons, milk, tobacco and calves offset part of the decline
for the other commodities.

The last time the monthly farm price index dropped below its level of a year
before was in June 1980. On a month-to-month basis, farm prices rose slightly
last January. Since then, they have held steady in three months and declined in
four.

The prices farmers paid to meet expenses in August rose seventenths of 1 percent
from July and averaged 7.9 percent above a year ago. Higher prices for
replacement livestock and family living items more than made up for declines in
many feed products and replacement cattle and hogs.

According to the preliminary August figures, which are based mostly on mid-month
averages, prices of meat animals as a group declined 1.3 percent from July. The
index was 6.1 percent below the level of August 1980.

The latest month's index for feed grains and hay declined 8.2 percent from July
and averaged 4.3 percent below the August 1980 level.

Decline for Vegetables

Vegetable prices at the farm dropped 3 percent from July and were 16 percent
below a year ago. Lower prices for lettuce, cantaloupes and onions contributed
most to the decrease from the previous month.  Higher prices were reported for
tomatoes and carrots.

Fruit prices collectively jumped 20 percent from July and averaged 8.3 percent
above a year ago. That included higher prices for apples, oranges, lemons,
strawberries and pears. Lower prices were reported for peaches.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: Illustrations: Graph of farm prices

                              280 of 998 DOCUMENTS


                               Right Vision News

                            November 23, 2012 Friday

Pakistan: US, Pakistani scientists increase Pakistan's wheat productivity

LENGTH: 392 words

DATELINE: ISLAMABAD


ISLAMABAD, Nov. 23 -- The U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) is helping
farmers to increase productivity and improving food security in Pakistan by
introducing disease-resistant varieties of wheat.

United States Department of Agriculture's Wheat Productivity Enhancement Project
(WPEP) has introduced 60 advanced wheat varieties in Pakistan in the first of
115 wheat trials scheduled this year at the National Agricultural Research
Council (NARC) and other locations throughout Pakistan.

USDA scientists, together with the International Maize and Wheat Improvement
Center (CIMMYT), helped researchers at the Pakistan Agricultural Research
Council (PARC) establish the annual National Uniform Wheat Yield Trial (NUWYT)
at the National Agricultural Research Center (NARC) in Islamabad. USDA helped
identify and multiply a variety of wheat called, "NARC 2011," which can resist
wheat rust. After NUWYT tests proved the variety was well-suited for the
environment in Pakistan, it was released to and is now being used by farmers.

"Wheat is critical to Pakistan's food security," said USDA Plant Health Advisor
Ian Winborne at a ceremony in NARC celebrating the establishment of the NUWYT.
"The United States is committed to working with Pakistani scientists to develop
solutions to wheat diseases that can affect crops here in Pakistan, and in the
United States. The NUWYT is an important step in finding disease-resistant wheat
varieties that will feed the people of Pakistan for years to come."

USDA's WPEP is a collaborative project focused on scientific exchanges on wheat
productivity that help develop and introduce disease-resistant varieties,
improve agronomy practices, and upgrade infrastructure in Pakistan.

Mutually beneficial scientific exchange and research is an important feature of
the work carried out by the United States and Pakistan in agriculture. U.S. and
Pakistani agricultural scientists will also deepen their cooperation at the
U.S.-funded Center for Advanced Studies on agriculture. The center is based in a
Pakistani university and hosts regular exchanges between top agricultural
scientists from the United States and Pakistan Published by HT Syndication with
permission from Right Vision News. For any query with respect to this article or
any other content requirement, please contact Editor at
htsyndication@hindustantimes.com

                               The New York Times

                February 13, 2000, Sunday, Late Edition - Final

IN BRIEF;
No U.S. Funds Allotted To Upgrade Plum I. Lab

BYLINE: By JOHN RATHER

SECTION: Section 14LI; Page 8; Column 2; Long Island Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 282 words


The White House has turned down a request by the Agricultural Research Service,
an agency of the United States Department of Agriculture, for $24 million to
upgrade the Plum Island Animal Disease Research Center.

The lack of funds in the budget for the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1, which
President Clinton proposed last week, means that plans for what are known as
Biosafety Level 4 laboratories on Plum Island will face delays or be dropped.

The laboratories, which would be the only ones of their kind in the United
States, would allow researchers to study deadly imported animal viruses that
infect humans. Plum Island is about a mile off the tip of the North Fork.

James S. Spurling, a spokesman for the Agriculture Department, said the
Agricultural Research Service continued to believe "it is important that we have
a Level 4 research facility." But, he added, "that doesn't mean it has to be at
Plum Island."

Representative Michael P. Forbes, a Democrat of Quogue and a member of the House
Appropriations Committee, had asked that the money be deleted from the budget.

"Research of this kind is better conducted at the Center for Disease Control in
Atlanta or at the U.S.D.A. facility in Ames, Iowa, not near our heavily
populated communities here on Long Island," Mr. Forbes said. His district
includes the East End of the Island.

Mr. Forbes and other critics of the upgrade have also expressed concern about
transporting viruses for which there are no known cures by motor vehicle from
John F. Kennedy International Airport to the laboratory. Plum Island officials
respond that packaging and safety features sufficiently protected the public.
   JOHN RATHER

http://www.nytimes.com
