                               The New York Times

              October 14, 1981, Wednesday, Late City Final Edition

Soviet Farm Import Rise Seen

BYLINE: AP

SECTION: Section D; Page 16, Column 2; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 289 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13


American farmers will be getting lower prices for their huge 1981 harvests but a
thriving export market may help soften the blow, the Agriculture Department said
today.

One of the big buyers on the international market is the Soviet Union, which is
now expected to import from all foreign sources a total of 43 million metric
tons of grain during the international marketing year that will expire on June
30, 1982. That was up by 3 million tons from the estimate of a month ago. A
metric ton is about 2,205 pounds and is equal to 36.7 bushels of wheat or 39.4
bushels of corn.

Last year the Soviet Union imported 34.5 million metric tons of grain, a record
at the time and close to what United States experts had believed to be its
maximum import capacity.

But the Russians ''appear to be maximizing efforts to expand'' their import
capability, the new analysis said, including improved facilities at Leningrad
and other ports.

Agriculture Department analysts last week estimated the Soviet Union's 1981
total grain harvest at 175 million metric tons, the smallest in six years and
far below Moscow's initial goal of 236 million tons.

The United States recently told the Soviet Union it could buy up to 23 million
metric tons of wheat and corn during the sixth year of a long-term purchase
agreement that runs through Sept. 30, 1982.  Purchases announced so far total
7.25 million tons.

In all, American grain production this year - which includes wheat, corn and
other feed grains, and rice -is estimated at a record 326.5 million metric tons.
Soybeans, an oilseed, add another 57.3 million tons.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                   Copyright 1981 The New York Times Company


                              283 of 998 DOCUMENTS

                                The Denver Post

                     November 27, 2001 Tuesday 1ST EDITION

Court has no beef with industry ads Cattleman had sued over 'It's What's for
Dinner' fees

BYLINE: Denver Post Staff and Wire Reports,

SECTION: BUSINESS; Pg. C-01

LENGTH: 472 words


WASHINGTON - The U.S. Supreme Court turned aside a  free-speech challenge to the
'Beef: It's What's for Dinner'  advertising campaign by a Kansas cattleman
seeking to avoid paying  fees to help fund the ads.

The justices, without comment, refused to question a federal  appeals court
decision upholding a U.S. Department of Agriculture  order that Jerry Goetz pay
$ 137,000 in back fees and penalties.

The beef ads are under fire following a 6-3 Supreme Court  ruling in June that
struck down a similar Agriculture Department  advertising program, known as a
'checkoff,' for the mushroom  industry. A separate challenge to the $ 88 million
beef program is  pending in a federal trial court in South Dakota.

The Denver-based National Cattlemen's Beef Association  applauded the decision.

'Our initial reaction is that the court decision is a  positive,' said spokesman
Kendal Frazier. 'We believe the checkoff  is constitutional.'

But the ruling was a setback for the Rocky Mountain Farmers  Union, which
represents small farmers and ranchers in Colorado,  Wyoming and New Mexico.

'We support checkoff programs to some degree, but only to the  extent that
they're constitutional,' said spokesman William  Lee-Ashley. 'We don't think the
beef checkoff is constitutional.'

Hog farmers this year voted to kill the national pork  promotion checkoff, but
the USDA later overturned the results  after several producer groups filed
lawsuits claiming the agency  had no legal authority to hold the election in the
first place.

Goetz argued that the beef fee, a $ 1 assessment on each head  of cattle sold,
compels him to pay for messages he doesn't  necessarily support.

'The Beef Act is materially indistinguishable from the  Mushroom Act and cannot
survive a First Amendment challenge,' he  said in his appeal to the nation's
highest court.

The 15-year-old beef-promotion law pays for advertising and  promotional
activities designed to increase sales of steak,  hamburger and other beef
products.

The Denver-based 10th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals twice  ruled against Goetz.

The Justice Department asked the Supreme Court to reject  Goetz's appeal. The
government said the mushroom ruling doesn't  necessarily mean the beef promotion
system is unconstitutional.

In a court filing last year, the Justice Department had said  the beef and
mushroom programs are 'virtually identical.' The  Supreme Court's decision in
the mushroom case surprised many  observers because the court in 1997 upheld the
fees that pay for  generic advertising for California peaches, plums and
nectarines.

The justices said the $ 2.65 million mushroom program was  different because it
wasn't part of a broader government effort to  regulate that market.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                        Copyright 2001 The Denver Post
                              All Rights Reserved

                          The Globe and Mail (Canada)

                           December 16, 2000 Saturday

PEI potatoes denied entry into U.S.

BYLINE: JACK MacANDREW, Special to The Globe and Mail

SECTION: NATIONAL NEWS; Pg. A3

LENGTH: 402 words

DATELINE: CHARLOTTETOWN


Trucks carrying Prince Edward Island potatoes were stopped from crossing into
the United States yesterday, despite a deal struck Wednesday between the United
States Department of Agriculture and its Canadian counterpart.

Under the deal, Island table stock potatoes could begin moving freely again in
the U.S. and Canada, except those from a restricted area where the potato wart
fungal disease was found eight weeks ago.

A letter signed by the second-in-command at the American agency was sent to the
Canadian Food Inspection Agency, notifying officials of the restrictions still
in effect, but opening the border to most shipments.

Yesterday, packing-house workers were called in and 11 truckloads of potatoes
moved out to fill orders from buyers in Eastern Seaboard cities of the United
States. This weekend was key to getting PEI potatoes to domestic and American
markets in time for Christmas.

But then, USDA officials at the Houlton, Me., border crossing called PEI
Agriculture Minister Mitch Murphy to tell him they had received no instructions
from Washington to let in PEI potaoes.

Mr. Murphy said he was upset at the refusal of Federal Agriculture Minister Lyle
Vanclief to immediately retaliate with restrictions against the import of
potatoes from Idaho and Wisconsin.

"He's letting this province twist in the wind while we lose more market share
with every passing day," Mr. Murphy said. "I'll tell you one thing - unless they
[the federal government] do something fast, they'd better be prepared to write a
cheque with a lot of zeros attached. Our economy is going down the drain."

Island farmers believe U.S. authorities are imposing unjustified trade sanctions
and that the potato wart does not pose a large threat.

Nearly two tonnes of Island soil and 8,000 individual soil samples have been
tested and found free of the potato-wart virus.

But the Americans refuse to accept the Canadian science, a tactic, Mr. Murphy
said, that "kept us out of the American Thanksgiving market and is designed to
keep us out of the market at Christmas."

He blamed a lobby group representing U.S. potato growers for causing the
agreement reached this week to founder.

Mr. Murphy said the potato industry accounts for one third of the Prince Edward
Island economy and a quarter of all jobs (about 15,000). Packing-house workers
have been laid off for the past seven weeks, ruling out EI cheques for many.

LOAD-DATE: September 20, 2006

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                              285 of 998 DOCUMENTS



                                US Official News

                            March 24, 2016 Thursday

Washington: Senators Call On Treasury Department To Review ChemChina's
Acquisition of Syngenta

LENGTH: 890  words

DATELINE: Lahore



 Washington, DC: U.S. Senate Committee on Agriculture, Nutrition & Forestry has
issued the following press release:


 U.S. Senator Debbie Stabenow (D-MI), ranking member of the U.S. Senate
Agriculture Committee, today led a bipartisan letter co-signed by U.S. Senators
Chuck Grassley (R-IA), Sherrod Brown (D-OH), and Joni Ernst (R-IA) - members of
the Senate Agriculture Committee - calling on the U.S. Department of the
Treasury to review China National Chemical Corporation's (ChemChina) proposed
acquisition of Syngenta for any potential effects on U.S. national security and
the American food system.





 "While this Committee has not reached any conclusions regarding the proposed
purchase of Syngenta by ChemChina, we believe that any foreign acquisition of an
important U.S. agricultural asset should be reviewed closely for potential risks
to our food system," the Senators said. "It is not unreasonable to suggest that
shifts in company governance; operational strategy; or financial
health--particularly in light of the magnitude of this leveraged
transaction--could have consequences for food security, food safety,
biosecurity, and the highly competitive U.S. farm sector as a whole."



 Pointing to growing investment from abroad in U.S. agriculture, the Senators
also urged Treasury Secretary Jack Lew to include both the United States
Department of Agriculture and the U.S. Food and Drug Administration on the
Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States (CFIUS) when reviewing
foreign acquisitions of major U.S. agriculture assets.



 The full text of the letter to Treasury follows.



 Dear Secretary Lew:



 As members of the Senate Committee on Agriculture, Nutrition, and Forestry, we
write to you regarding China National Chemical Corporation's (ChemChina)
proposed acquisition of Syngenta, a Switzerland-based crop protection and seed
company with significant operations in the United States. Despite the two
companies reported intent to voluntarily file for review with the Committee on
Foreign Investment in the United States (CFIUS), chaired by the U.S. Department
of the Treasury, we respectfully request that CFIUS exercise its authority to
review this transaction to assess any potential ramifications the purchase may
have for American national security, with a specific focus on the potential
effects on food security and the safety of our food system.



 There is shared sentiment among lawmakers, military officials, and everyday
Americans that protecting the safety and resiliency of our food system is core
to American national security. Notwithstanding this widely held conviction, the
composition of the CFIUS today does not include representation from the U.S.
Department of Agriculture (USDA) and the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) as
formal components of its process for reviewing foreign investments in critical
American assets, including agricultural assets.



 Constituents have approached us with concerns over this transaction, citing the
2013 CFIUS review of the Shuanghui-Smithfield acquisition. The most common
reflection on that experience is that growing foreign investment in U.S.
agriculture--and the prognosis of more to come--should be met with a careful
review process that captures the issues most relevant to safeguarding the
American food system going forward.



 To that end, we believe that it is imperative that both the USDA and the FDA be
included in the CFIUS for purposes of reviewing and making decisions on this
proposed acquisition by ChemChina.



 While this Committee has not reached any conclusions regarding the proposed
purchase of Syngenta by ChemChina, we believe that any foreign acquisition of an
important U.S. agricultural asset should be reviewed closely for potential risks
to our food system. It is not unreasonable to suggest that shifts in company
governance; operational strategy; or financial health--particularly in light of
the magnitude of this leveraged transaction--could have consequences for food
security, food safety, biosecurity, and the highly competitive U.S. farm sector
as a whole.



 The risk of negative outcomes is heightened to the extent that an acquired U.S.
agricultural asset becomes in some part governed by a foreign government with
clear strategic interests. In fact, the potential for unpredictable behavior
from global farm sector participants is a great challenge for the United States
as the importance of trade to American agriculture continues to grow and food
systems become more integrated. For instance, nonmarket behavior due to
state-ownership could lead to inconsistent or seemingly arbitrary treatment of
U.S. farm products in key export markets, particularly when company governance
includes governments of countries with which the United States exchanges a high
volume of trade.



 We support the mission of CFIUS to safeguard our national security.  At the
same time, it is important that the tools and processes used to review foreign
investments in critical U.S. assets accurately reflect the full range of
national security challenges our country faces today and in the future. Thank
you for your consideration of our request and views on this important matter.

                             March 31, 2015 Tuesday

FLORIDA:Scandinavian Countries Highlight "Fresh From Florida" Grapefruit in New
Promotion

LENGTH: 263  words

DATELINE: Tallahassee


Department of Agriculture and Consumer Services, The state of Florida has issued
the following news release:

Florida Commissioner of Agriculture Adam H. Putnam announced today a new
partnership between the Florida Department of Agriculture and Consumer Services
and Nordic Total Produce that will feature "Fresh From Florida" grapefruit in
724 stores in Denmark, Sweden, Finland and Norway.

"Florida's famed citrus is the best in the world," Commissioner of Agriculture
Adam H. Putnam said. "Expanding our reach to the rest of the United States and
across the globe supports Florida's economy."

Florida international agricultural exports remain a vital component of the
economic strength of the state, generating more than $4 billion in cash receipts
and placing the state as the 8th largest agricultural exporter in the United
States. More than 60 retailers in 27 countries that have partnered with "Fresh
From Florida" in 4,700 stores across the globe.

Recent efforts by the Florida Department of Agriculture and Consumer Services to
promote Florida agriculture include product sampling, store displays,
advertising circulars and promotional outreach to consumers.

"We have been pleased to work with Florida marketers to strengthen awareness and
sales interest for a variety of promotional support for Florida grapefruit. Our
team looks forward to discussing future opportunities as this season comes to a
close," said Total Produce Nordic Chief Operating Officer Jakob Scanning.

                               The New York Times

               February 18, 1985, Monday, Late City Final Edition

Separate Table Ruled Within Federal Law

BYLINE: AP

SECTION: Section D; Page 8, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 196 words

DATELINE: LINCOLN, R.I., Feb. 17


Segregating elementary school pupils who buy their lunches from those who bring
them to school does not violate pupils' civil rights or Federal law, the United
States Department of Agriculture says.

The department began investigating the case in September when the American Civil
Liberties Union filed a complaint on behalf of the family of Sherry DeQuattro, a
sixth grader.

The DeQuattros said that the separation of their children and others who took
their lunches to school from those who bought a hot lunch was unfair. The
complaint said the practice violated Federal laws prohibiting the creation of
separate dining areas for children who were enrolled in Federal lunch programs.

Although there are no separate dining rooms for children enrolled in the Federal
lunch program at the Saylesville Elementary School, the Civil Liberties Union
contended the ''net effect'' of the policy was to separate participants in the
program as if there were in different dining areas.

The Department of Agriculture said it found no discrimination in this.

The school principal, Samuel Williams, said he put the plan into effect because
it made it easier to serve lunches.


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                   Copyright 1985 The New York Times Company


                              290 of 998 DOCUMENTS

                      The Financial Post (Toronto, Canada)

                    January 28, 1994, Friday, DAILY EDITION

Hopes dim for farm trade deal with U.S.

BYLINE: Peter Morton

SECTION: SECTION 1, NEWS; Pg. 3

LENGTH: 321 words

DATELINE: Ottawa, Ont.


Hopes are fading that Canada and the U.S. will be able to resolve their
differences on several key farm issues after talks between them broke off this
week in Washington.

Canadian trade officials and agriculture industry representatives thought they
were close to a deal with the U.S. after initial talks between Agriculture
Minister Ralph Goodale and U.S. Agriculture Secretary Mike Espy. The disputes
centre on exports of Canadian durum wheat, sugar and peanut butter.

Negotiations broke off Wednesday night after failure to agree even on basic
issues, such as which year to use as a base for a proposed limit on grain
exports to the U.S., said one U.S. trade official.

Goodale said yesterday he could not comment directly on negotiations but
admitted talks were not going as smoothly as they once were.

''Whether this round of talks will succeed or not, quite frankly I don't know,''
he said outside the House of Commons.

Canadian officials thought they had an agreement from Espy that the base year
would be the 1994 crop year, which ends this summer. Canada wanted that time
frame because exports are expected to reach a record 2.5 million tonnes as a
result of flooding in U.S. grain states last year.

But U.S. negotiators said they wanted a more average year, such as 1992, when
Canadian grain shipments were only 1.6 million tonnes.

The two sides also remain far apart on limits on sugar and sugar products from
Canada as well as how much market access Ottawa is prepared to offer the U.S. in
what are now protected farm products such as ice cream and yogurt.

Canada, like the other 116 countries in the General Agreement on Tariffs and
Trade, must table tariff proposals to the GATT by Feb. 15. Ottawa has proposed
converting existing import quotas on farm products such as cheese, eggs and
poultry to tariffs as high as 351%. The U.S. is expected to object to those high
tariffs.

Soviet Corn Purchase

BYLINE: Reuters

SECTION: Section D; Page 6, Column 3; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 49 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13


Moscow maintained its brisk buying pace of United States corn this week,
purchasing 350,000 more metric tons of corn for shipment this fall, the United
States Agriculture Department reported today. With the latest sale, Soviet
purchases in the past two weeks total 2.95 million metric tons.

                              292 of 998 DOCUMENTS


                          The Globe and Mail (Canada)

                             July 4, 1990 Wednesday

Summit leaders facing critical trade issue   Reduced farm support to be
discussed

BYLINE: JENNIFER LEWINGTON and MADELAINE DROHAN; GAM

LENGTH: 1271 words


BY JENNIFER LEWINGTON and MADELAINE DROHAN The Globe and Mail
From the Canadian Prairies to French dairy farms to the rice fields of
Japan, the political stakes are high when it comes to talk of governments
reducing farm support payments at next week's Houston economic summit.

And not only are the stakes high for farmers, they are also
prohibitively high for taxpayers in the rich countries who supply the
billions of dollars paid out in domestic and export subsidies.

Currently, the seven richest industrial nations, whose leaders will
gather in Houston, are at an impasse over farm trade, although they
acknowledge that a resolution has to be found if the Uruguay Round of
world trade talks is to proceed toward a successful conclusion in
December.

The summit leaders must give a political push to the trade
negotiations, even though sharp disagreements over agricultural trade,
especially between the United States and the European Community, stand in
the way. The summit's success will test the leaders' will to find common
ground where little now exists.

One Canadian official likened the agricultural negotiators in the
General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade round to drug addicts who "require,
like a junkie, periodic injections of political will.

"If the negotiators don't get that, they'll just spin wheels."

Privately, U.S. officials are enthusiastic about compromise proposals
issued last week by Art de Zeeuw, the Dutch chairman of the agricultural
negotiating group at GATT, the 97-member world body that oversees global
trade. But the initial EC response was cool, making the United States wary
about sounding too keen on the draft GATT proposals.

One senior Canadian official, noting the dramatic changes sweeping
across Europe, said that "if there's ever a time to do something (on
agriculture) in Europe, it's now."

On Monday, U.S. Trade Representative Carla Hills said the GATT paper
offers "a good framework for negotiations." She said the proposals had
some "pluses and minuses" but would not elaborate to reporters.

In Houston, the summiteers have neither the time, interest nor skill to
resolve their differences over protectionist farm policies. But the GATT
paper offers the leaders some political cover to show progress on the
thorny issue without getting bogged down in details.

"It does (provide cover), if they want to use it," one U.S. trade
official said yesterday. Without some breakthrough on agriculture, the
summit leaders will have difficulty putting meat on the bones of the
existing draft communique.

The United States and the EC are the key adversaries in the debate over
agricultural trade reforms. But the battle is more than a protracted
harangue across the Atlantic Ocean.

Developing countries, dependent on exporting farm and other commodities
to the industrial world, look to the Uruguay Round to dismantle the
pervasive, expensive system of farm price supports and export subsidies
financed by taxpayers and consumers in the industrial world. GATT puts the
price tag at $250-billion (U.S.) a year.

Without a deal on agriculture, the developing countries will not
liberalize their markets to investors and others in the industrial world.

Canada and 13 other farm exporting nations who are members of the so-
called Cairns group meet today in Santiago, Chile, to discuss the GATT
proposals to cut farm payments, export subsidies and import barriers.
Canada will speak at the Houston summit for the Cairns group, which was
formed several years ago to promote freer farm trade.

Since the Uruguay Round 3 years ago, the United States has called for
dramatic reforms to eliminate all subsidies and price supports over time.
U.S. complaints about trade distorting farm policies are not confined to
the EC. Washington sees Canada's system of marketing boards, including
dairy, as a barrier to competition from south of the border. And the
United States has long-standing complaints about Japan's import
restrictions that protect domestic rice farmers.

Despite its purist views, the United States is a sinner too, with an
elaborate and expensive system of restrictive quotas, export subsidies and
production incentives.

Canada, which supports the ambitious U.S. goals on farm trade reform,
is also schizophrenic about farm support. It favors freer farm trade for
grain and beef because Canadian producers of those goods believe they can
compete internationally as long as other countries eliminate their export
subsidies.

It's a different story for the dairy and poultry sectors, which operate
under a system of supply management. The Canadian system tries to match
domestic supply and demand, using import restrictions to maintain the
balance.

Canada wants to retain its supply management system, despite its trade
restrictive features. In this, Canada has run afoul of the Cairns group,
which objects to Canada's attempt to shield its domestic program from
international reforms.

For its part, the 12-nation EC resists any meaningful assault on its
Common Agriculture Policy, which particularly benefits French and West
German farmers. U.S. officials say the EC farm program encourages
overproduction by setting high prices to boost domestic production. In
turn, the EC sells the surplus in third-country markets at a low price,
undercutting competitors from the United States, Canada and other farm
exporters.

One Canadian official summed up the dilemma for the summit leaders,
each with their own domestic political pressures on agriculture: "For
every leader, the politics of this are awful."

In the GATT talks so far, the EC offers a limited approach to farm
reform through reductions in the so-called "aggregate measure of support."
By this calculation, the EC could achieve an over-all reduction by cutting
support for internal production, exports or import barriers.

However, the United States contends that this formula is too vague,
since it permits the EC to raise support for internal production, for
example, while cutting export subsidies. U.S. officials point out that EC
price supports for some products are twice as high as the world price.
Thus, short of a 50 per cent reduction in these EC prices, the United
States and Canada, among others, believe the cuts would not be
significant.

This week, Mrs. Hills held to the United States' line that a meaningful
package on agriculture must include a formula for cutting internal price
supports, export subsidies and import barriers. "Agriculture is a key to
the (Uruguay) Round," she said, "it would be extremely helpful if all the
parties (at the summit) recognized that and urged trade ministers to move
with alacrity."

Time is running out for the Uruguay Round. In three weeks, the trade
negotiating committee of GATT meets to draft frameworks for all 15 subject
areas, including agriculture, covered by the multilateral talks that wrap
up in Brussels this December.

However, six weeks ago at a meeting of the Organization for Economic
Co-operation and Development in Paris, a forerunner of the Houston summit,
the divisions between the United States and the EC ran so deep on the farm
issue that the final communique only stated the two opposing views.

Dale Hathaway, a former senior U.S. Department of Agriculture official
and now a Washington consultant, is skeptical that the Houston summit will
produce a breakthrough on agriculture.

"Either the U.S. drops its demands or the Europeans go back for a new
mandate (on agriculture)," he said. "Neither is going to happen
politically at this point."

He said he will be "surprised" if the summit does more than extoll the
virtues of a successful Uruguay Round, including agriculture. Even with
such a bland statement, the summit leaders will likely declare their
three-day session a success.

                              293 of 998 DOCUMENTS

                               The New York Times

              September 3, 1988, Saturday, Late City Final Edition

School Lunch Chief Charged In Theft of Food for Nightclub

BYLINE: By MARVINE HOWE

SECTION: Section 1; Page 29, Column 1; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 317 words


The school lunch director for public schools in Hempstead, L.I., was arrested
yesterday on charges of stealing food from the lunch program.

Officials said Samuel V. Eveleno, who was in charge of food donated by the
United States Deparment of Agriculture, used the food in a Huntington nightclub,
where he had the food concession.

The complaint, filed by the United States Attorney for the Eastern District of
New York, said 50 to 60 cases were taken by Mr. Eveleno since August 1987, when
he became operator of the Backstage Cafe in the East Side Comedy Club. In the
complaint, a special agent for the United States Department of Agriculture,
Stephen T. Grogan, said an employee of Mr. Eveleno had told him that the
defendant usually took the food to the cafe every other week.

The food included American, mozzarella and cheddar cheese; raisins; peanuts;
tomatoes; refried beans; tomato paste; honey; spaghetti; butter; french fried
and instant mashed potatoes; fish nuggets, and mixed vegetables, the complaint
said. It did not list the value of the food.

Mr. Grogan said the diversion was discovered when a Suffolk County health
inspector in a routine inspection of the cafe discovered 320 pounds of federally
donated food. Mr. Grogan said other Government food was observed on three later
visits.

Mr. Eveleno, 56 years old, of Greenlawn, L.I., was arraigned before Magistrate
Carol B. Amon and released on his own recognizance. Neither he nor his lawyer,
Stephen C. Worth would make a comment. If Mr. Eveleno is convicted, he would
face five years' in prison and a maximum fine of $250,000.

An assistant school superintendent, James Galloway, said that Mr. Eveleno did
''not work for the public school system'' and that he was employed by a
subcontractor, Preferred Meals, part of TW Services Inc. Mr. Galloway said the
lunch program served 2,500 of the 5,200 students in the district.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                   Copyright 1988 The New York Times Company


                              294 of 998 DOCUMENTS



                                US Official News

                            August 25, 2015 Tuesday

CBP Preclearance in Shannon, Ireland Welcomes New Agriculture Canine Enforcement
Team

LENGTH: 417  words

DATELINE: Washington


Customs and Border Protection, The Government of USA has issued the following
news release:

U.S. Customs and Border Protection recently welcomed a new agriculture canine
enforcement team to the Preclearance facility in Shannon, Ireland. "Kingston," a
two-year-old beagle, arrived in Ireland in early August and was reunited with
his handler, CBP Agriculture Specialist
"Kingston and I are excited to be the first line in defending American
agriculture from harmful pests and disease prior to them entering the U.S. as
the only agriculture canine team at a Preclearance facility," said CBPAS Hall.
"Being a part of a canine detection team is not only one of the greatest jobs
there is at CBP, but it is also one of the most important."

The more than 116 CBP agriculture canine teams at ports of entry, land borders
and mail facilities are the front line in the fight against the introduction of
harmful insects and disease into the United States. Every pest or disease
intercepted could cause million in damages to U.S. agriculture. CBP agriculture
specialists' vigilance helps protect America's farms, forests and natural
resources.

"We are very pleased to have CBP Agriculture Specialist Hall and her K-9 partner
Kingston on board here in Shannon Preclearance," said (Acting) Port Director
Gregory Starr. "The CBP agriculture mission is an integral part of our
processing and we are extremely fortunate to have this canine team asset at our
Preclearance location."

Prior to arriving in Ireland, the team completed a mandatory U.S. Department of
Agriculture training at the National Detector Dog Training Center (USDA NDDTC)
in Georgia. All the detector canines at USDA NDDTC are adopted from rescue
shelters in the U.S., like Kingston was, or gifted through private donations.
CBPAS Hall joined CBP in 2005 and became a canine handler in 2007.

CBP Preclearance operations allow for advance inspection of passengers and
special coordination with law enforcement upon arrival in the United States.
Through preclearance, the same immigration, customs, and agriculture inspections
of international air passengers performed on arrival in the United States are
instead completed before departure at foreign airports.  Currently, preclearance
operations exist at 15 foreign airports in six different countries, benefitting
air passengers, airports, and air carriers, in the United States and abroad.

                              295 of 998 DOCUMENTS

                               The New York Times

                  March 19, 2000, Sunday, Late Edition - Final

A Battle Over Beetles Takes On Urgency

BYLINE: By DAVID STOUT

SECTION: Section A; Page 28; Column 3; National Desk

LENGTH: 646 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 18


Tree experts around New York City and Chicago are girding for a warm-weather
offensive against a creature, little more than an inch long, that could destroy
as much woodland as some of the worst forest fires in history.

The creature is the Asian long-horned beetle, which kills trees by eating them
from the inside and which has no natural enemies in the United States. Once a
tree is infected, it is doomed. Thousands of trees have been felled and ground
into bits to try to check the beetles' advance.

Federal and state agriculture officials have spent several million dollars and
expect to spend millions more in fighting the beetle, which was first spotted in
the United States four years ago.

The United States Department of Agriculture has assigned some of its top experts
to the campaign. Now, the department and the Environmental Protection Agency are
weighing whether to use a nicotine-based pesticide, one they think would carry
minimal risks to people and other trees.

"This is potentially a very, very serious problem," Agriculture Secretary Dan
Glickman said in a recent interview.

Officials say huge tracts of forest could be ruined. Vermont, which relies on
maple trees for its syrup business and its famed autumn foliage, has particular
reason to worry. Maples are among the many trees the beetle loves to dine on,
although none of the creatures have been spotted in the state.

Female beetles bore deep into trees to lay eggs. The larvae then eat their way
out, flying away and leaving their doomed hosts pocked with perfectly round
holes. Because adult beetles are active only in the summer and fall, officials
are mapping plans now.

Mr. Glickman and several others said that they were optimistic and that this
year would be the turning point. They think the nicotine-based pesticide will
work even though others have not. But they conceded that there was a long battle
ahead.

"We're going to eradicate it," said Vic Mastro, an entomologist with the
Department of Agriculture. "It's not going to be an easy or short process. But
we said that at the beginning."

In the beginning, there was Greenpoint, Brooklyn. The beetle's first known
outpost in this country was discovered there in 1996, after the beetle-colonists
traveled from China in a shipping container.

Before long, the beetles were found in other sections of Brooklyn, then in parts
of Queens and Manhattan. Soon, they were in Amityville, and then elsewhere on
Long Island. More than 4,000 trees were cut down in the New York region, some of
them magnificent giants that were saplings when Lincoln was president.

"We thought we had it off the mainland," said Joe Gittleman, the Agriculture
Department's leading beetle fighter in New York State.

So there was a sense of dread in 1998 when the beetles were found in the Chicago
area, perhaps because young beetles hitched a ride on a truck fender, or in logs
from infected trees. More than 1,000 trees have been cut down around Chicago.

The Forest Service and local agencies have been planting new trees, of species
less susceptible to the beetles, but it will be years before they are as tall as
the ones that were lost.

Officials say the Chinese have agreed to treat wooden shipping pallets, in an
effort to stop more beetles from coming to the United States. Quarantines have
been imposed on firewood from areas where infected trees have been found.

Ken Kruse, the Agriculture Department's beetle-campaign leader in Chicago, said
tree trimmers and landscapers had been very cooperative in identifying and
destroying infected trees. "But how do you get the last one?" he asked.

Still, although the battle is long and hard, it is also interesting for
scientists who were not previously familiar with the Asian long-horned beetle.
"It's something you could spend a career on," Mr. Mastro said. Not that he wants
to.


http://www.nytimes.com

around New York and Chicago. (United States Department of Agriculture)

                               The New York Times

                            June 15, 2005 Wednesday
                              Late Edition - Final

U.S. Receives Assurance From Japan on Beef Exports

BYLINE: By ALEXEI BARRIONUEVO and DONALD G. McNEIL Jr.

SECTION: Section A; Column 5; National Desk; Pg. 20

LENGTH: 867 words

DATELINE: CHICAGO, June 14


The United States Agriculture Department won assurance from the Japanese
government on Tuesday that a second potential case of mad cow disease found on
American soil would not affect negotiations to resume beef exports to Japan, the
top American export market.

But critics of the department's mad cow testing program said the case
underscored the need for more intensive testing to determine how prevalent the
fatal, brain-wasting disease was in the American herd.

The Agriculture Department said Friday that it had found bovine spongiform
encephalopathy, or mad cow disease, in an animal that had tested negative last
November. It would be the second case of the disease to be found in the United
States, and the fifth in North America, since 2003.

On Monday Taiwan, which had resumed imports of American beef two months ago, and
South Korea, which had been negotiating to restart them, expressed concern about
the new case. Taiwanese officials said that if a final round of testing
confirmed the disease that it would cease importing American beef. The news
helped sink cattle future prices to their lowest level in 13 months.

But beef prices recovered slightly on Tuesday after Japanese officials said the
latest discovery would not derail plans to restart exports to Japan, which
imported $1.4 billion worth of American beef in 2003, or 36 percent of all
American exports.

''This incident will not have any impact on our process,'' Shin Yokoyama,
Japan's agriculture counselor to the United States, said in an interview about
the negotiations. Mr. Yokoyama said his government was not bothered by the
discovery because the animal was older than 20 months, the cutoff age for
accepting beef into Japan.

''If this cow is born in the United States and raised in the United States it
still doesn't matter,'' Mr. Yokoyama said. ''As long as it is old.'' Japan,
which has been testing all its cattle since September 2001, has found 20 cases,
the most recent on June 6.

American agriculture officials said more tests would be conducted on the small
amount of remaining brain tissue from the animal at a laboratory in Ames, Iowa,
and at the world's premier mad cow testing facility, in Weybridge, England. The
process could take up to two weeks.

Taiwan, Japan and South Korea were among 53 countries that banned American beef
after mad cow was discovered in December 2003 in a dairy cow in Washington
State. Through intense lobbying, the Bush administration has restored about
one-third of its beef exports.

American officials have emphasized that there is no risk to humans from the
animal that tested positive on Friday because it was destroyed and did not get
into the animal or human food supply. The cow found in Washington had been sold
as hamburger.

So far, officials have released little else about the latest potential case,
other than that the cow was at least eight years old and was most likely not
imported.

The cow's origin could prove critical to efforts to restore the American beef
trade. In trying to bless the American herd as mad cow-free, American officials
have emphasized that the Washington cow was born in Canada before a 1997 feed
ban. The United States banned live cattle from Canada after mad cow was
discovered in a Canadian cow in May 2003.

In the latest American case, the cow tested positive only after the Office of
Inspector General, an independent watchdog group within the Agriculture
Department, required the use of a second type of test on three suspect animals
first tested in November.

Critics of the Agriculture Department asked Tuesday why the department had
refused for more than six months to perform the tests, called Western
blot.Michael K. Hansen, a senior research associate at Consumers Union, produced
copies of letters he wrote in January to the department's chief veterinary
officer and in February to the new secretary of agriculture, Mike Johanns,
asking the department to use the Western blot test on the cow's brain. He said
the newest test, used in Europe and Japan, where more mad cow cases have
surfaced, is 1,000 times more sensitive than the test used by the Agriculture
Department, the immunohistochemistry test.

In a letter dated March 18, an agriculture official replied that the department
did not think a Western blot test ''would have enhanced the result of our
November 2004 testing,'' and did not think that confirmatory testing in England
was necessary.

In the past, the Agriculture Department has repeatedly called its
immunohistochemistry test the ''gold standard'' for detection. But tests in
Belgium and Japan have shown, Dr. Hansen said, that it missed some cases. Ed
Loyd, an Agriculture Department spokesman, said the department made use of both
tests but usually used the Western blot test only when samples began to degrade.
''This is an instance where we had a very good sample.''

Since the discovery of the first mad cow case in 2003 the department enhanced
its surveillance program, testing 375,000 cattle, up from fewer than 20,000, and
testing high-risk ''downer'' cattle that are struggling to walk. But discussions
are underway to end the testing program, Mr. Loyd said.

                     Belfast News Letter (Northern Ireland)

                           August 25, 2004, Wednesday

US GIVES TEXAS BIRD FLU ALL-CLEAR

SECTION: 1st Edition; NEWS; Pg. 6

LENGTH: 359 words


The United States of America considers itself free from highly pathogenic avian
influenza.

Dr Peter Fernandez, Associate Administrator, Animal and Plant Health Inspection
Service, United States Department of Agriculture (USDA), Washington, DC, said
that the avian influenza virus strain (H5N2) detected in one non-commercial
flock and two live bird markets (LBMs) in Gonzalez County, Texas, had been
completely eradicated.

"Six months have passed since the detection and eradication of the virus strain,
and the completion of cleaning and disinfection of all the affected premises
(LBMs and backyard flock).

"Targeted and extensive surveillance has not detected any further evidence of
the virus," he said. "Also, as previously mentioned, with the successful
eradication of the virus, the State quarantine orders on affected premises were
released. The virus has been completely stamped out and in accordance with
Article 2.1.14.2 of the Terrestrial Animal Health Code, the United States of
America considers itself free from highly pathogenic avian influenza."

Meanwhile highly pathogenic avian influenza has been reported in Peninsular
Malaysia for the first time.

Dr Hawari Bin Hussein, Director General, Department of Veterinary Service,
Ministry of Agriculture, Kuala Lumpur, said that the disease had been detected
in one flock of village chickens consisting of 60 birds of mixed ages reared
free-range.

He said that the source of agent/origin of infection was under investigation.

Dr Bin Hussein pointed out that, within a one-kilometre radius of the affected
flock, there were a further 103 village chickens, 62 birds of mixed species and
eight ducks (173 birds). All these birds are clinically healthy and were also
reared free range.

Control measures are in force. Depopulation of poultry and birds within a
one-kilometre radius of the infected flock is ongoing, as well as quarantine and
clinical surveillance within a 10km radius of the infected flock.

Restrictions on the movement of birds and their products to other states are in
force along with clinical surveillance in the whole of Kelantan State.

                              Journal of Commerce

                           April 14, 1999, Wednesday

EU faces battle on farm subsidies

BYLINE: BRIDGE NEWS

SECTION: FINANCE; Pg. 2A

LENGTH: 219 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON


The United States and members of South America's Mercosur trade bloc met Monday
to form a common strategy against the European Union's agricultural subsidies.

Both Mercosur and the United States are expected to pressure the EU to do more
to remove such subsidies at the next round of World Trade Organization talks,
which the United States will host. The talks are scheduled to begin Nov. 30 in
Seattle.

That gathering could yield a new round of world trade negotiations that is
expected to center on issues of agricultural trade, on which the United States
and Europe have split sharply.

Agriculture ministers from Argentina, Brazil, Paraguay and Uruguay, as well as
associate Mercosur members Chile and Bolivia, met with U.S. Secretary of
Agriculture Dan Glickman here to reaffirm their will to work together.

Mr. Glickman told reporters that Washington hopes to push for lower subsidies of
agricultural exports as well as a discussion on health standards.

Paraguayan Agriculture Minister Luis Alberto Wagner said there will be meetings
to craft a common strategy ahead of the WTO gathering.

""There are more points of agreement than disagreement, and we will focus on the
few problems in order to resolve our differences,'' said Uruguayan Agriculture
Minister Ignacio Zorrilla de San Martin.

                              299 of 998 DOCUMENTS


                          The Globe and Mail (Canada)

                             March 7, 1998 Saturday

OECD members target farm subsidies  Agriculture ministers agree on reduction,
but disagree on timing and how to do it

BYLINE: BY HEATHER SCOFFIELD Parliamentary Bureau

SECTION: REPORT ON BUSINESS; Pg. B2

LENGTH: 479 words

DATELINE: OTTAWA


Agriculture ministers from the world's richest countries agreed yesterday to
reduce export subsidies on farm products, but they were not able to agree on how
or when, according to Canadian Agriculture Minister Lyle Vanclief.

Mr. Vanclief met with his counterparts in Paris from the other 28 countries in
the Organization for Economic Co-operation and Development yesterday and
Thursday to set a common course for future agriculture trade policy.

Everyone agreed to address trade barriers in the agriculture industry and to
target price-distorting subsidies in the next round of agriculture talks at the
World Trade Organization, scheduled to start at the end of 1999, Mr. Vanclief
said.

"The sense was clearly that was the direction we want to go," he said in a
conference call from Paris. But the methods and pace of reducing trade barriers
were the subjects of much debate, he said.

"From the Canadian perspective, I know that we have made good strides among the
leaders quite frankly as far as liberalizing trade, and that shows very clearly
[in the final communiqué].

"But we must be cautious that we do not move further without the others, so that
our industry is treated fairly compared to those in the other members of the
OECD. . . . One cannot get out of step."

Consumers and taxpayers in the OECD spent $280-billion (U.S.) on agricultural
policies in 1997, or about 1.3 per cent of gross domestic product for the group,
the OECD communiqué said.

That the ministers were actually able to sign a communiqué was significant.
Agriculture has always been a troublesome issue in global trade talks because of
the high subsidies and tariffs in the industry; this meeting was no different.
The United States was vociferous in its attack on protectionism, while Japan,
with its many small farms, was far more reluctant to drop protectionist
measures. And France, which relies on farm subsidies to prop up incomes, clashed
with the European Union proposals to cut farm support.

While the ministers emphasized the need to foster free trade in agriculture,
they also recognized the need to use government policy to support rural culture
and other social policy goals.

And the ministers vowed to take food safety concerns into account, and allow
actions to protect the environment and sustainable development, despite concerns
from Canada and the United States that these measures could become trade
barriers.

"All that type of activity must be science-based and cannot be emotionally
based," Mr. Vanclief warned.

Mr. Vanclief is meeting today with agriculture ministers of the so-called Quint
group of key agriculture exporters -- Canada, the United States, the European
Union, Australia and Japan. They hope to nail down more details for the next WTO
round of agriculture talks in 1999. Canada is expected to be under attack for
its supply management policies and the Canadian Wheat Board.

                               The New York Times

                June 11, 1981, Thursday, Late City Final Edition

RECORD U.S. WHEAT CROP FORECAST

BYLINE: By SETH S. KING, Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section D; Page 1, Column 6; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 611 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 10


The Agriculture Department today predicted a record American wheat crop for the
second consecutive year, giving the United States greater flexibility in
negotiating additional grain sales to the Soviet Union.

The department's latest crop report, which followed yesterday's offer to resume
selling grain to the Russians, estimated that the 1981 winter wheat harvest
would be 2.01 billion bushels, or 54.8 million metric tons. This would be 6
percent larger than last year's crop but 3 percent less than the department
forecast in May.

Although the per-acre yield is expected to be about one bushel less than last
year, farmers have planted 10 percent more acreage in winter wheat than last
year, the department said in its report on conditions as of June 1.

The Agriculture Department also released its latest monthly forecast of how much
grain the world's farmers will grow in the 1981-82 crop year. It predicted total
world grain production of 1.64 billion metric tons, slightly less than was
estimated last month but still about 5 percent above the 1980-81 total.

Outlook for Soviet Harvest

The June 1 forecast of Soviet grain production was unchanged from the 210
million tons predicted a month before. This total would fall short of the Soviet
target by more than 26 million tons, indicating that the Russians again might
have to import large supplies of grain to maintain their livestock herds.

After two days of talks with the Russians in London, the United States said
yesterday that the Soviet Union would be allowed to start buying American grain
again if it wished to do so.

Winter wheat, the principal bread variety that accounts for threefourths of the
wheat grown in the United States, is planted in October or November and is ripe
by early summer of the following year. America's winter wheat harvest has
already started in the Southwest.

It is still too early for the Agriculture Department to estimate this year's
American production of spring wheat because the crop has just been planted.
Spring wheat, which includes varieties used in pasta and pastries, will be
harvested early next fall.

This month's report on pasture conditions in the upper Middle West, where spring
wheat is grown, showed a shortage of moisture in that area. This could mean
smaller spring wheat yields.

Bigger Plantings Reported

But the department's wheat situation report in mid-May noted sharply increased
plantings of spring wheat, indicating that this year's total wheat production in
the United States would probably reach 2.7 billion bushels. This would be nearly
15 percent above last year's record of 2.4 billion bushels.

As the new wheat crop year began last week, American wheat farmers had a
carry-over, or surplus, of about 950 million bushels, the largest since 1978. If
the present crop does reach 2.7 billion bushels, the total supply for the
1981-82 crop year will be one of the largest in history.

Even if the United States manages to export nearly two-thirds of its total
production, as it often does, the 1981 carryover will be very large, placing
wheat prices under downward pressure.

Such pressure would be eased if the Russians buy most of the three million tons,
or about 111 million bushels, of wheat from the 1980 crop that was offered for
sale to them at yesterday's grain talks in London. Prices that American farmers
get would be helped even more if the Russians should order, for delivery next
winter, an additional three million tons from the 1981 crop, also offered
yesterday.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                   Copyright 1981 The New York Times Company

Farm ministers meeting

SECTION: SECTION 1, NEWS; Pg. 43, Ontario News

LENGTH: 113 words


Agriculture Minister Ralph Goodale said he and U.S. Agriculture Secretary Mike
Espy have tentative plans to meet in Toronto Monday to discuss various trade
disputes between the two countries. The officials are expected to discuss, among
other things, Canadian shipments of durum wheat and dairy products to the U.S.
The U.S. has turned up the heat in recent days, threatening to take unilateral
action againt Canadian wheat and dairy exports as well as other commodities if
no agreement is reached next week. ''All of the issues that we have been
discussing remain on the table,'' Goodale said. ''None of them have been
resolved and none of them have gone away.''

                          The Globe and Mail (Canada)

                             April 15, 1994 Friday

Canada-U.S. farm trade talks break off   Espy seeks reduction of Canada's dairy,
egg   and poultry protection, and concessions on wheat

BYLINE: MADELAINE DROHAN; GAM

LENGTH: 595 words

DATELINE: Marrakesh MOROCCO


BY MADELAINE DROHAN
European Bureau
  MARRAKESH
 Negotiations between Canada and the United States on a bilateral farm
dispute broke off yesterday with U.S. Agriculture Secretary Mike Espy
taking a tough line on Canada's continued protection of its dairy, egg and
poultry producers.

Mr. Espy made it clear that for a resolution to be reached in the
talks, which resume today, Canada will have to reduce that protection.

"Supply management is just not a system that's consistent with the
doctrine of free trade," he said, emerging from a meeting with Canadian
Agriculture Minister Ralph Goodale, International Trade Minister Roy
MacLaren and U.S. Trade Representative Mickey Kantor.

Mr. Espy's comments could be bluster in order to force concessions on
wheat exports to the United States, which are also in dispute. Or it could
be that the United States wants to win on both counts.

This will dismay Canadian officials who believed the question of
protection for dairy, egg and poultry producers was settled as part of the
world trade deal reached by members of the General Agreement on Tariffs
and Trade in December. Indeed, the Canadians believed they'd finessed the
United States by acceding to its demand that import quotas be replaced by
tariffs, and then setting the tariffs extraordinarily high. On butter, for
example, Canada will start with a tariff of $4.71 a kilogram, reducing it
over five years to $4.

Not surprisingly, a U.S. Department of Agriculture analysis of the
impact of the world trade deal indicates no gains for U.S. farmers in
these Canadian markets.

"Canada tariffied at prohibitive levels, extremely high levels," Mr.
Espy said. "That's very creative. Very innovative. But it's not trade
creating."

Mr. Goodale said he wasn't optimistic or pessimistic that the two sides
would reach a deal when they returned to the table today. And he rejected
the supposed April 22 deadline, saying it was something the United States
had pulled out of thin air.

He said it was only scheduling problems that prevented the two sides
from meeting again last night. The U.S. side was tied up with the visit of
U.S. Vice-President Al Gore and a bilateral meeting with the Japanese.

And while he would not elaborate on the issues still dividing the two
sides, Mr. Goodale indicated he would not reject out of hand a cap on
wheat exports to the United States. "I regard the idea of a cap as
something that is certainly not desirable, but I've also gone on to say
that as a practical matter, whether a cap at some point becomes acceptable
depends on a number of things." They include what the limit is, how long
it is in effect and what other changes would be made affecting wheat
exports.

While the United States is not threatening to reject the world trade
deal until these bilateral matters are settled, they could become part of
the debate in Congress, which has to ratify the GATT deal before it
becomes law in the United States.

The Canadian Parliament also has to pass legislation to implement the
deal. This is expected in September this year.

A long-simmering dispute between Canada and Australia over beef imports
to Canada also came to a boil yesterday with Australia launching action
under the GATT to force Canada to provide more access to its markets.

Although Canada has been preoccupied with bilateral talks with the
United States, the reason the trade ministers are in town is the official
ending of the Uruguay Round of GATT trade negotiations. GATT officials
said the number of participants in the round has risen in recent days to
125 from 121 after several former colonies of GATT members opted to join.

                              303 of 998 DOCUMENTS

                              Journal of Commerce

                            December 1, 1989, Friday

THE JOURNAL OF COMMERCE EXPORTERS' CLIP AND SAVE SERVICE AGRICULTURE IN U.S.
FOREIGN ECONOMIC POLICY

SECTION: EXPORTS, Pg. 5A

LENGTH: 867 words


BACKGROUND: U.S. agricultural exports make an important contribution to U.S.
foreign policy objectives. One priority of U.S. policy is to work toward a more
open, equitable trading environment, which should result in improved export
opportunities for U.S. agricultural products.

Another priority is greater cooperation in food aid, food security and
gricultural economic development in developing countries.

The United States participates in international organizations that address
global food issues.

U.S. AGRICULTURAL TRADE: Agricultural products accounted for about 12 percent of
U.S. exports and earned $ 35.3 billion in fiscal year 1988, compared with 19
percent and $ 44 billion in 1981, a peak year.

Although the United States is still the major exporter of coarse grains and
soybeans, and one of the largest suppliers of wheat, cotton, meat and
horticultural products, the U.S. position has been eroding because of increased
competition, primarily from the European Community and several developing
countries. Nevertheless, agriculture is one of the few sectors where the United
States consistently registers a trade surplus.

The United States is also an important market for agricultural products from
around the world. U.S. imports increased from $ 17 billion in fiscal year 1981
to $ 21 billion in fiscal year 1988. Coffee is the single largest import.

PROBLEMS IN AGRICULTURE: The volume of world trade in agriculture has been
declining in the 1980s. Government policies and support programs have cushioned
agricultural producers from the need to adjust to market changes caused by
improved technology and slower growth in demand.

The result has been chronic surpluses and huge government expenditures to
support agriculture. Unfortunately, in many cases the programs do not target the
neediest farmers. In 1981, the United States spent $ 4 billion on farm programs;
by 1986, the figure had jumped to $ 26 billion, before falling to $ 22.4 billion
in 1987.

World prices for most major crops rose in 1988 because of the drought and caused
U.S. spending on farm programs to drop sharply to $ 12.5 billion.

Without a change in agricultural policies, however, the problems caused by
oversupply and low prices are likely to re-emerge.

AGRICULTURAL TRADE POLICY: The Bush administration has placed a high priority on
resolving agricultural problems at the multilateral and bilateral levels. The
United States was instrumental in getting agriculture on the agenda for the
Uruguay Round of multilateral trade negotiations that began in September 1986.

Insisting that comprehensive and expeditious negotiations are the best way to
tackle the global problem in agricultural trade, the administration is
encouraging other governments to join it in making agricultural reform a
priority.

Last April, the United States and its Uruguay Round trading partners
successfully concluded a framework agreement on agriculture that specifies the
objectives and timetable for the multilateral agriculture negotiations. The
United States also is working in the 24-nation Organization for Economic
Cooperation and Development based in Paris to develop a consensus on the urgent
need for agricultural reform.

On the bilateral side, the main thrust of administration efforts is to maintain
and improve market access for U.S. products. For wheat and certain other
commodities, the United States selectively provides export subsidies through the
Export Enhancement Program to compete with subsidized agricultural exports of o
ther countries.

PROMOTION PROGRAMS: Trade promotion is an important means of boosting farm
exports. U.S. embassies overseas promote the following programs:

* Commodity Credit Corp. credits and credit guarantees have received broad
acceptance. In fiscal year 1988, U.S. agricultural sales were assisted by CCC
credits and guarantees totaling more than $ 4.5 billion. Mexico, Iraq, Brazil,
South Korea and Portugal together account for more than half this amount.

* PL-480 (Food for Peace) aid has proved to be a long-term market development
tool as well as a means of meeting economic development and other foreign policy
goals. Several countries, including Brazil, South Korea, Turkey, Spain and
Yugoslavia, have "graduated" from the PL-480 program to become large commercial
customers for products formerly provided on concessional credit.

* One of the most successful agricultural export promotion efforts is the U.S.
Department of Agriculture's Cooperator Market Development Program. This brings
together more than 50 non-profit agricultural commodity associations with the
USDA's Foreign Agricultural Service in market development activities throughout
the world. The program enables the U.S. government and private industry to pool
resources, so that each gets more mileage out of such activities.

FOR FURTHER INFORMATION ON THIS TOPIC: Contact Harriet Culley, Editor, Bureau of
Public Affairs, U.S. Department of State, (202) 647-1208.

''CLIP AND SAVE" is a feature of The Journal of Commerce. For information on how
to receive reprints in the series, call John Hoey at the number listed below. To
suggest topics, call Robert R. Frump.

LOAD-DATE: December 19, 1996

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

EDITOR-NOTE: THE JOURNAL OF COMMERCE EXPORTERS' CLIP AND SAVE SERVICE

                  Copyright 1989 The Journal of Commerce, Inc.


                              304 of 998 DOCUMENTS

                                The Toronto Star

                    November 30, 1987, Monday, FINAL EDITION

Washington offers Soviets new subsidized wheat deal

BYLINE: (REUTER)

SECTION: BUSINESS TODAY; Pg. B2

LENGTH: 460 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON


   WASHINGTON (Reuter) - The United States on Friday offered the Soviet Union
another 2.35 million metric tons of subsidized wheat in an apparent bid to
entice Moscow to continue its agricultural buying binge.

The agriculture department said the wheat was offered to Moscow under its export
subsidy program, called export enhancement.

Since April, the Soviet Union has purchased over 5.7 million tons of American
wheat at cut-rate prices. The new offer means the United States has offered
Moscow 8.8 million tons of subsidized wheat this year, in three separate
installments, totaling more than 10 percent of the entire U.S. wheat crop.

Washington offered 4.0 million tons to Moscow on April 30 and 2.4 million on
Nov. 9 as well as the 2.35 million announced on Friday.

A senior agriculture department official said the new offer was responding to
Soviet grain import needs.

Another offer

"Since they had now bought 1.7 million tons of the 2.4 (offer on Nov. 9) we
thought we should respond with another offer," said Tom Kay, administrator of
the agriculture department's Foreign Agricultural Service.

He said the quantity 2.35 million tons was decided upon because "they (Soviets)
ran that figure by us."

Meanwhile, European Community (EC) traders said in Brussels that they sold
nearly 1.0 million tons of bread-making wheat to the Soviet Union at just over a
third of the price it pays its own farmers. The deal handed European traders the
latest round in a seven-year fight with the United States for Moscow's market.

In recent weeks, Moscow also has bought 1.6 million tons of wheat from the
United States under a previous subsidy offer, 1.6 million tons of corn, 1.3
million tons of soybean meal and 800,000 tons of soybeans, according to the
agriculture department. The corn, soybean meal and soybeans were purchased
without the aid of a U.S. government subsidy.

The wheat sales are subsidized by providing private export traders who sign
sales contracts with Moscow with a certificate that entitles them to receive
surplus U.S. commodities in government storage. The amount of commodities
provided to the traders are enough to bridge the gap between high U.S. wheat
prices and depressed world market prices.

The EC has a different export subsidy program that has similar effects.

Fierce competition between the United States and EC for the lucrative Soviet
market has kept world wheat prices at depressed levels this year despite reduced
production in some key countries such as India, farm analysts said.

Some Soviet farm analysts have also speculated that the buying spree by Moscow
may be timed just before the superpower summit in early December between
President Reagan and Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev.

LOAD-DATE: May 13, 1999

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                  Copyright 1987 Toronto Star Newspapers, Ltd.


                              305 of 998 DOCUMENTS

                               The New York Times

                January 1, 1997, Wednesday, Late Edition - Final

Farm Price Index Declines by 1.8%

BYLINE: Reuters

SECTION: Section 1; Page 62; Column 3; Business/Financial Desk

LENGTH: 146 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 31


Lower prices for wheat, corn, oranges, cattle and milk pushed the farm price
index down by 1.8 percent in December, the United States Agriculture Department
said on Monday.

The index, a gauge of prices paid to farmers for their crops and livestock, had
a December reading of 108, down from 110 in November but unchanged from a year
ago.

Wheat dipped 12 cents, to an average of $4.02 a bushel, and was 86 cents below
the price in December 1995. The department said projected increases in world
wheat output caused prices at home to fall.

Corn prices were driven lower by the third-largest United States crop on record.
Corn was $2.56 a bushel, off 10 cents from November and 51 cents from December
1995.

Milk prices continued to decline after hitting a record high in September,
easing to $14.20 for one hundred pounds in December, down 80 cents from
November.

LOAD-DATE: January 1, 1997

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                   Copyright 1997 The New York Times Company


                              306 of 998 DOCUMENTS



                                US Official News

                            April 6, 2016 Wednesday

Washington: Progreso Port of Entry CBP Agriculture Specialists Intercept Rare
First in Nation Pest in Cut Flowers

LENGTH: 262  words

DATELINE: Lahore



 Washington: U.S. Customs and Border Protection has issued the following news
release:



 Agriculture specialists with U.S. Customs and Border Protection, Office of
Field Operations (OFO) at the Progreso International Bridge import cargo lot
intercepted a rare "First in Nation" pest in a shipment of cut flowers.



 "The interception of this unique, first in nation pest is an outstanding
example of the diligence and dedication of our CBP agriculture specialists in
safeguarding the agriculture of the United States," said Port Director Nestor
Garza III, Progreso Port of Entry.



 The interception occurred on Feb. 17, at the Progreso International Bridge
import lot when a shipment of cut flowers was referred to agriculture for
inspection.  Upon inspection of the cut flowers, CBP agriculture specialists
intercepted the pest on Dracaena sp. leaves.  The pest was submitted for
identification to a U.S. Department of Agriculture entomologist. The initial
identification was later confirmed by a national specialist as Charidotis
vitreata (Perty), a pest not known to occur in the United States and intercepted
for the first time at a port of entry. This insect belongs to the Chrysomelidae
family, commonly known as leaf beetles.  Many leaf beetles are serious pests of
cultivated plants, and a few act as vectors of plant diseases.



 Given the quarantine status of Charidotis vitreata (Perty), the cut flowers
were destroyed as a precautionary measure.



 In case of any query regarding this article or other content needs please
contact:

 editorial@plusmediasolutions.com

LOAD-DATE: April 7, 2016

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newswire

                              Journal of Commerce

                             May 31, 1990, Thursday

OECD SESSION RAPS US MOVE ON FARM TRADE

BYLINE: BRUCE BARNARD; Journal of Commerce Staff (Keith Rockwell contributed to
this story.)

SECTION: FRONT, Pg. 1A

LENGTH: 922 words

DATELINE: PARIS


The United States came under fire here for attempting to bring farm trade
negotiations from the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade to a meeting of the
Organization for Economic Cooperatio n and Development.

The United States made a "serious" mistake by trying to negotiate here, Frans
Andriessen, the EC's trade commissioner, charged. "If you try to negotiate here,
you damage the whole process (of the GATT Uruguay Round)," he aid.

U.S. officials, however, said the community's hard line stance on agriculture
has isolated Brussels from the other members of the OECD. Ministers from New
Zealand, Canada, and Australia strongly criticized the community's position
during heated debate Wednesday.

"It's starting to become clearer and clearer that people are tired of this. We
are not the only ones," said one U.S. official.

Community plans for addressing the question of reducing farm subsidies remain
vague, the official said, while the United States and other grain producers seek
to develop a mechanism for cutting such support.

"They are still talking about overall, emcompassing aggregate issues, and we're
trying to solve the problem," the official continued.

The long-simmering dispute between the United States and the European Community
over agriculture injected further uncertainty into delicately poised
multilateral negotiations to liberalize world trade under GATT.

A Canadian official raised the problem of GATT's long-term future, according to
Knight-Ridder Financial News. Canada's trade minister, John Crosbie, urged that
GATT be supplanted soon by a broader global agreement, regardless of the outcome
of the Uruguay Round.

He said he hoped a statement of support for negotiations to begin a new
organization would result from the OECD meeting.

Mr. Crosbie claimed support from the United States, the EC and Japan, according
to the KRF report from Paris. But U.S. and EC diplomats have not voiced any
support to the idea of a new organization since that would concede failure of
the Uruguay round.

The United States wanted this week's ministerial meeting of the OECD to focus on
agricultural subsidies, an issue that has threatened to scuttle the current
Uruguay Round of GATT.

The EC, whose 12 member states account for half the OECD membership of 24
leading industrial countries, reacted angrily to Washington's bid to elevate a
normally relaxed OECD meeting to a hands-on negotiating forum.

Before the meeting began, Richard Crowder, the U.S. agriculture undersecretary,
said the United States and the EC might not be able to agree on a common
statement on agriculture at the close of the OECD meeting. "We could end up with
separate communiques," he said.

In that event, both sides would save face.

The EC was satisfied that the communique will commit OECD members to refrain
from unilateral settlements of trade disputes. The EC has long berated
Washington for seeking to resolve its trade disputes outside GATT and has kept
up a constant attack against the controversial Super 301 provision of the 1988
U.S. Trade Act.

The U.S. position was buoyed in that the communique will refer to the
differences in agriculture policy. Carla A. Hills, the U.S. Trade
Representative, said Wednesday that "The United States has stood by its position
(on agriculture)."

Reaction was heated.

Trading nations should clarify their positions only in the formal Uruguay Round
negotiations in Geneva in late July, Mr. Andriessen said. Moreover, several farm
exporting nations were not represented at the OECD meeting, he added.

Washington's hard-line approach, signaled last week by President Bush when he
warned that the United States would reject an unsatisfactory Uruguay Round
accord, was re-emphasized here by Mrs. Hills.

She said the OECD must focus its efforts on three issues that are threatening
the success of the Uruguay Round: agriculture, subsidies, and the developing
countries' integration into the GATT regime.

To achieve fundamental reform in agriculture, Mrs. Hills said, GATT must have in
place by July a framework for achieving substantial progressive reduction in
each of the areas of negotiation - market access, internal supports and export
subsidies.

"After July, the hard bargaining must begin over how far and how fast reduction
in each area are to be achieved," Mrs. Hills said. "The result should be
translated into finding country programs that yield quantifiable market
liberalization."

The Uruguay round of negotiations under GATT, a Geneva-based body that sets the
rules for some 90 percent of world trade, is scheduled to be completed in
December.

Helmut Haussmann, West Germany's economics minister, said the United States
should not ask the EC to abandon all its agricultural subsidies. He contended
that the community's farm policy serves important regional, social and
environmental purposes.

"The United States must retreat from its position," he said.

However, Mr. Haussmann commented that if Washington dropped its demand for the
complete abolition of subsidies, the EC would agree to a substantial cut in
supports so long as it retained the right to distribute the remaining handouts
as it chose.

The United States sought to build on that support by portraying the EC as the
major obstacle to resolving the agriculture dispute.

"In addition to getting governments off the farm, we want to sweep them out of
the world's steel mills, shipyards and factories," Mrs. Hills said.

Keith Rockwell contributed to this story.

LOAD-DATE: December 19, 1996

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                  Copyright 1990 The Journal of Commerce, Inc.


                              308 of 998 DOCUMENTS


                          The Globe and Mail (Canada)

                            August 21, 1990 Tuesday

Japan rejects U.S. plea   to liberalize rice policy

BYLINE: REUT

LENGTH: 227 words

DATELINE: Tokyo JAPAN


Reuter News Agency
  TOKYO
 U.S. Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter's request for an end to a
Japanese ban on rice imports has been rejected, a Japanese Agriculture
Ministry official says.

"I would like Japan to understand the U.S. concerns on rice trade," the
official quoted Mr. Yeutter as telling Agriculture Minister Tomio Yamamoto
yesterday.

Liberalization of rice imports would spell death for Japanese
agriculture, the official quoted Mr. Yamamoto as saying. He asked for
understanding of Japan's position, the official told reporters.

Tokyo has firmly resisted mounting pressure at home and overseas,
especially from Washington, to end a ban on commercial rice imports saying
it must have self-sufficiency in its national staple.

Mr. Yeutter was quoted as saying the United States wants freer two-way
trade in farm goods to help narrow their big trade imbalance.

Japan's trade surplus with the United States totalled about $49-billion
(U.S.) last year.

Mr. Yeutter was also quoted as urging an overhaul of Japan's food
control system, which inflates the prices of rice, wheat and barley to
several times international levels.

In the one-hour meeting, Mr. Yeutter also emphasized the importance of
a successful conclusion of the Uruguay Round of talks under the auspices
of the General Agreement on Tarrifs and Trade, scheduled for the end of
this year, the official said.

                              309 of 998 DOCUMENTS


                          The Globe and Mail (Canada)

                           December 14, 1982 Tuesday

EEC, U.S.   to discuss   farm prices

BYLINE: DJ

LENGTH: 124 words

DATELINE: Brussels BELGIUM


BRUSSELS  (DJ) - The European Economic Community and the United States
 will open a round of special farm trade talks in January, U.S. Agriculture
 Secretary John Block says.

Mr. Block, who was part of a U.S. ministerial delegation that met five
 EEC commissioners, said an agriculture war between Europe and the United
 States would not take place.

But he urged the EEC to narrow the gap between its farm prices and
 world market prices to eliminate export subsidies.

Mr. Block said the United States had not withdrawn its threat to dump
 dairy products on world markets as a retaliation against the subsidies.

He told a news conference "there will be no agriculture trade war." He  said:
"It was agreed that we sit down and look at what can be done."

LOAD-DATE: January 12, 2007

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                              310 of 998 DOCUMENTS


                                  R&D Magazine

                                  January 2007

GE rice gets USDA's nod.

SECTION: Pg. 35 Vol. 49 No. 1 ISSN: 0746-9179

LENGTH: 110 words



HIGHLIGHT: genetically engineered


The U.S. Dept. of Agriculture (USDA), has approved a genetically engineered (GE)
strain of rice, called LLRICE601 .The investigation into the safety of this rice
began in July, when Bayer CropScience, Monheim am Rhein, Germany, notified the
USDA and the U.S. Food and Drug Administration, that they had found trace
amounts of it in commercial long-grain rice. Although the circumstances
surrounding how the genetically engineered rice ended up in the commercial
product is still under investigation, the government says LLRICE601 poses no
safety concerns and no recall or destruction of the long-grain rice is planned.

* U.S. Dept. of Agriculture: www.aphis.usda.gov

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH
