                              311 of 998 DOCUMENTS

                           The Daily Yomiuri (Tokyo)

                            April 7, 2004 Wednesday

'U.S. letter complicates row'

SOURCE: Yomiuri

SECTION: Pg. 8

LENGTH: 376 words


Vice Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries Minister Mamoru Ishihara said Monday a
recent proposal by U.S. Agriculture Secretary Ann Veneman over the possible
resumption of Japanese imports of U.S. beef had made the negotiation more
difficult to settle.

"I feel that because of Veneman's letter, we've lost the possibility of settling
(the Japan-U.S. talks over the issue)," he said at a press conference,
indicating the bilateral talks may be prolonged.

In the United States, small and midsize meatpacking companies demanded that the
U.S. Agriculture Department endorse results of their voluntary blanket tests on
cattle to detect bovine spongiform encephalopathy, or mad cow disease.

Japan might have resumed imports of U.S. beef by the end of April if the
Agriculture Department had accredited the blanket tests.

Analysts said Ishihara's remark indicated deep disappointment with the letter in
the Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries Ministry.

The ministry believes imports of U.S. beef would have resumed if U.S.
meatpacking companies conducted voluntary blanket tests and the Agriculture
Department accredited the results.

In the ministry's view, Veneman's response meant that the request for voluntary
blanket tests--which a ministry official said was "the only practical measure
for early resumption of import"--was rejected.

Given the ministry's reaction to the U.S. proposal, the prospect of quickly
resuming imports of U.S. beef is not good, analysts said.

At Monday's press conference, Ishihara demonstrated some sympathy for the United
States' position. "Japan as well as the United States wants to settle this
problem as soon as possible," he said.

Nevertheless, the ministry has rejected an easy compromise, saying the problem
"affects the safety and peace of mind of the people concerning food."

Concerning the disagreement between the Foreign Ministry and the agriculture
ministry over how to respond to the letter, some ministry officials said the
discord had actually functioned to harmonize opinions inside the government.

As it is clear that the two countries will not reach a compromise over the test
issue, it has become less certain when the resumption of U.S. beef imports will
be possible, analysts said.

LOAD-DATE: April 6, 2004

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                       Copyright 2004 The Yomiuri Shimbun

                      The Financial Post (Toronto, Canada)

                   October 13, 1994, Thursday, DAILY EDITION

Record crops in U.S.

SECTION: SECTION 1, NEWS; Pg. 59, International Business

LENGTH: 59 words


American farmers this fall will harvest the biggest corn and soybean crops ever
produced in the U.S., the Agriculture Department predicted yesterday. In a
closely watched report, the government estimated that farmers will reap a huge
9.602 billion bushels of corn and it said this year's soybean crop will total a
record 2.458 billion bushels.

                              313 of 998 DOCUMENTS

                     Belfast News Letter (Northern Ireland)

                           December 28, 2002, Sunday

NI EXCLUDED FROM UNITED STATES FMD REPORT

SECTION: FARMING LIFE; Pg. 22

LENGTH: 384 words


THE United States Department of Agriculture (USDA) recently announced that it
had added Britain to a list of regions considered free of Foot- and-Mouth
disease (FMD). The change in disease status covers England, Scotland, Wales, and
the Isle of Man.

USDA's Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS) announced the decision
in a report that describes which British products and by-products are now
allowed in the United States and which are still prohibited.

The report said: "The U. S. Department of Agriculture today announced that it is
amending its import regulations by adding Great Britain (England, Scotland,
Wales and the Isle of Man) to the list of regions considered to be free of Foot
-and-Mouth disease, which includes North America, Central America, Japan,
Australia, New Zealand and parts of Europe.

" In addition, USDA's Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service is adding Great
Britain to the list of regions subject to certain import restrictions on meat
and animal products because of their proximity to or trading relationships with
rinderpest or FMD-af fected regions.

" This rule relieves certain FMD-related prohibitions and restrictions on the
importation of ruminants and swine and fresh (chilled or frozen) meat and other
products of ruminants and swine into the United States from Great Britain. APHIS
will continue to prohibit importation of live ruminants from Great Britain due
to the known presence of bovine spongiform encephalopathy in that country.

"Other products derived from ruminants, such as fetal bovine serum, bonemeal,
meat-and-bone meal, bloodmeal, offal, fats, and glands, are also prohibited from
entry, except under special conditions or under USDA permit for scientific or
research purposes.

" This final rule follows an interim rule that removed Great Britain and
Northern Ireland effective Feb. 21, 2001, from those lists due to detection of
FMD in those regions. Based on the results of an evaluation of the current FMD
situation in Great Britain, which took into account, among other things, that
Great Britain has met the standards of the Office International des Epizooties
for being considered to be free of FMD, APHIS has determined that Great Britain
can be added to the list of regions considered free of FMD"

LOAD-DATE: December 28, 2002

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                     Belfast News Letter (Northern Ireland)

                          December 28, 2002, Saturday

NI EXCLUDED FROM UNITED STATES FMD REPORT

SECTION: FARMING LIFE; Pg. 22

LENGTH: 384 words


THE United States Department of Agriculture (USDA) recently announced that it
had added Britain to a list of regions considered free of Foot- and-Mouth
disease (FMD). The change in disease status covers England, Scotland, Wales, and
the Isle of Man.

USDA's Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS) announced the decision
in a report that describes which British products and by-products are now
allowed in the United States and which are still prohibited.

The report said: "The U. S. Department of Agriculture today announced that it is
amending its import regulations by adding Great Britain (England, Scotland,
Wales and the Isle of Man) to the list of regions considered to be free of
Foot-and-Mouth disease, which includes North America, Central America, Japan,
Australia, New Zealand and parts of Europe.

" In addition, USDA's Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service is adding Great
Britain to the list of regions subject to certain import restrictions on meat
and animal products because of their proximity to or trading relationships with
rinderpest or FMD-af fected regions.

" This rule relieves certain FMD-related prohibitions and restrictions on the
importation of ruminants and swine and fresh (chilled or frozen) meat and other
products of ruminants and swine into the United States from Great Britain. APHIS
will continue to prohibit importation of live ruminants from Great Britain due
to the known presence of bovine spongiform encephalopathy in that country.

"Other products derived from ruminants, such as fetal bovine serum, bonemeal,
meat-and-bone meal, bloodmeal, offal, fats, and glands, are also prohibited from
entry, except under special conditions or under USDA permit for scientific or

" This final rule follows an interim rule that removed Great Britain and
Northern Ireland effective Feb. 21, 2001, from those lists due to detection of

situation in Great Britain, which took into account, among other things, that

for being considered to be free of FMD, APHIS has determined that Great Britain
can be added to the list of regions considered free of FMD"

                              315 of 998 DOCUMENTS

                             Corporate Legal Times

                                September, 2000

Court Says Meat Inspections Are Tainted
Salmonella Can't Close Down a Plant



BYLINE:
BY DAVID RUBENSTEIN

SECTION: CIRCUIT-BY-CIRCUIT; Pg. 86

LENGTH: 1364 words

THE CURRENT U.S. Supreme Court, with its record of overruling federal law and
regulation, is an activist body with a conservative agenda, according to
critics. Justice Antonin Scalia defends the record by saying the Court is merely
reacting to legislators who have overreached and to federal agencies that have
been "pushing the administrative envelope."

A recent ruling by a federal district judge in Texas suggests that Justice
Scalia's view is a significant factor in the lower courts, too. In a ruling that
has appalled some consumer groups, a federal judge has determined that the USDA
exceeded its authority when it shut down a Texas meat-processing plant after
finding salmonella on samples of meat.

The defendant and meat-industry trade groups, while cheered by the ruling, found
a knotty public relations problem arose as the legal problem appeared to recede.
How do you explain to Joe Six Pack that a little salmonella is no big deal, or
that regulators are unfair because chicken processors can get away with more
salmonella than beef processors can?

"I think this case has been misinterpreted," says Philip C. Olsson, a senior
principal at Olsson, Frank & Weeda, Washington, D.C. Olsson acts as general
counsel of the National Meat Association, a trade group that supported plaintiff
Supreme Beef Processors Inc. in the lawsuit it filed against the U.S. Department
of Agriculture.

"A lot of people say this undercuts USDA authority to use microbiological
tests," Olsson says. "On the contrary, it clarifies that USDA has that
authority, where those tests are rationally related to the responsibility of
whoever it is regulating."

NEW RULES IN 1996

The controversy in the case-Supreme Beef Processors Inc. v. United States
Department of Agriculture-is over a salmonella test the USDA uses to determine
whether a meat processing plant is sanitary. The plaintiff argued that the
salmonella test is not valid under the Federal Meat Inspection Act.

Attorneys from both the Justice Department and the USDA participated in this
case. A DOJ spokesman said the department would not comment on the litigation,
except to corroborate reports that an appeal was under consideration. A call to
the USDA's Office of the General Counsel was not returned.

The attorney for plaintiff Supreme Beef Processors, John A. Gilliam, a
shareholder at Jenkens & Gilchrist in Dallas, explains his client's position.
"In 1994," he says, "the USDA, through its sponsors in Congress, attempted to
pass a law that would have given it congressional authority to use
microbiological testing as part of its regulatory procedures.

"It did not pass. So in 1996, without going back to Congress, the USDA
promulgated regulations that contain their salmonella performance standards."

The 1996 final rule outlined something called the HACCP, or "Hazard Analysis and
Critical Control Point" process. HACCP required meat processors to implement
controls at key process points and to submit to periodic sampling of the product
in order to ascertain whether the preventive controls were working.

The sampling was in the form of a salmonella test. That was a departure from the
old method of "sniff-and-poke" testing, where the inspector uses sight, smell
and touch to identify bad meat.

The USDA maintains that sniff-and-poke testing may have been good enough when
the main threat to the integrity of meat was diseased animals, but that it is
unlikely to uncover pathogenic bacteria that are today's big public health
threat from meat.

SALMONELLA AS INDICATOR

According to the USDA, salmonella is an "indicator" pathogen: Its presence is
evidence that other pathogens are present as well. But according to the meat
industry, there are fatal flaws in that logic.

First, according to the industry, salmonella is a questionable indicator,
because salmonella is common, difficult to eradicate and, although a pathogen,
not among the most dangerous. "Salmonella is a naturally occurring substance in
meat, as it is in other food products, including vegetables and eggs," according
to Gilliam. "Salmonella is not an adulterate like E. coli."

Moreover, the USDA's salmonella-based performance standards are arbitrary and
unfair to the beef industry, according to Gilliam. Poultry plants can have a
significantly higher number of positives and still pass. For ground pork, there
are no standards at all.

"So," he says, "meat that has salmonella in it is being inspected and approved
every day. It's a higher percentage in poultry, and a much higher percentage in
sausage, I would imagine."

Gilliam notes that when salmonella is found at a plant, it does not trigger a
recall. "The way you guard yourself as a consumer against salmonella is by
cooking," he says. "If you cook your meat, you don't have a problem, even if it
has salmonella in it."

But Gilliam's main contention-and the point that swayed the judge-is that the
presence of salmonella is not evidence of an unsanitary plant.

"We showed through testimony during the preliminary injunction hearing that it
was highly probable that the product had salmonella in it even before we got it.

"The salmonella performance standards," he says, "address only the end product.
And that's beyond the scope of the Act."

In its court filings, the USDA says that salmonella is far from harmless,
causing 1.4 million illnesses and 600 deaths a year. More central to the case,
the USDA argues that its testing of product for salmonella does address the
condition of the plant, because controlling "incoming raw product" is part of
what goes into running a sanitary plant. Without proper controls, the plant will
inevitably be contaminated with salmonella.

the JUDGE AGREES with plaintiff

Judge A. Joe Fish, U.S. District judge for the Northern District of Texas,
didn't buy it.

"While the Court agrees that such controls are important, the issue here is not
whether controls on meat entering a plant are important but whether the lack of
such controls can be part of the evaluation, under [the Federal Meat Inspection
Act]
601 (m)(4), of sanitary conditions in the plant."

Judge Fish concludes they can't, for several reasons.

He notes that beef at slaughtering plants has to be inspected and passed by the
USDA before it can be sold to a grinder.

"USDA testing at these other stages of meat processing would be unnecessary if
grinders were required to reject meat contaminated with salmonella coming into
their plants," he reasons.

In this case, according to the Judge Fish, "[B]ecause the USDA's performance
standards and salmonella tests do not necessarily evaluate the conditions of a
meat processor's establishment, they cannot serve as the basis for finding a
plant's meat adulterated under
601 (m)(4). Under that statute, a processor's meat is considered adulterated
only when the USDA finds the conditions of the processor's establishment to be
unsanitary.

"The USDA's salmonella tests, however, inspect a processor's end product to
determine whether its plant's conditions are sanitary. The flaw in such tests is
that the presence of salmonella is not solely-or even substantially-dependent
upon the sanitation in a grinder's establishment. Indeed, a plant could, in
theory, be completely sanitized from top to bottom, but if the meat in it tests
positive for salmonella, the USDA could withdraw its inspectors, effectively
closing a plant that is sanitary."

This case, Judge Fish notes, was a case of first impression not only in the 5th
Circuit, but nationwide.

He also notes that his opinion is not meant to reject "scientific" as opposed to
sniff-and-poke testing. He says he is not taking issue with scientific methods
in USDA inspections, he writes, but rather "the agency's science-based testing
of a processor's product to evaluate the conditions of its plant."

Judge Fish allows that scientific testing under the Federal Meat Inspection Act
could be used to inspect the product itself, as opposed to the plant, but not
under the specific sub-section of the FMIA that the USDA used in this case.

LOAD-DATE: August 21, 2000

LANGUAGE: English

GRAPHIC: Photo, "A lot of people say this undercuts USDA authority to use
microbiological tests," says Philip C. Olsson, general counsel of the National
Meat Association. "On the contrary, it clarifies that USDA has that authority,
where those tests are rationally related to the responsibility of whoever it is
regulating."

                              316 of 998 DOCUMENTS


                              The Bismarck Tribune

                            April 6, 1994 Wednesday

LENGTH: 345 words


WASHINGTON (AP) Ä A Canadian trade negotiator held out hopes Tuesday that a
settlement could be reached with the United States in a dispute over trade in
wheat and other farm goods. ""I think the time has come to see whether we can't
find a mutually agreed upon way of putting this behind us and move on to other
things,'' said John Weekes, Canada's senior assistant deputy minister for
Canada-U.S. relations. Weekes spoke after a daylong meeting with officials from
the U.S. Agriculture Department and the U.S. trade representative.

Weekes was returning to Ottawa but said he would be in telephone contact with
U.S. officials Wednesday about future meetings. The two countries are trying to
resolve a dispute over the amount of Canadian wheat entering the United States.
The United States blames Canadian rail subsidies and unfair pricing by the
Canadian Wheat Board. The two countries also disagree on access of U.S. dairy
and poultry products to Canada, and Canada's exports of sugar and peanut
products to the United States. Despite the hopeful talks, Tuesday's meeting was
not intended to reach any breakthroughs. ""Today was basically reviewing what's
happened and considering various options for how we might approach the matter,''
he said. He called the meeting a ""continuation'' of the discussion that had
taken place March 21 between U.S. Agriculture Secretary Mike Espy and Canadian
Agriculture Minister Ralph Goodale. ""We did mainly stock-taking today,'' said
Charles J. O'Mara, the chief trade negotiator for the U.S. Agriculture
Department. ""We went through the full collection of issues and all the
alternatives that are available.''Neither side would discuss the status of
threats of trade action, such as U.S. threats of quotas on Canadian wheat if no
agreement is reached by April 22. Espy and U.S. Trade Representative Mickey
Kantor will be meeting with their Canadian counterparts during a meeting of
ministers under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade in Marrakech,
Morocco, next week. The newest GATT agreement will be signed there April 15.

LOAD-DATE: May 9, 2006

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                              317 of 998 DOCUMENTS

                      The Financial Post (Toronto, Canada)

                   February 13, 1989, Monday, WEEKLY EDITION

Analysts wonder at size of 'phantom' cattle herd

BYLINE: Farm Market News

SECTION: SECTION 3, INVESTOR'S GUIDE; Pg. 28, FARM COMMODITIES

LENGTH: 533 words

DATELINE: Winnipeg,Man.


  The U.S. Department of Agriculture released a cattle inventory report this
past Wednesday that shocked livestock analysts, but should cause meat packers
and consumers to breathe a sigh of relief.

The report said the U.S. cattle inventory as of Jan. 1, 1989, was 99,484,000
head - nearly as large as last year's inventory and well above the figure that
traders had expected. Some traders described the report as ''unbelievable''.

Analysts felt that high 1988 livestock slaughter levels would force the USDA to
reduce its cattle inventory numbers. But the net slaughter in 1988 was estimated
at three million head - unchanged from 1987 - dropping the inventory from 102
million to 99 million.


''Total cattle kill relative to the starting inventory was too high for this,''
says Chuck Levitt, senior analyst with Shearson Lehman Hutton.

Analysts also believe the Midwest drought in the summer of 1988 should have
stopped any attempts to rebuild the cattle herd. And high feed-grain costs,
along with poor pasture conditions, should have deterred farmers from any
attempts to rebuild, they say.

Jerry Abbenhaus, an analyst with A. G. Edwards & Sons Inc., predicts the report
will be particularly ''bearish for feeder cattle futures and third-quarter live
cattle futures.''

He says the report ''implies that we have a huge number of steers to put on feed
during the second half of the year, and this will change attitudes and depress
demand for replacement cattle.''

Prior to the report, most analysts estimated cattle prices at the packers, and
beef prices at the supermarket, would rise to record levels in the April-June
period this year as result of the smallest U.S. cattle herd since 1961.

But the USDA report has dampened the bullish feeling. Levitt says: ''It appears
there is a phantom herd out there. The number was larger than anyone could have
possible pieced together using statistical data.''

Tom Morgan, president of Sterling Research Corp., predicts that packers and
consumers will benefit from this report because of the increased number of
cattle expected to come to market in late 1989 and early 1990.

Morgan says that consumer demand for beef, low cattle weight due to winter
weather, or the upcoming USDA cattle-on-feed report could re-ignite the bull
market.

Morgan notes the ''report implies the beginning of moderate herd expansion.'' He
also suggests that analysts were surprised because they were working off false
data from last year.

The USDA revised the July 1 total inventory up 600,000 head in this report.

The report caused many analysts to question the accuracy of USDA numbers. If
this report is not wrong, they say, then earlier reports were inaccurate. They
note that this was the second report in a month to alter production numbers
radically.

On Jan. 13, the USDA released a corn supply/demand report that said total U.S.
corn supplies were up by almost 600 million bushels. The USDA ''found'' more
corn in storage than its earlier reports stated, and increased the final 1988
corn production figure by 265 million bushels.

This amount of corn is equal to the entire Canadian barley crop of 1988.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: NEWS

                               The New York Times

                March 6, 1986, Thursday, Late City Final Edition

E.E.C. SEEKING U.S. TALKS

BYLINE: Reuters

SECTION: Section D; Page 5, Column 1; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 218 words

DATELINE: BRUSSELS, March 5


The European Economic Community's executive commission invited the United States
today to defuse a trade dispute over the accession of Spain and Portugal to the
community through negotiations in the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade,
the world trade body.

A spokesman said a letter had been sent to the United States trade
representative, Clayton K. Yeutter, and the Agriculture Secretary-designate,
Richard E. Lyng, proposing the cooling-off move.

Mr. Yeutter has said the

United States would lose valuable farm product exports to the two countries
because they are now subject to the European Economic Community's Common
Agricultural Policy.

He has threatened retaliatory action unless the community finds a satisfactory
solution to the problem.

The spokesman said the letter, from External Relations Commissioner Willy de
Clercq, and Agriculture Commissioner Frans Andriessen, proposed negotiations
with the United States alongside the multilateral talks that have already begun
with the community's major trading partners on the enlargement of the community.

However, commission sources said it appeared that the United States might not
accept the suggestion since it had been demanding immediate compensation for the
damage done to its trade by the accession of Spain and Portugal.

                              319 of 998 DOCUMENTS

                               The New York Times

               August 3, 1983, Wednesday, Late City Final Edition

REAGAN CALLS FOR 'NO HOLDS BARRED' EXAMINATION OF HUNGER REPORTS

BYLINE: By STEVEN R. WEISMAN

SECTION: Section B; Page 4, Column 3; National Desk

LENGTH: 512 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2


President Reagan said today that he was perplexed at reports of people going
hungry in the United States despite Federal programs to help them and he
directed a group of experts to examine the reported increasing hunger.

''I want the task force to bring me a no-holds-barred study,'' Mr. Reagan said
in a memorandum creating the new group. ''If the food assistance programs are
being mismanaged, I want to know that. If certain aspects of our food assistance
programs require more funding, I want to know that, too.''

At the same time, the Administration confirmed that the Department of
Agriculture would resume and increase distribution of free cheese and other
commodities to the poor. The cheese distribution was cut back last month because
it adversely affected sales in the commercial market.

David Lane, deputy press secretary at the Agriculture Department, said many
details had to be worked out, but there would be increases soon in the
distribution of cheese, butter, nonfat dry milk, corn meal and honey. In
addition, he said these commodities were to be released in bulk to states for
separate processing and distribution.

Reports of Hunger Cited Mr. Lane said Agriculture Secretary John R. Block had
decided on ''a little bit more'' in distributing food because of recent reports
of rising hunger. As for industry complaints that distribution was causing sales
to drop, Mr. Lane said: ''At this point, we are ignoring that factor.''

The Administration's actions came in response to complaints from mayors and
nutrition groups that hunger is rising because of the recession and because of
the Administration's cutbacks in food stamps, child nutrition and other
programs.

Few of Mr. Reagan's domestic programs have caused as much debate in Congress as
the deep cuts in these areas. Federal spending on food stamps declined last year
for the first time since 1969, according to the General Accounting Office. The
cuts have come in the form of ending the eligibility of some people and delaying
increases in benefits for others.

Last week the President signed legislation that included $1.2 billion to finance
the existing reduced food stamp program for the remaining two months of this
fiscal year.

For the next fiscal year, beginning Oct. 1, the Administration is seeking to
merge school breakfast, summer lunch and child-care food programs into a block
grant and to reduce the total amount spent.

With the rise in complaints about hunger, Congress appears less likely to go
along. Today, the House of Representatives approved a resolution by a vote of
408 to 15 declaring that there should be no further cuts in any food program
benefits this year.

Hunger Strikers End Fast

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Aug. 2 (AP) - About 20 people who have fasted since July 4 in
an effort to get the Federal Government to release some of its surplus food
ended their fast today because Mr. Block said more food would be distributed.
''We accomplished what we set out to do,'' said Mitch Snyder of the
Washington-based Community for Creative Non-Violence.

                              320 of 998 DOCUMENTS

                                The Toronto Star

                         November 23, 1987, Monday, ME1

U.S. wheat subsidies ruin export market board official says

BYLINE: (CP)

SECTION: BUSINESS TODAY; Pg. B4

LENGTH: 455 words

DATELINE: REGINA, Saskatchewan


   REGINA (CP) - A commissioner with the Canadian Wheat Board has lashed out at
United States export subsidy programs for pinning down grain prices that he says
would otherwise be floating upward.

Bill Smith told delegates at the Saskatchewan Wheat Pool annual meeting Friday
the U.S. is wasting billions of dollars to muscle its way back into markets it
priced itself out of in the early 1980s.

Despite the bullying of the United States, the Canadian Wheat Board, which
markets Canadian farmers' grain, won't back down, Smith said.

Seven years

"Our frustration is the only satisfaction the United States Department of
Agriculture is going to get from spending all this money," he said. "We are not
going to be driven out of any markets and our exports last year and so far this
year underline our determination."

U.S. President Reagan's export subsidy program, called the Export Enhancement
Program, has resulted in a "buy two, get one free" windfall for importers, Smith
said.

The program is galling because for the first time in seven years world
production is less than consumption. And since many producers around the world
have harvested a below-normal quality crop, stocks of high-quality milling wheat
are expected to be tight.

The price should move up, but when the U.S. increases its subsidy and sells some
of its stockpile, the Europeans follow suit and the price remains low.

"The (subsidy) program has been foolish from Day One, but it has reached the
point of being stupid," Smith said.

The subsidies were offered first to poor countries, but have expanded to almost
the entire world. Now even Saudi Arabia and Switzerland are benefiting.

Turning to board sales this year, Smith said exports are well above last year
which was the best on record.

The board is particularly happy with the price of oats. U.S. demand for
high-quality oats is greater than production and in the past the shortfall was
made up by Swedish and Finnish imports.

But a poor-quality American and Scandanavian crop has given high-quality oats a
substantial premium.

While a return to good-quality crops in the U.S. or Scandinavia could make
things more competitive next year, the Canadian product has at least gained a
foothold in the American market.

Rail system

However, Smith said the board is frustrated over the inability of the rail
system to supply Thunder Bay with enough grain to meet export contracts.

"All we can say is that we had hoped things would have come a little farther by
now," he said. "The board and the trade are pushing the system to the limit and
that is when the most problems will show up.

"I want to emphasize that we are not pushing any harder now than in the past."

                               Pakistan Observer

                              May 9, 2013 Thursday

US, Pakistan anti wheat diseases initiatives to improve rural economy

BYLINE:  Tariq Khattak

SECTION: Vol. XXIV No. 188

LENGTH: 519  words


U.S. Ambassador Richard Olson today reaffirmed the United States government's
long-term support to farming communities in Pakistan. "Since the 1950s, the
United States has been working to support agriculture in Pakistan, introducing
the Kinnow orange and helping to double Pakistan's wheat production. Today, we
continue our support because improving crop yields, protecting food sources from
disease, and boosting milk production will increase farmers' incomes, improve
nutrition, and ultimately strengthen Pakistan's prosperity."

Addressing a gathering of government officials, researchers, and farmers during
his visit to the National Agriculture Research Center (NARC), which was
established with the help of the U.S. government in the 1980s, Ambassador Olson
said, "The United States is committed to helping the small farmers of Pakistan
through projects that enhance agricultural productivity." The Ambassador lauded
the progress made by the Wheat Productivity Enhancement Project (WPEP), a United
States Department of Agriculture (USDA) program managed in collaboration with
national and provincial research partners that has successfully introduced the
UG 99-resistant wheat variety, "NARC 2011."

The introduction of this wheat variety helps protect Pakistan against UG 99, a
virulent wheat disease in the region that poses a threat to Pakistan's farming
community. "Wheat accounts for approximately 60 percent of the daily caloric
intake of the average Pakistani, so our joint efforts to combat this disease are
critical," said Ambassador Olson. "The Wheat Productivity Enhancement Project
team and Pakistani scientists at national and provincial research stations have
made great progress in the fight against wheat rusts, and I encourage you to
continue your work together."

In addition to support for the Wheat Productivity Enhancement Project, the
United States has provided new harvesting machines and funded improvements to
research stations around Pakistan to develop more disease-resistant wheat
varieties. The United States also provides specialized training opportunities to
Pakistani wheat scientists.

Dr. Muhammad Imtiaz, Country Liaison Officer for the International Maize and
Wheat Improvement Center, noted that without disease-resistant varieties of
wheat, such as the one being harvested at NARC, experts estimate that Pakistan's
annual wheat harvest could be reduced by as much as 50 percent if and when UG 99
arrives.

"Agriculture contributes 21 percent to the GDP of Pakistan and employs 45
percent of the labor force, making it one of the most significant economic
drivers of Pakistan," Dr. Imtiaz said. Pakistani farmers grew about 24 million
tons of wheat on eight million hectares last year, accounting for about 2.4
percent of the GDP.

"The United States and Pakistan have similar agricultural systems, and for that
reason we have been effective partners in agriculture for more than half a
century, working together to improve agricultural yields and to combat disease,"
said Ambassador Olson. "Since the 1950s, U.S. and Pakistani scientists have
collaborated to increase wheat production.

                         Telegraph Herald (Dubuque, IA)

                            February 1, 2004 Sunday

U.S. soybean sales to China rise by 40%

BYLINE: JOHN EVERLY

SECTION: Business; Pg. b2

LENGTH: 197 words


Brazil, the United States' chief competitor for world soybean markets, is
expected to export more than 26 million tons of soybeans this year, up from 21
million tons last year.

According to the U.S. Department of Agriculture, the United States expects to
export 24.5 million tons of soybeans, down 4 million tons from last year.

But Iowa State University economist Robert Wisner notes this year's sales have
been brisk, already at 91 percent of the department's 2003-2004 projections.

Fortunately for American growers, major soybean importer China seems to prefer
American soybeans. U.S. soybean sales to China are booming, up more than 40
percent from a year ago.

"The big question mark is Asian rust - will that come on strong?" Wisner said.

The disease has been found in Brazil and it could be a number of years before
researchers find rust-resistant soybean strains.

Brazil still threatens to eclipse the United States in soybean production.
Wisner points out Brazil still has a huge amount of land that could be developed
for crop production. Untapped acreage in Brazil is at least as large as the U.S.
corn, wheat, soybean and cotton acreage combined.

                              324 of 998 DOCUMENTS


                               The New York Times

                             June 15, 2002 Saturday
                              Late Edition - Final

Raising Farm Subsidies, U.S. Widens International Rift

BYLINE:  By ELIZABETH BECKER

SECTION: Section A; Column 1; Foreign Desk; Pg. 3

LENGTH: 1092 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 14


Less than one month after President Bush signed the new farm bill, agriculture
has leaped from the backwaters of diplomacy to near the top of the list of
international complaints against the United States.

Portrayed by its supporters as a necessary safety net for farmers and by its
detractors as an election-year welfare program to win Midwestern votes, the huge
increase in subsidies has become an overnight magnet for America-bashing.

Javier Solana, Europe's foreign policy chief, declared in Madrid this week that
the new American agriculture policy has created the "most profound" division
between Europe and the United States, worse than disputes over steel tariffs,
the Kyoto environmental treaty or the international criminal court.

In Washington, in an address to Congress, Prime Minister John Howard of
Australia said on Wednesday that the only problem between these closest of
friends was his country's "intense disappointment" over the $180 billion farm
bill.

In Rome, at a United Nations conference on hunger, developing countries pointed
this week to the huge new subsidies to American farmers as one of the biggest
obstacles to creating vital opportunities for their own farmers and enabling
them to climb out of poverty.

With Mr. Bush pressing other countries to knock down their trade barriers and
expand open markets, his approval of an 80 percent increase in farm subsidies --
with all the advantages that confers on American grain exports -- is viewed as a
move in the opposite direction.

Poor countries say the subsidies also work at cross purposes to the
administration's avowed desire to reduce poverty and to diminish foreign anger
against the United States.

In a private letter to Congressional leaders, a group of countries known as the
Cairns Group, which includes Australia, Thailand, Canada, Brazil and Argentina,
wrote this month that "the sheer size of the subsidy package will inevitably
hurt farmers around the world, particularly in developing countries."

"The United States should be sending a very different message," wrote Mark
Vaile, the group's chairman.

The heart of the dispute is that by underwriting its largest farmers, the United
States is flooding the world market with inexpensive corn, wheat, rice and
soybeans, which are sold at half what it costs to produce the grain. That leads
to artificially low world prices, which in turn undercut grain produced by
farmers in countries that do not give subsidies. The grain market becomes
distorted, domestic markets are ruined for producers overseas and their chances
of making inroads into foreign markets are reduced.

"Subsidies and other measures applied by the world's richest countries continue
to increase exponentially," said Navin Chandarpal, Guyana's minister of
agriculture, at the Rome conference. "We continue to be pressured into further
opening up our markets, without any regard being paid to the welfare of our
farming and rural communities as a whole."

Development experts agree and say the effects ripple throughout developing
economies. "American farm exports drive down prices paid to local farmers,
reduce rural family income around the world and push farmers off the land and
into overcrowded cities," said Mark Ritchie, president of the Institute for
Agriculture Trade Policy, a nonprofit organization in Minneapolis.

However, some developing countries with sufficient foreign reserves prefer to
import cheap American food as they build up other sectors of their economy.

Despite the complaints, the new American farm policy also conforms to the
current rules of the World Trade Organization. Indeed, the United States is not
alone as a wealthy country that gives generous welfare programs to farmers. The
15-nation European Union is notorious for giving lavish subsidies to its seven
million farmers.

In an address in Germany this month, Robert B. Zoellick, the United States trade
representative, defended the farm bill and suggested "respectfully that
America-bashing will not promote the E.U.'s enlightened self-interest.

"When Europeans criticize the recent U.S. farm bill, I wonder how many are even
aware that U.S. agricultural tariffs are less than half of the E.U.'s," he said.

Disputes between the world's major economies -- United States, Europe and Japan
-- over farm subsidies are nothing new. But the latest American increase,
European Union officials say, comes as they are trying to reduce their own
payments.

With plans to admit 10 new countries -- including Poland, where nearly one-third
of 40 million inhabitants identify themselves as full- or part-time farmers --
the European Union says it must slash expensive programs to support agricultural
production and give more money for conservation and rural development.

Critics of the new American policy say that, by giving in to the domestic farm
vote, the United States will have a difficult time persuading other countries to
open their markets to American agricultural products.

"The American farmers have shot themselves in the foot," said C. Fred Bergsten,
director of the Institute for International Economics. "The long term growth of
U.S. agriculture is clearly in foreign markets, particularly the rapidly growing
emerging markets. That requires liberalization and access to those markets. The
farm bill undercuts our ability to reach those markets."

During the debate on the farm bill, lawmakers in Congress painted a different
picture, arguing that American farmers needed subsidies to remain competitive in
the world.

America's main competitors on the global grain markets are not the European
Union countries but countries that pay few or no subsidies to farmers and indeed
may even tax food exports to earn more government revenue.

During the trade negotiations at Qatar six months ago, members of the World
Trade Organization agreed to remove barriers to farm trade.

Mr. Zoellick insists that the United States remains committed to the goals
worked out in Qatar. But both the Bush administration and the European Union --
whose dispute over farming is essentially one of their many trade battles over
state subsidies -- will be hard pressed to remove the barriers to foreign
agricultural products without upsetting their powerful farmers.

"We're all free traders and we're all hypocrites," said Peter L. Scher,
specialist on trade negotiations for agriculture in the Clinton administration.
"I blame the Europeans as well as the Americans. If we're going to develop these
poor countries, we've got to give these nations a chance to develop their own
agricultures."

URL: http://www.nytimes.com

                Intelligencer Journal (Lancaster, Pennsylvania)

                          December 12, 2007 Wednesday

County's ag record is lauded;
Lancaster farmland a model for success

BYLINE: Larry Alexander, Intelligencer Journal Staff

SECTION: B; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 484  words

DATELINE: Lancaster, PA


Lancaster County is a national role model in farmland preservation and a leader
in agriculture.

That lofty praise was delivered to more than 150 county residents and civic
leaders by Pennsylvania Department of Agriculture Secretary Dennis Wolff on
Tuesday, during an address sponsored by Lancaster County Planning Commission.

Wolff spoke in the renovated 1855 barn at Country Barn Farm Market, 211 S.
Donnerville Road.

He said Lancaster County's billion-dollar-a-year ag industry is bigger than the
ag economy in some states.

"The agriculture economy in this county is just something that most other
secretaries of agriculture, at least in the eastern part of the United States,
find hard to believe," Wolff said.

Lancaster County is blessed with "some of the best topsoil in the world," Wolff
said. The problem is the "continuing battle to keep the topsoil in farming."

That battle is another place where the county shines.

"We recently came to realize that you have the largest farmland preservation
program in the United States," Wolff said. "We knew it was one of the largest
agricultural counties in the nation, but through the great work of the Lancaster
County Farmland Preservation Trust and our state farmland preservation program,
you have now become the county that has made the largest investment and has the
most farms preserved of any county in the United States."

Wolff, who lives in Columbia County but whose roots trace back to Quarryville,
said the county, with its "great farms" and "great lifestyle," is "precious to
each and every one of you, and is certainly worth protecting and preserving."

Wolff praised the Blue Ribbon Commission for Agriculture, sponsored by the
Lancaster County Commissioners, in developing a new strategic plan in regards to
agriculture, which he said was "very, very well done."

Wolff said the county is on the right track in balancing agriculture with the
growth of population and needs for further development.

He said in his home area of Columbia County, officials planned poorly when it
came to subdividing farmland, by requiring that one house be built per two
acres.

"Looking back, it was a poor decision," he said. "When you put one house on two
acres, you're taking two acres of agriculture land out of production."

By leaning toward high density housing and urban growth boundaries, Lancaster
County planners, Wolff said, "keep agriculture at the heart and center of
decisions that they make."

Wolff said farming and development coexist well in Lancaster County, compared to
other parts of the state.

"When you look at how much ag there is here in this county, and you look at how
many people live here, it's done very, very well," he said. "It's something you
should be very proud of and something I think will be critical in terms of
moving ahead in preserving what is truly the wonderful natural resources you've
been given here."

E-mail: lalexander@lnpnews.com

                              326 of 998 DOCUMENTS


                              Daily Trust (Abuja)

                                January 18, 2013

FG, USAID Sign Agreement to De-Risk Lending to Agric Sector

BYLINE: Idris Ahmed

LENGTH: 414 words


Federal government and the United States Agency for International Development
(USAID) yesterday signed an agreement to de-risk banks lending to farmers in
Nigeria.

The Minister of Agriculture Dr. Akinwumi Adesina and governor of Central Bank of
Nigeria Sanusi Lamido Sanusi signed the Memorandum of Understanding on behalf of
Nigeria, while the USAID Administrator Rajiv Shah signed for US.

The agreement is under the federal government's Nigeria Incentive Based Risk
Sharing System for Agricultural Lending (NIRSAL), which the Federal Ministry of
Agriculture and the Central Bank of Nigeria are championing to enable banks lend
to farmers.

The NIRSAL has N75 billion funding capital.

Yesterday's agreement involved $3 billion that banks are expected to invest in
agriculture overtime and the United States of America has agreed to guarantee
the first $100 million so that farmers can access bank loans without collateral.

"Our specific part of the $3 billion vision is to take the first $100 million
and we will guarantee that the agricultural sector will pay back to banks so
that they can have the courage and conviction to make that loan," Shah said.

He said: "We know that access is very limited and the United State is committed
to working with the central bank and ministry of agric to offer technical
assistance to banks so that hundreds of millions of dollars can be provided at a
lower interest rate to farmers."

The minister of Agriculture said that the facility will reduce the interest rate
that is paid by farmers.

Adesina said: "If for example, the interest rate is 15 percent, because of the
risk sharing facility that NIRSAL will do and because of the fact the ministry
of agriculture is fixing the agric value chain, it means that the interest rate
would go down from 15 percent to about 9 percent. It is a facility that would
reduce the risk of lending and the interest rate paid by farmers.

"We are going to help the farmers to organize themselves into cooperative groups
and the agro dealers that are going to benefit from this facility are going to
be registered. The reason why banks ask for collateral is because if they think
that you are a high risk borrower, they need something they can hold on to. In
this particular case we are linking farmers to companies that are buying from
them. We need new ways of lending that are not based on collateral."

The central bank governor Sanusi Lamido Sanusi said banks are now convinced to
start lending to the agricultural sector.

                              327 of 998 DOCUMENTS

                              Journal of Commerce

                            March 5, 1998, Thursday

US red meat exports to Asia predicted to rise

BYLINE: BY RICK KNEE

SECTION: WORLD TRADE; Pg. 3A

LENGTH: 507 words

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO


Continuing economic woes in Japan will not prevent U.S. sales of red meat from
expanding over the next few years in what is by far the largest U.S. export
market for these products.

Even amid Asia's currency woes, the market in Japan for red meat ""is very
promising,'' said Bruce Cobb, director of development and marketing services for
the U.S. Meat Export Federation, Denver. The group is predicting steady growth
to Japan, despite a lackluster economy and few signs that the government is
committed to large scale economic reform.

The federation expects exports of beef and pork to Japan to reach 500,000 and
180,000 metric tons, respectively, this year; 510,000 and 200,000 tons in 1999;
and 550,000 and 240,000 tons in 2000.

Red meat exports overall to Japan have had a meteoric rise over the last decade,
expanding from just over 200,000 tons in 1987 to 700,000 tons in 1996.  Exports
dipped to just over 600,000 tons in 1997, according to the U.S. Department of
Agriculture, because of concern over possible E. coli bacteria contamination.

That experience illustrated the sensitivity of Japanese consumers to food safety
and triggered a major campaign to educate consumers about U.S. food safety
procedures. The campaign appears to be paying off. Japanese consumers also are
focusing more on product value and less on price, with branded products growing
in popularity, Mr. Cobb said.

The meat export group is trying to persuade members to increase exports of
boneless meats as a percentage of their total volume.

U.S. exporters face growing competition from beef producers in Australia and,
more recently, Argentina, and from pork producers in Denmark, Canada and South
Korea, Mr. Cobb said. Exports to South Korea are also expected to grow.
Projected volumes of beef and pork shipments to Korea are 101,000 and 20,000
tons this year, 113,000 and 27,000 tons in 1999, and 124,000 and 39,000 tons in
2000, the export federation said.

Red meat exports to Korea rose from zero in 1987 to 121,000 tons in 1995. They
plummeted to about 91,000 in 1996 and jumped back to about 105,000 in 1997,
according to the USDA. Food safety issues are prone to crop up in Korea the same
way they do in Japan, Mr. Cobb said.

Exporters should not be too discouraged by Korea's currency devaluation, Mr.
Cobb said. In fact, the Meat Export Federation believes the Korean market will
rebound more quickly than the Mexican market did after the peso's plunge a few
years ago, he said.

Moreover, Korea's beef and pork production has dropped steeply, which will allow
U.S. producers to boost their market share, he said.

Also boding well, Mr. Cobb said, are planned steps by the Korean government to
liberalize import policies. They include a drop in the duty for beef from the
current 42.4 percent to 40 percent by 2004; elimination in 2000 of a 20 percent
markup on import beef prices; a decrease in the duty for pork from the current
32.2 percent to 25 percent by 2004; and a liberalization of pork quotas last
July 1.

LOAD-DATE: March 5, 1998

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                    Copyright 1998 Journal of Commerce, Inc.


                              328 of 998 DOCUMENTS

                        Gazeta Mercantil Online (Brazil)

                           August 12, 1998, Wednesday

United States to import Brazilian limes_

SECTION: Agribusiness

LENGTH: 150 words

DATELINE: 08/12/98


Teresina - The United States Agriculture Department (USDA) is expected to
liberate a provisional authorization by the end of 1998 for the creation of
Brazil's first free zone for in natura lime exports to the US. The area chosen
is a region of 30,000 hectares in the municipal districts of Teresina, JosA de
Freitas and Uniao in the state of Piaui, which in 1997 exported 400 tons of
tahiti limes of the 1,500 tons produced in Brazil. The last details for the
creation of the free zone are being defined by Brazil's Agriculture Ministry in
conjuction with the US government, after a process which took two and a half
years in the monitoring of plagues and flies and statistical controls of insect
captures. The technical studies proved that the area chosen is the only one in
Brazil completely free of the Ceratitis fly and of other citric fruit diseases.
(Telma Pinto, Gazeta Mercantil)

                       St. Louis Post-Dispatch (Missouri)

                  April 24, 1991, WEDNESDAY, FIVE STAR Edition

BILL HITS PESTICIDE EXPORTS

BYLINE: Bill Lambrecht Post-Dispatch Washington Bureau

SECTION: BUSINESS; Pg. 3B

LENGTH: 338 words


WASHINGTON - Proposed free trading with Mexico makes it essential to stop the
''Circle of Poison,'' say sponsors of legislation to clamp down on pesticide
exports.  ''Trade of food and agricultural products is very important, but trade
of safe food ought to be at the heart of our policy,'' said Rep. Dan Glickman,
D-Kan., at a news conference Tuesday to announce the filing of the bill.  The
legislation would slap new controls on foreign sales of pesticides that are
banned or unregistered in the United States. A similar bill died last year.
Sponsors of the bill call some pesticide exports the ''Circle of Poison''
because banned chemicals often wind up on fruit and vegetables imported into the
United States.  Agriculture Department records show that more than 10 percent of
imported peas have residue of chemicals that can't be used in the United States.
Other imports and the amount of residue include eggplant 9.4 percent,
blackberries 8.9 percent, pears 8.3 percent, and peppers 7.4 percent.
''Breaking the circle of poison means blocking U.S. companies from dumping
chemicals abroad that the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency has found
unsafe,'' said Sen. Patrick Leahy, D-Vt., chairman of the Senate Agriculture
Committee and a co-sponsor of the legislation.  Exports of butachlor (sold as
Machete) and acetochlor - products of Monsanto Co. of St. Louis that are not
registered in the United States - would be banned under the legislation. The
bill also would: Require consent from other countries before U.S. companies send
them pesticides that have restrictions in the United States. Allow individuals -
not just government agencies - to file lawsuits to enforce the provisions.  Dan
Holman, a spokesman for Monsanto, said, ''The so-called circle of poison bill
does nothing to help the Food and Drug Administration do its job.'' He argued
that the legislation would damage U.S. chemical companies because they would
lose out in world markets to foreign competitors who sell similar pesticides.

LOAD-DATE: October 13, 1993

LANGUAGE: English

                  Copyright 1991 St. Louis Post-Dispatch, Inc.

                               The New York Times

                 January 1, 1999, Friday, Late Edition - Final

Low Hog Prices Hurt Agricultural Index

BYLINE: Bloomberg News

SECTION: Section C; Page 2; Column 2; Business/Financial Desk

LENGTH: 203 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 31


The lowest hog prices since 1964 helped drag down the December index of prices
received by farmers for their goods, the United States Agriculture Department
said on Wednesday.

Over all, the All Farm Products Index showed that farm prices, reflecting a
seasonal mix of commodities, were down 2 percent from November and down 6.7
percent from December 1997.

Falling prices for cattle, broilers and soybeans also contributed to the
decline, though it was cushioned by a record-high price for milk and higher
prices for corn, tomatoes and eggs.

The hog herd was the biggest since December 1980. As a result, in mid-December
farmers received an average cash price of $14.70 for each hundred pounds, the
lowest since prices fell to $14.30 in November 1964. Prices were off $4 from a
month ago and off $26.90 from a year ago.

The monthly survey showed December cattle prices averaged $55.80 for each 100
pounds, down $2.30 from November and down $7.10 from a year earlier, amid huge
supplies and competition from record pork production.

In the cash markets, corn sold for $1.96 a bushel, up 3 cents from November but
down 56 cents from a year ago because of the second-largest crop ever and weak
export demand.

                     Belfast News Letter (Northern Ireland)

                          November 3, 2004, Wednesday

TAIWAN AT ODDS WITH US OVER BEEF BAN CLAIM

SECTION: 1st Edition; NEWS; Pg. 3

LENGTH: 312 words


The government of Taiwan is disputing a United States Department of Agriculture
statement that Taiwan has agreed to resume US beef imports soon, according to
the news agency, Reuters.

In addition, Agriculture Undersecretary for Farm and reportedly Foreign
Agricultural Services, J B Penn, had said in a conference call from Hong Kong
that it was a "pretty correct characterization" that no significant progress had
been made.

A Taiwanese official has also stated that its government had not determined
whether US beef is safe from BSE and would not be sending inspectors to the
United States on November 10 as the USDA had announced earlier this week.

Meanwhile, the Government of Canada has announced that Implementation of the
national 'Repositioning the Livestock Industry Strategy' is fully underway.

The $ 488 million (pounds 218 million) strategy was first announced in September
Agriculture and Agri-Food Minister, Andy Mitchell.

The strategy is aimed at assisting Canada's beef and cattle industry in
repositioning itself to ensure its long-term viability in light of the ongoing
BSE situation.

Quick implementation of many of the strategy's components is indicative of the
high level of co-operation taking place between governments and industry.

"The priority has been to have these programmes in place to allow producers to
benefit from them this fall," said Minister Mitchell.

"While it remains critical to have a reopened US border, the federal government
is committed to returning our beef industry to profitability and these
programmes are a critical part of that commitment."

Stan Eby, president of the Canadian Cattlemen's Association, said: "The Canadian
Cattlemen's Association is pleased with the implementation of the repositioning
strategy and the flexibility shown by the Minister to make the programmes work."

                              332 of 998 DOCUMENTS

                               The New York Times

                  July 15, 1990, Sunday, Late Edition - Final

Gypsy Moth Spraying: Other Views

SECTION: Section 12NJ; Page 18, Column 2; New Jersey Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 476 words


In response to Pete Dunne's ''In the Natural State'' column, ''In Trying to Kill
the Gypsy Moth, Are We Going Too Far?'':

According to the New Jersey Department of Agriculture, the gypsy moth is
expected to cause defoliation of 300,000 acres in New Jersey despite an ongoing
spraying program to save our trees. In addition, the gypsy moth poses a health
hazard, as hundreds of schoolchildren in Hunterdon, Morris and Warren Counties
have reported welts and rashes after the tiny caterpillars are crushed on the
skin when mistaken for gnats. Yet Mr. Dunne says that the gypsy moth is not a
health hazard and that spraying programs should be terminated.

The current method of eliminating the gypsy moth is spraying with Bacillus
thuringiensis (Bt). This nonchemical substance has been deemed by the New Jersey
Forest Service, the New Jersey Department of Agriculture and the New Jersey
Department of Environmental Protection to affect only the gypsy moth and to be
harmless to humans, animals and beneficial insects like honeybees or lady
beetles. This is strikingly dissimilar to the claim that Bt kills inchworms and
butterflies.

Another substance, Sevin, was used effectively to eradicate the gypsy moth in
New Jersey from 1970 to 1985. Although the New Jersey Department of Agriculture
has not used Sevin since 1985, it has been proved safe by the World Health
Organization, the National Cancer Institute, the National Institute of
Occupational Health, the United States Food and Drug Administration, the United
States Department of Agriculture and the United States Army.

Sevin has been recently approved for use in controlling deer ticks, which carry
Lyme disease. It is also registered by the United States Environmental
Protection Agency and therefore proved safe for use on over 130 food crops
including tomatoes, beans, cucumbers, potatoes and squash.

We believe that the spraying programs in New Jersey are crucial to protecting
our trees and that spraying programs must use as many safe methods as possible
to eradicate the gypsy moth. At present, only 88,000 acres of recreational and
residential areas in New Jersey are sprayed, leaving more than 1.3 million acres
of open woodlands untreated. Our environment is being threatened.

We join with the thousands of New Jerseyans who hold an opposing viewpoint to
those who advocate protecting the destructive gypsy moth while putting nature's
beauty at risk. Let's insist on more state use of effective control mechanisms
to solve this crisis.

The Chemical Industry Council of New Jersey represents 105 member companies in
the chemical and allied products industry. The New Jersey chemical industry
employs nearly 120,000 workers and produces approximately $18 billion in
shipments.

HAL BOZARTH
  Executive Director
  Chemical Industry Council of New Jersey
  Trenton

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: Photo of a gypsy moth

TYPE: letter

                               The New York Times

               January 16, 1983, Sunday, Late City Final Edition

THE NATION;
REagan Tries His Hand at Farm Politics

BYLINE: By Carlyle Douglas, Michael Wright and Caroline Rand Herron

SECTION: Section 4; Page 2, Column 1; Week in Review Desk

LENGTH: 503 words


That more is less for the American farmer is not a matter of aesthetics but
fact. As the United States Department of Agriculture announced last week that
production of corn, wheat and some other major crops hit record highs in 1982,
some farm prices stood at their lowest levels in a decade and net farm income
was at its lowest in 50 years.

While farmers elsewhere in the country put up sometimes violent resistance to
loan-default sales, President Reagan was in Dallas telling members of the
American Farm Bureau Federation that ''help is on the way.'' He said that he
would sign a bill limiting Presidential power to curb foreign grain sales and
that his Administration would go ahead with its ''payment-in-kind'', or PIK,
program despite a lack of Congressional approval.

The measure didn't make it through the lame duck session, but Agriculture
officials believed that they already had ''adequate legislative authority'' to
implement most aspects of the program.  However, that position could be subject
to a challenge by the farmstate legislators who beat back the PIK bill.

The grain sale policy change - export contracts calling for delivery within 270
days of the announcement of an embargo would be allowed to go through - was
welcomed. But questions remained as to just how much help PIK would provide.

Under the program, grain and cotton farmers who receive cash subsidies for
reducing their normal acreage by 20 percent to 25 percent could get an
additional subsidy in the form of stored surplus crops by reducing their
plantings further, up to 50 percent. They would be given up to 95 percent of the
crop that would have been raised on the additional acres taken out of
production.

The farmers could do as they wished with the PIK payments. But the biggest
immediate benefit would be to the Agriculture Department, whose crop storage and
support costs would be reduced by more than $1 billion in fiscal 1984, according
to Agriculture Secretary John R. Block.

The second major aim of PIK, an increase in farm prices in 1984, would depend on
widespread participation in the program. An early estimate by the Pioneer Seed
Company of Des Moines, Iowa suggested that if three-quarters of eligible corn
farmers took the maximum additional 30 percent out of production, the harvest
would still be so big that only a slight reduction in the surplus would result.
Even that might be erased if cash-strapped farmers dumped their PIK corn on the
market. And the already depressed farm supply economy might be battered further
by the ripple effects of new decreases in planting -sales of seed, fertilizer,
and some equipment would surely fall off.

Among wheat farmers PIK's propects are even more clouded. Farmers in Kansas
reported last week that their winter wheat crop looked very good, so they
probably would lose money by participating in PIK. But wheatgrowers in Oklahoma,
hit by bad weather, might gladly plow under their ailing winter crop. The
Government has given them until March 11 to decide.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                   Copyright 1983 The New York Times Company

Wheat Rebound Seen

The United States wheat crop could rebound next year by almost 40 percent, to
2.5 billion bushels, with good weather and increased plantings, the Agriculture

a result of the drought.

                          The Globe and Mail (Canada)

                             June 4, 1986 Wednesday

Grain summit meeting fails to reach solution

BYLINE: OLIVER BERTIN; The Globe and Mail

SECTION: ROB; Pg. B15

LENGTH: 412 words


They had many cordial discussions during their three-day meeting in
 Whistler, B.C., and they toured some beautiful scenery. But the only
 concrete result was a promise to meet again.

The grain exporters refused to back down from their earlier stances,
 and two of them threatened to escalate a trade war that has driven
 thousands of farmers around the world to the verge of financial ruin.

The meeting was called by Mr. Mayer to bring some sense to world
 agriculture. The European Community and the United States are trying to
 cut each other out of Third World markets by spending billions of dollars
 on export subsidies.

The only result so far has been to lower the international price of
 food and cut the small exporters - Canada, Australia and Argentina - out
 of their traditional markets.

The EC is usually seen as the villain of world agriculture because it
 is spending an estimated $7.8-billion on wheat subsidies this year alone.
 The United States has responded with subsidies of its own, including wheat
 subsidies that total about $5.7-billion.

Canada spends an estimated $835- million on wheat, and the other
 exporters even less.

The meeting was attended by the five politicians who oversee 90 per
 cent of world grain exports. They are: Richard Lyng, U.S. Secretary of
 Agriculture; Frans Andriessen, Agriculture Commissioner for the EC; John
 Dawkins, Australia's Trade Minister; Lucio Reca, Argentina's Agriculture
 Secretary; and Mr. Mayer.

Instead of settling their differences, as Mr. Mayer hoped, the
 representatives from the United States and the EC assumed an air of
 injured innocence and blamed the opposite party.

"I have said consistently we don't want to have a trade war, but the
 United States is not going to make all the adjustments," Mr. Lyng said.
 "We pointed out that our aim is to regain markets we have lost."

In his rebuttal, Mr. Andriessen contended that the EC is just defending
 its traditional markets and its farmers from U.S. aggression.

"We are simply not prepared to expose our farmers to unlimited world
 market pressures, and to add one million unemployed," he said. "I think we
 can match their monies."

Canada also came under attack because it is growing a record volume of
 wheat this year. The United States said this was irresponsible because it
 would just add to the world grain surplus.

Canada is, however, a small player on the world agricultural scene. The
 states of Iowa, Illinois and California together grow more farm products
 than does Canada.

                              336 of 998 DOCUMENTS


                               The New York Times

                              June 26, 2005 Sunday
                              Correction Appended
                              Late Edition - Final

For Months, Agriculture Department Delayed Announcing Result of Mad Cow Test

BYLINE: By DONALD G. McNEIL Jr. and ALEXEI BARRIONUEVO

SECTION: Section 1; Column 1; National Desk; Pg. 16

LENGTH: 1580 words


Although the Agriculture Department confirmed Friday that a cow that died last
year was infected with mad cow disease, a test the agency conducted seven months
ago indicated that the animal had the disease. The result was never publicly
disclosed.

The delay in confirming the United States' second case of mad cow disease seems
to underscore what critics of the agency have said for a long time: that there
are serious and systemic problems in the way the Agriculture Department tests
animals for mad cow.

Indeed, the lengthy delay occurred despite the intense national interest in the
disease and the fact that many countries have banned shipments of beef from the
United States because of what they consider to be lax testing policies.

Until Friday, it was not public knowledge that an ''experimental'' test had been
performed last November by an Agriculture Department laboratory on the brain of
a cow suspected of having mad cow disease, and that the test had come up
positive.

For seven months, all that was known was that a test on the same cow done at the
same laboratory at roughly the same time had come up negative. The negative
result was obtained using a test that the Agriculture Department refers to as
its ''gold standard.''

The explanation that the department gave late Friday, when the positive test
result came to light, was that there was no bad intention or cover-up, and that
the test in question was only experimental.

''The laboratory folks just never mentioned it to anyone higher up,'' said Ed
Loyd, an Agriculture Department spokesman. ''They didn't know if it was valid or
not, so they didn't report it.''

On hearing that Friday night, Dr. Michael K. Hansen, a senior research associate
at Consumers Union and frequent department critic, reacted skeptically.

''That seems hard to fathom,'' he said. ''If it's true, we have a serious
communication problem at the Department of Agriculture. How can we be confident
of anything they're saying?''

Mr. Loyd, reacting to a reporter's question about the Agriculture Department's
handling of the issue, said, ''In hindsight, reporting it would have been the
thing to do.''

Agriculture Secretary Mike Johanns briefly mentioned the positive test result at
a news conference on Friday. The primary focus of the conference was to announce
that British scientists had confirmed the United States' second case of the
disease.

The sequence of events started in November, when an Agriculture Department
laboratory in Ames, Iowa, performed two tests on the animal in question. After
the ''gold standard'' test came up negative, the agency announced that the
animal had not had mad cow disease. But at the same time, the same lab also
conducted the experimental test, with different results.

Then two weeks ago, for reasons that are unclear, Phyllis K. Fong, the
Agriculture Department's inspector general, arranged for further tests on
specimens of the same cow. A test known as the Western blot, which is widely
used in England and Japan but not in the United States, came up positive.

Because this result conflicted with the ''gold standard'' result from November,
a specimen from the same animal was sent to a laboratory in Weybridge, England,
that is considered pre-eminent in its field. Several tests were conducted there,
and all of them came up positive; it was the results of those tests that Mr.
Johanns announced at the news conference on Friday afternoon.

The nation's mad cow testing system is now infuriating both ranchers and
consumers. Consumer lobbyists say the flawed results show once again that 15
years of testing has been dangerously inadequate. And now the beef lobby, which
has long enjoyed a cozy relationship with the Agriculture Department, is
complaining that the testing system is dangerously unpredictable.

Jim McAdams, president of the 25,000-member National Cattlemen's Beef
Association, has complained that unexpected testing creates ''great anxiety
within our industry,'' and leads to ''significant losses.''

Thirty-six countries have shut their doors to American beef, virtually wiping
out a $3 billion export market, which Australia happily moved into.

On Saturday, Taiwan reimposed a ban on American beef that it had lifted just two
months ago, Reuters reported.

The new case of mad cow appeared to be in a native-born animal, though Mr.
Johanns was vague about that. Testing also suggested that the animal caught the
disease from a new food source, since the strain was different from that of the
Washington State cow that tested positive in 2003.

Mr. Johanns said that catching one positive in 388,000 recent tests proved the
system worked.

But critics said it did no such thing, because the system was designed strictly
for surveillance. One positive caught after a seven-month delay was, at best, a
stroke of luck, the critics said.

Other countries use food-safety standards: Japan tests every cow, Europe tests
about one in four.

The United States instead uses statistical models that it says will let a few
tests detect the infection even in one cow in a million. It now tests one in 90;
when the first mad cow case was found in 2003, it was testing one in 1,700.

With its statistical logic under regular attack, the United States has increased
the number of tests to 388,000 in the past year, from 40 in 1990. But until
recently, Mr. Johanns was discussing cutting back to 40,000 tests.

That system is ''bizarre, illogical and woefully inadequate,'' said John
Stauber, co-author of the book, ''Mad Cow U.S.A.,'' which was first published in
1997.

''The bottom line,'' he said, ''is that the U.S. government is afraid of putting
in real food-safety testing because it would certainly find additional cases.''

Mr. Loyd of the Agriculture Department replied that surveillance testing assumed
a few animals would be positive, and that his department had nearly doubled its
own goal of testing 220,000 cases in a year.

''There is no scientific basis,'' he said, for doing what Japan and many critics
want: testing all animals or all those more than 20 months old.

But even a scientist who helped design the department's testing now harbors
doubts about it.

In an interview before the second case was found, Dr. Linda A. Detwiler, who
retired in 2002 as the chief of the mad cow testing program and now teaches
veterinary medicine at the University of Maryland, said the department should be
using the Western blot test it was resisting.

''You need to put as many tools in your tool kit as possible,'' she said.

Mr. Loyd said Secretary Johanns now agreed. The beef industry now cites its
consumer-protecting ''firewalls.''

But it took many years to erect them: a ban on feeding ruminants to cattle, a
ban on using near-dead dairy cows as beef and a ban on using the brains and
spinal cords of older cattle in feed.

Other practices that many veterinarians dislike continue, such as feeding
poultry litter with spilled cattle meal in it back to cattle, giving calves
''milk replacer'' made from cattle blood and letting cows eat dried restaurant
''plate waste.''

Dr. Detwiler was adamant that those practices should end, and that the brains
and spines of all cattle should be destroyed, not made into feed even for pigs
or chickens.

''That's how you keep infectivity out of the food chain,'' she said. ''If a
farmer makes a mistake and gives pig feed to cattle by mistake, the feed is
safe.''

The beef lobby has opposed many changes, and statements from the industry and
the lobby often echo each other. When Mr. Johanns held a sort of pep rally for
beef in Minnesota recently, no consumer groups were on a panel that declared
American beef ''very, very safe,'' but lobbyists were.

The industry casts a long shadow over the department. Ann M. Veneman, a former
agriculture secretary, had as her spokeswoman Alisa Harrison, who, in 1996,
accused a doctors' group of being an animal rights group opposed to eating meat.
The doctors' group had endorsed the ban on feeding cattle or sheep to cattle.

Mr. Johanns, a former Nebraska governor who grew up on a dairy farm, inherited
two officials of the cattlemen's group, Charles Lambert and Dale Moore, as
deputies. His under secretary for farm and foreign agriculture services, J.B.
Penn, worked at a consulting firm serving the industry.

Last week, according to the Kyodo news service in Japan, a group of Japanese
lawmakers who visited Mr. Penn in Washington accused him of ''threatening'' them
with trade retaliation and saying that the United States' patience was growing
short and that they should simply accept American beef.

Mr. Loyd denied that, saying the meeting was ''cordial.''

Such connections to industry impede the department's duty to police it, said
Representative Rosa L. DeLauro, a Connecticut Democrat on the House
Appropriations Committee. (On Tuesday, the department announced $140 million in
grants to advertise American food overseas, including $12 million to the U.S.
Meat Export Federation.)

She wants a new, separate food safety agency, like the one Britain created in
1999.

But the department's harshest critic has emerged from within -- it is Ms. Fong,
the inspector general, who ordered the new round of tests.

Last spring, she issued a scathing analysis of the testing program, saying, for
example, that it could not do scientific sampling because it was voluntary,
tested too few healthy-looking cattle, and could not assure that sick but
walking cattle and cattle that died on farms were tested.


URL: http://www.nytimes.com

LOAD-DATE: June 26, 2005

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

CORRECTION-DATE: June 29, 2005



CORRECTION: An article on Sunday about a delay by the Agriculture Department in
confirming the United States' second case of mad cow disease referred
incorrectly in some copies to Representative Rosa L. DeLauro of Connecticut, who
said connections to industry impede the department's policing. She is a member
of the House Appropriations Committee, but its ranking Democrat is David R. Obey
of Wisconsin.

                April 11, 1988, Monday, Late City Final Edition

Foreign-Held Farmland

BYLINE: AP

SECTION: Section D; Page 4, Column 6; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 94 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 10


Foreigners continue to own just under 1 percent of United States agricultural
land, slightly more than the level of a year ago, the Department of Agriculture
said Thursday. The department's Economic Research Service said its 1987 year-end
review of reports under the Agricultural Foreign Investment Disclosure Act found
12.5 million acres of agricultural land in foreign hands, 202,000 acres more
than reported in 1986. Corporations held 80 percent of the foreign-owned land,
with the balance held by individuals, partnerships, institutions and other
entities.
