                              338 of 998 DOCUMENTS

                           The Sunday Times (London)

                            December 18 1988, Sunday

If you're thinking of being a pig .; Overeating experiments on pigs

BYLINE: JEREMY LAURANCE

SECTION: Issue 8576.

LENGTH: 318 words


CHRISTMAS gluttons, do not despair. Scientists in America and Britain may have
the answer to the miseries of new year dieting. Instead of studying humans to
find a solution to the problem of overeating they have turned their attention to
the great 'consumers' of the animal kingdom pigs.

Porkers, say the scientists, have an image problem. Most people think they
 chomp through tons of food. But they have actually been moderate eaters
  .until now.


 Scientists in the United States Agriculture Department set out to make pigs
more piggish, injecting them with a vaccine that gave them an insatiable hunger.
It works by counteracting the effects of a hormone called cholecystokinin (CCK),
which induces a feeling of satiation when the stomach is full. In three months
the pigs hardly took their snouts out of the trough and put on 11lb more than
their less greedy friends.

Now scientists are asking if the experiment provides clues into how to reduce
eating. If you can make pigs gorge themselves, they reasoned, then it should be
possible to curb animal and human appetites.

One American researcher is now reported to be giving CCK to volunteer humans,
including those with eating disorders.

British researchers are also looking at the effects of CCK. At the Maudsley
Hospital in south London, Dr Tony Holland is studying patients with
Praader-Willi syndrome, which gives victims an insatiable appetite. One patient
went from 13 stone to 18 stone in a year. 'CCK is one of the things we are
measuring. Maybe Praader-Willi patients don't have it, ' he said.

But Professor John Garrow, an expert on obesity at St Bartholomew's Hospital,
London, said: 'CCK has some effect in man but it is much less dramatic because
we eat much less than pigs.'

For those who cannot wait for the ultimate diet pill, only a strong will stands
between them and gluttony on Christmas day.

LOAD-DATE: September 22, 2000

LANGUAGE: English

                              339 of 998 DOCUMENTS

                               The New York Times

               August 14, 1986, Thursday, Late City Final Edition

TRACTOR SLUMP SEEN ENDING

BYLINE: By STEPHEN PHILLIPS, Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section D; Page 1, Column 3; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1257 words

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Aug. 13


Charles B. Weeks and his wife, Lois, see nothing but ''great opportunity'' for
the tractor dealership they recently bought in Belvidere, Ill. ''There is a lot
of old and used equipment out there that has to be traded in,'' Mr. Weeks said.

It was an unexpectedly optimistic sounding from the farm equipment industry,
which is in its seventh year of slumping sales. But in the view of industry
officials and analysts, as well as Mr. and Mrs. Weeks, things should turn up in
1987. That is a result of a number of measures - many of them painful - that the
industry has taken in the last 18 months. Excess capacity, one of the industry's
biggest problems, has been slashed in half through mergers, bankruptcies and
restructuring. Bloated inventories, which led to years of sharp discounting,
have also been halved.

''The farm equipment market will bottom out in 1986,'' said Jerome K. Green,
president of Case IH, which is the second-largest farm equipment manufacturer,
after Deere & Company. ''And there are some good things going on that will make
1987 begin to turn up.''

Drop Seen in Farmers' Costs

Some of these things should improve farmers' lot, too. Falling petroleum prices
are expected to reduce farmers' fertilizer and fuel costs by $1.8 billion,
according to economists at the United States Department of Agriculture. Interest
rates have declined, too. And land prices - a key factor in determining farmers'
borrowing and buying power - have stopped falling.

The Food and Agricultural Policy Research Institute, which earlier forecast that
farm income would fall in 1987, now says net income will increase 14 percent, to
$29.4 billion.

''Now it's just a matter of getting those farmers who are debt-free to stop
thinking the world is going to end,'' said John E. McGinty, an analyst with the
First Boston Corporation. ''Then sales will take off.'' The Farm and Industrial
Equipment Institute, an industry trade association, predicts that farm tractor
sales will edge up to 116,600 units in 1987, from their projected low of 114,350
this year.

Admittedly, the industry's struggle is not over. With demand for grain storage
bins outrunning capacity and with commodity prices still falling, many farmers
are hard-pressed to buy tractors and combines.

Revenues at Half of '79 Level

Industry sales for 1986 are expected to total $5.5 billion, their lowest point
since 1979's record of $11 billion. And Richard A. Loewy, a grain analyst with
Prudential-Bache Securities, noted that the 1985 farm bill's scheduled decline
in price supports for grain, corn and wheat prices could pull prices down as
much as 22 percent in 1987.

But the industry has responded to the seven-year slump with layoffs and plant
closings that have sliced total employment to 53,000, from more than 100,000.
Product lines have been trimmed and some manufacturers have diversified. All
this has sharply reduced break-even levels.

The acquisition in 1985 by J. I. Case, a division of Tenneco Inc., of
International Harvester's nearly bankrupt agricultural equipment line was the
most significant step toward reducing overcapacity. The company, renamed Case IH
- whose market share grew to 30 percent from 20 percent through the acquisition
-promptly shut down Harvester's Farmall tractor plant in Moline, Ill., slashing
the industry's tractor capacity by 35 percent in one move. An effort to lower
Case IH's break-even point further over the next four years could mean three
more plant closings.

To cope with swollen dealer inventories, Case IH closed all 12 of its North
American plants for three months in 1985 and restricted production to less than
half of what its dealers sold. The resulting drop to a five-month stock from
nearly a full year supply saved about $70 million in interest costs, company
officials said. They plan to cut supplies to four-month levels by the end of
1986. 800 Fewer Dealers Since the merger, about 800 of the 2,600 North American
dealers who carried the Case or International Harvester lines have been dropped
or have voluntarily gone out of business. Some 5,000 workers have quit or been
laid off. Production levels are at 50 percent of capacity, up from 26 percent in
1985, and will be increased to 70 percent in 1987 - even without any upturn in
sales.

Case IH reported an operating profit of $18 million in the second quarter of
1986, ended in June, compared with an operating loss of $22 million a year
earlier. Even without an upturn in farm spending, Case IH should earn an
operating profit of $200 million in 1987, Mr. McGinty of First Boston predicted.

On the other hand, Deere, with more than half of the North American market, has
concentrated on improving plant efficiency. It has allocated $200 million this
year for plant modernization, up from $144 million in 1985. Throughout the
company, assembly operations can now be changed in minutes and many parts in its
product lines are interchangeable. Deere has thus reduced its break-even point
to less than 50 percent of capacity, from 75 percent, and plans to reduce it by
another 5 percent annually.

''We're looking at everything that does not add value, be it materials, labor or
overhead,'' said John K. Lawson, vice president of Deere's farm equipment and
consumer products manufacturing.

Diversification by Deere

Deere has also been diversifying, manufacturing equipment for a variety of
applications other than farming. It makes axles and chassis for Winnebago
Industries, the recreational vehicle maker. It even paints bumpers for Chrysler.
''We'll try to run anything we can through our plants,'' said L. Neel Hall,
Deere's senior vice president.

Last month Deere signed a joint venture with the General Motors Corporation to
manufacture and market diesel truck engines worldwide. Deere officials forecast
annual sales of about $1.5 billion.

But Deere has been slow to attack its farm equipment inventories, currently at
11-month levels. The company's reluctance to shut down facilities for an
extended period of time forced it to discount its estimated $1.5 billion worth
of inventories, analysts said.

Eli S. Lustgarten, an analyst with Paine Webber, predicted that Deere would lose
about $134 million on sales of $3.66 billion this year, compared with net income
of $30.5 million on sales of $4.06 billion in 1985. If Deere makes production
and personnel cuts, Mr. Lustgarten added, it could earn $30 million in 1987.

Other Consolidations

Elsewhere in the industry, there has also been consolidation and
diversification. The Sperry Corporation sold its New Holland division to the
Ford Motor Company's tractor operations. The Allis-Chalmers Corporation sold
most of its combine operations to Klockner-Humboldt-Deutz of West Germany.

Ford's farm division is manufacturing axles, drive trains and engines for more
than 100 foreign makers of industrial and earthmoving equipment. Ford has also
aggressively pursued what is considered the only growth market in agricultural
equipment - the under 40-horsepower tractor. That tractor, however is made in
Japan, leaving Ford and others the job of marketing it.

Most of the combine business of Massey-Ferguson Ltd., the Canadian company, has
been sold, and as part of a corporate restructuring, it has since changed its
name, to the Varity Corporation. The company has moved most of its production
facilities of its remaining product lines overseas and, like Ford, is marketing
low-horsepower tractors to take advantage of what is called the ''urban-suburban
market.''

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

being mounted on tractor at Case IH tractor plant (NYT/Steve Kagan); graph of
U.S. farm tractor sales, in thousands of units (Source: Farm and Industrial
Equipment Institute)

                            The Press (Christchurch)

                            January 21, 2000, Friday

Embassy to lodge US lamb protest

SECTION: NEWS; National; Pg. 7; NATIONAL BRIEFING

LENGTH: 144 words


Trade Negotiations Minister Jim Sutton has asked New Zealand's embassy in
Washington to lodge a protest with the United States Department of Agriculture
at the $ 194 million farm aid package unveiled last weekend.

A spokesman for Mr Sutton, who is also Agriculture Minister, said yesterday he
issued the instruction on Tuesday after learning of the United States
Government's handouts for sheep farmers. The spokesman said Mr Sutton had also
asked the high commission in Canberra to work with Australian officials on a
joint response to the package. This follows US President Bill Clinton's decision
last year to bow to pressure from local farmers and slap tariffs on sheepmeat
imports from Australasia. The World Trade Organisation is considering a
complaint from New Zealand and Australia over the tariffs, which the United
States argues are legal.

                              341 of 998 DOCUMENTS

                               The New York Times

              September 13, 1983, Tuesday, Late City Final Edition

SCIENCE WATCH;
The Productive Fungus

SECTION: Section C; Page 3, Column 5; Science Desk

LENGTH: 279 words


A fungus that lives symbiotically on the roots of wheat helps produce crop
yields that are twice as large as those produced by wheat that is uninfected by
the fungus, scientists at the United States Department of Agriculture Research
Service in Lincoln, Neb., have discovered. The fungi have a network of
microscopic filaments that penetrate plant roots and act as an extension of the
root system, enabling the roots to take up additional nutrients and moisture
from the soil.

James R. Ellis, a Department of Agriculture microbiologist, said that although
the fungus, known as vesicular-arbuscular mycorrhizae, had been known to soil
scientists, it had not been known that it could nourish wheat plants so they had
a better chance of surviving dry spells. The findings, the result of experiments
aimed at developing a drought-resistant wheat, were conducted under greenhouse
drought conditions in Lincoln.

In the greenhouse study, the researchers grew wheat in sterile soil four feet
deep so they could avoid growth conditions in which roots become restricted, and
so they could inoculate soil with the strains of the fungus they wanted to
study. Dr. Ellis said the findings showed that two common strains of the fungus
prevented drought-stressed wheat from having severely lowered yields. The fine
hairs of the fungi were found to penetrate places where the roots could not.

Reporting his findings to the American Society of Agronomy at its recent annual
meeting in Washington, Dr. Ellis noted that if the fungus could be transferred
to field-grown wheat it could save wheat and perhaps other grains that were lost
in this summer's extremely dry and hot weather.


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                   Copyright 1983 The New York Times Company


                              342 of 998 DOCUMENTS

                     Belfast News Letter (Northern Ireland)

                           December 1, 2001, Saturday

RISE IN PORK PRODUCTION

BYLINE: David Mccoy

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 38

LENGTH: 208 words


TOTAL global pork production in 2001 is expected to increase by two per cent on
corresponding year-earlier levels, to just over 84 million tonnes, according to
the United States Department of Agriculture.

Gains in the United States, Canada, Brazil and China are likely to offset the
declines expected to occur in the European Union and Poland.

Total pork production in the United States is forecast to increase by two per
cent, or nearly 200,000 tonnes, on year-earlier levels, to almost 8.8 million
tonnes.

The biggest producer will continue to be China, where overall pork production is
forecast to increase by nearly four per cent, to 43.2 million tonnes.

Increases in production are also forecast for Canada, Mexico and Brazil.

Pork production in the EU, which accounted for approximately one-fifth of global
pork production in 2000, is forecast to decline by almost one per cent, to 17.3
million tonnes.

Within the EU, the USDA forecasts that the biggest declines will occur in Dutch
and United Kingdom production.

Polish pork production is forecast to decline by almost seven per cent on 2000
levels, to 1.5 million tonnes, while Japanese production is expected to be
marginally lower, at 1.26 million tonnes.

LOAD-DATE: December 1, 2001

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUB-TYPE: PAPER

                              343 of 998 DOCUMENTS


                        The Balochistan Times (AsiaNet)

                            January 29, 2017 Sunday

American Embassy leads trade mission to promote innovation in agriculture

SECTION: Vol. 40 No. 29

LENGTH: 306  words


US Embassy Economic Counselor Joel Robert Garverick will lead a delegation of
senior Pakistani government officials, businessmen, farmers and agriculture
experts to Atlanta, Georgia, from January 28 to February 4, to promote
U.S.-Pakistan bilateral commercial

ties and increase trade and investment in agriculture.

According to US embassy here, the delegation will attend the 2017 International
Production and Processing Expo (IPPE), the United States' largest annual trade
show for the poultry, meat, and feed industries, building on the theme,
'innovation in agriculture.'

Agriculture is Pakistan's leading industry, accounting for more than 20 per cent
of GDP and two-fifths of employment. Major products include cotton, wheat, rice,
sugarcane, fruits, vegetables, dairy, beef, mutton, poultry and eggs.

The United States is Pakistan's largest trading partner, exporting $447 million
in agricultural goods to Pakistan in 2015. These imports help support Pakistani
agricultural exports, which were $ 3.7 billion in fiscal year 15/16 (July-June).

Following the expo, the group will meet with U.S. agribusiness executives and
researchers, including experts at the Georgia Tech Agriculture Technology
Research Group and Innovation Lab, to explore innovations that could benefit
Pakistan, expand bilateral trade, and

create investment opportunities for U.S. companies.

The group will also visit a peach farm in Georgia, and conduct meetings with
Georgia's Farm Bureau, Cotton Commission, State Department of Agriculture, and
the U.S. Department of Agriculture's Research Service.

Representatives from all four provinces of Pakistan will take part in the trade
mission, as well as officials from the Ministry of Food Security and Research,
the Pakistan Agriculture Research Council, and the Mohammad Nawaz Sharif
University of Agriculture Multan.

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                            Dayton Daily News (Ohio)

                           January 24, 2015 Saturday

Urban farming in China different;
Gardening

BYLINE: Pam Corle-Bennett

SECTION: LIFE; Pg. D1

LENGTH: 435 words


Last August I had the privilege to go to China with four of my Ohio State
University colleagues on an urban agriculture study tour. This was the first
time I had been to China.

As part of a United States Department of Agriculture partnership grant, our
group toured urban ag programs in Beijing, Zhengzhou, Nanjing and Shanghai in
August. In September a group of Chinese representatives from their Extension
service came to visit our OSU urban ag programs.

Most fascinating to me was the fact that urban agriculture in China is not the
same as it is in the United States.

Our urban agriculture focuses on growing food in urban areas such as community
gardens, urban farms and neighborhood gardens. Urban farming has increased in
popularity in recent years, and a lot of emphasis is on teaching people to
supplement their food with fresh produce.

OSU Extension has a signature program called Local Foods. Extension educators
and specialists around the state are working with people to create local food
programs.

I would consider urban agriculture in China similar to our agriculture
entertainment, or what's commonly called agritourism.

The focus is to help rejuvenate communities outside of the large cities by
creating an economic engine based on agriculture.

For instance, outside of Nanjing, we visited two communities that had thriving
urban agriculture. One emphasized growing tea and the other lavender.

Both of these communities had taken a crop and developed enterprises focused on
this crop. Tours of the fields, paths that you could walk, golf cart tours,
demonstrations, restaurants, shops and more all focused on the one agriculture
crop.

The goal was twofold; one was to reinvigorate the small rural communities, and
the other was to provide a respite or a relaxing atmosphere for those who live
in the city. They would drive two hours on a weekend, stay overnight in the
community, spend money and relax.

Another interesting farming practice that really blew me away was the production
of all kinds of crops in greenhouse or poly structures. These were unheated
greenhouse structures that are similar to our high-tunnel structures.

In China we saw grapes, apples, pears and bananas grown in these structures.
Again, the government was funding the use of these structures and the research.
China has a tremendous challenge in feeding the population, and they are looking
at all different kinds of ways to face this challenge.

Pamela Corle-Bennett is the state master gardener volunteer coordinator and
horticulture educator for Ohio State University Extension. Contact her by email
at bennett.27@cfaes.osu.edu

LOAD-DATE: January 24, 2015

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


                     Copyright 2015 Dayton Newspapers, Inc.

                   The Record-Eagle (Traverse City, Michigan)

                     Distributed by Tribune Content Agency

                              April 1, 2016 Friday

BRIEF: Agriculture in Brief: 04/02/2016

BYLINE: The Record-Eagle, Traverse City, Mich.

SECTION: BUSINESS AND FINANCIAL NEWS

LENGTH: 226 words


April 01--March hogs and pigs

TRAVERSE CITY -- Michigan's total hog and pig inventory was estimated at 1.16
million head March 1, an increase of 20,000 head from last year, according to
Marlo Johnson, regional director of the Great Lakes office of the United States
Department of Agriculture's National Agriculture Statistics Service. The
nationwide inventory of hogs and pigs on March 1 was 67.6 million head, a slight
increase from this time last year.

Honey production down

TRAVERSE CITY -- Michigan produced a total of 5.22 million pounds of honey in
2015, a 9 percent decrease from 2014. Michigan ranked eighth in honey production
for both years. The average price of honey in Michigan also dropped 6 cents to
$2.43 per pound, with total value of production down 11 percent to $12.7
million.

February milk production

TRAVERSE CITY -- Michigan's dairy herds produced 855 million pounds of milk
during February, 11.6 percent more than last February, according to Marlo
Johnson, regional director of the Great Lakes office of the United States
Department of Agriculture's National Agriculture Statistics Service. The daily
rate per cow increased by 3.3 pounds in that time to a total of 71.2 pounds.

(Traverse City, Mich.) at record-eagle.com Distributed by Tribune Content

                     Weston County Gazette (Upton, Wyoming)

  This content, including derivations, may not be stored or distributed in any
  manner, disseminated, published, broadcast, rewritten or reproduced without
                      express, written consent from STPNS

                                 March 17, 2011

Agriculture is AMAZING

BYLINE: Weston County Gazette staff

LENGTH: 478  words


Take a moment to think about how far technology has brought us in America. We
can golf, go to movies, take a vacation, drive our kids to soccer games or watch
a football game with friends because we don't have to work day and night to grow
our own food thanks to agriculture!

If you stop and truly think about this it will fill you with wonder --
Agriculture is Amazing! It is astounding to think that today each United States
farmer produces food and fiber for 155 people in the United States and abroad.
Compare that to only 19 people in the year 1940 -- Agriculture is Amazing!

Advancements in agriculture have freed up people to do things other man grow
their own food. At an October 2010 forum in Torrington, Dr. Gary Sides, with
Pfizer Animal Health, said it best when he said: "There is no culture without
agriculture." Without technology

Having food that is readily available is all most of us have ever experienced in
our lifetime. The picture would be much different though if technology was
frozen in time.

"If technology was frozen in the year 1955, it would require an additional 450
million acres (the total land mass of Texas, Colorado, Kansas, New Mexico and
Oklahoma) to produce the beef we are producing today," Sides commented.

"Globally, if we still achieved yields of 1960, an additional 15-20 milion
square miles of farmland would be needed to produce today's food supply," He
continued.

In 1961, the United States population was close to 184 million people. In 2006,
that number was greater than 300 million people. Sides related those numbers
back to 1960. "If agriculture technology today was the same as 1960, we would
either have to 1) expand acres by 63% or 2) decrease food consumption by 63% "He
explained.

21st century food challenge

It is predicted that the world population will increase to nine billion by 2050.
That means we will need a 50% increase in the food supply by 2030 and 100%
increase by 2050.

Sides commented there are simply two ways to meet global food demand. "One is to
take more land from nature (divert Yellowstone, the Black Hills or the Brazilian
rain forests into agricultural lands). The other choice is to produce more per
acre or per animal on lands currently in agricultural production," He said.
"Which alternative do you prefer?"

Sides points out that farming technology enables U.S. agriculture to produce 70%
more corn from each pound of fertilizer, use 50-80% less water, decrease soil
erosion by 43% in the last 20 years and produce 18% of the world's total food
supply on only 10% of the world's land mass. We have food

The old quote comes to mind: "When people have food, they have a lot of
problems. When people don't have food, they only have one problem." Fortunately,
thanks to agriculture and the impacts of technological advances, we don't have
to worry about not having food to eat--Agriculture is Amazing!

LOAD-DATE: February 4, 2012

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

DOCUMENT-TYPE: People

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

JOURNAL-CODE: WCG

                      Copyright 2011 Weston County Gazette

                           The Philadelphia Inquirer

                           November 19, 2013 Tuesday
                                 CITY-D Edition

Officials mark arrival of Uruguayan citrus in U.S.

BYLINE: By Linda Loyd; Inquirer Staff Writer

SECTION: BUSINESS; P-com Biz; Pg. A16

LENGTH: 758 words


Agriculture officials from Uruguay and the United States gathered at the Packer
Avenue Marine Terminal in South Philadelphia on Monday to mark the first
shipment of Uruguayan citrus fruit to the United States.

On a nearby pier, a Hamburg Sud refrigerated cargo ship had unloaded five
containers of Valencia oranges, which had arrived Sunday and were being taken by
truck to local distribution centers.

About 15 percent to 20 percent of all cargoes arriving at ports and terminals on
the Delaware River, in Philadelphia, South Jersey, and Wilmington, is fresh
fruit - bananas, grapes, kiwis, apples, pears, and citrus from Chile and other
nations.

And now Uruguay.

"It's important because it's the first time that Uruguayan citrus has been
permitted in the United States," said Robert Blackburn, the Philadelphia Port
Authority's deputy executive director.

Uruguay exports other goods to the United States, including meat, leather, fish,
and dairy products, said Ricardo Baluga, deputy chief of the Embassy of Uruguay
to the United States.

"This first shipment of citrus marks nearly 19 years of hard work and
negotiations between the United States and Uruguay," Baluga said. "We have
reached new levels of safety and look forward to expanding our offerings."

The shipment that arrived Sunday was a trial run before the Uruguayan fruit
season begins in May and continues through September.

Next summer, three varieties of Uruguayan mandarins, as well as oranges and some
lemons, will come regularly into the Philadelphia port.

A protocol was recently finalized between Uruguayan agriculture officials and
U.S. regulators that requires pest monitoring and control practices, grove
sanitation, and packinghouse requirements to eliminate potential pests and
bacteria and ensure safe importation.

"We are eager to expand this exciting new pipeline of goods into the U.S.," said
Leo Holt, president of Holt Logistics Corp., whose family runs the terminal.
"Our strategic location, with extensive transportation infrastructure and access
to over 100 million people within a day's drive, makes our port ideal for any
exporter looking to tap into the U.S. market."

Over the years, California citrus growers have been a strong lobby seeking to
limit competition from foreign suppliers, particularly Argentina, which lost its
right to bring citrus into United States 10 years ago.

Uruguay's citrus-producing season does not overlap with the U.S. season, said
Bruce McEvoy of Seald Sweet International, fruit importers and exporters in Vero
Beach, Fla. The Uruguayan exports are important to the small country, which
"needs to diversify its agricultural base," McEvoy said.

Bruce Cahan, officer in charge of the Agriculture Department's Animal and Plant
Health Inspection Service (APHIS) in Southeastern Pennsylvania, acknowledged the
years of "hard work" to bring the citrus here. "Our goal was to facilitate trade
and continue ensuring the health of U.S. agriculture. We are pleased to see the
results."

McEvoy told the crowd: "It's been a very long journey. Lots of patience was
needed along the way. Over the years, I can recall meeting with three of the
former presidents of Uruguay, with four ministers of agriculture, and with
ambassadors on both sides, U.S. and Uruguay."

Since 2000, imported citrus fruit has increased twentyfold, exceeding 200,000
metric tons this year, McEvoy said. "Summer citrus has emerged as a category,
and the buyers have converted. Joining Australia now, we have Chile, Peru, South
Africa, and today, the newest entry, Uruguay."

Top Area Importers by Tonnage

Products arriving at Philadelphia Regional Port Authority in 2011.

Company              Place of origin        Product             Tonnage

Ikea                 Sweden             foods, furniture             249,500

Turbana                Columbia, Costa Rica     bananas              243,562

M-Real                Finland             paper              194,528

Hyundai, Kia             South Korea          autos             174,978

Stora Enso North America       Sweden, Finland        paper              142,452

Norske SKOG             Scandinavia          paper              93,309

In Care of Corus Steel USA     Japan              steel                45,618

Myllykoski North America       Scandinavia           paper               40,000

Jac Vandenberg           Chile              fruit                28,664

                                US Official News

                            February 13, 2017 Monday

Agency Information Collection Activities; Proposals, Submissions, and Approvals

LENGTH: 692  words

DATELINE: New York



 Washington, DC:  This Notice document was issued by the Department of
Agriculture (USDA)



  The Department of Agriculture has submitted the following information
collection requirement(s) to OMB for review and clearance under the Paperwork
Reduction Act of 1995, Public Law 104-13. Comments are requested regarding (1)
whether the collection of information is necessary for the proper performance of
the functions of the agency, including whether the information will have
practical utility; (2) the accuracy of the agency's estimate of burden including
the validity of the methodology and assumptions used; (3) ways to enhance the
quality, utility and clarity of the information to be collected; and (4) ways to
minimize the burden of the collection of information on those who are to
respond, including through the use of appropriate automated, electronic,
mechanical, or other technological collection techniques or other forms of
information technology.





 Comments regarding this information collection received by March 15, 2017 will
be considered. Written comments should be addressed to: Desk Officer for
Agriculture, Office of Information and Regulatory Affairs, Office of Management
and Budget (OMB), New Executive Office Building, 725 17th Street NW.,
Washington, DC 20502. Commenters are encouraged to submit their comments to OMB
via email to: OIRA_Submission@OMB.EOP.GOV or fax (202) 395-5806 and to
Departmental Clearance Office, USDA, OCIO, Mail Stop 7602, Washington, DC
20250-7602. Copies of the submission(s) may be obtained by calling (202)
720-8958.



 An agency may not conduct or sponsor a collection of information unless the
collection of information displays a currently valid OMB control number and the
agency informs potential persons who are to respond to the collection of
information that such persons are not required to respond to the collection of
information unless it displays a currently valid OMB control number.

 Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service



 Title: Importation of Fresh Bananas from the Philippines into the Continental
United States.



 OMB Control Number: 0579-0394.



 Summary of Collection: Under the Plant Protection Act (7 U.S.C. 7701 et seq.),
the Secretary of Agriculture is authorized to carry out operations or measures
to detect, eradicate, suppress, control, prevent, or retard the spread of plant
pests new to the United States or not known to be widely distributed throughout
the United States. The regulations in  "Subpart-Fruit and Vegetables" (7 CFR
319.56, referred to as the regulations) prohibit or restrict the importation of
fruits and vegetables into the United States from certain parts of the world to
prevent the introduction and dissemination of plant pests that are new to or not
widely distributed within the United States.



 Need and Use of the Information: The Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service
(APHIS) uses the following information collection activities to allow the import
of fresh bananas from the Philippines into the continental United States in
accordance with the requirements which will restrict any plant pests from
entering the United States: (1) Bilateral Workplan; (2) Production Site
Registration; (3) Monitoring and Oversight; (4) Maintain All Forms and Documents
that Include Fruit Fly Detections and Updating Records; (5) Carton Marking with
Production Site Number; (6) Hard Green Stage Harvest Certification; (7)
Investigations; (8) Fruit Fly Trapping for Low Pest Prevalence; (9) Shipping
Documents; and (10) Phytosanitary Certificates with Declaration. Failure to
collect this information would cripple APHIS' ability to ensure that bananas
from the Philippines are not carrying plant pests.



 Description of Respondents: Business or other for-profit; Federal Government.



 Number of Respondents: 41.



 Frequency of Responses: Recordkeeping; Reporting: Other: One time.



 Total Burden Hours: 1,330.

 Ruth Brown,

 Departmental Information Collection Clearance Officer.

 [FR Doc. 2017-02872 Filed 2-10-17; 8:45 am]

 BILLING CODE 3410-34-P

               March 23, 1994, Wednesday, DAILY: PRAIRIES EDITION

Canada-U.S. trade talks

SECTION: SECTION 1, NEWS; Pg. 39, Prairie News

LENGTH: 81 words


Federal Agriculture Minister Ralph Goodale said he intends to be in touch over
the next few days with U.S. Agriculture Secretary Mike Espy to continue talks on
various U.S.-Canada trade disputes. The two officials met Monday in Toronto to
discuss, among other things, trade in wheat, milk and cheese, poultry, sugar and
peanut butter. The U.S. has threatened to take trade action against various
Canadian farm products because of allegedly inappropriate Canadian trade
practices.

                              351 of 998 DOCUMENTS

                               The New York Times

                 June 20, 1983, Monday, Late City Final Edition

U.S. SEEKS TO CUT FARM EXPORT LOSS

BYLINE: By SETH S. KING, Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section D; Page 2, Column 2; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 739 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 19


Farm exports by the United States continue to decline, and so once again
American trade and agriculture officials will hold talks with their European
Economic Community counterparts this week to ask them to stop subsidizing grain
and meat sales.

At the same time, an American trade delegation will resume talks in Moscow on a
new long-term grain trade agreement with the Soviet Union.

And on Friday in Paris, Deputy Agriculture Secretary Richard E.  Lyng will
discuss the growing problems of agricultural trade with officials of the
Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development. Among the 24 members of
the O.E.C.D. are Japan and the Common Market nations, the two largest customers
for United States farm exports, as well as Australia and Canada, two major grain
exporters.

$9 Billion Loss of Trade

Export subsidies by the Common Market countries and by Argentina and Brazil will
cause other nations to lose more than $9 billion in foreign sales this year, of
which the United States will lose $6 billion, the Agriculture Department said
last week.

In retaliation, the United States will allocate more than $4.8 billion this year
to subsidize sales of American grain and cotton to developing countries, to
guarantee export loans to these countries and, in a special instance, for Egypt
to buy American flour at below market rates instead of purchasing it from France
at a subsidized price.

The department said it expects United States' food and cotton sales abroad to
fall for the fourth year in a row in 1983, to 149 million metric tons, the
lowest level since 1979. Last year these sales totaled 158 million tons, and in
1980 they were 162 million tons.

American farmers must export two-thirds of their wheat, half their soybeans and
at least a third of their corn and feed grain crops, or else surpluses rise and
their prices fall.

Recent Record Crops

For the past two years, American farmers have grown record grain crops. This
year, the prospects are excellent for more bumper wheat, corn and soybean crops
despite the Reagan Administration's new programs that have reduced acreage for
these crops by about one third. Grain and cotton supplies in the United States
have moved up to their highest level since the early 1970's.

The increasing use of subsidies by this country's competitors is only one factor
contributing to the foreign trade problem, American trade officials said last
week.

They also attributed the decline to unusually large world supplies of grain. The
Agriculture Department reported this month that world wheat stocks were at
record levels. World supplies of corn were at their highest point in five years.
Although soybean crops in Brazil have been hurt by bad weather, world stocks
were expected to remain high.

Daniel G. Amstutz, recently appointed Under Secretary of Agriculture for
International Affairs, also said that high interest rates, by pushing up the
value of the dollar, are making American commodities more expensive in the world
market.

But most disturbing, he said, was the capture of American markets by Argentina,
Brazil and the Common Market countries, which have been subsidizing exports of
grain and poultry and underselling this country.

Before President Carter curtailed grain shipments to the Soviet Union in 1980,
the United States delivered 70 percent of Russia's grain purchases. This fell to
20 percent last year. Part of this loss was attributed to subsidized exports
from the Common Market and Argentina.

Soviet Discussions

The United States hopes to persuade the Russians to sign another five-year grain
purchase agreement and to increase their annual purchases of American corn and
wheat. Under an agreement that expires in September, they were obligated to buy
between six million and eight million metric tons of these grains annually.

American trade and agriculture officials did not expect any marked progress in
the talks with the Common Market this week in Washington.  But the American
representatives expect some flexibility among the Common Market officials
because of the rapidly rising costs of export subsidies. The Common Market
spends more than 70 percent of its agriculture budget for these subsidies,
American officials said.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                   Copyright 1983 The New York Times Company


                              352 of 998 DOCUMENTS

                      The Financial Post (Toronto, Canada)

                     July 27, 1993, Tuesday, DAILY EDITION

U.S. crop estimates hit by rain, drought

BYLINE: Mary Lou Peter Reuter

SECTION: SECTION 1, NEWS; Pg. 8

LENGTH: 471 words

DATELINE: Chicago, IL


Twin U.S. disasters - the Midwestern flood and a drought in the southeast - will
dent the fall harvest, but higher prices could provide a boon to many farmers
who manage to produce a crop, agriculture analysts said yesterday.

''I think everybody's flying by the seat of their pants,'' said grains analyst
Dale Durchholz of AgriVisor Services Inc. as he estimated the magnitude of crop
losses.

He expects U.S. farms to produce 1.8 billion to 1.85 billion bushels of soybeans
this year, with a maximum of 1.9 billion. The figure is down from the
Agriculture department's latest estimate of 1.975 billion bushels.

USDA will update its estimate Aug. 11.

''The biggest problem is that we don't have a rock-solid acreage figure,''
Durchholz said, adding that without good estimates for the number of acres
actually planted in the waterlogged Midwest, it is ''almost impossible'' to
estimate average yields.

On June 30, the Agriculture department estimated that 74.259 million acres were
planted to corn and 61.6 million acres were planted to soybeans.

But two weeks and several torrential rain storms later, Agriculture Secretary
Mike Espy said at least eight million acres of cropland had been flooded and
that there were ''20 million plus acres adversely affected by this situation.''

The ''situation'' has only worsened since.

Bedford, Mass.-based Weather Services Corp. said the western corn-belt has
received an average of 9.3 inches of rain or 241% of normal in the past 30 days.
In the eastern belt, rainfall averaged 8.4 inches or 225% of normal during the
period.

In stark contrast, states in the southeast have averaged just 3.5 inches of rain
in the past 30 days and many areas, particularly the Carolinas, have been much
drier.

ADM Investor Services analyst Steve Freed said making an assessment of the corn
and soybean crops in the U.S. now is almost impossible and that a truly accurate
picture may not unfold until the department's January report.

At this point Freed expects corn production at 7.6 million bushels with an
average yield of 114.5 bushels per acre. He expects soybean production of 1.88
million bushels with average yields of 32 bushels per acre.

Those numbers could change as the season progresses, Freed said.

The disparity in crop conditions through key growing regions and the uncertainty
regarding this year's production has rocked Chicago's grain futures market.

At the Chicago Board of Trade, November delivery soybeans soared to a year high
of US$7.57 1/2 a bushel on July 19 - a 25% rise from the US$6.08 1/2 level of a
month earlier.

Yesterday, November soybeans retreated sharply on a Midwest forecast for warmer
and drier weather, dropping US17.5 cents to US$7.09 1/2 a bushel. December corn
fell US3 cents to US$2.48 1/2 a bushel.

                             National Post (Canada)

                     May 8, 2002 Wednesday National Edition

Vanclief may hike farming subsidies: Minister threatens to battle back against
U.S. support for agriculture: Exports threatened

SOURCE: Bloomberg News

BYLINE: Kevin Carmichael

SECTION: Financial Post: News; Pg. FP10

LENGTH: 390 words

DATELINE: OTTAWA

OTTAWA - Lyle Vanclief, Minister of Agriculture, said Canada may boost farm
subsidies to compete with new U.S. measures and bolster production in one of the
world's biggest grain exporters.

The six-year, US$51.7-billion farm bill would increase subsidies for big grain
and cotton growers by 80%.

That would drop commodity prices and hurt producers in other countries, critics
from Europe to South America say. George W. Bush, U.S. President, has said he
will sign the bill.

The European Union, Canada, Australia and Brazil say the legislation breaks a
commitment by the United States to cut subsidies, and have threatened a
challenge at the Geneva-based World Trade Organization. Canada is one of the
first to say it's considering boosting aid to keep pace with the United States.

"We pledged to continue to pursue means to challenge and counter [the U.S.
legislation's] effect on the marketing of Canadian agricultural products and
Canadian farmers," Mr. Vanclief said on a conference call with reporters after
meeting with provincial farm ministers in Ottawa.

Mr. Vanclief said he would take a proposal to cabinet, though he refused to say
when or how much he would ask for.

The Canadian Federation of Agriculture, which represents some 200,000 farmers,
has said the U.S. measures will cost the group's members $1.3-billion a year.

Canada is the world's third-largest wheat exporter after the United States and
Australia, and leads in shipments of canola and oats. Canadian producers drew on
$3.7-billion in government support payments to offset drought conditions and
poor commodity prices last year, a 32% increase from 2000 and just short of
1992's record of $3.8-billion, according to Statistics Canada.

Canadian farm aid was worth $58 per hectare in 2000, while the EU gave its
farmers $655 and the United States paid $116, according to the Paris-based
Organization for Economic Co-operation and Development. Japan was highest at
$12,307 per hectare and Australia the lowest at $2, the 30-member OECD said.

Mr. Vanclief wouldn't say when he would decide on a WTO challenge. He said he
planned to call counterparts from the EU, Australia and developing countries to
discuss ways to challenge the U.S. bill.

"I think [the United States] has annoyed the whole world."

LOAD-DATE: May 8, 2002

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: Black & White Photo: Fred Chartrand, The Canadian Press; Lyle Vanclief,
Minister of Agriculture, with Rosann Wowchuk, Manitoba's Agriculture Minister,
yesterday.

                                US Official News

                           November 20, 2014 Thursday

Washington: Country of origin label for meat cuts endangered

LENGTH: 657  words

DATELINE: Washington


Association of Western Pulp & Paper Workers has issued the following news
release:

Package labels on fresh cuts of meat that identify where animals were born,
raised and slaughtered face an uncertain future after successful trade
challenges from Canada and Mexico.

Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack says the U.S. is running out of options for
the meat labels, which are required under a 2008 law. A label might say, for
example, that the animal was "born in Canada, raised and slaughtered in the
United States" or "born, raised and slaughtered in the United States."

The World Trade Organization has agreed more than once with Canada and Mexico
that the labels on steaks, ribs and other cuts of fresh meat give the U.S.
livestock industry an unfair advantage. In its most recent ruling Oct. 20, the
WTO said the labeling requirement forced meatpackers to segregate and keep
detailed records on imported livestock, giving them an incentive to favor U.S.
livestock.

The trade organization ruled in 2011 and upheld in 2012 that an earlier version
of the labels was discriminatory.

A spokesman for U.S. Trade Representative Michael Froman said the United States
has not decided whether it will appeal the latest WTO decision. If the October
ruling stands, Canada and Mexico could retaliate against the United States with
other trade sanctions if the labels aren't changed or scrapped.

Vilsack said he believes Congress either needs to change the law or Mexico and
Canada need to negotiate a settlement with the United States.

"There is no apparent regulatory solution available that could make this rule
compliant with the WTO's recent decision and also uphold the law Congress
passed," Vilsack said in a statement.

Canada and Mexico need to tell the U.S. "more clearly and more specifically,
what, if any, variation of this will work for them," the agriculture secretary
said last week at an event in Kansas City, Missouri.

The embattled labeling rules have support from consumer groups and some farm
groups. U.S. ranchers who raise cattle near the northern border and compete with
Canadian ranchers have pushed hardest for the labeling law, which Congress
originally wrote in 2002 and revised in 2008 after years of haggling with the
meat industry. Ranchers and meatpackers in the Southwest who do a lot of
business with Mexico have traditionally opposed it.

It's unclear what lawmakers will do. But the new Republican Congress is expected
to be friendly to the meat industry, which has called for repeal of the
country-of-origin labeling law, saying it is burdensome. Meatpackers have sued
the government to block it, so far unsuccessfully.

Farm-state lawmakers said earlier this year that they didn't have the votes for
repeal. But Rep. Mike Conaway, R-Texas, the incoming chairman of the House
Agriculture Committee, and Sen. Pat Roberts, R-Kan., expected to head the Senate
agriculture panel, are both from cattle-heavy states and have championed the
meat industry.

After the ruling was issued, more than 100 meat, agriculture and food industry
groups concerned about sanctions down the road called on Congress to immediately
repeal parts of the rule.

"Given the negative impact on the U.S. manufacturing and agriculture economies,
we respectfully submit that it would be intolerable for the United States to
maintain, even briefly, a rule that has been deemed non-compliant by the WTO,"
the industry groups wrote.

Canada is also calling for congressional action.

"The onus is now on the United States to put forward a solution acceptable to
all parties that removes the unfair segregation and discrimination against
Canadian cattle and hogs," Canadian Agriculture Minister Gerry Ritz said in a
statement to The Associated Press. He said Canada "will take whatever steps may
be necessary, including retaliation, to achieve a fair resolution."

                               The New York Times

               December 10, 1982, Friday, Late City Final Edition

U.S.-EUROPEAN FARM TALKS

BYLINE: Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section D; Page 3, Column 1; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 669 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 9


Five Cabinet officers will meet Friday in Brussels with ministers of the
European Economic Community for what the Agriculture Department says will be the
final attempt to persuade Common Market countries to stop subsidizing farm
exports.

If the talks fail to gain any concessions, as a senior department official
believes will happen, the Administration is threatening retaliation within the
next month.

''Our patience is wearing out,'' said Secretary John R. Block. ''We had hoped
for more from the Common Market at last month's GATT meetings in Geneva. But
their officials insisted that export subsidies were permissible under the GATT
rules.''

''If that is indeed the case, then surely they cannot object to the United
States proceeding accordingly,'' Mr. Block added. ''They may claim that this
will disrupt their markets. But that's not going to stop us. We will do what we
have to do so our farmers can compete in world markets.''

GATT is the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, subscribed to by 88 nations.


Pressure on Both Sides

The United States contends that the government subsidies give the Europeans
unfair advantages in competing for world agriculture markets, some of which they
have captured from American exporters.

American exporters and farmers and Congressmen from farm states are demanding
immediate retaliation against the Common Market. But the Common Market ministers
say they are facing similar pressures from their farmers to make no concessions.

A special group has been set up within the Agriculture Department to develop new
regulations for subsidizing export sales, according to a senior department
official who asked not to be identified.

The official said the department planned to start ''dumping'' some of its vast
stores of surplus dairy products on world markets, although this is still not
final Administration policy. Dumping means selling products abroad for less than
they would fetch in domestic markets.

If that failed to force European nations to reduce their subsidies, the official
added, the Administration would start subsidizing exports of poultry and offer
subsidized loans to developing countries with which to buy American grain.

Members of Delegation

The American delegation will include Mr. Block, Secretary of State George P.
Shultz, Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan, Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige
and Bill Brock, the special trade representative.

Friction between the United States and Europe has increased in recent disputes
over steel imports and the Soviet natural gas pipeline. But trade experts say
these problems will seem minor compared with the trade war developing over farm
exports.

For the past three years, both the volume and the value of America's share of
these exports have declined. And since 1978, the Common Market has gone from
being a net importer of wheat, sugar, meat and eggs to being a major exporter,
with the value of these exports rising by 164 percent.

$8 Billion in Subsidies

In the 1981-82 marketing year just ended, the 10 Common Market members spent
more than $8 billion subsidizing farm exports, according to the Agriculture
Department.

Part of the decline in America's market share was due to greatly increased grain
and meat production in other countries. But large shares of these markets, the
United States now charges, have been grabbed unfairly by Common Market
countries, led by France, and by Brazil and Argentina, all of whom - according
to the Agriculture Department - use some form of subsidy.

The United States tried last month, during the GATT talks in Geneva, to discuss
farm subsidies. But Common Market officials refused, declaring they would not
even consider changing either export policies or farm price supports.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                   Copyright 1982 The New York Times Company


                              356 of 998 DOCUMENTS


                               The Washington Post

                    August 31, 2000, Thursday, Final Edition

U.S. Information Agency Editor Marie A. Dolan

SECTION: METRO; Pg. B05

LENGTH: 297 words


Marie A. Dolan, 79, a retired U.S. Information Agency writer and editor who
specialized in educational and cultural affairs, died Aug. 21 at her home in
Washington. She had emphysema and heart ailments.

Ms. Dolan was born in Lawrence, Mass., and graduated from Lowell State
University in Massachusetts. She received a master's degree in communications at
American University. She was a public school teacher in Windsor, Vt., and from
1943 to 1945, she was a World War II member of the Marine Corps Women's Reserve,
where she did weather observation and forecasting.

After the war, she settled in Washington and became an information specialist
for the U.S. Weather Bureau Regional Office at Washington National Airport. In
1951, she joined the State Department's International Press and Publications
Division, which became part of the U.S. Information Agency in 1953. She was a
photo editor until 1953, then a writer and editor in USIA's East Asia and
Pacific Branch, specializing in educational and cultural affairs, until she
retired in 1975. She had traveled extensively overseas during her career.

Ms. Dolan was a member of the Washington Press Club, the American Newspaper
Women's Club and Women in Communication Inc. She taught feature writing at the
U.S. Department of Agriculture's graduate school and writing at the YWCA in
Washington.

In the 1950s, she helped to organize and supervise adult and junior college
programs in religious education for the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of
Washington. She served on the parish council of St. Stephen Martyr Catholic
Church in Washington, where she organized and directed a summer recreation
program for neighborhood children in the West End-Foggy Bottom area for five
years.

There are no immediate survivors.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                       Copyright 2000 The Washington Post


                              357 of 998 DOCUMENTS

                              Journal of Commerce

                             July 11, 1988, Monday

ANALYSTS QUESTION CONTINUATION OF SUBSIDIZING GRAIN EXPORTS

BYLINE: HOWARD SIMON; Journal of Commerce Staff

SECTION: FRONT, Pg. 1A

LENGTH: 791 words


The United States may have to decide soon the wisdom of continuing to offer
low-priced grains to foreign customers at the expense of depleting supplies at
home, analysts say.

According to these analysts, continuing to encouraging overseas grain sales
through export subsidies may be imprudent because of drought-related crop osses.

Farmers dipping into their reserves to replenish crops lost to this summer's
drought could determine the amount of subsidized export grain, says Steve Freed,
senior grain analyst for Dean Witter Reynolds Inc.

The Export Enhancement Program, as it is known, subsidizes exporters who sell
grain to traditional U.S. customers. The program has been a boon to U.S.
agriculture exporters, who have sold millions of tons of grain to the Soviet
Union, China and various North African and Middle Eastern nations.

The Reagan administration is reluctant to cut the program because it has helped
U.S. agriculture stay competitive in the world market, analysts said.

The U.S. Department of Agriculture, which administers the subsidies, also noted
that the program has contributed to the narrowing of the trade deficit.

Agriculture Secretary Richard Lyng said recently that the United States has no
intention of cutting off grain exports. We will continue to be exporting this
year, Mr. Lyng said, although he acknowledged that the United States may not be
as aggressive as in the past, as a result of drought-reduced supplies.

However, the United States could see drastic reductions in grain surpluses next
year because of the Midwest drought, and we have to chip away at our reserves,
said Arthur Parrish, senior grain analyst for Shearson Lehman Hutton.

We always see ourselves as having great surpluses, Mr. Parrish said, but that
could change if drought conditions persist into next year.

Mr. Parrish noted that grain reserves built up during the bumper crop years of
the mid-1980s will still tend to blunt a drastic drop in grain production this
year.

Still, analysts are in general agreement that there is little chance that grain
silos will be bulging after the fall harvest because grain and soybean crops
will be the smallest in years no matter how favorable the weather turns.

Tuesday's special report by the U.S. Department of Agriculture on the grain and
soybean crop as of July may give a clearer picture of drought-damage and the
nation's grain supplies as of July 1.

Grain traders said the report will show reductions in all crops and project
severely diminished stocks of spring wheat and less severe losses in oats, corn
and soybeans by the fall harvest.

Recent pronouncements by the USDA project no serious shortages of most grains
and soybean stocks on Sept. 1.

Recent stock figures, released by the Agriculture Department in June showed that
government and farmer-led reserves, prior to this year's plantings, were at 1.27
billion bushels; corn at 4.54 billion bushels; and soybeans at 655 million
bushels.

Exacerbating the growing fear of reduced supplies, the United States is facing
stiff competition from the European Community's own subsidized export program.

Curbing a booming U.S. agricultural export trade is not easy, said Dean Witter's
Mr. Freed, especially when major U.S. competitors are stepping up their
agricultural exports.

European competitors, who have taken a more aggressive stance on exporting
grain, have come under attack by U.S. agricultural officials who have
characterized the activity as taking advantage of the U.S. drought.

The European Community has denied it is exploiting any wheat export
opportunities that might arise from the U.S. drought. (Story Page 6A.)

Nevertheless, the EC has stepped up its grain sales, exporters said, with recent
subsidized sales of 300,000 metric tons of flour going to Egypt and 50,000
metric tons to North Yemen.

The United States countered EC subsidized sales over the past year by offering
low-priced wheat and corn under the more than $ 2 billion government- funded
Export Enhancement Program.

In addition to the Soviet Union (buying about 14 million metric tons of grain in
the past 12 months) China has been been a customer for U.S. grain (nearly 6
million metric tons in the past year.) China has also been in a drought
situation.

U.S. wheat exports of 40.58 million metric tons for the 1987-88 marketing year,
ended May 31, zoomed by 65 percent of last year's total of 24.56 million was
helped by the export subsidy program.

Analysts said there are mitigating factors that could relieve some pressure on
U.S. export demand. The Soviet Union could lean less heavily on grain imports
because of increased domestic production, put at about 215 million to 218
million metric tons.

                                US Official News

                             March 1, 2014 Saturday

Washington: SPEECH OF HON. BILL FLORES OF TEXAS IN THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES
FRIDAY, FEBRUARY 28, 2014

LENGTH: 526  words

DATELINE: Washington


The Library of Congress, The Government of USA has issued the following Speech:

Mr. FLORES. Mr. Speaker, I submit the following.

Whereas, The United States House of Representatives recognizes the delegation of
the National Cereal Producers Association of Poland; and

Whereas, The twenty-eight members in the delegation of the Polish farmers and
representatives of agricultural producer organizations to include the Polish
Association of Cereals Producers, the Polish Agro-Business Club, the Polish
Federation of Cattle Breeders and Milk Producers Zamojskie Agriculture
Association are actively involved as agricultural leaders in Poland; and

Whereas, The Polish delegation's mission is to study Texas agriculture and oil &
gas industries working in tandem in a safe and healthy environment making Texas
the 11th largest economy in the world; and

Whereas, The goals of the program are to provide insight and educational
information into United States agriculture and oil & gas industries, identify
potential investments, enhance export and import opportunities and

[Page: E283] GPO's PDF

continue to build strong Texas/US and Poland/EU relationships; and

Whereas, The areas of study and business opportunities will include crops such
as wheat, corn, soybeans, canola and vegetables; livestock to include cattle,
horses, poultry and dairy; policies to include the farm bill, taxation,
environmental regulation and tort reform; and the new technologies and
production practices with oil & gas especially, shale gas; and

Whereas, The agricultural leaders from the National Cereal Producers Association
of Poland represent Polish landowners and all sectors of Polish agriculture and
will visit Lubbock, Amarillo, San Antonio, Panna Maria, Austin, College
Station/Bryan, Brenham, Anderson, Chappell Hill, East Bernard and Houston, Texas
during a two week span; the delegation will learn firsthand the diversity of
Texas to include rainfall, agriculture and oil & gas production practices,
temperature, soils, size and distance, population densities, infrastructure,
ethnic groups and the various economic industries; and

Whereas, The delegation of the Polish farmers and representatives of
agricultural producer organizations are devoting their time and finances to
explore Texas Agriculture and Oil & Gas from production to transportation to
processing to storage to marketing to selling commodities while studying the
issues facing Texas and the United States of America while discovering fertile
opportunities to enhance business and personal relationships between Poland and
Texas; they deserve recognition for their initiative and motivation to explore
new opportunities to enhance food and energy production for all; and therefore,
be it

Resolved, That the United States House of Representatives:

Congratulates the members of the Polish farmers and representatives of
agricultural producer organizations on their involvement and participation in
the agriculture industries of Poland with interest in the Texas agriculture and
oil & gas industries and extend best wishes and prosperity for the future.

                              360 of 998 DOCUMENTS


                          The Globe and Mail (Canada)

                            July 12, 2000 Wednesday

Vanclief slams U.S. farm aid policies;
Says rhetoric belies reality of subsidies

BYLINE: BARRIE McKENNA, Washington Bureau

SECTION: REPORT ON BUSINESS: CANADIAN; Pg. B5

LENGTH: 347 words

DATELINE: Washington


The United States continues to boost aid to its own farmers even as it vows to
get rid of agricultural subsidies elsewhere in the world, Canadian Agriculture
Minister Lyle Vanclief complained yesterday.

As efforts continue to revive stalled global trade talks at the World Trade
Organization, the U.S. has quietly restored its own farm subsidies to the record
levels hit more than a decade ago, Mr. Vanclief said as he emerged from a
meeting with U.S. Agriculture Secretary Dan Glickman in Washington.

"When the United States continues to increase [its] support to producers and at
the same time say[s] to the world 'you shouldn't be doing that,' it raises a lot
of questions in people's minds," Mr. Vanclief told reporters. "Where's the
rhetoric and where's the reality?"

Canadian officials said the United States will transfer $25-billion (U.S.) to
farmers this year, based on spending already approved by Congress. Much of that
aid is destined for wheat farmers, who have been hit hard by depressed world
commodity prices.

U.S. wheat subsidies have now reached $50 per ton, compared with $15 a ton in
Canada, a top Canadian official noted.

But Mr. Vanclief said one of the most divisive issues in Canada-U.S. farm trade
- the operations of the Canadian Wheat Board - didn't come up during an annual
bilateral meeting between the countries' top farm officials.

Nonetheless, the U.S. has repeatedly vowed to target the CWB's practices in any
new round of trade talks - most recently in a submission late last month to the
WTO in Geneva.

Mr. Vanclief also warned the U.S. that proposed new health regulations in North
Dakota for imported cattle and hogs may violate WTO pacts and the North American
Free Trade Agreement.

"If we feel that whatever is done is not in accordance with the WTO and the
NAFTA, we'll take the challenge to the next step" he said.

Mr. Vanclief complained that the proposed North Dakota measures, now out for
comment, are aimed directly at hindering imports from Canada.

He is slated to meet with U.S. trade representative Charlene Barshefsky today.

LOAD-DATE: September 20, 2006

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: Illustration

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                               The New York Times

                  April 1, 1994, Friday, Late Edition - Final

Goldman Unit Settles Case

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News

SECTION: Section D;  Page 2;  Column 5;  Financial Desk

LENGTH: 193 words


A commodities subsidiary of Goldman, Sachs & Company agreed yesterday to pay $7
million to settle Government allegations involving a former employee's
submission of false information to obtain United States agricultural subsidies.

The subsidiary, J. Aron & Company, reached the settlement with the United States
Attorney's office in Manhattan without admitting wrongdoing or acknowledging
that it knew about the former employee's activities. The United States
Attorney's office declined to name the former employee.

A Goldman, Sachs spokesman declined to comment on the settlement.

According to the settlement, the former J. Aron worker provided false data to
get more subsidies than J. Aron was entitled to receive under a Department of
Agriculture program to encourage agricultural exports. The false information to
the Commodities Credit Corporation, which administers the United States Export
Enhancement Program, helped J. Aron win $5.6 million in subsidies between 1990
and 1991, the Federal prosecutors said.

J. Aron is a New York-based commodities broker for producers and distributors of
farm products, crude oil and other commodities.

LOAD-DATE: April 1, 1994

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                   Copyright 1994 The New York Times Company


                              362 of 998 DOCUMENTS


                                Dawn (Pakistan)

                              March 4, 2016 Friday

Pakistan needs to increase agriculture production: US official

BYLINE: AMIN AHMED

SECTION: Vol. 70 No. 64

LENGTH: 409  words


Pakistan would need to increase agriculture production from its existing land
resources but with lesser water to feed its additional 20 million people by
2050, said Jocelyn G. Brown, a senior official of the US department of
agriculture, on Thursday.

Ms Brown, the department's deputy administrator of foreign agricultural service,
was speaking at inauguration of the National Bio-Control Laboratory at the
National Agriculture Research Centre.

She seemed to be convinced that the government and people of Pakistan fully
understood the challenges vis-a-vis feeding the growing population of the
country.

We need the highest level of commitment from our governments and partners to
further enhance agricultural production to feed the nine billion people in the
world by 2050, she said. Our two governments value the agriculture sector for
food security, added Ms Brown, who served as a Peace Corps volunteer at the
University of Agriculture in Peshawar from 1988 to 1990.

The US official said our joint effort to improve agriculture productivity has
taken on a new urgency. Changing climates in both the United States and Pakistan
are threatening the production of staple crops... Rain is hitting Pakistan
earlier and in the US weather is much more severe than before.

Over the last five years, she said, the Centre for Agriculture and Bio-Science
International had collaborated with Pakistani scientists to support projects in
the areas of animal disease, crop estimation, water management and capacity.

About the national bio-control laboratory, Ms Brown said the work undertaken
there would help farmers control harmful insect attacks on sugar and other
crops, reduce the use of dangerous chemicals, and ensure safer food supplies in
Pakistan and the world.

She said our governments and institutions can work together to introduce new
technologies and research. The United States and Pakistan share the goal of
supporting farmers across Pakistan and the globe to ensure that we have safe and
nutritious food in adequate amounts especially for those people who have little
income and who are most under-served people in the world.

About the capability of Pakistani scientists, she said: I think Pakistan can
bring knowledge to other parts of the world including the United States and
helpful to all agricultural systems.

Dr Babar Bajwa and Dr Nadeem Amjad also spoke on the occasion and thanked the US
government for its assistance for setting up the laboratory.

                               The New York Times

               December 21, 1981, Monday, Late City Final Edition

Farm Debts Are High

BYLINE: AP

SECTION: Section D; Page 6, Column 6; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 78 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20


The Agriculture Department said Friday that farmers' debts in relation to assets
were at a 10-year high. Moreover, the financial plight of farmers is not
expected to improve in the near future, the department's Economic Research
Service said in a preliminary report. Officials said that farm debt was expected
to total a record $194.5 billion on Jan.1. Total farm assets are expected to
rise to $1.18 trillion.

                              365 of 998 DOCUMENTS

                      The Financial Post (Toronto, Canada)

                     April 22, 1994, Friday, DAILY EDITION

U.S. farmers dig in over GATT

BYLINE: Kelly McParland

SECTION: SECTION 1, NEWS; Pg. 6

LENGTH: 429 words

DATELINE: Washington, DC


The Clinton administration has a new problem to face with America's restive
farmers.

Already pressing the administration to get tough with Canada over an array of
Canadian agricultural exports, farmers have notified the White House they don't
want to get stuck with the bill for the newly minted world trade pact, either.

Following approval of the pact in Marrakech, reports indicated President Bill
Clinton planned big cuts in farm programs to offset the estimated US$13.9
billion the U.S. will lose in tariff revenue.

A group of 21 agriculture organizations wrote Clinton to protest, and recruited
a powerful group of legislative allies who warned this week that congressional
approval of the agreement will be ''seriously complicated'' if farm programs are
slashed.

''You can't afford to lose 17 votes'' for the pact, Senate agriculture committee
chairman Patrick Leahy told U.S. Trade Representative Mickey Kantor, referring
to the number of senators supporting the farmers.

'HEAVY WINNERS'

Kantor promised that farmers ''will not pick up the tab'' for the agreement. But
he added that agriculture is a among the ''heavy winners'' in the pact and the
White House feels those who benefit should help carry the cost.

Administration officials say farmers will gain billions of dollars in new
exports to markets opened up in the pact.

The U.S. Department of Agriculture estimates wheat exports will increase US$100
million a year by 2000 and US$600 million a year by 2005. Beef exports should
increase US$1.7 billion by 2005.

Opponents counter that agriculture budgets have been shrinking for years and
benefits will be reduced further because of subsidy reductions agreed to in the
pact.

''To many in my state it appears we've given up way too much in exchange for
much too little,'' said Montana Senator Max Baucus. ''We went to war without our
armor, and came back without our clothing.''

The farmers' opposition complicates Clinton's effort to win congressional
approval for the pact in time for it to take effect Jan. 1, as pledged.

The White House must produce a formula to replace the lost revenues before it
can send the deal to Congress. Republicans have opposed suggestions the
administration be granted a waiver on replacing the funds.

NO DECISIONS

Agriculture Secretary Mike Espy said the administration has not made any
decisions on farmers' share of the bill.

He said about 5% of the lost tariffs will come from agriculture products, and
indicated farmers will be expected to foot at least that much.


LOAD-DATE: November 4, 1997

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: LETTER

                       Copyright 1994 Financial Post Ltd.


                              366 of 998 DOCUMENTS

                        Gazeta Mercantil Online (Brazil)

                          November 13, 2002 Wednesday

Forecasts of world soybean crop grows

SECTION: Agribusiness

LENGTH: 195 words

DATELINE: Sao Paulo and Washington, DC, 11/13/02

The American government foresees a 2.4% increase in world soybean production.
The projection of the United States Department of Agriculture (USDA) for the
2002/03 crop is 188.8 million metric tonnes, in the report disclosed Tuesday.
Last year the harvest was 184.3 million tonnes.  The crop of the United States,
the world's biggest producer of the grain, should total 73.2 million tonnes,
1.35% more than foreseen in October forecasts. "The market expected an increase
of up to 74 million tonnes," said Renato Sayeg, of Tetras Corretora brokerage.
With this, futures prices of soybeans fell 1% in Chicago. For Brazil, the USDA
estimate is 49 million tonnes, 2% more than was forecast in October and 12.6%
greater than the 2001/02 crop. The Department also revised upward the Argentine
crop. The outlook is for the harvest to reach 32.5 million tonnes, volume 4.8%
greater than the October projection.  With the greater production, world soybean
stocks should reach the end of the crop year with 29.68 million metric tonnes,
volume 13.6% greater than that foreseen in October.  (Luciana Franco, Gazeta
Mercantil and Bloomberg News - Translated by James Bruce)

LOAD-DATE: November 13, 2002

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                         Copyright 2002 InvestNews S.A.

                        Gazeta Mercantil Online (Brazil)

                          November 13, 2002 Wednesday

World soybean crop increases

SECTION: Front Page

LENGTH: 195 words

DATELINE: Sao Paulo and Washington, DC, 11/13/02

The American government foresees a 2.4% increase in world soybean production.
The projection of the United States Department of Agriculture (USDA) for the
2002/03 crop is 188.8 million metric tonnes, in the report disclosed Tuesday.
Last year the harvest was 184.3 million tonnes.  The crop of the United States,
the world's biggest producer of the grain, should total 73.2 million tonnes,
1.35% more than foreseen in October forecasts. "The market expected an increase
of up to 74 million tonnes," said Renato Sayeg, of Tetras Corretora brokerage.
With this, futures prices of soybeans fell 1% in Chicago. For Brazil, the USDA
estimate is 49 million tonnes, 2% more than was forecast in October and 12.6%
greater than the 2001/02 crop. The Department also revised upward the Argentine
crop. The outlook is for the harvest to reach 32.5 million tonnes, volume 4.8%
greater than the October projection.  With the greater production, world soybean
stocks should reach the end of the crop year with 29.68 million metric tonnes,
volume 13.6% greater than that foreseen in October.  (Luciana Franco, Gazeta
Mercantil and Bloomberg News - Translated by James Bruce)

                        Gazeta Mercantil Online (Brazil)

                            June 18, 2003 Wednesday

Brazilian agricultural advance already bothers USA

SECTION: Front Page

LENGTH: 225 words

DATELINE: Sao Paulo, 06/18/2003

Country leads in production of sugar, orange juice and coffee. A Brazilian
ambassador with vast experience in the United States and Europe, and profound
knowledge of American negotiating tactics, read a report by the US Department of
Agriculture (USDA) published in January and could not contain himself. "When the
charity is generous, the saint is suspicious," he said. The USDA document is
more optimistic about the prospects of Brazilian agriculture than the government
statistics show.  "The future of agriculture in Brazil has enormous potential
and the estimates that have been made about the scope of a possible agricultural
expansion are largely underestimated," accorcding to the report entitled
"Brazil: Future Agricultural Expansion Potential Underrated." The document gives
an idea of how the evolution and potential of Brazilian farming preoccupies the
United States.  Brazil is the world's leading producer and exporter of sugar,
first in production and export of orange juice and coffee; the second leading
producer of soybeans after the United States and taking the lead in exports;
second in world ranking of beef production; second in the production of chicken,
and the third leading producer of corn and fruits. Another statistic that shocks
the Americans: the productivity of cotton increased 121% between 1995 and 2002.
