                              441 of 998 DOCUMENTS

                               The New York Times

              November 17, 1984, Saturday, Late City Final Edition

MIDDLE WEST GOVERNORS URGED TO PUT FARM PROBLEMS IN FOREFRONT

BYLINE: AP

SECTION: Section 1; Page 10, Column 3; National Desk

LENGTH: 331 words

DATELINE: LINCOLN, Neb., Nov. 16


Governors must educate the public about severe economic conditions affecting
farmers and the relationship between agriculture and the economy, Gov. Ted
Schwinden of Montana said today.

''Agriculture must catch America's attention if it is to earn America's
commitment,'' Governor Schwinden, a Democrat who is a member of the Western
Governors Association, said in a speech to the Midwestern Governors Conference.

''As governors,'' he said, ''we can and must agitate for a more informed
policy-making climate where agricultural policy decisions can be made with a
maximum of information and a minimum of emotion.''

Mr. Schwinden cited a public information program on the economic importance of
agriculture that had been initiated by the Western Governors Association.

He said the ''Image of Agriculture'' project was ''based on the belief that
unless the American public better understands agriculture and its role in the
economy, Congress won't be convinced to develop a responsible, long-term,
comprehensive food and farm policy.'' Even New York City'

He said that if the efforts succeeded, debate on farm legislation in 1985 '' can
focus more on long-term agricultural policy and less on short-term,
crisis-response programs.''

''If we can show that agriculture affects the prosperity of a state like New
York, and even New York City,'' he added, ''the issue will no longer be
relegated to the back pages of the newspaper.''

The governors adopted a resolution offered by Gov. Bob Kerrey of Nebraska, a
Democrat, urging the Federal Government to reduce its budget deficit. Governor
Kerrey said the deficit had kept interest rates high and curtailed exports
because of a strong dollar.

He said the ailing farm economy had sent ''a ripple effect'' through the economy
by reducing the purchasing power of farmers and of others in farm-related jobs.

His resolution also called for governors in the Middle West to lobby for
increased prices for farmers' goods.


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                   Copyright 1984 The New York Times Company


                              442 of 998 DOCUMENTS



                                US Official News

                           September 26, 2014 Friday

Washington: U.S. Forest Service Encourages Participation in Public Lands Day

LENGTH: 721  words

DATELINE: Washington


US Department of Agriculture, The Government of USA has issued the following
news release:

The U.S. Forest Service is offering a fee-free day on Sept. 27, 2014 in
conjunction with the 21st annual National Public Lands Day (NPLD), the Nation's
largest, single-day volunteer effort for public lands projects that ensure
sustainable ecosystems and promote vibrant communities.

"On National Public Lands Day, we welcome you to join trail maintenance
projects, campouts, shoreline cleanups and much more," said U.S. Forest Chief
Tom Tidwell. "Volunteering on a project on this special day will provide a rare
opportunity to learn about safe outdoor recreation and natural resources
conservation, and may even offer a glimpse of wildlife that you don't get to see
every day."

National Public Lands DayThis is an external link or third-party site outside of
the United States Department of Agriculture (USDA) website. began in 1994 with
three sites and 700 volunteers. It proved to be a huge success and became a
yearly tradition, typically held on the last Saturday in September. Since the
first NPLD, the event has grown by leaps and bounds. In 2013, about 175,000
volunteers served at 2,237 sites in every state, the District of Columbia, Guam
and the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico.

Nearly 108,000 volunteers and service members contributed 4.3 million hours on
critical projects on national forests, grasslands and prairies last year. Their
service was valued at close to $94 million.

Nationwide, the Forest Service has registered over 156 sites across the United
States and Puerto Rico. As an agency that manages public lands, the Forest
Service highlights National Public Lands Day projects on national forests and
grasslands that include connections to wilderness and youth engagement in
conservation stewardship, education and outdoor recreation.

The following projects were selected as National Signature Events, based on
demonstrated commitment to conservation stewardship:

Sawmill Gulch TrailheadThis is an external link or third-party site outside of
the United States Department of Agriculture (USDA) website., Missoula, Montana
 Spring Mountains National Recreation AreaThis is an external link or
third-party site outside of the United States Department of Agriculture (USDA)
website., Las Vegas, Nevada
 Grey Towers National Historic SiteThis is an external link or third-party site
outside of the United States Department of Agriculture (USDA) website., Milford,
Pennsylvania

All three projects will focus on expanding volunteerism, engaging diverse
communities, 21st Century Conservation Service Corps and the Wilderness 50th
Anniversary.

Several other Federal agencies are also observing National Public Lands Day. To
find an event near you, visit the NPLDThis is an external link or third-party
site outside of the United States Department of Agriculture (USDA) website.
website.

The Forest Service also offers fee-free days in honor of Martin Luther King Jr.
Day, National Get Outdoors Day and Veterans Day. Fees are waived generally for
day use areas, such as picnic grounds, developed trailheads and destination
visitor centers. Fees are not waived for concessionaire-operated facilities or
for overnight use such as camping or recreation rentals. Contact your local
national forest to learn if your destination requires a fee and if that fee is
waived.

The mission of the Forest Service, part of the U.S. Department of Agriculture,
is to sustain the health, diversity, and productivity of the Nation's forests
and grasslands to meet the needs of present and future generations. The agency
manages 193 million acres of public land, provides assistance to state and
private landowners, and maintains the largest forestry research organization in
the world. Public lands the Forest Service manages contribute more than $13
billion to the economy each year through visitor spending alone. Those same
lands provide 20 percent of the Nation's clean water supply, a value estimated
at $7.2 billion per year. The agency has either a direct or indirect role in
stewardship of about 80 percent of the 850 million forested acres within the
U.S., of which 100 million acres are urban forests where most Americans live.

In case of any query regarding this article or other content needs please
contact: editorial@plusmediasolutions.com

                              443 of 998 DOCUMENTS



                                US Official News

                             March 21, 2014 Friday

West virginia: 2012 Census of Agriculture Preliminary Results Show Growing Farm
Economy

LENGTH: 481  words

DATELINE: Charleston


The State of West Virginia has issued the following news release:

USDA today released the preliminary 2012 Census of Agriculture results.  Key
findings include an increase in the value of agricultural products sold in the
United States totaling $394.6 billion in 2012, up 33 percent ($97.4 billion)
from 2007.  The number of farms and land in farms were down slightly, but held
steady. Additionally, agriculture is becoming more diverse.

The 2012 Census reported several historic changes in value of sales for
agriculture producers in the United States:

In 2012, crop sales of $212.4 billion exceeded livestock sales of $182.2
billion. This occurred for only the second time in Census history; the other
time was 1974.
    Between 2007 and 2012, per farm average value of sales increased from
$134,807 to $187,093, continuing a steady 30-year upward trend. The increase of
$52,286 was the largest rise in Census history.

Preliminary data from the 2012 Census of Agriculture also highlights national
and state farm numbers, land in farms and farmer demographics.

The 2012 Census showed principal farm operators are becoming older and more
diverse; following the trend of previous censuses. In 2012, the average age of a
principal farm operator was 58.3 years, up 1.2 years since 2007, and continuing
a 30-year trend of steady increase. The Census also accounted for more
minority-operated farms in 2012 than in 2007.
    In 2012, the United States had 2.1 million farms - down 4.3 percent from the
previous Census in 2007. In terms of farm size by acres, this continues an
overall downward trend in mid-sized farms, while the smallest and largest-size
farms held steady.
    Between 2007 and 2012, the amount of land in farms in the United States
continued a slow downward trend declining from 922 million acres to 915 million.
This is only a decline of less than one percent and is the third smallest
decline between censuses since 1950.

Conducted since 1840, the Census of Agriculture accounts for all U.S. farms and
ranches and the people who operate them. The Census tells a story of how
American agriculture is changing and lays the groundwork for new programs and
policies that will invest in rural America; promote innovation and productivity;
build the rural economy; and support our next generation of farmers and
ranchers.

"The release of the preliminary 2012 Census of Agriculture results is only a
first look at the data and we are eager to publish the final report this May,"
said NASS Administrator Cynthia Clark. "The 2012 Census was not conducted in a
typical crop year, and drought had a major impact on U.S. agriculture, affecting
crop yields, production and prices. NASS is still reviewing all 2012 Census
items to the county level and therefore data are preliminary until published in
the final report."

For more information please visit: http://www.nass.usda.gov

LOAD-DATE: March 21, 2014

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newswire


              Copyright 2014 Plus Media Solutions Private Limited
                              All Rights Reserved


                              444 of 998 DOCUMENTS


                          The Globe and Mail (Canada)

                             May 26, 1994 Thursday

U.S. envoy sides with Canada   Ambassador assails Agriculture Secretary's
tactics in grain   dispute

BYLINE: DREW FAGAN, ALAN FREEMAN; GAM

LENGTH: 466 words

DATELINE: Washington, Ottawa


BY DREW FAGAN, ALAN FREEMAN
  Washington, Ottawa
DREW FAGAN, Washington
ALAN FREEMAN, Ottawa
  The Globe and Mail
 James Blanchard, the U.S. ambassador to Canada, has accused his country's
Agriculture Secretary of conducting a rogue lobbying effort aimed at
strengthening Washington's hand in its trade battle with Ottawa over grain
exports.

"I don't think he (Agriculture Secretary Mike Espy) had authority from
the President, and I don't agree with him," Mr. Blanchard said yesterday
in an interview on CBC Newsworld. "I don't fault (Canadian Trade Minister)
Roy MacLaren for being frustrated."

Mr. Blanchard, who is a friend of U.S. President Bill Clinton, spoke to
the White House and had its authorization to go ahead with the interview
before criticizing a recent trip to South America by Mr. Espy, trade
sources say.

During the trip, Mr. Espy accused Canada of predatory pricing in
shipping its grain to Brazil, and he offered to provide Brazilian
authorities with evidence of unfair trade practices by Canada that were
alleged to have kept Argentine grain out of Brazilian markets.

On his return to the United States, Mr. Espy said concern about
Canadian trade practices, which are being investigated by U.S. trade
panels, "has moved to a greater level of world scrutiny."

Sources said Mr. Blanchard sought out the television interview after
reading published reports of a speech by Mr. MacLaren on Tuesday in
Washington.

Mr. MacLaren had expressed concern that the United States was harassing
Canadian exports at the behest of such interests as Midwest farm groups,
and had sharply criticized Mr. Espy for escalating a trade battle while
both sides should be seeking a solution.

"I don't have any evidence to suggest that whatever's going on in
Brazil is something the President authorized or supports, or is even aware
of," Mr. Blanchard said yesterday.

Canada and the United States have been on the brink of a trade war for
weeks over agricultural products such as durum wheat. The United States
has formally complained about Canadian practices to the General Agreement
on Tariffs and Trade.

Canadian grain shipments to the United States have risen rapidly in
recent years because, Ottawa contends, the United States doesn't grow
enough for its own needs. Washington says much of the Canadian exports are
unfairly subsidized and are hurting U.S. producers.

Mr. MacLaren said yesterday, however, that he is more hopeful of
reaching a negotiated solution to the dispute after meeting with U.S.
Trade Representative Mickey Kantor.

In an interview, Mr. MacLaren said he, Mr. Kantor and their agriculture
ministers intend to set aside up to two days in mid-June to try to resolve
the dispute.

"I had a definite impression that Mr. Kantor is eager to gain an
agreement on grain," he said. "We both want to attempt to resolve the
question."

LOAD-DATE: January 8, 2007

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


 Copyright 1994 The Globe and Mail, a division of CTVglobemedia Publishing Inc.
                              All Rights Reserved

                           Oakes Times (North Dakota)

                                 March 12, 2015

Agriculture Under Secretary Scuse Leads USDA Trade Mission to Southeast Asia

BYLINE: The Oakes Times staff

LENGTH: 412  words


WASHINGTON, March 4, 2015 - Leaders from six state agriculture departments and
21 U.S. agribusinesses and organizations will accompany U.S. Department of
Agriculture (USDA) Under Secretary Michael Scuse on a trade mission to Southeast
Asia from March 9 to March 13 to expand export opportunities for U.S. food and
agricultural products in one of the world's fastest-growing markets.

"U.S. agricultural exports to Southeast Asia have been on the rise thanks to
strong economic growth and increasing demand for high-value products in the
region," said Scuse, who leads. USDA's Farm and Foreign Agricultural Services
mission area. "With this growth expected to continue, the region holds
significant untapped market potential tor U.S. exporters."

"I am especially pleased to be traveling with a broad cross-section of U.S.
agricultural interests who represent every region of the country and will help
me showcase the quality, variety and abundance of farm and food products
produced for export by the United States," Scuse said.

Scuse noted that the majority of participating companies are small- or
medium-sized enterprises and many are owned by women, minorities and veterans.

The delegation will travel to Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, and Manila, Philippines,
and will also meet with potential customers from Burma and Thailand while in
Kuala Lumpur.

Malaysia, the Philippines, Burma and Thailand boast a combined population of 262
million. As members of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN), these
countries are already strong trading partners Of the United States. U.S. exports
of food and agricultural products to the four countries have doubled over the
past five years, from $2.7 billion in fiscal year 2009 to $5.4 billion in 2014.

Mission participants include a representative from GM Grain of Garrison, ND as
well as those from Idaho, Iowa, Nebraska, North Dakota, Texas and Virginia
departments of agriculture.

USDA trade missions open doors and deliver results for U.S. exporters, giving
them the opportunity to forge relationships with potential customers and foreign
government officials, as well as to gather market intelligence that will help
them develop strategies to expand their sales in key markets overseas. The next
USDA trade mission will take place June 1 to June 5, 2015, to Panama and the
Dominican Republic. Visit
https://public.govdelivery.com/accounts/USDAFAS/subscriber/new for more
information or to sign up for an upcoming USDA trade mission.

LOAD-DATE: April 13, 2016

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                                THE KOREA HERALD

                             June 28, 2005, Tuesday

Korea still interested in restarting U.S. beef import talks

BYLINE: By Yoo Soh-jung

LENGTH: 489 words



The government said it is still keen to restart negotiations on resuming U.S.
beef imports once it receives information requested from Washington, despite a
second confirmed case of mad cow disease recently reported in the United States.

"Our position has not changed. We still plan to jumpstart negotiations on
lifting the ban on U.S. beef once we receive and review the information we asked
from the U.S. government," Kim Chang-seob, chief veterinary officer at the
Ministry of Agriculture and Forestry, told The Korea Herald.

The government says it needs to know what type of cattle feed is used in the
United States and the location of other potentially affected cattle. The
information request was made earlier this month, during an inspection tour of
the United States by Korean officials.

Kim said the government does not know when the U.S. Department of Agriculture
will respond to the queries. Once the information is received, the Ministry of
Agriculture's livestock quarantine committee is expected to decide whether it is
safe to eat U.S. beef again, the official said.

After the conclusion of a third round of working-level talks and on-site
inspections in the United States this month, Kim said that Korea could decide to
restart formal negotiations on restarting beef imports as soon as the end of
this month.

The discovery of the brain-wasting illness bovine spongiform encephalopathy, or
BSE, at a Washington state farm prompted a total ban on U.S. beef imports in
December 2003. Until then, Korea had been among the top five importers of U.S.
beef.

In 2003, Korea imported 293,653 metric tons of beef, of which 68 percent, or
199,443 tons, came from the United States, according to government figures.

After the on-site inspections by Korean officials this month, Kim said the
government was generally satisfied with the standards of U.S. farms, butchering
facilities and livestock authorities.

Local experts have generally agreed that the United States has an effective BSE
early detection system. This includes using feed free of animal components and
the safe handling of meat so it does not get contaminated by specified nerve
tissue. The U.S. has banned the use of cattle feed containing animal parts,
which is suspected of leading to the brain-wasting illness.

The USDA said there is no evidence that the latest mad cow case involved
imported cattle, which means it is the first domestic case of BSE in the U.S.
Washington has been criticized for failing to regularly apply the "Western blot"
test, which is used in Japan and Europe to detect BSE. Mike Johanns, U.S.
agriculture secretary, assured that the BSE-positive cow had not entered the
food chain. He also said the government will now use the Western blot test, in
addition to another screening method called immunohistochemistry, or IHC, when
initial screening indicates that an animal may have the disease.

(sohjung@heraldm.com)

LOAD-DATE: June 30, 2005

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

Copyright 2005 The Korea Herald


                              447 of 998 DOCUMENTS

                               The New York Times

                 August 24, 1997, Sunday, Late Edition - Final

The Nation;
So Let's Just Have Veggies

BYLINE: By TOM KUNTZ

SECTION: Section 4; Page 3; Column 1; Week in Review Desk

LENGTH: 457 words


DOES the picture at right evoke Norman Rockwell -- or Alfred Hitchcock? The
question seems a fair one in light of the scary news lately about food. Last
week the meat processor Hudson Foods recalled 25 million pounds of possibly
tainted ground beef and shut down the Nebraska plant that it came from, causing
shortages at Burger King and Boston Market restaurants.

Only a handful of people have gotten sick from potentially deadly E. coli
bacteria in the meat, but every year in the United States, bacteria in food
kills thousands of people, mostly children and elderly people, and sickens
millions.

So a practical question for the coming weekend is, what's a Labor Day chef to
do?

Here's help from the United States Department of Agriculture's Food Safety and
Inspection Service:

*You may think your wacky "Hot Stuff" apron is essential, but what about a meat
thermometer? Yes, a meat thermometer. The U.S.D.A. says you should use one to
make sure meat has been cooked enough to kill E. coli and other bacteria.
Hamburgers should be cooked to 160 degrees; whole poultry and thighs to 180
degrees, breasts to 170 degrees. Steaks need only be cooked to 145 degrees and
can be reddish inside since bacteria collects only on the outside of such cuts.

*Completely thaw meat and poultry before grilling so that it cooks evenly.

*Keep cold foods cold (40 degrees or lower), and hot food hot (at least 140
degrees).

*Clean all work surfaces and utensils and your hands before and after preparing
food.

*To prevent cross-contamination, make sure raw meat and poultry are separate
from other foods. Never put cooked food on a platter that held raw meat.

*Shop with summer heat in mind: put meat in the shopping cart last, just before
checkout. Meat should go in the car's air-conditioned interior -- not the trunk
-- or in a cooler for trips of more than 30 minutes.

*Thoroughly wash fruits and vegetables to be eaten raw. No nibbling grapes from
the grocery bag.

*Hold the carcinogens: Some studies suggest there is a cancer risk from grilling
food at high heat. To avoid the hazardous chemicals formed by charring meat,
grill at medium temperatures. Trim as much fat as possible to avoid grill
flame-ups. Microwave precooking helps drain off fat.

*As for dangers from the grill itself, the Barbecue Industry Association says
pollution from charcoal units has been minimized with a reformulation of lighter
fluid. Among its common-sense tips: set up the grill in an open area away from
buildings. When lighting a liquid-propane grill, always keep the lid open to
prevent an explosion from built-up gas. And as for that wacky apron, make sure
its strings aren't hanging loose near the fire, or you really will be hot stuff.


LOAD-DATE: August 24, 1997

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: Photo: Cold war fears overlooked the enemy in our backyards:
undercooked burgers. A 50's barbecue. (Elliott Erwitt/Magnum)

                   Copyright 1997 The New York Times Company

                                US Official News

                           February 16, 2017 Thursday

Washington: Dulles CBP Seizes Hidden Horsemeat and Horse Genitals from Mongolian
Travelers

LENGTH: 596  words

DATELINE: New York



 Washington: U.S. Customs and Border Protection has issued the following news
release:



 U.S. Customs and Border Protection agriculture specialists have seen some
really unusual things in traveler baggage at Washington Dulles International
Airport over the years.  From charred full monkeys, to voodoo ceremony tools, to
cocaine concealed inside the cavity of fully cooked chickens, to live sea horses
and giant African land snails.  So it seems that after a while, the oddity is
not so odd anymore.





 Then two women arrived from Mongolia on January 29 with horsemeat concealed
inside juice boxes, including 13 pounds of horse genitals that one woman claimed
were for medicinal purposes.After they deplaned, CBP officers referred the women
for a routine agriculture examination. There, CBP agriculture specialists
discovered a combined 42 pounds of meat described as horsemeat and other
ruminant meat, including 13 pounds of horse genitals, and three liters of yak
milk.



 Horsemeat is prohibited from entering the United States if it is not
accompanied by an official government horsemeat certification from the country
or government it originates. Otherwise, CBP treats it as unknown ruminant meat
and seizes it due to fears of foot and mouth disease. Horsemeat from Mongolia is
prohibited due to concerns of introducing animal diseases to U.S. livestock
industries.



 "Customs and Border Protection takes no pleasure in seizing and destroying
travelers' food products," said Wayne Biondi, CBP Port Director for the Area
Port of Washington Dulles.  "We're in the business of protecting America's
agriculture industries, like the livestock industry, from the potential
introduction of animal diseases posed by these unpermitted food products."



 CBP incinerated all food products.



 Neither woman was criminally charged.  CBP officers released them to continue
their visit.



 Often travelers bring with them food products from their countries that is
normal to their cultures; however, some items are prohibited from the United
States and CBP will seize those products upon arrival.  CBP encourages all
travelers to learn what they can and cannot bring into the United States at
CBP's Travel website.



 "Safeguarding America's agriculture industries, and by extension our nation's
economy, remains an enforcement priority for Customs and Border Protection.  It
is a mission that we take very seriously," said Casey Owen Durst, CBP's Field
Operations Director in Baltimore, the agency's operational commander in the
mid-Atlantic region.



 CBP Agriculture Specialists have extensive training and experience in the
biological sciences and agricultural inspection. Learn more about CBP's
agriculture protection mission.



 On a typical day nationally, CBP agriculture specialists inspect over 1 million
people, and air and sea cargo imported to the United States. Those inspections
net an average of 404 agriculture pests and diseases and 4,638 materials for
quarantine, including plant, meat, animal byproduct, and soil every day.



 Learn more about what CBP's accomplishes in "A Typical Day."



 CBP Office of Field Operations routinely conducts inspection operations on
arriving and departing international flights and intercepts narcotics, weapons,
currency, prohibited agriculture products, and other illicit items at our
nation's 328 international ports of entry.



 Learn how CBP's Office of Field Operations secures our nation's borders at
international Ports of Entry.



 In case of any query regarding this article or other content needs please
contact:

 editorial@plusmediasolutions.com

LOAD-DATE: February 16, 2017

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newswire

                          The Globe and Mail (Canada)

                           September 1, 1987 Tuesday

Latin American ministers of agriculture seeking plan for   reform, modernization

BYLINE: DAVID STEWART-PATTERSON; GAM

LENGTH: 612 words

DATELINE: Ottawa ONT


BY  DAVID STEWART-PATTERSON
 The Globe and Mail
  OTTAWA
  Developing countries in Latin America and the Caribbean are desperate
for reforms to international trade rules in agriculture. They are also
afraid of moving too fast.

That dilemma is at the centre of the discussions of the Inter-American
Institute for Co-operation in Agriculture this week in Ottawa.

Agriculture ministers of 31 countries in North and South America are
searching for a miraculous middle ground and hoping at least for a
consensus on how to help each other survive.

Canadian farmers can testify to the effects of the raging agricultural
trade war between the United States and the European Community, which has
depressed food prices around the world.

The effects are even worse in the debt-burdened countries of Latin
America. Low prices and trade barriers against food exports not only hurt
their ability to pay interest on their foreign debts, but undermine
economic and social stability.

Martin Pineiro, director-general of the IICA, said the agricultural
sector could be the key to short-term revival of their economies. A
failure to restore the health of Latin American farmers, on the other
hand, threatens the survival of peace and democracy in the region.

Joao Baena Soares, Secretary-General of the Organization of American
States, said developing countries are trying to boost their economic
growth by modernizing their agricultural practices. When they succeed and
produce more food, however, they face resistance to the exports that
result.

"You have many faces of the same problem," Mr. Soares said. "We have to
modernize; we have to change the structure in the agricultural activities;
we have to be able to export; we have to be able to sell the products of
our people."

Canadian Agriculture Minister John Wise agreed that agriculture is the
key to solving the broader economic problems of the region. "It must drive
the revitalization of economies in Latin America and the Caribbean."

At the same time, however, developing countries remain skeptical of
U.S. President Ronald Reagan's offer to defuse the agricultural trade ar.

Eduardo Pesqueira, Mexico's Secretary of Agriculture and Hydraulic
Resources, told the conference that the U.S. offer to end all trade-
distorting farm subsidies by the year 2000 will not work because of the
huge gap in economic development between rich and poor countries.

In the United States and Europe, he said, farm subsidies try to promote
commercial trade, while in Latin America, millions of rural poor depend on
support and subsidies from government just to survive.

"Is that the same kind of subsidies as for promotion of commerce in
industrialized countries?" Mr. Pesqueira asked.

Instead of a blanket liberalization of farm markets, "we should
negotiate step by step, maybe product by product, condition by condition,
country by country," recognizing that each country in the region is at a
different level of development and faces different problems.

The ministers who have gathered in Canada's capital recognize that
their discussions this week will not be the end of negotiations, but
rather a warmup for the Uruguay Round of multilateral trade talks under
the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.

They do hope that they can find some measures to help themselves,
without waiting for the end of the ponderous GATT process.

They expect to come up with a joint "Declaration of Ottawa" on world
farm trade, but its content will depend on reaction to the Mexican
proposal from others in the group, especially the United States.

U.S. Agriculture Secretary Richard Lyng would not comment on Mr.
Pesqueira's proposal, saying that he had been unable to hear the speech
through the translation system.

LOAD-DATE: January 4, 2007

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


 Copyright 1987 The Globe and Mail, a division of CTVglobemedia Publishing Inc.
                              All Rights Reserved


                              450 of 998 DOCUMENTS



                                US Official News

                             April 5, 2016 Tuesday

Washington: Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack to Travel to Germany and France

LENGTH: 278  words

DATELINE: Lahore



 Washington: United States Department of Agriculture has issued the following
news release:



 Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack will travel to Berlin and Paris next week to
discuss areas of mutual interest between the European and American agricultural
sectors. In Berlin, Vilsack will meet with German officials as well as farmers
about rural economic development opportunities and to underscore the importance
of the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP). He will then lead
the U.S. delegation to the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development
(OECD) Meeting of Agriculture Ministers, which is being held in Paris.





 While in Berlin April 4-5, Vilsack will meet with German Minister of Food and
Agriculture Christian Schmidt and other government officials, as well as with an
organization of rural youth and young farmers. He will discuss how the TTIP
agreement, currently being negotiated between the United States and the European
Union, will benefit both parties' agricultural sectors by stimulating rural
economies, streamlining import procedures, providing more food choices for
consumers, addressing climate change, and increasing food security.



 Vilsack will then travel to Paris, where he will co-chair the OECD agricultural
ministerial that takes place April 7-8. He and other agriculture ministers from
OECD countries and partner economies around the world will explore how their
governments can work together to feed a growing world population, while managing
natural resources and dealing with climate change.

                              451 of 998 DOCUMENTS


                      Knight-Ridder Tribune Business News

                                August 11, 2006

Got organic milk? Maybe it is, maybe not.

BYLINE: Matt Mckinney

LENGTH: 571 words



HIGHLIGHT: organic dairy cow's feeding practices


Aug. 11--A simmering national debate about -- of all things -- organic milk
comes to Minneapolis today, when several of the largest names in the business
gather at the Minneapolis Women's Club to talk cows, pastures and the spirit of
the organics movement.

The event will center on the question of an organic dairy cow's feeding
practices, and whether the animal is truly "organic" if it eats feed from a
trough rather than nibbling on pasture grasses.

Some farmers, especially smaller operations such as New Prague's Cedar Summit
Dairy, say cows need time to roam in a pasture to produce nutritious milk, while
some larger producers have argued that it makes the milk more expensive.

It's become a bitterly divisive debate within the organic community, spawning
boycotts of some companies and complaints to the U.S. Department of Agriculture
(USDA), which has begun to weigh in.

The agency took public comments this summer on a proposal to make a new pasture
requirement for dairy cows to be labeled organic. The National Organic Standards
Board, a USDA advisory panel, has recommended that ruminants spend at least 120
days a year on pasture, and that 30 percent of all the animal's food come from
grazing.

A strident critic of some of the nation's largest organic dairy operations filed
a complaint Thursday with the USDA's office of compliance, charging that Horizon
Organic, owned by Dallas-based Dean Foods and one of the country's largest
organic dairy producers, does not give its cows enough pasture time. The
complaint from the Wisconsin-based Cornucopia Institute, a pro-organic consumer
association, is its fifth in two years against Horizon and Aurora Organic Dairy,
based in Boulder, Colo.

"These people have built their market share by gaming the system," said Mark
Kastel, co-founder of the institute.

A spokeswoman for Horizon defended the company Thursday, calling the allegation
"without merit." "We support active grazing for 120 days during the growing
season," Molly Keveney said.

The national standards concerning organic dairies require access to pastures,
but the rule is somewhat vague and enforcement actions are rare for violations,
according to Jim Riddle, organic outreach coordinator for the University of
Minnesota.

A provision within the regulations requires access to pastures that have edible
forage, and a second provision asks the farmer to accommodate the natural
behaviors of the animal, meaning giving cows room to graze.

"That phrase, 'access to pasture,' is where the confusion comes," said Riddle,
who until January was chairman of the National Organic Standards Board.

Horizon Organic has defended itself in the past by pointing out that more than
80 percent of its milk is produced by 342 family farms.

A statement on its website also defends the company's use of larger farms that
have as many as 10,000 animals.

"We believe organic is about a dedicated method of food production, and that
there's room in the organic movement for farms of all sizes," the statement
says.

To see more of the Star Tribune or to subscribe to the newspaper, go to
http://www.startribune.co.il.

Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News.

847-635-6550, send a fax to 847-635-6968, or write to The Permissions Group
Inc., 1247 Milwaukee Ave., Suite 303, Glenview, IL 60025, USA.

                      Knight-Ridder Tribune Business News

                                August 11, 2006

Got organic milk? Maybe it is, maybe not.

BYLINE: Matt Mckinney

LENGTH: 571 words



HIGHLIGHT: organic dairy cow's feeding practices


Aug. 11--A simmering national debate about -- of all things -- organic milk
comes to Minneapolis today, when several of the largest names in the business

                              453 of 998 DOCUMENTS

                  The State Journal-Register (Springfield, IL)

                             May 25, 2005 Wednesday

Beef checkoff ruling affects every farmer;
15 products promoted by such programs

BYLINE: CHARLYN FARGO AGRIBUSINESS EDITOR

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 704 words


Monday's U.S. Supreme Court ruling that cattle producers can be required to pay
for an industry marketing program has ramifications for every farmer in the
nation.

The justices ruled 6-3 that the beef checkoff, a mandatory $1-per-head
assessment on cattle, is constitutional. The program is best known for funding
the "Beef, It's What for Dinner" campaign. The beef checkoff is just one of a
variety of farm checkoff programs designed to promote or improve sales prospects
for a variety of agricultural products. Altogether, producers in 15 industries
paid $693 million in such mandatory fees in 2003. In the beef business alone,
producers and importers paid $83.6 million in checkoff dollars during fiscal
2003, money that supported advertising, research and education on behalf of
beef.

The beef checkoff, like many others, is operated by the U.S. Department of
Agriculture.

As a result, the Supreme Court said, the generic advertising at issue is the
government's own speech. That makes it exempt from the First Amendment
free-speech challenge brought to court by an anti-checkoff group, the Livestock
Marketing Association.

"Compelled support of government - even those programs of government one does
not approve - is, of course, perfectly constitutional, as every taxpayer must
attest," wrote Justice Antonin Scalia. "And some government programs involve, or
entirely consist of, advocating a position."

Cattlemen have supported checkoff assessments since 1922. Supporters credit the
checkoff with helping increase demand for beef by more than 25 percent since
1998 and increasing the prices that producers receive for their cattle.

"We are elated," said Jim McAdams, an Adkins, Texas, cattleman and president of
the National Cattlemen's Beef Association.  "Throughout the lengthy litigation
process, we believed in the merits of our case and the merits of the beef
checkoff. This is a victory for all producers who want demand-building efforts
in beef safety, nutrition and promotion continued."

Maralee Johnson, executive vice president of the Illinois Beef Association, said
the ruling is a green light to keep promoting beef.

"We're very pleased the government-speech argument prevailed," she said. "That's
because USDA has sufficient oversight of the beef program."

The ruling in the beef case will affect similar cases pending before the Supreme
Court, including the "Pork: the Other White Meat" pork checkoff and the "Got
Milk?" dairy program.

For starters, a challenge to the pork checkoff will be sent back to the lower
courts to be considered in light of the high court's ruling.

"We're very pleased with the Supreme Court's decision," said Darrell Stitzel of
Shannon, president of the Illinois Pork Producers Association. "This decision by
the highest court in the land is a victory for all commodity programs, including
the pork checkoff."

In the case of the pork checkoff, the Supreme Court's decision provides an
answer to a legal proceeding that began four years ago in Michigan.

A federal judge ruled in 2002 that mandatory collections of the pork checkoff
violated the First Amendment rights of producers who disagree with certain
messages paid for with checkoff funds. The 6th Circuit Court of Appeals upheld
that decision in 2003.

Critics argued the programs support activities that favor large corporate
producers, and the checkoffs violated free-speech rights of individual farmers
who have to pay for advertisements with which they disagree.

Among checkoff critics is the National Farmers Union. NFU president Dave
Frederickson said the ruling did nothing to address issues such as
accountability to producers and access to fair checkoff referendums.

The beef promotion program raises more than $80 million a year by requiring
cattle producers to contribute $1 per animal from their cattle sales. In
addition to television and magazine ads, the program pays for research and
consumer education. The beef checkoff has stimulated the development of more
than 2,100 new beef products since 1998, supporters say.

The pork checkoff has operated since 1985. The "Pork: The Other White Meat"
campaign is one of the nation's most recognized slogans.

LOAD-DATE: May 27, 2005

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: LOCAL

                               The New York Times

                 April 3, 1987, Friday, Late City Final Edition

WASHINGTON TALK: BRIEFING;
Who Owns This Land?

SECTION: Section A; Page 14, Column 4; National Desk

LENGTH: 182 words


This land is not necessarily our land. The Department of Agriculture's Economic
Research Service has found that the amount of land in the United States owned by
foreigners is rising sharply.

Reports submitted to the department under the Agricultural Foreign Investment
Act show that agricultural land held by foreign interests -which represents a
potential security issue because of how it might affect the United States food
supply - increased by 369,000 acres in 1986, to 12.4 million, just under 1
percent of the total acreage.

Of that land, 70 percent is owned by companies and individuals in Britain,
Canada, West Germany, the Netherlands Antilles and Switzerland, it said.

Forestlands accounted for more than half of the foreign-owned acreage, and the
largest holdings by foreigners were in Maine, where 15 percent of agricultural
land was owned by noncitizens, mostly Canadian timber companies.

Most of the acreage in foreign hands, 79 percent, is held by corporations,
according to the department.The rest is held by partnerships, individuals,
trusts and other institutions.

                               Pakistan Observer

                            January 29, 2017 Sunday

US diplomat to lead trade mission to promote economic ties

BYLINE: Muhammad Arshad

SECTION: Vol. 28 No. 29

LENGTH: 304  words


The US Embassy Economic Counselor Joel Robert Garverick will lead a delegation
of senior Pakistani government officials, businessmen, farmers and agriculture
experts to Atlanta, Georgia to promote U.S.-Pakistan bilateral commercial ties
and increase trade and investment in agriculture.

The delegation will remain in the US till February 04, 2017 attend the 2017
International Production and Processing Expo (IPPE), the United States' largest
annual trade show for the poultry, meat, and feed industries, building on the
theme, 'innovation in agriculture.'

Agriculture is Pakistan's leading industry, accounting for more than twenty
percent of GDP and two-fifths of employment. Major products include cotton,
wheat, rice, sugarcane, fruits, vegetables, dairy, beef, mutton, poultry and
eggs.

The United States is Pakistan's largest trading partner, exporting $447 million
in agricultural goods to Pakistan in 2015. These imports help support Pakistani
agricultural exports, which were $ 3.7 billion in fiscal year 15/16 (July-June).

Following the expo, the group will meet with U.S. agribusiness executives and
researchers, including experts at the Georgia Tech Agriculture Technology
Research Group and Innovation Lab, to explore innovations that could benefit
Pakistan, expand bilateral trade, and create investment opportunities for U.S.
companies. The group will also visit a peach farm in Georgia, and conduct
meetings with Georgia's Farm Bureau, Cotton Commission, State Department of
Agriculture, and the U.S. Department of Agriculture's Research Service.

Representatives from all four provinces of Pakistan will take part in the trade
mission, as well as officials from the Ministry of Food Security and Research,
the Pakistan Agriculture Research Council, and the Muhammad Nawaz Sharif
University of Agriculture Multan.

                              Journal of Commerce

                           November 16, 1990, Friday

BRAZILIAN FRUIT EXPORTER POISED FOR US MANGO SALES USDA TO MONITOR SANITATION
PROCESS

BYLINE: JAMES BRUCE; Journal of Commerce Special

SECTION: FOREIGN TRADE, Pg. 5A

LENGTH: 589 words

DATELINE: SAO PAULO, Brazil


An increasingly aggressive Brazilian fruit exporter is about to try its hand in
the U.S. fresh fruit market.

"We are expecting major increases in (mango) production, so we are looking for
new markets," said Edmond Yedid, president of Batia Exportacao e Importacao A,
Sao Paulo.

The company intends to send its first shipment of mangoes early next week,
pending the arrival of U.S. Department of Agriculture technicians to begin
monitoring sanitation processing of the fruit.

Batia plans to export 350,000 of its 4-kilogram boxes of Haden and Tommy Atkins
mangoes to the United States by the end of February, with sales totaling $ 2
million. The target next year is to ship up to a million boxes for more than $ 5
million.

Batia's advantage will be delivering the fruit to American consumers in the
fall, winter and spring, Mr. Yedid told The Journal of Commerce.

Brazil's two mango seasons, August to November in the northeast and November to
February in the southeast, complement the Northern Hemisphere season from May to
September.

Established in 1979, Batia is Brazil's leading fruit exporter with anticipated
revenues this year of $ 16 million. Until now, Europe has accounted for 80
percent of its export sales.

Batia received authorization from the U.S. Department of Agriculture to export
mangoes to the United States in September, but the company was preparing for a
long time before that.

Since 1987 it has invested $ 300,000 in market and sanitation research. USDA
technicians monitored the research, conducted by the University of Sao Paulo
here.

The mangoes will all be shipped by air, from Sao Paulo to New York, Miami and
Los Angeles at a price of $ 1.34 a kilo.

"Unfortunately, Brazilian ports don't have the infrastructure for handling fresh
fruits," said Mr. Yedid.

Italmangesio, another company that financed half the market research and that is
also authorized by the USDA to export to the United States, canceled this year's
shipments at the last minute after a windstorm damaged fruit in its groves.

"But we are still qualified by the USDA, and the project still stands for next
year," an Italmangesio spokesman told The Journal of Commerce.

Until recently, sanitation problems blocked the sale of Brazilian fruit in the
United States. The USDA maintains a high barrier against the import of blights
that might infest American fruit trees and insects that attack fruit.

Growers in the big Sao Francisco river valley only last year met USDA sanitation
standards to begin exporting melons to the United States.

Growing environmental and health movements are also significant barriers. Brazil
exported mangoes to the United States from 1983 to 1985, treating them with a
fumigation process. Anti-insecticide restraints halted the shipments.

Batia already sells ginger to U.S. buyers. The company will sell grapes in the
United States beginning in January and the company is seeking USDA approval to
export papayas.

Batia's next target is to export mangoes to Japan.

To get a toehold in the Japanese market, Batia is investing another $ 450,000 in
further research, expected to be completed by the end of next year.

Entering the Japanese market will involve the purchase of steam treatment
equipment, required by Japanese agricultural regulations to assure sanitation of
imported fruits.

Mr. Yedid said Japan's Leyton House holding company is interested in financing
the $ 2 million equipment acquisition in return for exclusive rights to
distributing the fruit.

LOAD-DATE: December 19, 1996

PERFORMANCE,

                               The New York Times

                             April 1, 2003 Tuesday
                              Late Edition - Final

Nations Fail to Agree on Farm Subsidies

BYLINE:  By ELIZABETH BECKER

SECTION: Section C; Column 1; Business/Financial Desk; Pg. 2

LENGTH: 939 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 31


Negotiators failed today to meet their deadline for figuring out how wealthy
nations can reduce their huge agriculture subsidies, the issue at the heart of a
current round of negotiations at the World Trade Organization.

The poorer nations were promised that this round of trade talks, named after
Doha in Qatar, where they began in November 2001, would especially benefit them
and require the first major reductions in what amounts to $300 billion a year in
subsidies paid by the world's richest nations to their farmers.

The developing nations have said that if these subsidies are not scaled back,
then the entire round of talks would be in doubt. That would jeopardize the
opening of markets favored by the wealthy nations, especially in services like
banking, telecommunications and information technology.

Supachai Panitchpakdi, the director general of the W.T.O., issued a statement
today saying it was a "great disappointment" that the negotiators had missed
today's deadline on agriculture, but he said he thought trade officials were
committed to finding a compromise.

There is little disagreement that these subsidies are among the biggest trade
barriers for poor nations. They are blamed for depressing world grain and fiber
prices, for leading to the dumping of excess grain in wealthy nations and for
undercutting farmers in developing nations. Because agriculture is often the one
route out of poverty for some nations, the subsidies are seen as a chief reason
for the growing disparity between the haves and the have-nots.

In dispute is how the two biggest providers of subsidies -- Europe and the
United States -- will cut back the payments. If they can agree, then Japan,
Korea and Switzerland are expected to follow.

Robert B. Zoellick, the United States trade representative, said today that he
was disappointed in the deadlock but played down suggestions that this was
another example of the widening gap between Washington and Europe during this
time of war.

While noting there was "a lot of sensitivity" about trans-Atlantic relations,
Mr. Zoellick said he was working very hard with his counterpart, Pascal Lamy,
the European Union's trade commissioner. Mr. Zoellick praised the European
Commission proposals to overhaul the community's agriculture.

"All of us face political difficulties in these negotiations," said Mr.
Zoellick, referring to the missed deadline at the W.T.O. "We need to help one
another work through them, seeking constructive solutions."

The European reaction was less muted. The countries of the European Union --
especially France -- have been criticized for being more attached to farm
subsidies than the United States.

Franz Fischler, the agriculture commissioner for the European Union, said today
that he, too, was disappointed and suggested that the proposal rejected at the
W.T.O. required European farmers to make greater sacrifices than American
farmers.

"If we are to make these substantial reductions to our tariffs and
trade-distorting support, we need, and want, our partners to go down this same
road," Mr. Fischler said.

The European Union subsidizes its farmers in a different fashion, placing a
stronger emphasis on environmental concerns and relying heavily on export
subsidies for their producers.

The United States has almost no export subsidies and has proposed cutting
subsidies to 5 percent of the value of farm production. Yet the 2002 farm bill
signed by the administration drastically raised permanent subsidies. Moreover,
trade negotiators are asking for an end to much of the nonemergency food aid
given by the United States, which they say is a disguised form of dumping.

The final deadline for serious negotiations on agriculture and the other
outstanding issues of this round is this September, when the trade ministers
meet in Cancun, Mexico.

By missing today's deadline, negotiators are compiling a growing backlog of
critical issues.

The W.T.O. failed to meet its December deadline to agree on a trade deal that
would help developing nations fight AIDS, tuberculosis, malaria and other
diseases. But the United States, with the strong approval of the American
pharmaceutical industry, exercised the veto that every nation possesses and
stopped the deal. Negotiators say they fear that a compromise will have to wait
until September.

Even though nations have yet to agree on a formula for reducing farm subsidies
and opening markets for agriculture products, the campaign against subsidies has
been hitting its mark, propelled by human rights groups, the United Nations and
even the World Bank.

President Jacques Chirac of France promised African leaders this month that he
would suspend shipments of subsidized grains to their continent.

But this was seen as a gesture, not a solution, for countries that have been
told to climb out of poverty through trade, not foreign aid. They have then
found that the free trade of food, the one commodity they all produce, is
hampered by subsidies, tariffs and export subsidies for farm products.

Mr. Zoellick is credited with pushing the reform of the trade rules for
agriculture at Doha. Trade negotiators say, however, that they are worried that
the agreement is too vague, promising "substantial reductions in
trade-distorting domestic support" that can lead to many interpretations.

At a news conference today, Mr. Zoellick said these hurdles were not
insurmountable, especially because he considered the chance to reduce subsidies
a "once in a generation opportunity."

"Trade cannot promote the development of countries across Latin America, Africa
and Asia without much freer movement of farm products," he said.

                      The Financial Post (Toronto, Canada)

                    December 15, 1989, Friday, DAILY EDITION

Farm program faces review

BYLINE: Reuters

SECTION: SECTION 1, NEWS; Pg. 8

LENGTH: 248 words

DATELINE: Washington,DC


  A Kansas legislator plans to investigate a federal farm-export program,
despite industry worries that resulting negative publicity could erode the
program's political support.

Kansas Democrat Dan Glickman said yesterday he will review the U.S. Agriculture
Department's Export Enhancement Program, under which the government gives
American exporters surplus commodities, to subsidize the cost of selling U.S.
farm products overseas.

Two recent studies say the department wasted up to US$200 million ($232.2
million) between 1985 and 1988 through excessive bonuses and mismanagement.

''The way the program is currently operated, it gives those folks who are
multimillion-dollar grain dealers a preferential hand over farmers,'' Glickman
said.

Concerned over a possible congressional backlash, the Agriculture Department has
said rules for the program will be revised within months.

The department has spent more than US$2.6 billion on the program since 1985 to
promote U.S. exports worth about US$8.9 billion. Wheat exports have accounted
for most spending by the program.

Glickman is proposing a 10-point plan to improve the program's management,
including replacing guidelines with legislation, developing better criteria for
evaluating bids and auditing individual transactions.

Although the probe will focus on program management, industry officials worry
that the debate could erode congressional support for subsidizing U.S. farm
exports.

                          The Globe and Mail (Canada)

                             March 13, 1992 Friday

U.S. farm aid bountiful: study   State, local subsidies keep milk, fruit,
vegetables cheap

BYLINE: OLIVER BERTIN; GAM

LENGTH: 413 words


BY OLIVER BERTIN
Agriculture and Food Reporter
Recent analyses of U.S. farm support programs by the Canadian Department
of Agriculture's policy branch show the United States has a highly
developed system of government subsidies that is among the richest in the
world.

The report, Assistance Programs for Agriculture and the Food Processing
Sector in the United States, also helps explain why milk, fruit and
vegetables are often cheaper in the United States than they are in Canada.

Take milk, a favourite item for Canadian cross-border shoppers.

The federal and state governments spent $4-billion (U.S.) on dairy
subsidies in 1989 to keep the price of milk down. And these figures
referred to a sample of only seven states.

Other subsidies keep down the price of fruit and vegetables.

California farmers received $454-million and Florida $253-million from
their state governments, much of it to defray the cost of growing winter
crops for export to Canada.

In addition, California farmers received $2-billion in crop insurance
and disaster payments, $1-billion in low-cost housing, $1.2-billion in
industrial development bonds and up to $1-billion in low-cost irrigation
water.

And those were the obvious subsidies. The authors of the report found
that U.S. farmers get the bulk of their financial assistance from a host
of "hidden" state and county programs that are often overlooked in studies
of this kind.

To find these hidden programs, the authors conducted a detailed study
of farm subsidies in 28 counties in California, Iowa, Kansas, New York,
North Dakota, Texas and Wisconsin.

In 1989, farmers there were paid a total of $9.1-billion by Washington
and $3.1-billion by the states.

But the municipal and county programs were also highly lucrative. The
authors found that farmers in these seven states saved more than $2-
billion a year in property and sales tax exemptions, low-cost interest
programs and other "hidden" programs.

Most states give a break to farmers by underestimating the market value
of agricultural land when levying property taxes. For farmers in Texas,
this hidden subsidy is worth an estimated $1.2-billion a year, the authors
found.

The state of Wisconsin chooses a different route. Farmers must pay
their full property taxes, but they get $443-million back in tax credits.

Farmers also get a break when hiring farm labour. They are usually
allowed to pay less than the minimum wage, and are often exempted from
health and safety laws, compensation payments and income insurance plans.

LOAD-DATE: January 9, 2007

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                              All Rights Reserved


                              461 of 998 DOCUMENTS

                      The Financial Post (Toronto, Canada)

                   August 10, 1988, Wednesday, DAILY EDITION

Armed camp guards crop report secrecy

BYLINE: Maggie McNeil Reuters

SECTION: SECTION 1, NEWS; Pg. 8

LENGTH: 534 words

DATELINE: Washington,DC


  At 3 a.m. tomorrow, 25 people will be locked up by armed guards in the U.S.
Agriculture Department building.

For the next 12 hours, they will not be able to talk on the telephone, look out
a window or have any contact at all with the outside world.

Before the day is over, almost 200 government employees will be confined in that
same remote corner of the cavernous building as they prepare the U.S. crop
report.

SERIOUS IMPACTS

In the report, the government will detail damage to this year's crops, which
have been hit by the worst drought in more than 50 years.

The survey, based upon inspections of thousands of fields and interviews with
farmers, is expected to show a steep drop-off in this year's corn and soybean
harvests.

The data could have serious and far-reaching impacts for the multibillion-dollar
international grain industry. The report will give government officials and
grain merchants around the world the first firm numbers on which to make policy
and trading decisions in the coming year.

Since the early 1920s, crop reports have been put together under tight security
to prevent employees from leaking information to gain a quick profit.

Advance knowledge of these reports could mean millions of dollars in profits,
since a widely anticipated report such as this week's release can jolt commodity
prices.

For example, if the government pegged the corn harvest sharply below
expectations, crop prices would probably rise in anticipation of tighter
supplies. Traders who knew the figures in advance could buy corn to sell when
the prices increased.

So the department adheres to elaborate procedures to ensure the secrecy of the
reports. ''The window shade incident started all of this,'' said Sam Rives,
deputy secretary for the Agricultural Statistics Board.

He was referring to an incident in the early 1920s involving two government
employees who had worked out a scheme to leak the information before the
official release. One employee was inside the agriculture building, helping put
together the report. The other was outside, watching the building. If the
production estimate was higher, the employee inside was to raise the window
shade. A lowered shade meant lower production.

But when statisticians gather tomorrow to put together the ''lock-up'' report,
all windows where they work will be locked and window shades sealed shut with
wires. Telephone lines will have been cut and outside computer lines shut off.

All elevators and stairwells will be locked off and sealed to prevent anyone
from leaving the lock-up area once he or she has entered it. Armed security
guards will be posted outside the two entrances to the lock-up area.

TIGHT SECURITY

The entire report, which normally involves hundreds of numbers on a variety of
crops, is compiled, double-checked and printed within the sealed area that
contains its own closed-circuit computer system and printing facility. By 3
p.m., the department will have 300 reports to distribute to anxious reporters
and government officials.

''Whatever goes in, stays in until 3,'' Rives said. ''If you accidentally get in
there, you're there for the duration.''




LOAD-DATE: December 9, 1997

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: NEWS

                       Copyright 1988 Financial Post Ltd.


                              462 of 998 DOCUMENTS

                                The Toronto Star

                        December 16, 1986, Tuesday, ME1

'Big Five grain exporters to discuss decline in prices

BYLINE: (REUTER)

SECTION: BUSINESS TODAY; Pg. D5

LENGTH: 423 words

DATELINE: LONDON


   LONDON (Reuter) - The world's major grain exporters plan to meet in
California in February to discuss falling prices and an increasingly bitter
grain trade confrontation between the United States and the European Community,
the International Wheat Council says.

The meeting, scheduled for San Diego, will be attended by agriculture ministers
from the so-called "Big Five" exporters - the United States, the 12-nation
European Community, Canada, Australia and Argentina. The group accounts for 95
per cent of world wheat trade.

The conference will be the second of its kind at the ministerial level, the
London-based wheat council said yesterday.

The first was held in June in British Columbia at Canada's request to discuss an
alarming drop in grain prices and other problems caused by grain export-subsidy
competition between the United States and Western Europe. Participants at the
conference failed to reach agreement over how to stem the price slide or on
solutions to the trade protectionism battle.

Wheat down 35%

Grain prices have plunged in the past year, with wheat down by 35 per cent,
according to wheat council statistics. World grain trade will decline 20 per
cent this year from a 1984-85 record of 104 million metric tons.

A condition for any degree of success in the February meeting will be a speedy
resolution of a dispute between the United States and the European Community
over market share, after Spain's and Portugal's accession to the EC early this
year, wheat council officials said.

The U.S. wants compensation for lost grain sales to the EC after Spanish entry,
and is angry that an interim agreement guaranteeing that Spain would import 1.4
million tons of U.S. corn by Dec. 31 has not yet been fulfilled.

"If the U.S. and EC can't resolve those bilateral trade issues, we won't get too
far in any trade negotiations, either at the General Agreement on Tariffs and
Trade (GATT) round continuing in the new year or at San Diego," one official
said.

Talks between the EC and United States on the issue broke up in Brussels on
Sunday with both sides deadlocked. The United States has said it would impose
curbs on EC imports if no progress was made by the end of the year.

U.S. Agriculture Secretary Richard Lyng, European Agriculture Commissioner Frans
Andriessen, Canadian Wheat Board Minister Charles Mayer, Australian Trade
Minister John Dawkins and Argentine Agriculture Minister Lucio Reca attended the
June meeting, and are expected to attend the San Diego conference.

LOAD-DATE: May 13, 1999

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                  Copyright 1986 Toronto Star Newspapers, Ltd.


                              463 of 998 DOCUMENTS

                      The Financial Post (Toronto, Canada)

                   November 22, 1988, Tuesday, DAILY EDITION

Farmers to lobby Ottawa on trade deal all over again

BYLINE: Frances Phillips

SECTION: SECTION 1, NEWS; Pg. 9, ELECTION '88

LENGTH: 320 words


  Farm leaders concerned about the free trade deal with the U.S. took a
philosophical approach to yesterday's election results.

''We will just have to present our briefs again, but more strongly than
before,'' said Patty Townsend, communications co-ordinator for the Canadian
Federation of Agriculture.

''The legislation for the (free trade) bill will have to be re-entered into the
House and we will use the usual procedures to have changes made so that we can
ameliorate the damage to farmers,'' said Brigid Pyke, president of the Ontario
Federation of Agriculture.

The CFA, which represents 100,000 farmers across Canada, came out strongly
against several key issues of the agreement with the U.S.


But in the latter stages of the election campaign, federal Grains & Oilseeds
Minister Charlie Mayer, who was re-elected last night, met the organization,
''and we clarified things on both sides. We started a good consultative
process,'' Townsend said.

The CFA has also recently received assurances that broiler hatching eggs will be
added to the import control list as soon as the paperwork can be prepared.

The CFA will also return to the government with its framework for a restructured
Farm Credit Corp., which would essentially make the federal agency the lender of
last resort for beleaguered farmers.

Both the CFA and OFA lobbied on behalf of fruit and vegetable growers, who will
lose seasonal import tariffs under free trade. In the past, these tariffs have
protected producers from being swamped by cheaper, U.S. products during the
short Canadian growing season.

Pyke is also concerned that beef producers will not receive the full protection
under free trade they are looking for. She also said she believes Canadian food
processors using supply-managed products - like chicken, eggs and dairy products
- will be unable to compete with their U.S. counterparts.




LOAD-DATE: December 9, 1997

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: NEWS

                       Copyright 1988 Financial Post Ltd.


                              464 of 998 DOCUMENTS

                               The New York Times

                July 25, 1985, Thursday, Late City Final Edition

House Passes Agriculture Bill

BYLINE: AP

SECTION: Section B; Page 5, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 305 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 24


The House today approved by a wide margin a $33.1 billion agriculture bill for
the fiscal year 1986 that basically maintains services at the same level as last
year.

''This shows how Congress feels about agriculture,'' Representative Jamie L.
Whitten, Democrat of Mississippi, chairman of the House Appropriations
Committee, said after the 354-to-71 vote. The fiscal year begins Oct. 1.

The only addition to the bill, which now goes to the Senate, was a $2 million
provision for the Government to develop and improve tests for acquired immune
deficiency syndrome, or AIDS.

Meanwhile, President Reagan signed a bill today providing $1 billion to the
Agriculture Department, allowing it to resume making price-support loans to
farmers after a nearly weeklong cutoff. The action sent emergency money to the
Commodity Credit Corporation, which went broke last week forcing Federal
officials to halt loans to producers for their newly harvested crops. Once the
bill became law, the Agriculture Department told local offices to immediately
resume making the loans.

Mr. Whitten said the new provision of the appropriation measure was needed to
prevent AIDS from contaminating the nation's blood supply.

The bill meets the spending targets in the House-passed budget resolution for
the next fiscal year. The House and Senate are deadlocked over the budget.

The bill includes $9.2 billion for the Commodity Credit Corporation, about $3
billion less than the 1985 appropriation. Expiration of certain programs would
account for the savings.

It also provides for $14.8 billion for domestic food programs, including food
stamps and child nutrition. This is $686 million more than the President wanted.

Rural development assistance would get $4.8 billion under the bill, including
$3.9 billion for the Farmers Home Administration.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                   Copyright 1985 The New York Times Company


                              465 of 998 DOCUMENTS



                                US Official News

                            July 23, 2014 Wednesday

COCHRAN: "WOTUS" RULE A SOURCE OF UNCERTAINTY, ANXIETY & DISTRUST FOR RURAL
AREAS, FARMERS

LENGTH: 517  words

DATELINE: Washington


Office of the Senator Thad Cochran, U.S Government has issued the following news
release:

U.S. Senator Thad Cochran (R-Miss.), ranking member of the Senate Agriculture
Committee, today continued to raise red flags about the impact on agriculture
and rural economies of the new Clean Water Act regulations proposed this spring
by the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA).

Accepting an invitation issued in May by Cochran and Republican members of the
Senate Agriculture Committee, EPA Administrator Gina McCarthy on Tuesday met
with the Senators to discuss their concerns about an assortment of environmental
regulations planned by the Obama administration and their effects on agriculture
production and rural economies.

Chief among the concerns raised by Senators representing rural communities and
agriculture is the "waters of the United States" (WOTUS) rule, which could bring
more waters under the jurisdiction of the Clean Water Act making them subject to
EPA permitting requirements, and the agriculture interpretive rule that outlines
specific practices which qualify producers for exemptions from regulation if
approved by U.S. Department of Agriculture.  The public comment period ends
October 20, 2014, on the proposed WOTUS regulations that were unveiled by the
EPA and Army Corps of Engineers in March, and the comment period closed on July
7 for the agriculture interpretive rule.

"The waters of the United States proposal and the agriculture interpretive rule
are a source of uncertainty, anxiety and distrust for people in rural areas.
This is particularly true for states like Mississippi whose economies are built
on agriculture production and where landowners want the peace of mind that what
they are doing is not subject to ever more regulations," said Cochran, who has
sponsored legislative measures to stop or withdraw the WOTUS proposal.

"I appreciate Administrator McCarthy agreeing to hear our concerns, and I hope
the concerns we shared on behalf of our constituents will prompt the EPA to
engage with agriculture organizations and to abandon or at least rethink some of
the regulations it wants to impose," he said.

The joint EPA-Army Corps regulatory proposal was intended to clarify a so-called
guidance document issued by the two agencies to expand the scope of the Clean
Water Act.  Since its rollout, however, concerns have grown that the WOTUS
proposal would effectively expand provisions of the Clean Water Act. The new
rule would greatly broaden government regulatory and permitting control to
additional streams, creeks, wetlands, ponds and ditches.

In June, Cochran became an original cosponsor of the Protecting Water and
Property Rights Act of 2014 (S.2496), which seeks to stop the WOTUS initiative
and prohibit the EPA and Army Corps from using the proposed rule or any
substantially similar rule or guidance document in any other rulemaking or
regulatory decision.  Earlier this month, the veteran Mississippi lawmaker also
cosponsored a similar amendment offered to the Bipartisan Sportsmen's Act.

For further information please visit: http://www.cochran.senate.gov

LOAD-DATE: July 23, 2014

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newswire


              Copyright 2014 Plus Media Solutions Private Limited

COCHRAN: "WOTUS" RULE A SOURCE OF UNCERTAINTY, ANXIETY & DISTRUST FOR RURAL
AREAS, FARMERS

LENGTH: 517  words

DATELINE: Washington


Office of the Senator Thad Cochran, U.S Government has issued the following news
release:

                                US Official News

                           September 23, 2014 Tuesday

United States Courts Opinions: United States Court of Appeals for the Federal
Circuit: MCNAIR v. DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE

LENGTH: 296  words

DATELINE: Washington


United States Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit has issued the following
order:

NOTE: This order is nonprecedential.
United States Court of Appeals
for the Federal Circuit
______________________
SHEILA A. MCNAIR,
Petitioner,
v.
DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE,
Respondent.
______________________
2014-3141
______________________
Petition for review of the Merit Systems Protection
Board in No. DC-0752-14-0385-I-1.


______________________
ON MOTION
______________________
Before O'MALLEY, WALLACH, and HUGHES, Circuit Judges.
PER CURIAM.
O R D E R
The Department of Agriculture moves to dismiss the
petition for lack or jurisdiction. Sheila A. McNair has not
responded.
McNair petitioned this court for review of a decision of
the Merit Systems Protection Board (MSPB) that affirmed
her removal. After the initial decision, McNair filed a
Case: 14-3141 Document: 12 Page: 1 Filed: 09/19/2014
MCNAIR 2 v. DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE
petition for review with the Office of the Clerk of the
MSPB. The petition remains pending with the MSPB.
This court's review of MSPB decisions is limited to final
orders or final decisions. See Weed v. Soc. Sec. Admin.,
571 F.3d 1359, 1361-63 (Fed. Cir. 2009); see also 28
U.S.C. § 1295(a)(9). Because McNair's claims are pending
before the MSPB, the order from which she seeks review
is not final. See 5 C.F.R. § 1201.113(a) ("The initial
decision will not become the Board's final decision if
within the time limit for filing . . . any party files a petition
for review . . . ."). McNair may, of course, file a notice
of appeal after the MSPB disposes of all claims and enters
a final decision.
Accordingly,
IT IS ORDERED THAT:
(1) The motion to dismiss is granted.
(2) Each side shall bear its own costs.
FOR THE COURT
/s/ Daniel E. O'Toole
Daniel E. O'Toole
Clerk of Court
s24
ISSUED AS A MAN
