                              468 of 998 DOCUMENTS

                               The New York Times

                 July 4, 1982, Sunday, Late City Final Edition

LONG ISLAND JOURNAL

SECTION: Section 11; Long Island; Page 3, Column 1; Long Island Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 922 words


SINCE the mid-1950's, the Federal Government has financed a program to control
infestations of golden nematodes in East End potato fields. Now the program is
in trouble and some potato growers are worried, since $1.7 million in Federal
funds runs out in October and the current Federal budget provides no funds for
the program next year.

The nematodes attack potato roots and lessen yields. United States Department of
Agriculture crews apply soil fumigants to fields they find are infested, and the
department then requires growers to plant varieties of potatoes that are
resistant to the microscopic pest for several seasons.

Now ''it's the Administration's feeling that the State of New York can handle
the program,'' said Harvey Ford, Agriculture Department deputy administrator. He
said the department had no plans to try to restore funds to the program.

''They are putting us in a very difficult situation,'' said Walt Brown of the
New York State Department of Agriculture and Markets.  ''The Federal program is
the basis for other states and countries accepting our crops.''

Mr. Brown said that without the program there was a danger that a number of
states would place an embargo on Long Island potatoes, the cash crop that
sustains East End agriculture. He said state officials were working to get
Congress to restore funds to the program. ''We are also studying alternative
plans to keep the program going,'' he said.

Ron Leuthardt, the executive secretary of the Long Island Farm Bureau, said that
it would be important for the Federal Government to remain as the overseer even
if the state had to pay for the program.  ''The Federal Government is in a
better position to keep states that want to put up embargoes at bay,'' he said.

But even if the program ends, Mr. Leuthardt said, growers could survive, though
at a price. ''A number of our growers won't like it and it will cost money,'' he
said, ''but it's within the realm of possibility that all potatoes leaving Long
Island could be washed.''

That, he said, would eliminate the possibility that the potatoes could be
carrying nematodes.

The 21 Fresh Air Fund Friendly Town Committees on Long Island are still
accepting applications from families who are willing to be hosts to a child for
two weeks this summer. Although the responses this year are only a bit down from
last year, they aren't being made ''with the same great deal of enthusiasm as
last year - the extra food is a consideration,'' said Claudia Moriarity, the
North Shore/Suffolk County representative.

Last year 260 families participated on the Island. With more women returning to
work, a high divorce rate and a sluggish economy, Miss Moriarity is concerned
about the possibility that the decline in host families may increase. Any
families in Nassau or Suffolk Counties who are interested in being hosts to a
child for two weeks in July or August should contact Miss Moriarity at 271-7620.

Never let it be said that the big ones got away - the fish, that is. Over at
Jones Beach and Captree and Robert Moses State Parks, the Long Island State Park
and Recreation Commission is running its 23d annual fishing contest now through
Nov. 30. For rules and regulations that lead to prizes in 75 different
categories, prospective participants may check at the various boat basins or
call 669-1000, extension 247.

The Nassau Department of Recreation and Parks is running its own contests, too.
At Grant Park in Hewlett, the emphasis will be on anglers under 16 who can fish
weekdays from 9 A.M. to 5 P.M. through Aug. 27. At Bay Park in East Rockaway,
age is no factor, and the hours are 9 A.M. to 4 P.M. on Wednesday through Aug.
25. Information may be obtained by calling 295-4337 at Grant or 593-5855 at Bay.

With the help of the Long Island Community Foundation, the Suffolk Community
Council and Blue Cross-Blue Shield of Greater New York have published the second
edition of ''Where to Secure Help,'' a 48-page pocket-size guide listing more
than 200 social and health services in Suffolk County.

The booklet, which has been distributed to police and fire departments as well
as health and social agencies in Suffolk, lists in alphabetical order agencies
and hot lines that provide information, assistance and referrals for a wide
range of problems, from alcoholism to venereal disease. Current Federal, state
and county legislators are listed in the guide also, along with their office
addresses and their telephone numbers.

''The guide is meant for the general public as well as for professionals,'' said
Thomas Chawner, the Suffolk Community Council's executive director. ''The first
edition had been distributed to bartenders as well as social agencies, and we
plan to do that again with the updated edition.''

A more comprehensive guide that lists 1,400 public and private services in
Suffolk, called the ''1982-83 Directory of Community Services,'' will be
completed by the Suffolk Community Council this month with the aid of Suffolk
County and the United Way of Long Island.

Copies of ''Where to Secure Help'' are available at the Suffolk Community
Council, 1 Edgewood Avenue, Smithtown, L.I. 11787. If one requests a copy by
mail, a $1 contribution is requested to cover postage and handling.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                         TendersInfo - Project Notices

                               May 9, 2016 Monday

Strengthening Afghan Agricultural Faculties (SAAF)

LENGTH: 330  words


Project budget: $7.8 million planned initially
OVERVIEW : The objective of SAAF is to strengthen education and research at
Faculties of Agriculture and Veterinary Science, in Afghan universities.  SAAFs
primary partner is Afghanistans Ministry of Higher Education (MOHE). Project
managers also collaborate closely with officers from the Ministry of Agriculture
, Irrigation and Livestock (MAIL).


The program has provided scholarships to students working towards Masters and
Ph.D. degrees in agriculture-related subjects. Students already awarded
scholarships will receive additional support to pursue higher-level degrees in
the United States and India through 2016.
Additional scholarship awards were planned through 2016, but in 2012 USAID
curtailed awards of new scholarships as a cost-saving measure.
ACTIVITIES :
-Continued support to students already awarded scholarships to pursue
higher-level degrees in the United States and India through 2016.
ACCOMPLISHMENTS :


-Selected and sent 34 Afghan professionals from six Agriculture Faculties and
Ministry of Agriculture, Irrigation and Livestock (MAIL) for Masters and Ph.D.
degrees in the United States and India.
-Eight professors have graduated with MS degrees from U.S. universities. Six
from Purdue University and two from North Carolina State University.
-Thirteen professors have finished their post graduate studies from universities
in India. Six from the University of Horticultural Sciences and seven from the
University of Agricultural Sciences.
-All graduates have now returned to Afghanistan and resumed their professional
activities with either the MoHE or the MAIL.
Project completion date : 2016-12-31 12:00:00
Major organization : UNITED STATES AGENCY FOR INTERNATIONAL DEVELOPMENT (USAID)


Address : Great Masood Road
Kabul, Afghanistan
Kabul

Country :Afghanistan
Email : KBLAIDDOCInformation@usaid.gov

Url : https://www.usaid.gov /afghanistan

Financier : UNITED STATES AGENCY FOR INTERNATIONAL DEVELOPMENT (USAID),

                              Journal of Commerce

                           November 9, 1999, Tuesday

China: Pine pallets must be treated

BYLINE: BY JACK LUCENTINI

SECTION: WORLD TRADE; Pg. 3

LENGTH: 406 words


U.S. Department of Agriculture officials said they are available to help
exporters comply with a new Chinese rule requiring imported packing materials
made of U.S. pinewood to be heat-treated.

The Chinese regulation comes a year after the United States, in a bid to prevent
the spread of a voracious wood-boring beetle, imposed similar requirements on
wooden crates and pallets from China.

Chinese officials announced the rule on Nov. 1, saying it was necessary to
prevent the spread of the pinewood nematode, a tiny parasite associated with
pine wilt disease.

""The U.S. Department of Agriculture is prepared to work together with exporters
and the Chinese government to ensure there is a minimal disruption to trade,''
said Michael V. Dunn, undersecretary for the USDA's marketing and regulatory
programs.

China's heat-treatment requirements, which will apply to shipments from the
United States and Japan, will start on Jan. 1.

The USDA cited reports saying the pest has been intercepted 44 times in U.S.
shipments to China since October 1998, and that it has been found in five
provinces of China.

A pest risk assessment has been prepared by the Chinese government addressing
the issue, said U.S. Agriculture officials.

China is the latest addition to the list of countries, including the United
States and Canada, that regulate solid wood packing material to prevent the
introduction of pests.

The Chinese rule covers wood packing materials made of U.S. conifers, a class of
mostly cone-bearing evergren trees that includes pines and cypresses.

Exporters seeking more information about the rules can call the USDA's Animal
and Plant Health Inspection Service at (301) 734-8295. The pinewood nematode is
a microscopic worm that is carried from tree to tree by pine sawyer beetles. The
nematode feeds on the pine trees, which then turn brown and die, usually within
a year.

The nematodes eat the fungi that invade the dead tree; finally, their larvae
enter the trachea of beetles, which carry them to a new tree.

The pest has been found in 36 U.S. states, according to Kansas State University
researchers, who say its widespread distribution here suggests it is native to
the United States.

The pest was discovered in China in 1982, but it has not spread much,
researchers with the Chinese Academy of Forestry, said in a paper for the
International Symposium on Pine Wilt Disease in Beijing in 1995.

LOAD-DATE: November 9, 1999

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                    Copyright 1999 Journal of Commerce, Inc.


                              471 of 998 DOCUMENTS

                              Journal of Commerce

                           August 26, 1992, Wednesday

MEAT-IDENTIFICATION TEST PAVES WAY FOR IMPORTS

SECTION: COMMODITIES, Pg. 9A

LENGTH: 298 words

DATELINE: NEW YORK


The recent removal of a 70-year-old U.S. Department of Agriculture ban on the
import of ground meat to the United States should raise demand for fast,
reliable methods to identify and verify the species content of raw ground meat.

In fact, the availability of user-friendly tests, which facilitate such meat
speciation," helped pave the way for the lifting of the import ban.

Cortecs Diagnostics Ltd. of Deeside, U.K., has developed an easy-to-use test
being marketed in the United States under the trade name DTEK Immunostick, Raw
Meat Species Screening Test Kit. ELISA Technologies Inc. of Alachua, Fla.,
markets the test kits in the United States and Canada.

The DTEK Immunostick kits provide government regulatory bodies and the meat
industry with a quick ( 1/2 hour), accurate means of determining the species
composition of uncooked meats. Other test methods take longer, are less accurate
and are more difficult to carry out, its developers say.

With the DTEK test, users are now able to identify the presence of particular
meats comprising as little as 1 percent of a ground meat mixture.

The accuracy and ease of use of DTEK Immunosticks led to their being recommended
for "immediate implementation" for raw meat species determinations at all of the
USDA's Food Safety and Inspection Service laboratories.

DTEK Immunosticks test for the presence of beef, horse, pork, sheep/goat,
poultry, rabbit, water buffalo, goat, chicken, turkey, deer and even kangaroo
meat.

United Kingdom-based Cortecs Diagnostics is a subsidiary of Cortecs
International Ltd. In addition to its diagnostics and pharmaceutical marketing
operations, Cortecs International also is involved in the development of unique
drug delivery systems for a wide variety of pharmaceuticals.

LOAD-DATE: December 16, 1996

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                  Copyright 1992 The Journal of Commerce, Inc.


                              472 of 998 DOCUMENTS

                              Journal of Commerce

                            March 24, 1988, Thursday

JAPAN SEES NOTHING NEW IN US ATTACK ON IMPORTS

BYLINE: A.E. CULLISON; Journal of Commerce Staff

SECTION: EXPORTS, Pg. 5A

LENGTH: 540 words

DATELINE: TOKYO


A senior government official Wednesday described the latest U.S. demand to
liberalize beef and citrus import controls was nothing new, but added: Now we
know they mean business.

At the same time, the government said it will cut government support prices f
beef and pork, Agriculture Ministry sources said.

The maneuvering over beef comes a few days before the current, four-year- old
agreement on U.S. beef and citrus fruit exports to Japan is set to expire.

The United States today sells about $ 700 million worth of American beef in
Japan as well as $ 150 million worth of oranges, grapefruit and other citrus
fruit.

The United States wants Japan to eradicate or at least phase out those import
limits, saying it likely could vastly increase its beef and fruit exports. But
Japan, seeking to protect its domestic ranches and orchards, wants to negotiate
a new set of import quotas.

U.S. Trade Represe ntative Clayton Yeutter and Agriculture Secretary Richard
Lyng said in Washington on Tuesday that if the United States and Japan fail to
reach agreement, the United States will file a formal complaint with the General
Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. GATT, as the 95-nation body is known, governs
most worldwide commerce.

In Tokyo on Wednesday, the Agriculture Ministry official called the threat by
Mr. Yeutter and Mr. Lyng nothing new because they had been implied for several
months.

The only change, he said, is that now we know they mean business.

The ministry spokesman talked to reporters the same day Japan's ruling
Liberal-Democratic Party rejected the U.S. demand on beef and citrus.

Koichi Kato, leader of an LDP agriculture panel and member of Japan's House of
Representatives, said his group was angry with the tough U.S. stance and agreed
not to yield to pressure from the United States.

He added that politicians and farmers who dislike conceding imports to the
United States believe Japan should take up its fight before GATT.

It was clear to the Japanese government, however, that if the United States does
finally take the problem to GATT there is an excellent chance the Geneva-based
group will rule against Japan.

In a similar dispute last autumn, a multilateral GATT panel decided that
Japanese import curbs on 10 categories of agricultural products violated
international free trade regulations. A review panel upheld that ruling last
month.

While the government appears uncertain of what to do on beef and citrus imports,
it does seem more sure of itself on agricultural prices.

Agriculture Minister Takashi Sato told a ministry advisory group that he wanted
to lower the stable price zones of beef and pork, on which wholesale prices are
based, by 4.3 percent and 9.9 percent, respectively.

U.S. officials sounded pessimistic about their prospects for agreement when they
discussed the issue earlier this week.

There's certainly nothing at the moment that would indicate we're anywhere near
a resolution, Mr. Yeutter said.

Mr. Lyng estimated that without quotas, beef exports to Japan would double in
the next few years and citrus exports would show a substantial increase.

He noted that sirloin steak costs $ 4.99 a pound in Washington and $ 20.56 a
pound in Tokyo.

LOAD-DATE: January 7, 1997

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                  Copyright 1988 The Journal of Commerce, Inc.


                              473 of 998 DOCUMENTS

                      The Financial Post (Toronto, Canada)

                      June 29, 1990, Friday, DAILY EDITION

Report will be bullish for Chicago soybean prices

BYLINE: Farm Market News

SECTION: SECTION 2, INVESTMENT AND FINANCE; Pg. 18, FARM COMMODITIES

LENGTH: 283 words

DATELINE: Winnipeg,Man.


Traders at the Chicago Board of Trade and Winnipeg Commodity Exchange were
sidelined for the better part of yesterday awaiting the publication of the U.S.
Department of Agriculture's planted acreage and grain stocks reports.

The report, made public after the close of trading, was termed bullish for CBOT
soybean prices today, and bearish for both corn and wheat prices.

The department estimated U.S. farmers seeded 58.045 million acres of land to
soybeans in 1990. This is at the low end of pre-report estimates and could
ultimately create a soybean shortage. Total U.S. soybean stocks as of June 1,
1990 were pegged at 595.91 million bushels.

Corn plantings were at the higher end of pre-report guesses while the corn
stocks forecast was within market expectations.

U.S. wheat stocks as of June 1 totaled 535 million bushels, well above the
highest guess of what the trade had anticipated.

CBOT corn prices closed US2 1/2 cents to US8 1/4 cents a bushel higher. The most
active contract, September, settled at US$2.89 1/4, up US4 3/4 cents.

Continued concerns about the impact of intense heat on the U.S. corn crop drove
futures higher.

Wheat prices at the CBOT ended US1 1/2 cents to US3 cents lower. September
closed at US$3.35 1/4 a bushel, down US2 1/4 cents.

Sluggish export demand and an active harvest pace pressured wheat futures.

Poor exporter demand as well as the lack of fresh buying incentives pushed
flaxseed prices at the Winnipeg Commodity Exchange lower.

WCE flaxseed closed $2 to $10 a metric ton lower. The most active contract,
October, settled at $314.20, down $2. The most the flax contract can move in a
single day is $10.




LOAD-DATE: November 6, 1997

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: NEWS

                       Copyright 1990 Financial Post Ltd.


                              474 of 998 DOCUMENTS



                                US Official News

                            April 11, 2015 Saturday

Nash County Farmer Sentenced In Federal Crop Insurance Fraud Scheme

LENGTH: 432  words

DATELINE: Raleigh


United States Attorney's Office for the eastern District of North Carolina has
issued the following press release:

United States Attorney Thomas G. Walker announced that in federal court on April
6, 2015 CLAY TAYLOR STRICKLAND, 74, of Spring Hope, North Carolina, was
sentenced by Chief United State District Judge James C. Dever III, to 6 months
imprisonment to be followed by 3 years of supervised release.  STRICKLAND was
ordered to make restitution in the amount of $233,559 to the United States
Department of Agriculture Risk Management Agency and $64,856 to the United
States Department of Agriculture Farm Service Agency.  STRICKLAND was also fined
$10,000.  STRICKLAND previously pled guilty to conspiring to make false
statements, to make material false statements, to commit mail fraud and wire
fraud, and to structuring transactions all in violation of Title 18, United
States Code, Section 371 and aiding and abetting the making of false statement
in connection with the Federal Crop Insurance Program, in violation of Title 18,
United States Code, Section 1014.

Mr. Walker stated, "As a farmer, STRICKLAND understood the importance of the
federal crop insurance program as a safety net to the community in times of
disaster and yet, he stole from that same program.  The sentence imposed today
reflects the seriousness of his offense and should serve as a deterrent for
others."

The Criminal Information, filed on October 2, 2014, alleges that STRICKLAND was
engaged in the business of farming, doing business as Clay T Strickland Farms,
Inc.  The Information goes on to allege that STRICKLAND filed a false crop
insurance claim in that he hid tobacco production from USDA by selling tobacco
for cash to a tobacco warehouseman who then sold the tobacco in nominee names.
STRICKLAND profited under the scheme because he was paid twice for each pound of
tobacco; once through the false crop insurance claim and also from the sale of
the "hidden" tobacco for cash.  To conceal the conspiracy, STRICKLAND made false
statements to law enforcement officers during the investigation.

Investigation of this case was conducted by the United States Department of
Agriculture - Office of Inspector General, Investigations; the United States
Department of Agriculture - Risk Management Agency, Special Investigations
Branch, and the Internal Revenue Service - Criminal Investigations.  Assistant
United States Attorney Banumathi Rangarajan served as prosecutor for the
government.

contact: editorial@plusmediasolutions.com

                              Journal of Commerce

                           January 7, 1988, Thursday

UNSCHEDULED AIR, SEA ARRIVALS FACE NEW USDA ADVANCE NOTICE RULES

BYLINE: Journal of Commerce Staff

SECTION: AIR, Pg. 5B

LENGTH: 511 words


Unless regularly scheduled, airlines will have to notify U.S. Department of
Agriculture at least 12 hours before foreign flights land in the United States
beginning Feb. 1.

The new rule also requires at least 12 hours' notice for ships arriving at U.S.
ports from abroad, said Charles A. Havens, the USDA's chief operations fficer,
port operations.

The USDA implemented the new rule, Mr. Havens said, because certain companies
declined to notify it of vessel and aircraft arrivals from foreign nations. Now
we can enforce the arrival notification, he said. The rule ensures that USDA
inspectors will be present to prevent cargo from entering the United States that
may carry diseases and pests that could threaten U.S. agriculture, he said.

Airline and vessel operators must notify the USDA about all foreign ports where
the craft has picked up crew, passengers or cargo destined for the United States
since the craft's last visit to the United States, he said.

All airlines with flights scheduled in the North American and Worldwide editions
of the Official Airline Guide are exempt from the new rule, Mr. Haven said. The
USDA accepts the published schedules as first notification, he said.

However, a USDA port office must be notified if the estimated time of arrival
changes by more than one hour, he said.

Also exempt are pre-cleared aircraft and craft that do not regularly transport
passengers or cargo for a fee, he said.

Some airline officials viewed the new rule as an annoyance.

This just means another telephone call to let these people know that we've got a
plane coming in, said Tom Ray, liaison to the Federal Aviation Administration
for San Francisco-based World Airways.

Mr. Ray said some carriers would find notifying USDA regarding the contents of
an aircraft's cargo difficult. You're going to have to call customer service to
find what the hell is in the airplane, he said.

Even if the ruling did affect regularly scheduled airlines, the effect on many
of them would be minimal, according to a New York-based Swiss Air official.

We can call up on computers the manifests of what is loaded aboard a plane, the
official said. With a six-hour time difference between the U.S. East Coast and
Switzerland, New York-based Swiss Air officials would have 14 hours' notice, the
official said.

However, if immediate communication were needed, there would be a problem, he
said. For example, if an aircraft was due to arrive in New York at 3 p.m., no
one could be reached in Switzerland because it would be 9 p.m. and no staff
would be available, he said.

Richard Owens, cargo manager for Arrow Air Inc., said 12 hours' notice would not
be enough time for this Miami-based carrier.

We send planes out to Santo Domingo and we come back in only a few hours, he
said. Arrow offers cargo service to the Caribbean and points in South America
using four DC-8 aircraft, Mr. Owen said.

Arrow will comply with the new rule, he said, but added the carrier hopes to
work something out with USDA officials to avoid problems.

LOAD-DATE: January 7, 1997

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                                October 22, 2014

Family farms key player in ending worldwide hunger

BYLINE: The Power County Press staff

LENGTH: 198  words


People from around The United States and Canada celebrated World Food Day on
Thursday, Oct. 16. The continent-wide celebration was intended to bring
attention to the food needs around the world being met by family famers across
North America.

The theme for the 2014 World Food Day was "Family farming: feeding the world,
caring for the earth" According to the website www.worldfooddayusa.org, over 98
percent of farms in the world are family farms.

According to the Food and Agriculture Organizations of the United Nations
estimates that of all agricultural production in the United States, 84 percent
is grown on family farms totaling more than $230 billion in sales annually.

As part of the World Food Day celebration Unites State Secretary of Agriculture
Tom Vilsak said American farmers are an integral part of ending hunger.

"While they are not always fully appreciated and recognized for their capacity
to address these challenges, I believe the role that agriculture and family
farmers can play is significant," said Vilsak.

World Food Day is celebrated on October 16, in honor of the founding day of the
Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations, which was October 16,
1945.

                               The New York Times

                 June 20, 1982, Sunday, Late City Final Edition

FOLLOW-UP ON THE NEWS;
Killer Bees

BYLINE: By Richard Haitch

SECTION: Section 1; Part 2; Page 37, Column 1; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 261 words


Like a menacing thunderhead, the African ''killer'' bees appeared suddenly in
news reports in the late 1970's. They were portrayed as savage creatures, prone
to attack animals and humans in great swarms and with greater tenacity than
European bees, common in North America. Somehow they had made their way from
Africa to Brazil.  Inevitably, biologists warned, they would spread north.

The predictions then were that the African bees would reach the United States by
the 1990's.  They are on schedule - ''they're reported now in Panama,'' says
Hachiro Shimanuki, national technical adviser on bees to the United States
Department of Agriculture in Beltsville, Md.

Positive identification in Panama was made last March, Dr.  Shimanuki says. From
there the African bees are expected to move through the rest of

Central America into Mexico, then into the United States.  Dr. Shimanuki looks
for their arrival in this country by natural migration ''probably in the early
1990's.'' But it could be sooner, he observes, if the bees slipped in unnoticed
by ship.

One such attempt has already been made but has not been widely publicized.
Philip Lima, a specialist with the Federal Animal Plant Health Inspection
Service in Hyattsville, Md., says the service found two hives of African bees on
an oil tanker from Venezuela when the ship docked at Corpus Christi, Tex., in
March 1979.

The bees were exterminated, Mr. Lima says.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                   Copyright 1982 The New York Times Company


                              479 of 998 DOCUMENTS

                               The New York Times

               August 28, 1984, Tuesday, Late City Final Edition

SOVIET UNION IS FACING ANOTHER POOR HARVEST

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANSBy JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

SECTION: Section D; Page 1, Column 1; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 977 words

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Aug. 27


The Soviet Union appears to be heading for its sixth poor grain harvest in a
row. After a summer of hot, dry weather in some areas and unusually heavy rain
in others, a cold snap now threatens to cut short the Siberian growing season.

With about half of this year's crop harvested, the United States Agriculture
Department earlier this month revised its projection for the 1984 Soviet harvest
downward to 180 million metric tons, from 190 million, and it estimated that the
Russians would have to import 43 million tons of grain, only three million less
than the record total in 1982. The official target for the 1984 harvest is 240
million tons.

The estimate comes at a time when heavy Soviet purchases of grain from the
United States have already re-established America as a major supplier a year
after the ending of the curb imposed by President Carter in response to the
Soviet military intervention in Afghanistan. The United States and the Soviet
Union signed a five-year grain agreement on Aug. 25, 1983.

The Soviet Union is also buying heavily from France, Canada and other grain
producers.

The Soviet Union has not approached its crop target since the record of 235
million tons was set in 1978. Its best harvest since then was last year's 190
million tons.

This year the crucial July rainfall that farmers count on did not come to
western Kazakhstan, the Urals, the north Caucasus and the Volga River basin. The
parched crop is expected to be well below what they had hoped.

Meanwhile, heavy rainfall has hurt the quantity and quality of the crop in the
western and north-central Ukraine and western Russia.

Now the early cold weather that moved in over the weekend from the Baltic Sea is
chilling the northern half of the country as far south as the Ukraine, with
temperatures dropping toward freezing.

In Moscow, children who were running barefoot in the grass only two days ago
have appeared in woolen leggings, with knitted hats tied snugly around their
chins. In the Urals, where harvesting is still under way, frost has already been
reported. In Siberia, where the harvest is just beginning, the cold weather
could damage the ripening crop.

Cold autumn weather can also bring rainfall that reduces the quality of the
harvest by knocking the grain off the stalks and causing mold in the cut grain.
If the weather is cold, a wet harvest dries more slowly.



Soviet Press Coverage

Meanwhile, the Soviet press is beginning to acknowledge the problems that a lack
of rain has brought in other areas.

In the first official confirmation that conditions have been bad in the Kazakh
farm belt, a local newspaper has reported that the crop is stunted and is
proving difficult to harvest. Kazakhstanskaya Pravda said in its issue of Aug.
18, which recently reached Moscow, that this year's harvest had developed amid
extremely complicated conditions in every part of Kazakhstan, which usually
produces about 27 million tons of grain, or 14 percent of the Soviet total in
recent years.

The newspaper also reported that poor maintenance had idled many of the badly
needed harvesting machines. Throughout the Soviet press, as in other harvest
seasons, there have been complaints of inefficiency, poor management and faulty
equipment. Such problems are seen by Western experts as more or less normal for
Soviet agriculture. The weather, one of them said, either exaggerates these
built-in problems or overcomes them when there is a really good year, such as
1978.

Soviet Buying Pattern




WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 - According to the Agriculture Department, the Soviet Union
has purchased 14.3 million metric tons of American wheat and corn in this crop
year, which ends Sept. 30. This includes a 100,000-ton purchase of wheat today.

Of the total, 7.5 million tons is wheat and 6.6 million is corn. The Russians
have also purchased 416,200 tons of soybeans.

Their record purchase from the United States was 15.5 million metric tons in the
1978-79 crop year, and many analysts expect they will top that this time. A
metric ton, or 1,000 kilograms, is about 2,205 pounds.

Under the five-year grain agreement signed by the United States and the Soviet
Union a year ago, the Kremlin was to buy a minimum of 9 million tons a year and
a maximum of 12 million tons. This range was up from the limits of 6 million to
8 million tons set in the earlier agreement.

The present pact stipulates that the Russians notify Washington if they want to
buy more. This provision harks back to the heavy Soviet buying of American grain
in 1973 that drove up domestic prices in the United States.



Comment by President

Last week President Reagan indicated that such added purchases would be no
problem. ''If they want to buy more,'' he said, ''we'll sell them more.'' He
made this remark at the Missouri State Fair in Sedalia.

The United States Government has already approved a waiving of the 12-
million-ton limit for the 1984-85 year. The new limit adds 10 million tons,
bringing the maximum possible purchase for this year to 22 million tons,
according to Jeffrey Idleman, assistant to the Assistant Secretary of
Agriculture for Economics.

In addition, the Russians already have bought 1.3 million metric tons of wheat
for delivery in the 1984-85 year, which begins Oct. 1, and 6.6 million metric
tons of corn. A consultation on the grain agreement is scheduled for October,
which could be an occasion for the Russians to ask for a waiver of the
12-million-ton limit for 1984-85.

Such an announcement at that time by President Reagan could help his re-election
campaign among farmers, many of whom have been hurt by high interest rates.

Since the present agreement was signed, Moscow has bought a total of 22.2
million metric tons of wheat and corn for delivery this year and next.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: graph of Soviet grain imports (page D17)

                             National Post (Canada)

                    August 9, 2003 Saturday National Edition

U.S. begins to lift ban on beef: Animals still not allowed across border

SOURCE: National Post

BYLINE: Mary Vallis

SECTION: News; Pg. A1

LENGTH: 672 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

WASHINGTON - The Bush administration partially lifted its ban on Canadian beef
yesterday, marking a major step forward in Canada's struggle to recover from the
mad cow crisis that is said to be costing the industry $11-million a day.

The border will remain closed to live animals, but the U.S. Department of
Agriculture has lifted its sanctions on meat from cattle under the age of 30
months, veal from calves younger than 36 weeks and fresh or frozen beef liver.

Beef could begin crossing the border by September, as soon as the first import
permits are approved, Ann Veneman, the U.S. Secretary of Agriculture, said
yesterday.

The USDA will immediately begin accepting applications.

"I cannot stress strongly enough that the continued protection of the U.S. food
supply is our top priority," Ms. Veneman said.

"Our experts have determined that the risk to public health is extremely low."

The complete list of products that will be allowed across the border -- which
also includes young sheep and goat meat, pet products that contain animal
protein, and wild game -- represents roughly half of the beef products Canada
usually exports to the United States.

The USDA is also working on an expedited process for the importation of live
cattle to the United States from Canada so the remaining restrictions can be
lifted.

"This represents a significant first step in resuming trade in beef and cattle,"
Jean Chretien, the Prime Minister, said in a statement.

"This decision is testimony to the high standards to which the Canadian beef
industry operates."

Mr. Chretien urged other countries to follow the United States' lead and
immediately lift their trade barriers.

Almost three dozen countries imposed a ban on Canadian beef after scientists
found a lone case of mad cow disease, or bovine spongiform encephalopathy (BSE),
in Alberta on May 20. The United States imposed its ban the same day; Canada has
been struggling to persuade the world its beef is safe ever since.

Lyle Vanclief, the federal Agriculture Minister, said the decision by the USDA
to lift some sanctions is a "good start."

"Government officials and industry have worked very hard to get this far. Our
job is not done yet," he stressed. The announcement marks the first time any
country affected by BSE has been successful in marketing its beef products into
a country that has not been affected by the disease, he added.

Officials in the United States acknowledged Canadian beef is safe following a
joint Canada-U.S. investigation. The United States was prepared to ease its
restrictions, but ran into problems with two of its major trading partners --
South Korea and Japan, the chief importer of U.S. beef. They pressured
Washington to institute additional measures that would prove any beef products
they imported from the United States did not originate in Canada.

Tokyo demanded a system be put in place by Sept. 1. U.S. and Japanese officials
met this week to develop a suitable "segregation" system.

Under the new "beef export verification program," beef producers and suppliers
can opt to pay a fee and receive documentation their meat was raised in the
United States. The program will be running by Sept. 1, Japan's deadline, even
though the United States "does not feel that the science justifies these
requests," Ms. Veneman said.

Japan is the chief importer of U.S. beef and South Korea is No. 3, so the United
States complied to avoid economic harm, she explained.

"We do not feel such a program is necessary," she told reporters. "It could have
been avoided if there were a more practical, risk-based approach to trade with
countries such as Canada that have had only isolated occurrences of BSE and have
responded aggressively, with appropriate mitigation measures."

The United States, Mexico and Japan are the top three importers of Canadian
beef. Canada provided $1.8-billion of beef products to the United States in
2002, 87% of its export market. Japan imported $81-million worth of Canadian
beef.

LOAD-DATE: August 9, 2003

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: Black & White Photo: Jeremy Ashley, Belleville Intelligencer; Lyle
Vanclief, the Agriculture Minister, says the U.S. move to lift the ban on some
Canadian beef products is a "good start."

                              Journal of Commerce

                            December 2, 1996, Monday

TURKEY, US NEAR END TO WHEAT ROW USDA SAYS COUNTRIES ARE "BACK ON TRACK'

BYLINE: JONATHAN EWING; JOURNAL OF COMMERCE SPECIAL

SECTION: COMMODITIES, Pg. 7B

LENGTH: 361 words

DATELINE: ISTANBUL


The United States and Turkey Wednesday appeared close to resolving a dispute in
which Ankara had virtually banned U.S. wheat and other grains sales to Turkey
over the past four weeks, according to U.S. Department of Agriculture officials.

U.S. officials said they regarded the ban as an unfortunate incident, which
should have been avoided. ''We're very pleased to be getting back on track,''
one spokesman said.

The row between Turkey and the United States began in October, after the Turkish
Ministry of Agriculture ordered U.S. wheat cargoes to be held for inspection
against ergot fungus - a substance not considered by the United States to be
harmful if consumed by humans.  The Agricultural Ministry declared that U.S.
wheat that contained ergot would no longer be acceptable, and declared a zero
tolerance of the fungus in all internationally produced wheat, as well as zero
tolerance for Tilletia controversa (TCK) and Urosistas - both plant diseases.
''None of them present a risk when consumed by humans,'' said Jonathan Jones,
export program manager for USDA.

''And TCK and Urosistas, if used for agricultural production can cause damage
because they are plant diseases, but in this case they were not for crops, they
were strictly for human consumption.''

And independent analysts are calling the Turkish zero tolerance regulation a
reaction to an earlier decision made by the Ministry of Agriculture which set
support prices for domestically produced wheat. The ministry had set the price
at $ 260 per ton - much higher than the world price for wheat.

''The end result is that Turkish wheat was not as competitively priced as
American wheat, and the Turkish consumers were forced to pay for the
difference,'' said Petek Coskun, an analyst with the Istanbul-based IBS Research
& Consultancy.  Turkey remains the second largest growing agricultural market
for U.S. farmers after China. In 1995, U.S. agricultural exports totaled just
over $ 500 million, according to USDA officials. If approved, the new policy
will allow for the presence of ergot, TCK and Urosistas in international grains
at no higher than five parts per 10,000.

LOAD-DATE: December 13, 1996

competition organised by Quality Meat Scotland, the representative body for the
Scottish red meat industry.

before it was destroyed.

* SEVENTY pedigree Limousin cattle are entered for a show and sale in Builth
Wells on Tuesday (May 11).

* SEVERAL leading Spanish food companies are reported to be planning to expand
operations in Eastern Europe via a joint venture.

* THE United States Department of Agriculture and US ranchers have agreed to
halt plans to expand imports of Canadian beef until the law works its way
through the normal rule-making process.

                     Belfast News Letter (Northern Ireland)

                            July 16, 2003, Wednesday

POTATO PRICES FALL BACK

SECTION: FARMING LIFE; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 116 words


EARLY potato prices in Great Britain eased last week as, in the drier weather
conditions, more growers were lifting.

Prices for early season chipping material remained firm, according to the
British Potato Council.

Meanwhile, in the United States, the autumn potato acreage is reported to be
down compared to last week.

The National Agricultural Statistics Service of the United States Department of
Agriculture released its report on Crop Production on Friday.

According to the report, a total of 1,114,400 acres was planted with potatoes in
the autumn-producing states this year (1,144,200 acres were planted last year).
This is 2.6 per cent below last year's plantings.

                              484 of 998 DOCUMENTS

                       St. Louis Post-Dispatch (Missouri)

                February 9, 1998, Monday, FIVE STAR LIFT EDITION

SMALL BUSINESS BRIEFING

BYLINE: Compiled By William Flannery; Of The Post-Dispatch

SECTION: BUSINESS PLUS, Pg. 13, SMALL BUSINESS BRIEFING COLUMN

LENGTH: 371 words



Corn growers forecast a slump in prices

The National Corn Growers Association is forecasting that continuing economic
problems in East Asia will have an adverse impact on U.S. corn prices in 1998.

The St. Louis-based Corn Growers warn that America's corn, soybeans, wheat and
other grains and crops are twice as dependent upon exports as the rest of the
U.S. economy. Foreign exports now account for 30 percent of all farm sales, they
said.

Asia is also the largest single market for U.S. farm goods and, until the
current economic crisis, the fastest-growing market as well.

In 1997, Asia purchased nearly $ 24 billion from America's farmers, or 42
percent of all farm goods.

Citing ''conservative'' estimates from the U.S. Department of Agriculture, the
Corn Growers said the Asian financial crisis could cut $ 500 million in American
farm exports this year.

Little to give address

William G. ''Bill'' Little, the new national chairman of the U.S. Chamber of
Commerce, will give the lead address at the Missouri Chamber of Commerce's
seventh annual Missouri Chamber Day on Feb. 18 at the Capital Plaza Hotel in
Jefferson City.

Gov. Mel Carnahan will give the the introduction to an  estimated 300 state
business leaders.

Little will speak about welfare-to-workfare, the role of government policies on
job creation and the role of businesses in setting government policy.

Issue panels with Missouri legislative leaders will be held from 9 to 11:30 a.m.
before the luncheon at the Capital Plaza.

For more information, call the Missouri Chamber at 573-634-3511.

April will mark the 75th anniversary of the Missouri Chamber.

Informational luncheon set

''Corporate Sponsorship of Non-Profits,'' will be the topic of an informational
luncheon on Friday from 11:30 a.m. to 1:30 p.m. at the Frontenac Hilton, 1335
South Lindbergh Boulevard.

The featured speaker is Rodney Scott, director for corporate development for
Optimist International.

The meeting is sponsored by Business Marketing Association, St. Louis.
Reservations are needed by Wednesday. The luncheon fees are $ 20 for members of
BMA and $ 25 for non-members.

For more information, call 314- 995-0022.

                      The Financial Post (Toronto, Canada)

                    January 25, 1994, Tuesday, DAILY EDITION

Farm trade deal with U.S. elusive

BYLINE: Peter Morton

SECTION: SECTION 1, NEWS; Pg. 5

LENGTH: 429 words


Canadian and U.S. negotiators are still trying to find common ground in several
key areas of a comprehensive farm trade deal, industry and government sources
close to the talks said yesterday.

Agriculture Minister Ralph Goodale and U.S. Secretary of Agriculture Mike Espy
held talks over the weekend to try to find acceptable quotas on the export of
Canadian grain, sugar and peanuts to the U.S.

Goodale told the Commons yesterday he could not detail where the negotiations
were but promised to protect the interests of Canadian farmers.

The last-minute snags in talks aimed at sorting out disputes in five agriculture
-related areas is typical strategy of the U.S. negotiators, said one former U.S.
trade official.

''The closer a deal is, the harder the U.S. will push to see how anxious the
other side is in getting a deal,'' the official said.

Besides export limits on grain, sugar and peanuts, the U.S. is pushing hard to
eliminate the proposed 100% tariffs on processed food products such as yogurt
and ice cream over six years. Goodale has proposed lowering those tariffs by 36%
over six years and then eliminating them over another four years.

But one U.S. source said the U.S. would probably agree to a 10-year phase-out on
ice cream and yogurt if the proposed tariffs on all supply-managed farm products
- including eggs, chicken, cheese and other dairy products - followed the same
schedule.

In December, Canada and other countries in the General Agreement on Tariffs and
Trade agreed to replace by next July all existing import quotas with tariffs and
reduce those by a minimum of 15% over six years. Those tariffs are to go to GATT
by Feb. 15 for final approval.

Goodale and Espy do not see eye to eye on how much market access each country is
to receive in dairy products, said one U.S. official. Canadian negotiators have
offered to exchange 5% of the Canadian market to get 3% of the U.S. market.

Canadian dairy farmers have said they would be content with 3% of the huge U.S.
market but want assurances they would not be hit with anti-dumping charges since
Canadian domestic prices would be higher than those on exports to the U.S. In
international trade, dumping occurs when products are sold in a foreign market
at prices below those in the domestic market.

The U.S. is also balking at a Canadian proposal it had once tentatively accepted
to limit for three years Canadian wheat and grain exports to the U.S. to 2.5
million tonnes, the record amount of grain shipped to the U.S. last year, said
one industry source.


LOAD-DATE: November 4, 1997

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: APPOINTMENT NOTICE

                       Copyright 1994 Financial Post Ltd.


                              486 of 998 DOCUMENTS

                      The Financial Post (Toronto, Canada)

                   February 11, 1991, Monday, WEEKLY EDITION

P.E.I. vows fight over U.S. ban

SECTION: SECTION 1, NEWS; Pg. 3, CANADIAN BUSINESS BRIEFS

LENGTH: 119 words


Prince Edward Island Agriculture Minister Keith Milligan met with Federal
Agriculture Minister Don Mazankowski Friday to discuss the U.S. ban on P.E.I.
and New Brunswick potatoes. ''We might have to fight fire with fire by banning
some U.S. products to Canada if the ban is not lifted immediately,'' Milligan
said. The U.S. Department of Agriculture said it banned potato imports from
P.E.I. and New Brunswick because of a virus affecting some seed potatoes.
Milligan said the ban is a case of ''protectionism.'' Potatoes are P.E.I.'s
major industry, worth about $125 million last year. Growers there say the ban is
devastating, since the U.S. traditionally buys 30% of P.E.I. seed potatoes sold.

                               The New York Times

                 June 28, 1982, Monday, Late City Final Edition

DOMINICAN POSITION ON SUGAR QUOTAS

SECTION: Section A; Page 14, Column 3; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 261 words


To the Editor:

A news article on May 22 considered the effects of the sugar quotas recently
announced by President Reagan on the Dominican Republic.

In our view, it is less than accurate to headline that ''Dominicans Fear Sugar
Quotas.'' Moreover, the concluding comment (about lobbying to end the quotas)
misrepresents the official position taken by the Dominican Republic before
Congress, the United States International Trade Commission and the United States
Department of Agriculture.

Statements to Congressional committees by the Dominican Republic's International
Sugar Policy Coordinating Commission have emphasized that we support Mr.
Reagan's Caribbean Basin Initiative sugar quota allocation of 780,000 metric
tons, duty free.

Statements to the Trade Commission and the Agricultural Department have argued
that, if a protective mechanism is considered necessary, quotas without duties
and fees would be preferable to duties and fees. Quotas are considered to be
less damaging to the interests of foreign suppliers to the U.S. market and, at
the same time, a more effective protective mechanism for this market.

With the establishment of quotas, fees no longer have any regulatory effect on
the U.S. market. The current, highly restrictive quota adversely affects the
Dominican sugar industry and economy because it keeps our exports to the U.S.
market substantially below our historical supply levels. It also maintains what
to us are punitive duties and fees.
RAFAEL MOLINA MORILLO, Ambassador of the Dominican Republic, Washington, June
16, 1982

TYPE: letter

                               The New York Times

                 March 8, 1985, Friday, Late City Final Edition

Block Depicts Reagan As Sensitive to Farms

BYLINE: AP

SECTION: Section A; Page 15, Column 5; National Desk

LENGTH: 159 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 7


Agriculture Secretary John R. Block said today that President Reagan did not
mean to suggest that only a handful of farmers were having critical problems
with cash flow.

''The President understands the problem in agriculture,'' Mr. Block told
reporters.

In remarks accompanying the veto of an emergency credit bill Wednesday, Mr.
Reagan said: ''In need of immediate help are less than 4 percent, or around 4
percent at best, of all the farmers in the United States. Ninety- six percent do
not have liquidity problems.''

According to Agriculture Department economists, about 8 percent of ''family-size
commercial farms'' with sales of $40,000 to $500,000 annually have debts in
excess of 40 percent of their assets and are in a severe cash- flow squeeze.

Mr. Block said: ''What he was really saying is that he feels that we will
probably lose about 5 percent or 4 percent. He wasn't suggesting there aren't
more than that in trouble.''


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                   Copyright 1985 The New York Times Company


                              490 of 998 DOCUMENTS

                               The New York Times

              January 28, 1981, Wednesday, Late City Final Edition

'81 WHEAT SUPPLY IS UP, BUT FEED STORAGE IS LOW

BYLINE: By SETH S. KING, Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section D; Page 2, Column 5; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 476 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27


American farmers are expected to have in storage at least a year's domestic
supply of wheat when the 1981 harvest begins in June, the Agriculture Department
reported today.  But it said carry-over stocks of feed grains would be the
lowest since 1976.

The estimate of wheat reserves was reassuring in view of the extremely dry
seasonal weather that has left this year's winter wheat crop with very little
snow cover and highly vulnerable to freezing February temperatures.

In its January supply and demand estimate, the Agriculture Department noted that
reserve wheat stocks were larger than last year but if the rate of wheat exports
continued these stocks would be at about 24.5 million metric tons.

The United States was expected to use about 22.9 million tons for bread and
livestock feed during the crop year that will end next June.

With the total world grain supply now at one of the lowest levels since 1974,
foreign demand for American wheat is expected to pull exports up to a record 66
million tons by June 1, the department said.

It said it expected feed grain stocks to drop to only 21.4 million tons before
the new crops are harvested early next fall. This was less than half of the 52.4
million tons carried over from the record 1979 yields.

''This leaves the supply of feed grains very tight, a prospect that could lead
to even lower levels of meat production in the second and third quarters of this
year than we were expecting,'' said Terry Barr, a department economist.

Stocks of soybeans, another major element in livestock feeding, were estimated
at 42.2 million metric tons, down 12 percent from last year.

But Mr. Barr said the department did not expect any major rise in soybean prices
because of the carry-in from last year's record crop and the prospects of large
soybean yields soon to be harvested in Brazil and Argentina.

Foreign demand for American feed grains was also continuing and the department
expected exports of these grains to exceed 74 million tons, another record.

Supplies of corn, the largest of the feed grain components, were slightly larger
than earlier estimates but reserve stocks expected to be on hand when the 1981
harvest begins next October were set at 14.4 million tons, the lowest since
1976.

The tightness of corn supplies and continued high export demand were expected to
hold corn prices above $3.25 a bushel, compared with last season's $2.52
average. The department expected wheat prices to range between $3.95 and $4.15,
higher than last year's $3.78-a-bushel average.

Unusually low subsurface moisture levels in the Corn Belt states this month were
causing concern among that region's farmers, whose corn and soybean crops were
badly damaged by drought last summer.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                   Copyright 1981 The New York Times Company


                              491 of 998 DOCUMENTS


                            Norwalk Reflector, Ohio

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                            March 23, 2011 Wednesday

Trade deals needed for agriculture's benefit

BYLINE: Aaron Krause, Norwalk Reflector, Ohio

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 608 words


March 23--WASHINGTON -- People who care about agriculture need to be "engaged on
trade," a national agriculture advocate told members of a farming group this
months.

Rosemarie Watkins, director of the international policy team for the American
Farm Bureau Federation, said exports account for between 1/3 and 1/4 of U.S.
agriculture receipts.

"It's critical to the future," she added

While agriculture is the only U.S. industry that enjoys a trade surplus,
problems loom ahead, Watkins told Ohio county farm bureau presidents --
including Huron County Farm Bureau President John Brooks.

U.S. trading to Columbia, for example, is declining very rapidly, Watkins said.
A group of South American countries have made a deal with Columbia.

"Their grain is replacing our grain," Watkins said. "In short, their grain is
cheaper," with no tariffs.

Also, Peru is displacing the United States as a wine exporter to Korea, she
said.

"Other countries are moving into markets that are traditionally ours," Watkins
said.

Congress needs to pass three outstanding free trade agreements, according to the
American Farm Bureau Federation (AFBF). The organization estimates that the
combined agreements represent almost $2.5 billion in additional exports, but
that is only if they are implemented.

The U.S.-Columbia agreement represents U.S. agricultural export gains of more
than $815 million per year at full implementation.

Currently, Colombian products enter the U.S. dutyfree through the Andean Trade
Preference Act, which Congress has passed and extended numerous times. U.S.
farmers, meanwhile, continue to face tariff barriers that average 25 percent
when exporting products into the Colombian market.

Passage of the Columbia agreement will eliminate the tariffs placed on U.S.
products, according to the AFBF.

The U.S.-Panama Trade Promotion Agreement could mean increased U.S. agricultural
exports to Panama of more than $195 million per year by full implementation.

"Most Panamanian agricultural imports to the United States enter with zero
tariffs under U.S. preference programs," the AFBF fact sheet reads. "The
agreement will level the playing field by providing U.S. products exported to
Panama with the same duty-free access already enjoyed by Panamanian products
imported by the United States."

The Korea Free Trade Agreement is one of the largest trade agreements for the
United States, according to the AFBF. An economic analysis by the Farm Bureau
estimates that, once fully implemented, U.S. agriculture could exceed $1.9
billion per year in additional agricultural exports.

In response to a question, Watkins said based on an economic analysis, these
agreements represent fair trade.

Sen. Sherrod Brown, one of Ohio's two senators, also addressed the group.
Someone asked him why trade with China is "so out of balance."

"We've had presidents of both parties that have sold us out," the Democratic
senator said. "We are finally starting to enforce some of the trade laws."

Turning to matters at home, one county farm bureau representative told Brown
there has been talk about changing the crop insurance payment due date from
November to August.

"A lot of farmers don't have money in August," the representative said.

Brown said he's not aware of the talk about changing the date.

"It's very helpful to know that," he said.

To see more of the Norwalk Reflector or to subscribe to the newspaper, go to
http://www.norwalkreflector.com/. Copyright (c) 2011, Norwalk Reflector, Ohio
Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Information Services. For more information
about the content services offered by McClatchy-Tribune Information Services
(MCT), visit www.mctinfoservices.com.

                                US Official News

                           October 15, 2015 Thursday

Tulsa Convenience Store Owner Sentenced for Stealing Nearly $300,000 From
Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program

LENGTH: 268 words

DATELINE: Lahore



 Office for the United States Attorneys,Northern District of Oklahoma has issued
the following news release:




 TULSA, Okla.- Milton Islam, 47, of Broken Arrow, and owner of Apache Food Mart
in Tulsa, was sentenced to 18 months in prison for stealing $282,912 from the
United States Department of Agriculture's Supplemental Nutrition Assistance
Program (SNAP), formerly known as Food Stamps, announced United States Attorney
Danny C. Williams Sr. for the Northern District of Oklahoma. In addition to the
prison sentence, United States District Court Chief Judge Gregory K. Frizzell
ordered Islam to pay $282,912 in restitution to the United States Department of
Agriculture. Islam was indicted by a grand jury in March 2015 and pleaded guilty
on May 12, 2015.


 At the change of plea hearing, Islam admitted that from May 26, 2011 to July
31, 2014, he stole from SNAP using a scheme in which customers used their SNAP
benefits to receive cash, rather than nutritional assistance. The cash customers
received was only half the amount that Islam received from SNAP.
 The case was investigated by the United States Department of Agriculture-Office
of the Inspector General. Assistant United States Attorneys Clinton J. Johnson,
Shannon Cozzoni, and Catherine Depew prosecuted the case.
 SNAP offers nutrition assistance to eligible, low-income individuals and
families. To report suspicious Nutrition Assistance fraud, call the Oklahoma
Fraud Hotline at (405) 521-3444 or email OIGFraud2@okdhs.org

                                US Official News

                              April 8, 2016 Friday

Washington: UPDATED: Statement from Agriculture Secretary Vilsack on Child
Nutrition

LENGTH: 548  words

DATELINE: Lahore



 Washington: United States Department of Agriculture has issued the following
news release:



 April 8, 2016 - Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack today released the following
statement in response to a new report done jointly by the Food Research & Action
Center (FRAC) and the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities (CBPP)This is an
external link or third-party site outside of the United States Department of
Agriculture (USDA) website. regarding positive outcomes of the Community
Eligibility Provision (CEP), part of the 2010 Healthy, Hunger-Free Kids Act,
which allows eligible high-poverty schools to offer school meals to all students
at no charge, so they can focus on serving children the nutritious meals they
need to learn, instead of doing paperwork.





 "This report is further evidence that schools participating in CEP are making
great strides ensuring that all children are well nourished and prepared to
learn, especially since many of these students rely on school meals as their
best source of nutritious food. CEP is a win for schools, parents and students,
and the results we've seen in the first 2 years of nationwide implementation are
inspiring. The report also underscores how the 2010 bipartisan child nutrition
law has achieved significant positive results for child nutrition and health. It
is because of these undeniable results that I urge Congress to stay the course
in child nutrition. It would be unwise to roll back standards, saddle parents
and school administrators with more paperwork or weaken assistance for our most
vulnerable children. USDA stands ready to work with Congress to support the
reauthorization of child nutrition programs that continue to improve the health
and wellbeing of the next generation."



 The CEP report shows:



     In the 2014-2015 school year, 4,000 new schools took advantage of the
ability to streamline school meal administration through CEP;

     In total, 3,000 school districts and 18,000 schools-more than half of all
eligible schools-are participating, benefitting more than 8.5 million students
without stigma;

     Due in part to CEP, more than 90,000 schools and child care sites now
participate in the School Breakfast Program; participation among children has
increased 27 percent since 2009; and

     Schools participating in CEP are benefiting from improved program
integrity, fewer hours spent on administrative work, and increased student
participation in meal programs;



 Since passage of the bipartisan Healthy, Hunger-Free Kids Act in 2010,
America's children have benefitted in the following ways:



     Data show that obesity rates are falling among young kids;

     97 percent of schools have embraced updated, healthier meal standards;

     Kids are now eating at least 13 percent more of their entrees, at least 16
percent more vegetables and 23 percent more fruit at lunch;

     More low-income children are benefiting from breakfast and lunch programs;

     Nearly 4 million children have access to healthy food in the summer when
school is out and meals are scarce; and

     8 million low-income women, infants and young children now receive an
improved variety of healthy food through WIC.

                    BBC Monitoring Latin America - Political
                      Supplied by BBC Worldwide Monitoring

                              June 6, 2016 Monday

Cuban agriculture minister holds several meetings in USA

LENGTH: 280 words


Text of report in English by Cuban News Agency (ACN) website

HAVANA, Cuba, Jun 2 (acn) Cuba's Minister of Agriculture, Gustavo Rodriguez, who
is on an official visit to the United States, held meetings on Thursday with the
Deputy Secretary of Agriculture, Michael Scuse, and the Secretary of Commerce,
Penny Pritzker.

As reported by the official website of the Cuban Embassy to Washington, in the
morning, the Cuban minister of Agriculture was received at the headquarters of
the Chamber of Commerce by its vice-president for Latin America, Jodi Bond, and
by the president of the Cuba-US Business Board, Carlos Gutierrez.

At the Chamber of Commerce he spoke with US businessmen on the development and
prospects of the agricultural sector in Cuba and the possibilities of
cooperation and relations with the US in this specific sector.

He also he participated in a meeting with executives of the US Rice Federation.

As part of his programme for June 3, Rodriguez and his accompanying delegation
will visit the state of Iowa, where they will hold an official meeting with the
Secretary of Agriculture, Thomas Vilsack, and will tour agricultural production
and research centres.

The visit of the Cuban Minister of Agriculture is part of the new stage of
relations between Cuba and the United States on the path towards the
normalization of relations.

Previously, the Cuban ministers of Foreign Affairs and Foreign Trade and
Investment, Bruno Rodriguez and Rodrigo Malmierca, respectively, paid official
visits to the northern country, the first ones since July 20, when diplomatic
relations between the two countries were reestablished.

                           The Aberdeen Times (Idaho)

                                 April 28, 2010

USDA initiative targets farm energy efficiency

BYLINE: The Aberdeen Times staff

LENGTH: 625  words


An initiative designed to help agricultural producers transition to more energy
efficient operations has begun through the United States Department of
Agriculture.

The initiative will make funding available for individual on-farm energy audits
designed to save both money and energy when fully implemented, according to
Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack.

Reducing energy use on America's farms and ranches will not only help our
agricultural producers become more profitable, but also help the United States
become more energy independent," said Vilsack. "Through this initiative,
producers will be able to receive individual on-farm energy audit evaluations
and assistance with implementation of energy conservation and efficiency
measures."

Approximately 1,000 on-farm energy audit evaluations in 29 states will be funded
by $2 million through the Environmental Quality Incentives Program (EQIP) in
fiscal year 2010. The energy audits will be individually tailored to ensure
coverage of each farm's primary energy uses such as milk cooling, irrigation
pumping, heating and cooling of livestock production facilities, manure
collection and transfer, grain drying, and similar common on-farm activities.

Participating states include: Alabama, Arizona, Arkansas, California, Colorado,
Connecticut, Florida, Georgia, Idaho, Louisiana, Maine, Maryland, Massachusetts,
Mississippi, Nevada, New Hampshire, New Mexico, New York, Oklahoma,
Pennsylvania, Rhode Island, South Dakota, Tennessee, Texas, Utah, Vermont,
Virginia, West Virginia, and Wisconsin.

Implementation will occur in stages beginning with the short-term immediate goal
of providing the on-farm energy audits to help identify how the operations can
become more energy efficient. Longer term goals will involve development of
agricultural energy management plans for cost effective implementation of the
recommendations provided in their on-farm energy audits. More information about
agricultural energy management plans is available at:
www.nrcs.usda.gov/programs/eqip/cap.html.

The 2008 Farm Bill provides authority to use EQIP financial assistance funds for
payment of practices and conservation activities involving the development of an
Agricultural Energy Management Plan (AgEMP) appropriate for the eligible land of
a program participant. The Farm Bill statute allows EQIP payments for up to 75
percent of the estimated incurred cost of practice implementation for the
development of an AgEMP meeting agency standards and requirements.

Eligible producers in the above listed states may apply for the AgEMP through
application at their local NRCS office. EQIP payments are made directly to
program participants for development of an AgEMP by a certified Technical
Service Provider Capitol in 1971, I was serving

Information about how to apply for an AgEMP is available at
www.nrcs.usda.gov/programs/eqip/EQIP_signup/2009_sign-up/index.html. Click on
the State where the property that you are interested in obtaining an EQIP AgEMP
is located.

Dairy, beef, poultry, swine, and other agricultural operations are included in
this energy efficiency initiative. USDA's Natural Resources Conservation
Service, in partnership with USDA Rural Development, will implement the
agricultural energy conservation and efficiency initiative.

For information about other NRCS conservation programs, online visit:
www.nrcs.usda. gov, or visit the nearest USDA Service Center. This year
represents the 75th year of NRCS "helping people help the land." Since its
inception the NRCS conservation delivery system has advanced a unique
partnership with state and local governments and private landowners delivering
conservation based on specific, local conservation needs, while accommodating
state and national interests.

LOAD-DATE: October 28, 2010

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

DOCUMENT-TYPE: Energy

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                               All Rights Reserved
                             SmallTownPapers, Inc.
                       Copyright 2010 The Aberdeen Times


                              498 of 998 DOCUMENTS


             National Post's Financial Post & FP Investing (Canada)

                           October 12, 2005 Wednesday
                                National Edition

U.S. sees breakthrough in farm-subsidy conflict: WTO talks in Zurich: Canada
onside with proposal, Trade Minister says

BYLINE: Peter Morton, Washington Bureau Chief, Financial Post

SECTION: FINANCIAL POST; Pg. FP6

LENGTH: 464  words


The United States and the European Union continued yesterday to push their joint
proposal to phase out farm subsidies in the stalled round of global trade talks,
despite opposition from developing countries and Japan.

Rob Portman, the U.S. trade negotiator, insisted yesterday in Zurich there is a
chance there could be a breakthrough in the Doha Round of World Trade
Organization talks planned for Hong Kong in December.

"For the first time, I see real movement toward having a successful meeting in
Hong Kong," he said, referring to a ministerial meeting of the World Trade
Organization (WTO) in December at which vital decisions have to be made.

The United States and the European Union have proposed phasing out as much as
90% of import tariffs on foreign agricultural products imposed by the richest
countries in one stage, eventually bringing the import duties to zero.

The move, outlined this weekend in preliminary talks, was welcomed by Jim
Peterson, the Canadian Trade Minister.

"One of our key priorities has been to achieve substantial reductions in
trade-distorting domestic support, particularly by the highest spenders, the
European Commission and the United States," he said.

"The negotiations had been stalled, and Canada appreciates the fact that the
United States has now taken steps to move the negotiations forward."

Yet other countries, including Brazil and Japan, said the United States and EU
did not go far enough.

Celso Amorim, Brazil's Foreign Minister, said developing countries in the G20
group he chairs believed the U.S. plan was "insufficient because it does not
lead to real cuts in U.S. budgetary expenditures on subsidies."

Kamal Nath, India's Trade Minister, also said poorer countries were less than
happy with the proposals.

"I would welcome this step [the U.S. plan], but what we need is a leap that
removes the great structural imbalances in agriculture," he said.

Mineichi Iwanaga, Japan's Agriculture Minister, also said the United States was
not going nearly far enough.

"The reductions which are being asked of Japan and Europe are out of balance
with the reductions that the U.S. is ready to make," he said.

The powerful farm union in the United States, called COPA, also said it was
unhappy with the proposals from the EU and United States.

But Mr. Portman said now is the time for countries to make concessions if they
want to see any hope of the round, launched in Doha three years ago, succeeding.

"We really don't have time to play games," he said. "We need to make real
progress. If others don't come along, then the Doha Round is in danger."

The 148 countries in the WTO are trying to kick-start the talks in a bid to wrap
them up in five days of meetings starting on Dec. 13 in Hong Kong. The round was
originally scheduled to end on Jan. 1 this year.

LOAD-DATE: October 12, 2005

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

DOCUMENT-TYPE: Business

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper
